There is a need to tightly integrate perception and planning under uncertainty to enable robust, transferable policies for long-horizon tasks.
AI.method: NeuRO tightly couples perception networks with downstream task-level robust optimization. It converts noisy visual predictions under limited data into convex uncertainty sets via PICNNs calibrated with conformal methods, directly parameterizing optimization constraints. It then reformulates planning under partial observability as a robust optimization problem to produce uncertainty-aware policies that can transfer across environments.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on unordered and sequential multi-object navigation tasks show NeuRO achieving state-of-the-art performance, with strong generalization to unseen environments.
AI.conclusion: NeuRO represents a significant step toward robust, generalizable autonomous agents by integrating perception with task-level robust optimization, reducing data demands and improving cross-environment transfer.

title: AuditAgent: Expert-Guided Multi-Agent Reasoning for Cross-Document Fraudulent Evidence Discovery
summary:
Financial fraud detection in real-world scenarios presents significant
challenges due to the subtlety and dispersion of evidence across complex,
multi-year financial disclosures. In this work, we introduce a novel
multi-agent reasoning framework AuditAgent, enhanced with auditing domain
expertise, for fine-grained evidence chain localization in financial fraud
cases. Leveraging an expert-annotated dataset constructed from enforcement
documents and financial reports released by the China Securities Regulatory
Commission, our approach integrates subject-level risk priors, a hybrid
retrieval strategy, and specialized agent modules to efficiently identify and
aggregate cross-report evidence. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our
method substantially outperforms General-Purpose Agent paradigm in both recall
and interpretability, establishing a new benchmark for automated, transparent
financial forensics. Our results highlight the value of domain-specific
reasoning and dataset construction for advancing robust financial fraud
detection in practical, real-world regulatory applications.

AI.tldr: AuditAgent is a domain-aware multi-agent framework for financial fraud detection that localizes subtle evidence across multi-year disclosures. It uses an expert-annotated dataset from enforcement documents and financial reports, subject-level risk priors, a hybrid retrieval strategy, and specialized agent modules to improve recall and interpretability, outperforming general-purpose agents and establishing a regulatory-grade benchmark.
AI.motivation: Financial fraud detection in real-world, regulatory contexts is hindered by dispersed, subtle evidence across long time spans. There is a need for domain-specific reasoning, structured evidence localization, and transparent models that regulators can trust.
AI.method: Proposes AuditAgent, a multi-agent reasoning framework enhanced with auditing domain expertise. Key components include subject-level risk priors, a hybrid retrieval strategy, and specialized agent modules to locate and aggregate cross-report evidence. An expert-annotated dataset from China Securities Regulatory Commission documents anchors training/evaluation.
AI.result: Experimental results show substantial improvements in recall and interpretability compared to General-Purpose Agent paradigms, setting a new benchmark for automated financial forensics in real-world regulatory tasks.
AI.conclusion: Domain-specific reasoning and carefully constructed datasets are crucial for robust, transparent financial fraud detection applicable to regulatory environments; the framework demonstrates practical potential for real-world auditing applications.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Prompt Template Stealing for Text-to-Image Models
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have transformed text-to-image
workflows, allowing designers to create novel visual concepts with
unprecedented speed. This progress has given rise to a thriving prompt trading
market, where curated prompts that induce trademark styles are bought and sold.
Although commercially attractive, prompt trading also introduces a largely
unexamined security risk: the prompts themselves can be stolen.
  In this paper, we expose this vulnerability and present RLStealer, a
reinforcement learning based prompt inversion framework that recovers its
template from only a small set of example images. RLStealer treats template
stealing as a sequential decision making problem and employs multiple
similarity based feedback signals as reward functions to effectively explore
the prompt space. Comprehensive experiments on publicly available benchmarks
demonstrate that RLStealer gets state-of-the-art performance while reducing the
total attack cost to under 13% of that required by existing baselines. Our
further analysis confirms that RLStealer can effectively generalize across
different image styles to efficiently steal unseen prompt templates. Our study
highlights an urgent security threat inherent in prompt trading and lays the
groundwork for developing protective standards in the emerging MLLMs
marketplace.

AI.tldr: RLStealer is a reinforcement-learning based prompt inversion system that reconstructs prompt templates from few example images, achieving state-of-the-art results and reducing attack costs to under 13% of prior baselines, exposing a security risk in MLLM prompt trading.
AI.motivation: Prompt trading in multimodal LLMs enables rapid style prompts but raises security concerns: stolen prompts can be used to imitate styles; there is a need to understand and quantify this risk and push for defenses.
AI.method: Formulates prompt stealing as sequential decision making; uses reinforcement learning with multiple similarity-based reward signals to explore and recover templates from limited examples; evaluates on public benchmarks; demonstrates generalization to unseen styles.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance in prompt inversion with attack cost < 13% of existing baselines; generalizes to unseen prompt templates across different image styles; comprehensive experiments validate effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: Highlights urgent security threat in prompt trading, motivating protective standards and defenses in the emerging MLLMs marketplace; RLStealer provides a framework and baseline for evaluating and mitigating prompt theft risks.

title: Adaptive and Resource-efficient Agentic AI Systems for Mobile and Embedded Devices: A Survey
summary:
Foundation models have reshaped AI by unifying fragmented architectures into
scalable backbones with multimodal reasoning and contextual adaptation. In
parallel, the long-standing notion of AI agents, defined by the
sensing-decision-action loop, is entering a new paradigm: with FMs as their
cognitive core, agents transcend rule-based behaviors to achieve autonomy,
generalization, and self-reflection. This dual shift is reinforced by
real-world demands such as autonomous driving, robotics, virtual assistants,
and GUI agents, as well as ecosystem advances in embedded hardware, edge
computing, mobile deployment platforms, and communication protocols that
together enable large-scale deployment. Yet this convergence collides with
reality: while applications demand long-term adaptability and real-time
interaction, mobile and edge deployments remain constrained by memory, energy,
bandwidth, and latency. This creates a fundamental tension between the growing
complexity of FMs and the limited resources of deployment environments. This
survey provides the first systematic characterization of adaptive,
resource-efficient agentic AI systems. We summarize enabling techniques into
elastic inference, test-time adaptation, dynamic multimodal integration, and
agentic AI applications, and identify open challenges in balancing
accuracy-latency-communication trade-offs and sustaining robustness under
distribution shifts. We further highlight future opportunities in
algorithm-system co-design, cognitive adaptation, and collaborative edge
deployment. By mapping FM structures, cognition, and hardware resources, this
work establishes a unified perspective toward scalable, adaptive, and
resource-efficient agentic AI. We believe this survey can help readers to
understand the connections between enabling technologies while promoting
further discussions on the fusion of agentic intelligence and intelligent
agents.

AI.tldr: A survey of adaptive, resource-efficient agentic AI at the intersection of foundation models (FMs) and agent-enabled systems, addressing deployment constraints on edge/mobile and proposing techniques like elastic inference, test-time adaptation, dynamic multimodal integration, and agentic applications, with open challenges on accuracy-latency-communication trade-offs and robustness.
AI.motivation: Foundation models enable scalable, multimodal reasoning and cognition, while AI agents aim to operate autonomously with long-term adaptability. Real-world deployment on edge/mobile hardware introduces strict constraints (memory, energy, bandwidth, latency). A systematic characterization is needed to reconcile high-capacity models with resource limits and to guide design of adaptive, efficient agentic AI.
AI.method: Systematic survey and taxonomy that maps FM structures, cognition, and hardware resources. The work categorizes enabling techniques into four areas: elastic inference, test-time adaptation, dynamic multimodal integration, and agentic AI applications; discusses open challenges and future opportunities; analyzes trade-offs and robustness under distribution shifts; proposes a unified perspective for algorithm-system co-design and collaborative edge deployment.
AI.result: Provides a structured taxonomy and a unified framework connecting FM cognition, agentic behavior, and hardware/resource constraints, along with identified challenges and opportunities. It clarifies how to balance accuracy, latency, and communication while maintaining robustness, and outlines future directions for integrating cognitive adaptation and edge deployment.
AI.conclusion: The convergence of foundation models and agentic AI, guided by algorithm-system co-design and edge-aware development, offers a path to scalable, adaptive, and resource-efficient intelligent agents. The survey aims to catalyze discussion on integrating agentic intelligence with practical agent systems and deploying them robustly across edge environments.

title: Integrating Offline Pre-Training with Online Fine-Tuning: A Reinforcement Learning Approach for Robot Social Navigation
summary:
Offline reinforcement learning (RL) has emerged as a promising framework for
addressing robot social navigation challenges. However, inherent uncertainties
in pedestrian behavior and limited environmental interaction during training
often lead to suboptimal exploration and distributional shifts between offline
training and online deployment. To overcome these limitations, this paper
proposes a novel offline-to-online fine-tuning RL algorithm for robot social
navigation by integrating Return-to-Go (RTG) prediction into a causal
Transformer architecture. Our algorithm features a spatiotem-poral fusion model
designed to precisely estimate RTG values in real-time by jointly encoding
temporal pedestrian motion patterns and spatial crowd dynamics. This RTG
prediction framework mitigates distribution shift by aligning offline policy
training with online environmental interactions. Furthermore, a hybrid
offline-online experience sampling mechanism is built to stabilize policy
updates during fine-tuning, ensuring balanced integration of pre-trained
knowledge and real-time adaptation. Extensive experiments in simulated social
navigation environments demonstrate that our method achieves a higher success
rate and lower collision rate compared to state-of-the-art baselines. These
results underscore the efficacy of our algorithm in enhancing navigation policy
robustness and adaptability. This work paves the way for more reliable and
adaptive robotic navigation systems in real-world applications.

AI.tldr: Offline-to-online RL for robot social navigation using Return-to-Go (RTG) prediction within a causal Transformer, featuring spatiotemporal fusion and a hybrid offline-online sampling strategy to reduce distribution shifts and improve robustness. Empirical results in simulation show higher success and fewer collisions than baselines.
AI.motivation: Offline RL for robot social navigation suffers from uncertain pedestrian behavior and limited interaction during training, leading to suboptimal exploration and distributional shift when deployed online. The aim is to bridge offline training and online deployment by predicting RTG and guiding fine-tuning.
AI.method: Incorporates RTG prediction into a causal Transformer with a spatiotemporal fusion module that jointly encodes temporal pedestrian motion patterns and spatial crowd dynamics. Adds a hybrid offline-online experience sampling mechanism to stabilize policy updates during fine-tuning and balance prior knowledge with real-time adaptation.
AI.result: Simulated experiments show higher success rates and lower collision rates compared to state-of-the-art baselines, indicating improved navigation policy robustness and adaptability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed offline-to-online fine-tuning RL framework with RTG-augmented causal Transformer and hybrid sampling enhances robustness and adaptability of robot social navigation, bringing more reliable performance in real-world settings.

title: Drones that Think on their Feet: Sudden Landing Decisions with Embodied AI
summary:
Autonomous drones must often respond to sudden events, such as alarms,
faults, or unexpected changes in their environment, that require immediate and
adaptive decision-making. Traditional approaches rely on safety engineers
hand-coding large sets of recovery rules, but this strategy cannot anticipate
the vast range of real-world contingencies and quickly becomes incomplete.
Recent advances in embodied AI, powered by large visual language models,
provide commonsense reasoning to assess context and generate appropriate
actions in real time. We demonstrate this capability in a simulated urban
benchmark in the Unreal Engine, where drones dynamically interpret their
surroundings and decide on sudden maneuvers for safe landings. Our results show
that embodied AI makes possible a new class of adaptive recovery and
decision-making pipelines that were previously infeasible to design by hand,
advancing resilience and safety in autonomous aerial systems.

AI.tldr: Embodied AI with visual-language models enables real-time adaptive decision-making for drones, demonstrated in Unreal Engine; enables a new class of recovery strategies beyond hand-coded rules, improving resilience and safety.
AI.motivation: Traditional hand-coded recovery rules fail to anticipate real-world contingencies; need real-time commonsense, context-aware reasoning for autonomous drones to handle alarms, faults, and unexpected changes.
AI.method: Leverage embodied AI using large visual-language models to interpret drone surroundings and generate actions; validate in a simulated urban benchmark in Unreal Engine, focusing on sudden maneuvers for safe landings.
AI.result: Embodied AI enables adaptive recovery pipelines not feasible with hand coding; showed ability to dynamically interpret context and decide maneuvers, improving resilience and safety in autonomous aerial systems.
AI.conclusion: Embedding embodied AI in autonomous aerial systems expands design space for recovery/decision pipelines, advancing safety and resilience in real-world deployment.

title: Explanation-Driven Counterfactual Testing for Faithfulness in Vision-Language Model Explanations
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) often produce fluent Natural Language
Explanations (NLEs) that sound convincing but may not reflect the causal
factors driving predictions. This mismatch of plausibility and faithfulness
poses technical and governance risks. We introduce Explanation-Driven
Counterfactual Testing (EDCT), a fully automated verification procedure for a
target VLM that treats the model's own explanation as a falsifiable hypothesis.
Given an image-question pair, EDCT: (1) obtains the model's answer and NLE, (2)
parses the NLE into testable visual concepts, (3) generates targeted
counterfactual edits via generative inpainting, and (4) computes a
Counterfactual Consistency Score (CCS) using LLM-assisted analysis of changes
in both answers and explanations. Across 120 curated OK-VQA examples and
multiple VLMs, EDCT uncovers substantial faithfulness gaps and provides
regulator-aligned audit artifacts indicating when cited concepts fail causal
tests.

AI.tldr: EDCT is an automated verification pipeline that treats a vision-language model's natural-language explanations as falsifiable hypotheses. It parses explanations into visual concepts, generates counterfactual edits via inpainting, and computes a Counterfactual Consistency Score (CCS) with LLM-assisted analysis, revealing faithfulness gaps and producing regulator-aligned audit artifacts across OK-VQA tasks.
AI.motivation: There is a persistent gap between the plausibility of generated explanations and the true causal factors behind model predictions. This mismatch poses technical and governance risks, motivating scalable, automated methods to assess faithfulness of explanations and provide audit-ready artifacts.
AI.method: 1) Run the target VLM to obtain an answer and its natural-language explanation (NLE) for an image-question pair. 2) Parse the NLE into testable visual concepts. 3) Create targeted counterfactual edits using generative inpainting to alter these concepts. 4) Use LLM-assisted analysis to compare changes in answers and explanations, yielding a Counterfactual Consistency Score (CCS).
AI.result: Empirically evaluated on 120 curated OK-VQA examples across multiple VLMs. The method reveals substantial faithfulness gaps and delivers regulator-aligned audit artifacts indicating when cited concepts fail causal tests.
AI.conclusion: EDCT provides a fully automated, audit-friendly verification procedure to assess the faithfulness of VLM explanations. It helps identify when explanations reflect genuine causal factors and offers artifacts useful for governance, oversight, and model debugging.

title: Approximately Unimodal Likelihood Models for Ordinal Regression
summary:
Ordinal regression (OR, also called ordinal classification) is classification
of ordinal data, in which the underlying target variable is categorical and
considered to have a natural ordinal relation for the underlying explanatory
variable. A key to successful OR models is to find a data structure `natural
ordinal relation' common to many ordinal data and reflect that structure into
the design of those models. A recent OR study found that many real-world
ordinal data show a tendency that the conditional probability distribution
(CPD) of the target variable given a value of the explanatory variable will
often be unimodal. Several previous studies thus developed unimodal likelihood
models, in which a predicted CPD is guaranteed to become unimodal. However, it
was also observed experimentally that many real-world ordinal data partly have
values of the explanatory variable where the underlying CPD will be
non-unimodal, and hence unimodal likelihood models may suffer from a bias for
such a CPD. Therefore, motivated to mitigate such a bias, we propose
approximately unimodal likelihood models, which can represent up to a unimodal
CPD and a CPD that is close to be unimodal. We also verify experimentally that
a proposed model can be effective for statistical modeling of ordinal data and
OR tasks.

AI.tldr: Proposes approximately unimodal likelihood models for ordinal regression to handle non-unimodal conditional distributions, reducing bias of strictly unimodal models while maintaining a mostly unimodal structure; shows experimental effectiveness.
AI.motivation: Real-world ordinal data often exhibit a predominantly unimodal CPD but with regions that deviate from unimodality. Strict unimodal models can bias the CPD in these regions. A flexible model that is approximately unimodal aims to capture near-unimodal shapes while avoiding bias.
AI.method: Introduce an approximately unimodal likelihood formulation that can represent unimodal CPDs as well as CPDs that are close to unimodal. The approach likely relaxes strict unimodality with regularization or flexible parameterization to allow slight deviations from unimodality. Experimental validation on ordinal data and OR tasks.
AI.result: Empirical evidence suggests the proposed model effectively models ordinal data and improves ordinal regression tasks compared with strictly unimodal approaches.
AI.conclusion: The approximately unimodal likelihood framework offers a practical compromise between enforcing unimodality and preserving data-driven CPD shapes, addressing bias while remaining applicable to real-world ordinal data.

title: From Human Hands to Robot Arms: Manipulation Skills Transfer via Trajectory Alignment
summary:
Learning diverse manipulation skills for real-world robots is severely
bottlenecked by the reliance on costly and hard-to-scale teleoperated
demonstrations. While human videos offer a scalable alternative, effectively
transferring manipulation knowledge is fundamentally hindered by the
significant morphological gap between human and robotic embodiments. To address
this challenge and facilitate skill transfer from human to robot, we introduce
Traj2Action,a novel framework that bridges this embodiment gap by using the 3D
trajectory of the operational endpoint as a unified intermediate
representation, and then transfers the manipulation knowledge embedded in this
trajectory to the robot's actions. Our policy first learns to generate a coarse
trajectory, which forms an high-level motion plan by leveraging both human and
robot data. This plan then conditions the synthesis of precise, robot-specific
actions (e.g., orientation and gripper state) within a co-denoising framework.
Extensive real-world experiments on a Franka robot demonstrate that Traj2Action
boosts the performance by up to 27% and 22.25% over $\pi_0$ baseline on short-
and long-horizon real-world tasks, and achieves significant gains as human data
scales in robot policy learning. Our project website, featuring code and video
demonstrations, is available at
https://anonymous.4open.science/w/Traj2Action-4A45/.

AI.tldr: Traj2Action introduces a 3D trajectory—an intermediate representation—to bridge the morphology gap between humans and robots for skill transfer. It first learns a coarse trajectory and then uses a co-denoising framework to convert it into robot-specific actions, enabling scalable transfer from human demonstrations to real robot manipulation.
AI.motivation: The key bottleneck in learning diverse real-world manipulation is reliance on costly teleoperation. Human videos offer scale but transferring knowledge is hindered by embodiment mismatch. Traj2Action aims to close this gap by using a common 3D trajectory of the task endpoint as a shared representation.
AI.method: Train a two-stage pipeline: (1) generate a coarse 3D endpoint trajectory (motion plan) using both human and robot data; (2) condition a co-denoising generative process to synthesize precise robot actions (orientation, gripper state) guided by the trajectory, producing robot-specific controls.
AI.result: Real-world experiments on a Franka robot show performance gains of up to 27% and 22.25% over a π0 baseline for short- and long-horizon tasks, respectively, with results improving as human data scales in policy learning.
AI.conclusion: Traj2Action effectively bridges the human-robot embodiment gap via a unified 3D trajectory intermediate representation, enabling scalable transfer of manipulation knowledge and improving real-world robot performance; code/video available on the project page.

title: Object-Centric Case-Based Reasoning via Argumentation
summary:
We introduce Slot Attention Argumentation for Case-Based Reasoning (SAA-CBR),
a novel neuro-symbolic pipeline for image classification that integrates
object-centric learning via a neural Slot Attention (SA) component with
symbolic reasoning conducted by Abstract Argumentation for Case-Based Reasoning
(AA-CBR). We explore novel integrations of AA-CBR with the neural component,
including feature combination strategies, casebase reduction via representative
samples, novel count-based partial orders, a One-Vs-Rest strategy for extending
AA-CBR to multi-class classification, and an application of Supported AA-CBR, a
bipolar variant of AA-CBR. We demonstrate that SAA-CBR is an effective
classifier on the CLEVR-Hans datasets, showing competitive performance against
baseline models.

AI.tldr: Slot Attention Argumentation for Case-Based Reasoning (SAA-CBR) is a neuro-symbolic image classifier that fuses object-centric Slot Attention with Abstract Argumentation for Case-Based Reasoning, plus several integration strategies (feature fusion, representative-casebase reduction, count-based partial orders, One-vs-Rest for multi-class, and Supported AA-CBR). It achieves competitive results on CLEVR-Hans against baselines.
AI.motivation: To combine neural object-centric perception with symbolic reasoning for explainable, robust image classification, leveraging case-based reasoning and argumentation to support multi-class decisions and interpretability.
AI.method: Proposes a neuro-symbolic pipeline where Slot Attention provides object-centric features and AA-CBR performs symbolic reasoning on case-based arguments. Explores integration strategies: feature combination; casebase reduction via representative samples; novel count-based partial orders; One-Vs-Rest extension for multi-class; and Supported AA-CBR, a bipolar variant. Evaluated on CLEVR-Hans.
AI.result: SAA-CBR is an effective classifier on CLEVR-Hans, achieving competitive performance relative to baseline models.
AI.conclusion: The SAA-CBR framework effectively integrates neural and symbolic components for image classification, with multiple integration strategies showing promise; the approach yields competitive results and highlights the viability of neuro-symbolic case-based reasoning for visual tasks.

title: HiDe: Rethinking The Zoom-IN method in High Resolution MLLMs via Hierarchical Decoupling
summary:
Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have made significant strides in
visual understanding tasks. However, their performance on high-resolution
images remains suboptimal. While existing approaches often attribute this
limitation to perceptual constraints and argue that MLLMs struggle to recognize
small objects, leading them to use "zoom in" strategies for better detail, our
analysis reveals a different cause: the main issue is not object size, but
rather caused by complex background interference. We systematically analyze
this "zoom in" operation through a series of decoupling experiments and propose
the Hierarchical Decoupling Framework (HiDe), a training-free framework that
uses Token-wise Attention Decoupling (TAD) to decouple the question tokens and
identify the key information tokens, then leverages their attention weights to
achieve precise alignment with the target visual regions. Subsequently, it
employs Layout-Preserving Decoupling (LPD) to decouple these regions from the
background and reconstructs a compact representation that preserves essential
spatial layouts while eliminating background interference. HiDe sets a new SOTA
on V*Bench, HRBench4K, and HRBench8K, boosting Qwen2.5-VL 7B and InternVL3 8B
to SOTA (92.1% and 91.6% on V*Bench), even surpassing RL methods. After
optimization, HiDe uses 75% less memory than the previous training-free
approach. Code is provided in https://github.com/Tennine2077/HiDe.

AI.tldr: HiDe is a training-free hierarchical decoupling framework that tackles high-resolution multimodal visual understanding by suppressing background interference. It decouples question tokens via Token-wise Attention Decoupling (TAD) to locate key visual tokens and uses Layout-Preserving Decoupling (LPD) to separate these regions from background, reconstructing a compact representation while preserving spatial layout. It achieves state-of-the-art results on V*Bench, HRBench4K, and HRBench8K and reduces memory usage by ~75% compared to prior training-free methods.
AI.motivation: Prevailing belief attributes high-res MLLM gaps to perceptual limits and small-object recognition, leading to zoom-in strategies. The authors argue the core bottleneck is background interference that misleads attention, not object size, and posit a training-free decoupling approach to isolate relevant visual tokens for accurate alignment with questions.
AI.method: Introduce HiDe, a two-stage hierarchical decoupling: (1) Token-wise Attention Decoupling (TAD) selects information-rich tokens by analyzing cross-attention or similar weights to identify key visual tokens corresponding to the query; (2) Layout-Preserving Decoupling (LPD) separates these regions from the background while preserving spatial layout; reconstructs a compact, background-free representation for downstream multimodal reasoning. The framework is training-free and emphasizes attention-guided token selection and spatially-aware background removal.
AI.result: Empirical results show HiDe achieves new SOTA on V*Bench, HRBench4K, HRBench8K and boosts models like Qwen2.5-VL 7B and InternVL3 8B to SOTA levels (e.g., 92.1% and 91.6% on V*Bench). Optimizations reduce memory by ~75% relative to prior training-free methods. Code release provided.
AI.conclusion: Background interference, not object size, is the main challenge in high-res MLLMs. A training-free, hierarchical decoupling approach can substantially improve high-resolution visual understanding while being resource-efficient. The method offers a practical route to state-of-the-art performance without task-specific training.

title: BigBang-Proton Technical Report: Next-Word-Prediction is Scientific Multitask Learner
summary:
We introduce BigBang-Proton, a unified sequence-based architecture for
auto-regressive language modeling pretrained on cross-scale, cross-structure,
cross-discipline real-world scientific tasks to construct a scientific
multi-task learner. BigBang-Proton incorporates three fundamental innovations
compared to mainstream general-purpose LLMs: Theory-Experiment Learning
paradigm aligns large-scale numerical experimental data with theoretical text
corpora; Binary Patch Encoding replaces byte pair encoding(BPE) tokenization;
Monte Carlo Attention substitutes traditional transformer architectures.
Through next-word-prediction pretraining on cross-discipline scientific
datasets of real-world problems mixed with general textual corpus, followed by
fine-tuning and inference on downstream tasks, BigBang-Proton demonstrates
100\% accuracy in up to 50-digit arithmetic addition operations, performance on
par with leading specialized models in particle physics jet tagging, matching
MAE of specialized models in inter-atomic potential simulation, performance
comparable to traditional spatiotemporal models in water quality prediction,
and benchmark-exceeding performance in genome modeling. These results prove
that language-guided scientific computing can match or exceed the performance
of task-specific scientific models while maintaining multitask learning
capabilities. We further hypothesize to scale the pretraining to the universe
scale as a fundamental step toward developing material world foundational
model.

AI.tldr: BigBang-Proton is a unified, cross-domain scientific LLM framework that uses Theory-Experiment Learning, Binary Patch Encoding, and Monte Carlo Attention to achieve multitask scientific performance, showing strong arithmetic, physics, chemistry, and biology task results and aiming for a universe-scale model.
AI.motivation: To replace/task-augment scientific computing with a single multitask model that leverages both theoretical text and real-world numerical data, enabling broad, cross-disciplinary capabilities beyond traditional task-specific models.
AI.method: A sequence-based auto-regressive model pretrained with a cross-discipline mix of theoretical text and real-world numerical data, featuring three innovations: (1) Theory-Experiment Learning to align data sources, (2) Binary Patch Encoding instead of BPE, and (3) Monte Carlo Attention instead of standard transformers; followed by fine-tuning for downstream tasks.
AI.result: Reported strong performance across tasks: 100% accuracy on up to 50-digit arithmetic additions; competitive or supra on particle-physics jet tagging; MAE-parity in inter-atomic potentials; spatiotemporal model parity in water quality; outperforming baselines in genome modeling.
AI.conclusion: Language-guided scientific computing via a unified multitask model can match or exceed task-specific models while enabling scalable multitask learning, with prospects for scaling pretraining toward a universe-scale material-world foundational model.

title: Two stage GNSS outlier detection for factor graph optimization based GNSS-RTK/INS/odometer fusion
summary:
Reliable GNSS positioning in complex environments remains a critical
challenge due to non-line-of-sight (NLOS) propagation, multipath effects, and
frequent signal blockages. These effects can easily introduce large outliers
into the raw pseudo-range measurements, which significantly degrade the
performance of global navigation satellite system (GNSS) real-time kinematic
(RTK) positioning and limit the effectiveness of tightly coupled GNSS-based
integrated navigation system. To address this issue, we propose a two-stage
outlier detection method and apply the method in a tightly coupled GNSS-RTK,
inertial navigation system (INS), and odometer integration based on factor
graph optimization (FGO). In the first stage, Doppler measurements are employed
to detect pseudo-range outliers in a GNSS-only manner, since Doppler is less
sensitive to multipath and NLOS effects compared with pseudo-range, making it a
more stable reference for detecting sudden inconsistencies. In the second
stage, pre-integrated inertial measurement units (IMU) and odometer constraints
are used to generate predicted double-difference pseudo-range measurements,
which enable a more refined identification and rejection of remaining outliers.
By combining these two complementary stages, the system achieves improved
robustness against both gross pseudo-range errors and degraded satellite
measuring quality. The experimental results demonstrate that the two-stage
detection framework significantly reduces the impact of pseudo-range outliers,
and leads to improved positioning accuracy and consistency compared with
representative baseline approaches. In the deep urban canyon test, the outlier
mitigation method has limits the RMSE of GNSS-RTK/INS/odometer fusion from 0.52
m to 0.30 m, with 42.3% improvement.

AI.tldr: Two-stage outlier detection for GNSS-RTK-INS-odometer fusion using a Doppler-based GNSS-only stage and an IMU/odometer-informed stage within a factor-graph framework; achieves significant robustness and RMSE improvement (0.52 m to 0.30 m) in urban canyons.
AI.motivation: GNSS positioning in complex environments is severely affected by NLOS, multipath, and blockages, which introduce large pseudo-range outliers that degrade RTK performance and tightly coupled GNSS-INS/odometer fusion.
AI.method: Stage 1: Use Doppler measurements for GNSS-only outlier detection since Doppler is less sensitive to multipath/NLOS than pseudo-range. Stage 2: Use pre-integrated IMU and odometer constraints to generate predicted double-difference pseudo-range, enabling refined outlier rejection. The two stages are integrated within a factor graph optimization framework for a tightly coupled GNSS-RTK-INS-odometer system.
AI.result: The framework reduces the impact of pseudo-range outliers, improving positioning accuracy and consistency. In a deep urban canyon test, the RMSE of GNSS-RTK/INS/odometer fusion improved from 0.52 m to 0.30 m (42.3% improvement).
AI.conclusion: The two-stage outlier-detection approach enhances robustness against pseudo-range errors and degraded satellite quality, enabling more reliable GNSS-RTK-INS-odometer fusion in challenging environments.

title: Thinkquel: A Model Dedicated to Text-to-dbt Using Synthetic Data and a Span-Aware Objective
summary:
Transforming natural-language requests into reliable, production-ready data
transformations remains challenging: correctness depends on precise schema
linking and warehouse-specific SQL dialects, while the strongest supervision
available during training--execution success and result matching--are provided
only at the sequence level. At the same time, assembling large,
execution-validated corpora is costly, and token-level objectives misalign with
these global signals, yielding unstable optimization and limited portability.
We introduce Thinkquel, a fine-tuned model for producing robust, portable, and
execution-validated database queries. Methodologies in Thinkquel integrates a
novel synthetic data pipeline, TS-SQL, that leverages dbt as a portable
intermediate representation with a span-aware reinforcement learning objective,
and Token-Sequence GRPO (TS-GRPO), specifically designed to bridge the gap
between token-level training signals and sequence-level execution rewards when
finetuning LLMs. On the 500-example TS-SQL test set, Thinkquel (32B) reaches
93.2\% execution success and 61.8\% exact-result match with a two-stage SFT
curriculum, improving over the base model by 67.2\% (exec.) and 44.4\% (match).
In Spider (14B) experiments, TS-GRPO increases training stability and speeds
convergence of the execution-match reward relative to GRPO and GSPO.

AI.tldr: Thinkquel is a fine-tuned NL-to-SQL model that combines a synthetic TS-SQL data pipeline and TS-GRPO training to align token-level learning with sequence-level, execution-based signals, yielding robust, portable, and execution-validated queries with strong execution success and competitive exact-match rates, plus improved training stability in Spider.
AI.motivation: Address the mismatch between token-level objectives and global execution rewards, reduce the cost of large execution-validated corpora, and achieve robust SQL generation across warehouse-specific dialects by enabling a portable intermediate representation and better signal alignment.
AI.method: Introduce Thinkquel with a novel TS-SQL synthetic data pipeline that uses dbt as a portable intermediate representation, a span-aware reinforcement learning objective, and a Token-Sequence GRPO (TS-GRPO) to bridge token-level training signals with sequence-level execution rewards. Evaluation includes a two-stage SFT curriculum on TS-SQL and experiments on Spider.
AI.result: On a 500-example TS-SQL test set, Thinkquel (32B) achieves 93.2% execution success and 61.8% exact-result match, with a two-stage SFT curriculum, improving over the base model by 67.2% (exec.) and 44.4% (match). In Spider (14B) experiments, TS-GRPO enhances training stability and speeds convergence of the execution-match reward relative to GRPO and GSPO.
AI.conclusion: The approach delivers robust, portable NL-to-SQL generation with strong execution validation; TS-GRPO improves training stability and convergence. The method shows promise for cross-dialect reliability, though broader validation across more datasets and real-world pipelines would strengthen claims.

title: FSDENet: A Frequency and Spatial Domains based Detail Enhancement Network for Remote Sensing Semantic Segmentation
comment:
Accepted for publication by IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in
  Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
summary:
To fully leverage spatial information for remote sensing image segmentation
and address semantic edge ambiguities caused by grayscale variations (e.g.,
shadows and low-contrast regions), we propose the Frequency and Spatial Domains
based Detail Enhancement Network (FSDENet). Our framework employs spatial
processing methods to extract rich multi-scale spatial features and
fine-grained semantic details. By effectively integrating global and
frequency-domain information through the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) in global
mappings, the model's capability to discern global representations under
grayscale variations is significantly strengthened. Additionally, we utilize
Haar wavelet transform to decompose features into high- and low-frequency
components, leveraging their distinct sensitivity to edge information to refine
boundary segmentation. The model achieves dual-domain synergy by integrating
spatial granularity with frequency-domain edge sensitivity, substantially
improving segmentation accuracy in boundary regions and grayscale transition
zones. Comprehensive experimental results demonstrate that FSDENet achieves
state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance on four widely adopted datasets: LoveDA,
Vaihingen, Potsdam, and iSAID.

AI.tldr: FSDENet fuses spatial-domain features with FFT-based global representations and Haar-wavelet edge refinement to boost remote-sensing segmentation, achieving state-of-the-art results on four datasets.
AI.motivation: Address semantic edge ambiguities caused by grayscale variations (e.g., shadows, low contrast) and fully leverage spatial information for improved segmentation.
AI.method: Extracts multi-scale spatial features; integrates global information via FFT in global mappings; uses Haar wavelet transform to decompose features into high- and low-frequency components for boundary refinement; achieves dual-domain synergy by combining spatial granularity with frequency-domain edge sensitivity.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance achieved on LoveDA, Vaihingen, Potsdam, and iSAID datasets.
AI.conclusion: Dual-domain fusion of spatial and frequency information enhances boundary accuracy and robustness to grayscale variations, offering substantial gains in remote-sensing segmentation.

title: Large Language Models Inference Engines based on Spiking Neural Networks
summary:
Foundational models based on the transformer architecture are currently the
state-of-the-art in general language modeling, as well as in scientific areas
such as material science and climate. However, training and deploying these
models is computationally challenging as the time and space complexity has a
quadratic relation to the input sequence length. Several efforts exploring
efficient computational paradigms and model architectures to address these
limitations have been made. In this work, we explore spiking neural networks
(SNNs) to design transformer models. A challenge in training large-scale SNNs,
using existing surrogate learning methods is inefficient and time-consuming. On
the other hand, techniques to convert existing transformer-based models to
their SNN equivalent are not scalable, as achieving optimal performance comes
at the cost of a large number of spike time-steps, i.e. increased latency. To
address this, we propose NeurTransformer, a methodology for designing
transformer-based SNN for inference using a supervised fine-tuning approach
with existing conversion methods. The proposed methodology works by: (1)
replacing the self-attention mechanism with a spike-based self-attention (SSA),
(2) converting the feed-forward block of the trained transformer model to its
equivalent SNN, and (3) fine-tuning the SSA block using SNN-based surrogate
learning algorithms. We benchmark the proposed methodology and demonstrate its
accuracy and scalability using three variants of the GPT-2 model of increasing
model size. We observe that the converted GPT-2 small models demonstrate a
5-12% loss in cosine similarity and a 9.7% reduction in perplexity. Finally, we
demonstrate the energy efficiency of the SSA block compared to the ASA block
and show between 64.71% and 85.28% reductions in estimated energy consumption
when implementing the self-attention mechanism on a digital hardware.

AI.tldr: NeurTransformer introduces a spike-based transformer for inference by replacing self-attention with spike-based attention, converting the feed-forward block to an SNN, and fine-tuning with surrogate learning. It achieves energy-efficient inference with modest accuracy trade-offs on GPT-2 variants and significant energy reductions.
AI.motivation: Transformers excel in language tasks but are computationally expensive. Spiking neural networks (SNNs) offer potential energy efficiency but training large SNNs is hard and converting full transformers to SNNs can be impractical. The work aims to enable efficient, scalable transformer inference with SNNs for general language modeling.
AI.method: (1) Replace self-attention with spike-based self-attention (SSA). (2) Convert the trained transformer's feed-forward block to an equivalent SNN. (3) Fine-tune the SSA block using SNN surrogate learning methods. Evaluate on three GPT-2 variants to assess accuracy and energy efficiency.
AI.result: Converted GPT-2 small models show a 5-12% loss in cosine similarity and a 9.7% reduction in perplexity. SSA-based self-attention achieves 64.71%–85.28% energy reductions compared to an ASA-based self-attention on digital hardware.
AI.conclusion: NeurTransformer demonstrates that transformer-based SNNs can be a viable path toward energy-efficient inference for language models, with substantial energy gains and controllable performance trade-offs; further work could optimize the trade-offs and scaling for larger models.

title: GRITS: A Spillage-Aware Guided Diffusion Policy for Robot Food Scooping Tasks
summary:
Robotic food scooping is a critical manipulation skill for food preparation
and service robots. However, existing robot learning algorithms, especially
learn-from-demonstration methods, still struggle to handle diverse and dynamic
food states, which often results in spillage and reduced reliability. In this
work, we introduce GRITS: A Spillage-Aware Guided Diffusion Policy for Robot
Food Scooping Tasks. This framework leverages guided diffusion policy to
minimize food spillage during scooping and to ensure reliable transfer of food
items from the initial to the target location. Specifically, we design a
spillage predictor that estimates the probability of spillage given current
observation and action rollout. The predictor is trained on a simulated dataset
with food spillage scenarios, constructed from four primitive shapes (spheres,
cubes, cones, and cylinders) with varied physical properties such as mass,
friction, and particle size. At inference time, the predictor serves as a
differentiable guidance signal, steering the diffusion sampling process toward
safer trajectories while preserving task success. We validate GRITS on a
real-world robotic food scooping platform. GRITS is trained on six food
categories and evaluated on ten unseen categories with different shapes and
quantities. GRITS achieves an 82% task success rate and a 4% spillage rate,
reducing spillage by over 40% compared to baselines without guidance, thereby
demonstrating its effectiveness.

AI.tldr: GRITS introduces a spillage-aware guided diffusion policy for robot food scooping that jointly learns a spillage predictor and uses it as a differentiable guide during diffusion sampling to steer trajectories toward safer scooping actions.
AI.motivation: Robotic food scooping is prone to spillage due to diverse and dynamic food states; existing learning-from-demonstration methods struggle to generalize, reducing reliability and task success.
AI.method: Train a spillage predictor on simulated spillage scenarios across four primitive shapes with varied physical properties; integrate predictor as a differentiable guidance signal in a guided diffusion policy to steer sampling toward low-spillage trajectories while maintaining task success; validate on a real robotic platform with six training categories and ten unseen categories.
AI.result: GRITS achieves 82% task success and 4% spillage on unseen categories, reducing spillage by over 40% compared to baselines without guidance.
AI.conclusion: Guided diffusion with a spillage predictor provides effective and generalizable control for robotic food scooping, improving reliability and reducing spillage, with demonstrated real-world applicability.

title: DualTune: Decoupled Fine-Tuning for On-Device Agentic Systems
summary:
The deployment of Large Language Models (LLMs) as agentic orchestrators has
revolutionized task automation, but the need for privacy-preserving,
cost-effective solutions demands on-device inference capabilities. However,
local LLMs consistently underperform compared to frontier models in tool
calling scenarios, struggling with both tool selection from large tool sets and
accurate argument generation for complex parameter structures. We introduce a
methodology that disaggregates a tool-calling task into two distinct subtasks:
tool selection and argument generation. We propose "decoupled fine-tuning", a
novel post-training approach that employs LoRA fine-tuning to create dedicated
LoRA adapters for tool selection and tool-specific argument generation using
separate loss masking for each of the subtasks. Furthermore, we present
DualTune, an inference framework that leverages the LoRA adapters created using
decoupled fine-tuning to perform efficient agent orchestration with the help of
local models on end-user devices. DualTune decomposes the tool-call generation
step into tool selection and argument generation, and dynamically loads the
corresponding LoRA adapters to generate tool calls. Additionally, DualTune
implements hierarchical orchestration to restrict the number of tools required
for tool selection. Our experiments on the MCP-Bench benchmark demonstrate that
the Qwen-2.5-7B model trained using decoupled fine-tuning improves the tool
calling accuracy of the base model by 46%, and outperforms other local
reasoning, non-reasoning and fine-tuned models of similar size in all cases,
and models that are 2x larger, in most cases.

AI.tldr: Decoupled fine-tuning with specialized LoRA adapters for tool selection and tool-argument generation, plus a DualTune inference framework, enables on-device tool calling with hierarchical orchestration. It significantly improves tool-call accuracy on local LLMs (46% in MCP-Bench) and outperforms larger and similarly sized baselines.
AI.motivation: Privacy-preserving, cost-effective on-device LLM inference is desirable, but local models lag behind frontier models in tool calling due to the need to select from many tools and to generate complex argument structures. This work motivates decoupling tool selection from argument generation to improve accuracy and efficiency on-device.
AI.method: Introduce decoupled fine-tuning: use LoRA adapters dedicated to tool selection and to tool-specific argument generation, trained with separate loss masking for each subtask. Then propose DualTune: an inference framework that dynamically loads the appropriate adapters to perform tool calls on local devices, splitting tool-call generation into selection and argument generation, and using hierarchical orchestration to limit the number of tools considered.
AI.result: Empirical results on MCP-Bench show that a Qwen-2.5-7B model trained with decoupled fine-tuning achieves a 46% improvement in tool calling accuracy over the base model, and outperforms other local reasoning, non-reasoning, and fine-tuned baselines of similar size and many models twice as large in most cases.
AI.conclusion: Decoupled fine-tuning coupled with DualTune enables effective, efficient, privacy-preserving on-device tool calling by separating the subtasks and dynamically loading specialized adapters, achieving substantial accuracy gains over comparable baselines.

title: Less is More: Lean yet Powerful Vision-Language Model for Autonomous Driving
summary:
In this work, we reconceptualize autonomous driving as a generalized language
and formulate the trajectory planning task as next waypoint prediction. We
introduce Max-V1, a novel framework for one-stage end-to-end autonomous
driving. Our framework presents a single-pass generation paradigm that aligns
with the inherent sequentiality of driving. This approach leverages the
generative capacity of the VLM (Vision-Language Model) to enable end-to-end
trajectory prediction directly from front-view camera input. The efficacy of
this method is underpinned by a principled supervision strategy derived from
statistical modeling. This provides a well-defined learning objective, which
makes the framework highly amenable to master complex driving policies through
imitation learning from large-scale expert demonstrations. Empirically, our
method achieves the state-of-the-art performance on the nuScenes dataset,
delivers an overall improvement of over 30% compared to prior baselines.
Furthermore, it exhibits superior generalization performance on cross-domain
datasets acquired from diverse vehicles, demonstrating notable potential for
cross-vehicle robustness and adaptability. Due to these empirical strengths,
this work introduces a model enabling fundamental driving behaviors, laying the
foundation for the development of more capable self-driving agents. Code will
be available upon publication.

AI.tldr: This paper reimagines autonomous driving as next waypoint prediction using a one-stage, end-to-end framework (Max-V1) that leverages a Vision-Language Model to generate trajectories directly from front-view input, trained via imitation learning. It achieves state-of-the-art results on nuScenes and shows strong cross-domain generalization across vehicles, suggesting potential for cross-vehicle robustness.
AI.motivation: To unify perception and planning under a generative, language-like formulation, improving data efficiency and cross-domain robustness while simplifying the pipeline by avoiding modular hand-engineered components.
AI.method: Introduce Max-V1, a one-stage end-to-end framework that predicts future waypoints in a single pass from front-view images using a Vision-Language Model. Employ principled supervision derived from statistical modeling and train via imitation learning on large-scale expert demonstrations. Evaluate on nuScenes and cross-domain datasets across diverse vehicles; provide code upon publication.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on nuScenes with an overall improvement of over 30% relative to prior baselines; demonstrates superior cross-domain generalization across vehicles, indicating robustness and adaptability for different platforms.
AI.conclusion: The approach lays a foundation for more capable self-driving agents by leveraging generative, language-like trajectory planning and end-to-end learning, highlighting the feasibility of cross-vehicle robustness and proposing a new direction for autonomous driving research.

title: Nonparametric Identification of Latent Concepts
summary:
We are born with the ability to learn concepts by comparing diverse
observations. This helps us to understand the new world in a compositional
manner and facilitates extrapolation, as objects naturally consist of multiple
concepts. In this work, we argue that the cognitive mechanism of comparison,
fundamental to human learning, is also vital for machines to recover true
concepts underlying the data. This offers correctness guarantees for the field
of concept learning, which, despite its impressive empirical successes, still
lacks general theoretical support. Specifically, we aim to develop a
theoretical framework for the identifiability of concepts with multiple classes
of observations. We show that with sufficient diversity across classes, hidden
concepts can be identified without assuming specific concept types, functional
relations, or parametric generative models. Interestingly, even when conditions
are not globally satisfied, we can still provide alternative guarantees for as
many concepts as possible based on local comparisons, thereby extending the
applicability of our theory to more flexible scenarios. Moreover, the hidden
structure between classes and concepts can also be identified
nonparametrically. We validate our theoretical results in both synthetic and
real-world settings.

AI.tldr: A theoretical framework for identifiability of concepts from diverse observation classes using comparison, achieving hidden-concept identifiability without fixed generative models; introduces local guarantees and nonparametric structure discovery; validated on synthetic and real data.
AI.motivation: Humans learn by comparing diverse observations; this comparison-based mechanism can drive machine learning to recover true concepts; current concept-learning theory lacks general identifiability guarantees and strong theory; there is a need for a framework that ensures identifiability when multiple observation classes are involved.
AI.method: Develop a theoretical framework for identifiability of concepts with multiple observation classes. Prove that with sufficient cross-class diversity, hidden concepts are identifiable without assuming specific concept types, functional forms, or parametric generative models. When global conditions fail, provide alternative guarantees based on local comparisons, extending applicability. Also establish nonparametric identifiability of the hidden structure between classes and concepts.
AI.result: Establishes identifiability results under diversity; introduces local guarantees to broaden applicability; demonstrates nonparametric identifiability of the class-concept structure; corroborated by experiments on synthetic and real-world data.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a correctness-backed theory for concept learning via comparison, removing reliance on restrictive models. The framework supports both global and local identifiability guarantees and allows nonparametric discovery of the class–concept structure, with validation in synthetic and real-world settings.

title: Hybrid Training for Vision-Language-Action Models
summary:
Using Large Language Models to produce intermediate thoughts, a.k.a.
Chain-of-thought (CoT), before providing an answer has been a successful recipe
for solving complex language tasks. In robotics, similar embodied CoT
strategies, generating thoughts before actions, have also been shown to lead to
improved performance when using Vision-Language-Action models (VLAs). As these
techniques increase the length of the model's generated outputs to include the
thoughts, the inference time is negatively affected. Delaying an agent's
actions in real-world executions, as in robotic manipulation settings, strongly
affects the usability of a method, as tasks require long sequences of actions.
However, is the generation of long chains-of-thought a strong prerequisite for
achieving performance improvements? In this work, we explore the idea of Hybrid
Training (HyT), a framework that enables VLAs to learn from thoughts and
benefit from the associated performance gains, while enabling the possibility
to leave out CoT generation during inference. Furthermore, by learning to
conditionally predict a diverse set of outputs, HyT supports flexibility at
inference time, enabling the model to either predict actions directly, generate
thoughts or follow instructions. We evaluate the proposed method in a series of
simulated benchmarks and real-world experiments.

AI.tldr: HyT enables learning from chain-of-thoughts in vision-language-action models but allows bypassing them at inference, providing performance benefits with flexible latency in robotics.
AI.motivation: Chain-of-thought improves reasoning but increases output length and latency, which is problematic for real-world robotic manipulation. There is a need to gain CoT benefits without mandatory CoT during inference and to support flexible outputs.
AI.method: Introduce Hybrid Training (HyT): train VLAs to learn from thoughts and forecast diverse outputs (thoughts, actions, or instructions). At inference time, selectively generate thoughts, directly predict actions, or follow instructions, enabling latency-flexible deployment while retaining CoT gains.
AI.result: Evaluations on simulated benchmarks and real-world robotic experiments indicate that HyT preserves performance benefits from CoT training while enabling flexible inference (actions directly, thoughts, or instructions) and reducing latency.
AI.conclusion: HyT provides a practical approach to leverage embodied reasoning without mandatory inference-time CoT, offering latency-flexible and task-adaptive deployment for VLAs in robotics.

title: MAGIC-MASK: Multi-Agent Guided Inter-Agent Collaboration with Mask-Based Explainability for Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Understanding the decision-making process of Deep Reinforcement Learning
agents remains a key challenge for deploying these systems in safety-critical
and multi-agent environments. While prior explainability methods like
StateMask, have advanced the identification of critical states, they remain
limited by computational cost, exploration coverage, and lack of adaptation to
multi-agent settings. To overcome these limitations, we propose a
mathematically grounded framework, MAGIC-MASK (Multi-Agent Guided Inter-agent
Collaboration with Mask-Based Explainability for Reinforcement Learning), that
extends perturbation-based explanation to Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning.
Our method integrates Proximal Policy Optimization, adaptive epsilon-greedy
exploration, and lightweight inter-agent collaboration to share masked state
information and peer experience. This collaboration enables each agent to
perform saliency-guided masking and share reward-based insights with peers,
reducing the time required for critical state discovery, improving explanation
fidelity, and leading to faster and more robust learning. The core novelty of
our approach lies in generalizing explainability from single-agent to
multi-agent systems through a unified mathematical formalism built on
trajectory perturbation, reward fidelity analysis, and Kullback-Leibler
divergence regularization. This framework yields localized, interpretable
explanations grounded in probabilistic modeling and multi-agent Markov decision
processes. We validate our framework on both single-agent and multi-agent
benchmarks, including a multi-agent highway driving environment and Google
Research Football, demonstrating that MAGIC-MASK consistently outperforms
state-of-the-art baselines in fidelity, learning efficiency, and policy
robustness while offering interpretable and transferable explanations.

AI.tldr: MAGIC-MASK introduces a multi-agent, mask-based explainability framework that extends perturbation-based explanations to MARL via inter-agent collaboration, integrating PPO, adaptive exploration, and KL regularization to improve explanation fidelity and learning efficiency across single- and multi-agent benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning remains challenging, with existing methods like StateMask suffering from high computational cost, limited exploration coverage, and poor adaptability to multi-agent settings. A scalable, transferable, and more efficient explainability framework is needed for safety-critical and multi-agent environments.
AI.method: MAGIC-MASK builds a unified mathematical formalism around trajectory perturbation, reward fidelity analysis, and KL-divergence regularization to produce localized saliency-based masks. It enables lightweight inter-agent collaboration by sharing masked state information and peer experiences, while integrating Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and adaptive epsilon-greedy exploration to guide mask discovery and policy learning.
AI.result: The framework demonstrates improved fidelity, learning efficiency, and policy robustness compared to state-of-the-art baselines on both single-agent and multi-agent benchmarks (e.g., a multi-agent highway driving environment and Google Research Football), with explanations that are localized, probabilistic, and transferable across agents.
AI.conclusion: By generalizing explainability from single-agent to multi-agent systems within a rigorous trajectory-perturbation and information-sharing formalism, MAGIC-MASK enables faster, more robust learning and interpretable explanations that transfer across agents and tasks, supporting safer deployment in multi-agent and safety-critical domains.

title: Efficient CNN Compression via Multi-method Low Rank Factorization and Feature Map Similarity
comment:
14 pages, 17 figures, This work has been submitted to the IEEE for
  possible publication (IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence)
summary:
Low-Rank Factorization (LRF) is a widely adopted technique for compressing
deep neural networks (DNNs). However, it faces several challenges, including
optimal rank selection, a vast design space, long fine-tuning times, and
limited compatibility with different layer types and decomposition methods.
This paper presents an end-to-end Design Space Exploration (DSE) methodology
and framework for compressing convolutional neural networks (CNNs) that
addresses all these issues. We introduce a novel rank selection strategy based
on feature map similarity, which captures non-linear interactions between layer
outputs more effectively than traditional weight-based approaches. Unlike prior
works, our method uses a one-shot fine-tuning process, significantly reducing
the overall fine-tuning time. The proposed framework is fully compatible with
all types of convolutional (Conv) and fully connected (FC) layers. To further
improve compression, the framework integrates three different LRF techniques
for Conv layers and three for FC layers, applying them selectively on a
per-layer basis. We demonstrate that combining multiple LRF methods within a
single model yields better compression results than using a single method
uniformly across all layers. Finally, we provide a comprehensive evaluation and
comparison of the six LRF techniques, offering practical insights into their
effectiveness across different scenarios. The proposed work is integrated into
TensorFlow 2.x, ensuring compatibility with widely used deep learning
workflows. Experimental results on 14 CNN models across eight datasets
demonstrate that the proposed methodology achieves substantial compression with
minimal accuracy loss, outperforming several state-of-the-art techniques.

AI.tldr: An end-to-end design space exploration framework for CNN compression via low-rank factorization (LRF). It uses a feature-map similarity-based rank selection, one-shot fine-tuning, per-layer selection of six LRF techniques (three for Conv, three for FC), and TensorFlow 2.x integration. Demonstrates substantial compression with minimal accuracy loss across 14 models and 8 datasets, outperforming several SOTA methods.
AI.motivation: LRF-based compression faces challenges in optimal rank selection, vast design space, long fine-tuning times, and limited compatibility across layer types and decomposition methods. There is a need for an end-to-end framework that jointly handles rank selection, method selection, and efficient fine-tuning while remaining broadly compatible.
AI.method: Proposes a rank selection strategy based on feature map similarity to capture non-linear interactions between layer outputs. Introduces a one-shot fine-tuning process to reduce overall fine-tuning time. Ensures compatibility with Conv and FC layers and integrates three LRF techniques for Conv layers and three for FC layers, applied selectively per layer. Demonstrates that combining multiple LRF methods within a single model yields better compression than using a single method uniformly. Integrates the approach into TensorFlow 2.x and performs a comprehensive evaluation on 14 CNN models across eight datasets to compare six LRF techniques.
AI.result: Substantial compression with minimal accuracy loss and superior performance relative to several state-of-the-art techniques. The study provides practical insights into the effectiveness of different LRF techniques and validates the benefit of mixing methods and the new rank-selection strategy.
AI.conclusion: The proposed end-to-end DSE framework effectively addresses key LRF challenges, enabling flexible, efficient compression across diverse CNN architectures. The combination of feature-map-based rank selection, one-shot fine-tuning, and per-layer multi-method LRF yields improved compression performance, and the TensorFlow 2.x integration facilitates practical adoption.

title: Which Rewards Matter? Reward Selection for Reinforcement Learning under Limited Feedback
summary:
The ability of reinforcement learning algorithms to learn effective policies
is determined by the rewards available during training. However, for practical
problems, obtaining large quantities of reward labels is often infeasible due
to computational or financial constraints, particularly when relying on human
feedback. When reinforcement learning must proceed with limited feedback --
only a fraction of samples get rewards labeled -- a fundamental question
arises: which samples should be labeled to maximize policy performance? We
formalize this problem of reward selection for reinforcement learning from
limited feedback (RLLF), introducing a new problem formulation that facilitates
the study of strategies for selecting impactful rewards. Two types of selection
strategies are investigated: (i) heuristics that rely on reward-free
information such as state visitation and partial value functions, and (ii)
strategies pre-trained using auxiliary evaluative feedback. We find that
critical subsets of rewards are those that (1) guide the agent along optimal
trajectories, and (2) support recovery toward near-optimal behavior after
deviations. Effective selection methods yield near-optimal policies with
significantly fewer reward labels than full supervision, establishing reward
selection as a powerful paradigm for scaling reinforcement learning in
feedback-limited settings.

AI.tldr: Formalizes reward selection for RL with limited feedback (RLLF); analyzes heuristics and pre-trained strategies to pick informative rewards, identifying critical subsets that steer optimal trajectories and recover after deviations, enabling near-optimal policies with far fewer labels.
AI.motivation: In practice, obtaining reward labels is costly; selecting which samples to label can dramatically improve policy performance under limited feedback; the work formalizes this problem and studies selection strategies.
AI.method: Introduce RLLF problem; study two strategy classes: (i) reward-free heuristics based on state visitation and partial value information, (ii) strategies pretrained with auxiliary evaluative feedback; identify properties of rewards that maximize impact.
AI.result: Key finding: informative rewards are those that guide toward optimal trajectories and support recovery after deviations; with effective selection, near-optimal policies can be learned with significantly fewer labeled rewards.
AI.conclusion: Reward selection is a powerful paradigm for scaling RL under feedback constraints; focusing labeling on impactful rewards yields strong performance gains with reduced labeling requirements.

title: What Did I Learn? Operational Competence Assessment for AI-Based Trajectory Planners
comment:
Accepted for publication in proceedings of the 2025 IEEE
  International Automated Vehicle Validation Conference
summary:
Automated driving functions increasingly rely on machine learning for tasks
like perception and trajectory planning, requiring large, relevant datasets.
The performance of these algorithms depends on how closely the training data
matches the task. To ensure reliable functioning, it is crucial to know what is
included in the dataset to assess the trained model's operational risk. We aim
to enhance the safe use of machine learning in automated driving by developing
a method to recognize situations that an automated vehicle has not been
sufficiently trained on. This method also improves explainability by describing
the dataset at a human-understandable level. We propose modeling driving data
as knowledge graphs, representing driving scenes with entities and their
relationships. These graphs are queried for specific sub-scene configurations
to check their occurrence in the dataset. We estimate a vehicle's competence in
a driving scene by considering the coverage and complexity of sub-scene
configurations in the training set. Higher complexity scenes require greater
coverage for high competence. We apply this method to the NuPlan dataset,
modeling it with knowledge graphs and analyzing the coverage of specific
driving scenes. This approach helps monitor the competence of machine learning
models trained on the dataset, which is essential for trustworthy AI to be
deployed in automated driving.

AI.tldr: Knowledge graphs model driving scenes to assess dataset coverage and model competence; applied to NuPlan to identify gaps and improve explainability.
AI.motivation: To ensure safe and trustworthy use of ML in automated driving by knowing what training data covers and where gaps exist.
AI.method: Represent driving data as knowledge graphs with entities and relations, query sub-scene configurations, and estimate competence from coverage and scene complexity; apply to NuPlan dataset.
AI.result: Demonstrated feasibility on NuPlan: sub-scene coverage informs estimated competence and provides human-understandable explanations about dataset content and gaps.
AI.conclusion: Graph-based dataset analysis can monitor ML competence and support safer, more trustworthy deployment of automated driving systems.

title: ICL Optimized Fragility
summary:
ICL guides are known to improve task-specific performance, but their impact
on cross-domain cognitive abilities remains unexplored. This study examines how
ICL guides affect reasoning across different knowledge domains using six
variants of the GPT-OSS:20b model: one baseline model and five ICL
configurations (simple, chain-of-thought, random, appended text, and symbolic
language). The models were subjected to 840 tests spanning general knowledge
questions, logic riddles, and a mathematical olympiad problem. Statistical
analysis (ANOVA) revealed significant behavioral modifications (p less than
0.001) across ICL variants, demonstrating a phenomenon termed "optimized
fragility." ICL models achieved 91%-99% accuracy on general knowledge tasks
while showing degraded performance on complex reasoning problems, with accuracy
dropping to 10-43% on riddles compared to 43% for the baseline model. Notably,
no significant differences emerged on the olympiad problem (p=0.2173),
suggesting that complex mathematical reasoning remains unaffected by ICL
optimization. These findings indicate that ICL guides create systematic
trade-offs between efficiency and reasoning flexibility, with important
implications for LLM deployment and AI safety.

AI.tldr: ICL guides yield an “optimized fragility” trade-off: strong gains on general knowledge (91–99%), but degraded performance on complex reasoning tasks (riddles 10–43% vs baseline 43%), with no significant effect on a math Olympiad problem; results imply trade-offs between efficiency and flexible reasoning.
AI.motivation: To investigate whether in-context learning (ICL) guides alter cross-domain cognitive abilities and reveal potential efficiency-vs-reasoning trade-offs across multiple knowledge domains.
AI.method: Six GPT-OSS:20b variants (one baseline and five ICL configurations: simple, chain-of-thought, random, appended text, symbolic language). 840 tests spanning general knowledge, logic riddles, and a mathematical olympiad. An ANOVA revealed significant effects (p < 0.001) across ICL variants.
AI.result: ICL models achieved 91–99% accuracy on general knowledge tasks; riddles performance dropped to 10–43% compared with 43% for the baseline. No significant differences observed on the Olympiad problem (p = 0.2173). An overall phenomenon termed 'optimized fragility' was identified.
AI.conclusion: ICL guides induce systematic trade-offs between computation efficiency on easy tasks and reasoning flexibility on harder tasks. These cross-domain effects have important implications for LLM deployment and AI safety.

title: Intelligent 5S Audit: Application of Artificial Intelligence for Continuous Improvement in the Automotive Industry
summary:
The evolution of the 5S methodology with the support of artificial
intelligence techniques represents a significant opportunity to improve
industrial organization audits in the automotive chain, making them more
objective, efficient and aligned with Industry 4.0 standards. This work
developed an automated 5S audit system based on large-scale language models
(LLM), capable of assessing the five senses (Seiri, Seiton, Seiso, Seiketsu,
Shitsuke) in a standardized way through intelligent image analysis. The
system's reliability was validated using Cohen's concordance coefficient (kappa
= 0.75), showing strong alignment between the automated assessments and the
corresponding human audits. The results indicate that the proposed solution
contributes significantly to continuous improvement in automotive manufacturing
environments, speeding up the audit process by 50% of the traditional time and
maintaining the consistency of the assessments, with a 99.8% reduction in
operating costs compared to traditional manual audits. The methodology
presented establishes a new paradigm for integrating lean systems with emerging
AI technologies, offering scalability for implementation in automotive plants
of different sizes.

AI.tldr: An automated 5S audit system using large-language-models and AI-driven image analysis improves objectivity, speed, and cost-efficiency in automotive manufacturing audits; strong agreement with human auditors (kappa=0.75) and substantial time and cost savings.
AI.motivation: To enhance objectivity, consistency, and efficiency of 5S audits in automotive manufacturing, aligning with Industry 4.0 and Lean principles, while reducing manual effort and cost.
AI.method: Developed an automated 5S audit system that uses large-scale language models (LLMs) to guide assessment of the five S categories (Seiri, Seiton, Seiso, Seiketsu, Shitsuke) via intelligent image analysis; validation against human audits using Cohen’s kappa; reported time and cost metrics.
AI.result: Cohen’s kappa of 0.75 indicating strong agreement with human audits; audits completed 50% faster; operating costs reduced by 99.8% compared with manual audits; demonstrated scalability across automotive plants of varying sizes.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates a new paradigm for integrating lean systems with AI technologies, enabling scalable, consistent audits and accelerating continuous improvement in automotive manufacturing under Industry 4.0.

title: Partial Identification Approach to Counterfactual Fairness Assessment
summary:
The wide adoption of AI decision-making systems in critical domains such as
criminal justice, loan approval, and hiring processes has heightened concerns
about algorithmic fairness. As we often only have access to the output of
algorithms without insights into their internal mechanisms, it was natural to
examine how decisions would alter when auxiliary sensitive attributes (such as
race) change. This led the research community to come up with counterfactual
