fairness measures, but how to evaluate the measure from available data remains
a challenging task. In many practical applications, the target counterfactual
measure is not identifiable, i.e., it cannot be uniquely determined from the
combination of quantitative data and qualitative knowledge. This paper
addresses this challenge using partial identification, which derives
informative bounds over counterfactual fairness measures from observational
data. We introduce a Bayesian approach to bound unknown counterfactual fairness
measures with high confidence. We demonstrate our algorithm on the COMPAS
dataset, examining fairness in recidivism risk scores with respect to race,
age, and sex. Our results reveal a positive (spurious) effect on the COMPAS
score when changing race to African-American (from all others) and a negative
(direct causal) effect when transitioning from young to old age.

AI.tldr: Partial identification bounds for counterfactual fairness with a Bayesian method, applied to COMPAS; finds a spurious positive race effect and a negative age effect.
AI.motivation: Assessing counterfactual fairness is challenging when the mechanism is unknown and the measure is not identifiable; informative bounds from observational data are needed to evaluate fairness.
AI.method: Develop a partial-identification framework to bound counterfactual fairness measures; introduce a Bayesian approach to produce high-confidence bounds; apply to COMPAS dataset examining race, age, and sex.
AI.result: Produced informative bounds for counterfactual fairness; observed a positive (spurious) effect on the COMPAS score when changing race to African-American and a negative (direct causal) effect when aging from young to old.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates feasibility of Bayesian partial identification for counterfactual fairness and highlights the risk of misinterpreting associations as fairness signals; useful for fairness evaluation when identifiability is not possible.

title: Trajectory Based Observer Design: A Framework for Lightweight Sensor Fusion
summary:
Efficient observer design and accurate sensor fusion are key in state
estimation. This work proposes an optimization-based methodology, termed
Trajectory Based Optimization Design (TBOD), allowing the user to easily design
observers for general nonlinear systems and multi-sensor setups. Starting from
parametrized observer dynamics, the proposed method considers a finite set of
pre-recorded measurement trajectories from the nominal plant and exploits them
to tune the observer parameters through numerical optimization. This research
hinges on the classic observer's theory and Moving Horizon Estimators
methodology. Optimization is exploited to ease the observer's design, providing
the user with a lightweight, general-purpose sensor fusion methodology. TBOD's
main characteristics are the capability to handle general sensors efficiently
and in a modular way and, most importantly, its straightforward tuning
procedure. The TBOD's performance is tested on a terrestrial rover localization
problem, combining IMU and ranging sensors provided by Ultra Wide Band
antennas, and validated through a motion-capture system. Comparison with an
Extended Kalman Filter is also provided, matching its position estimation
accuracy and significantly improving in the orientation.

AI.tldr: An optimization-based observer design framework (TBOD) for nonlinear systems and multi-sensor fusion that tunes observer parameters using pre-recorded measurement trajectories, inspired by Moving Horizon Estimation; demonstrated on rover localization with IMU and UWB, achieving EKF-like position accuracy but improved orientation.
AI.motivation: Efficient, modular, and tunable observers for nonlinear systems with multiple sensors—addressing the challenge of manual, ad-hoc observer design and the need for accurate sensor fusion.
AI.method: Parametrize observer dynamics and optimize the parameters over a finite set of nominal measurement trajectories. Leverages ideas from Moving Horizon Estimators to tune the observer and fuse sensors in a lightweight, modular fashion.
AI.result: Applied to a terrestrial rover localization task using IMU and UWB ranging; validated against a motion-capture system. TBOD matched EKF in position accuracy and significantly improved orientation estimation.
AI.conclusion: TBOD provides a lightweight, general-purpose sensor fusion and observer-design framework that is easy to tune and can handle general sensors in a modular way, with good position accuracy and enhanced orientation estimation compared to a baseline EKF.

title: BiasBusters: Uncovering and Mitigating Tool Selection Bias in Large Language Models
summary:
Agents backed by large language models (LLMs) often rely on external tools
drawn from marketplaces where multiple providers offer functionally equivalent
options. This raises a critical point concerning fairness: if selection is
systematically biased, it can degrade user experience and distort competition
by privileging some providers over others. We introduce a benchmark of diverse
tool categories, each containing multiple functionally equivalent tools, to
evaluate tool-selection bias. Using this benchmark, we test seven models and
show that unfairness exists with models either fixating on a single provider or
disproportionately preferring earlier-listed tools in context. To investigate
the origins of this bias, we conduct controlled experiments examining tool
features, metadata (name, description, parameters), and pre-training exposure.
We find that: (1) semantic alignment between queries and metadata is the
strongest predictor of choice; (2) perturbing descriptions significantly shifts
selections; and (3) repeated pre-training exposure to a single endpoint
amplifies bias. Finally, we propose a lightweight mitigation that first filters
the candidate tools to a relevant subset and then samples uniformly, reducing
bias while preserving good task coverage. Our findings highlight tool-selection
bias as a key obstacle for the fair deployment of tool-augmented LLMs.

AI.tldr: A benchmark reveals tool-selection bias in LLM-powered agents using external tools. Bias arises from metadata and pretraining exposure, with models favoring a single provider or earlier-listed tools. A mitigation using subset filtering followed by uniform sampling reduces bias while maintaining task coverage.
AI.motivation: Ensure fair deployment of tool-augmented LLMs by preventing systematic favoritism among tool providers and maintaining competitive neutrality in tool selection.
AI.method: Build a benchmark with diverse tool categories, each containing multiple functionally equivalent tools. Evaluate seven models. Conduct controlled experiments on tool features, metadata (name, description, parameters), and pre-training exposure to assess drivers of bias. Analyze predictors of tool choice and test a lightweight mitigation that filters to a relevant subset and samples uniformly.
AI.result: Unfairness is observed: models can fixate on a single provider or disproportionately prefer earlier-listed tools. Semantic alignment between queries and metadata strongly predicts choice. Perturbing descriptions shifts selections. Repeated pre-training exposure to a single endpoint amplifies bias. Mitigation by first filtering to a relevant subset and then sampling uniformly reduces bias and preserves task coverage.
AI.conclusion: Tool-selection bias is a key obstacle for fair deployment of tool-augmented LLMs. A simple, practical mitigation can reduce bias without sacrificing performance.

title: OIG-Bench: A Multi-Agent Annotated Benchmark for Multimodal One-Image Guides Understanding
summary:
Recent advances in Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have demonstrated
impressive capabilities. However, evaluating their capacity for human-like
understanding in One-Image Guides remains insufficiently explored. One-Image
Guides are a visual format combining text, imagery, and symbols to present
reorganized and structured information for easier comprehension, which are
specifically designed for human viewing and inherently embody the
characteristics of human perception and understanding. Here, we present
OIG-Bench, a comprehensive benchmark focused on One-Image Guide understanding
across diverse domains. To reduce the cost of manual annotation, we developed a
semi-automated annotation pipeline in which multiple intelligent agents
collaborate to generate preliminary image descriptions, assisting humans in
constructing image-text pairs. With OIG-Bench, we have conducted a
comprehensive evaluation of 29 state-of-the-art MLLMs, including both
proprietary and open-source models. The results show that Qwen2.5-VL-72B
performs the best among the evaluated models, with an overall accuracy of 77%.
Nevertheless, all models exhibit notable weaknesses in semantic understanding
and logical reasoning, indicating that current MLLMs still struggle to
accurately interpret complex visual-text relationships. In addition, we also
demonstrate that the proposed multi-agent annotation system outperforms all
MLLMs in image captioning, highlighting its potential as both a high-quality
image description generator and a valuable tool for future dataset
construction. Datasets are available at https://github.com/XiejcSYSU/OIG-Bench.

AI.tldr: OIG-Bench introduces a benchmark for One-Image Guide understanding in multimodal LLMs, featuring a semi-automated, multi-agent annotation pipeline for image-text pairs and evaluating 29 MLLMs. Qwen2.5-VL-72B tops with 77% accuracy; all models show gaps in semantic reasoning and complex visual-text relations; the annotation system itself outperforms MLLMs in image captioning; dataset available at the project URL.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of evaluation for human-like understanding in One-Image Guides (OIGs) for Multimodal LLMs and to reduce annotation costs in constructing image-text datasets.
AI.method: Develop OIG-Bench spanning diverse domains; implement a semi-automated annotation pipeline where multiple intelligent agents collaboratively generate preliminary captions/descriptions to aid humans in creating image-text pairs; evaluate 29 state-of-the-art MLLMs (proprietary and open-source) on the benchmark; compare with the proposed annotation system on image captioning.
AI.result: Qwen2.5-VL-72B achieves the best overall performance with 77% accuracy; all models exhibit notable weaknesses in semantic understanding and logical reasoning for OIG tasks; the multi-agent annotation system outperforms all MLLMs in image captioning, suggesting strong potential for high-quality image descriptions and dataset construction.
AI.conclusion: OIG-Bench provides a comprehensive, challenging benchmark for evaluating human-like One-Image Guide understanding in MLLMs and reveals current models’ limits in complex visual-text reasoning; the multi-agent annotation approach is effective for generating high-quality image descriptions and valuable for future dataset creation; the dataset is publicly available for community use.

title: Why Can't Transformers Learn Multiplication? Reverse-Engineering Reveals Long-Range Dependency Pitfalls
summary:
Language models are increasingly capable, yet still fail at a seemingly
simple task of multi-digit multiplication. In this work, we study why, by
reverse-engineering a model that successfully learns multiplication via
\emph{implicit chain-of-thought}, and report three findings: (1) Evidence of
long-range structure: Logit attributions and linear probes indicate that the
model encodes the necessary long-range dependencies for multi-digit
multiplication. (2) Mechanism: the model encodes long-range dependencies using
attention to construct a directed acyclic graph to ``cache'' and ``retrieve''
pairwise partial products. (3) Geometry: the model implements partial products
in attention heads by forming Minkowski sums between pairs of digits, and
digits are represented using a Fourier basis, both of which are intuitive and
efficient representations that the standard fine-tuning model lacks. With these
insights, we revisit the learning dynamics of standard fine-tuning and find
that the model converges to a local optimum that lacks the required long-range
dependencies. We further validate this understanding by introducing an
auxiliary loss that predicts the ``running sum'' via a linear regression probe,
which provides an inductive bias that enables the model to successfully learn
multi-digit multiplication. In summary, by reverse-engineering the mechanisms
of an implicit chain-of-thought model we uncover a pitfall for learning
long-range dependencies in Transformers and provide an example of how the
correct inductive bias can address this issue.

AI.tldr: A reverse-engineered implicit chain-of-thought Transformer for multi-digit multiplication reveals long-range dependencies encoded in attention, a DAG-based cache/retrieve mechanism for pairwise partial products, and geometric representations (Minkowski sums and Fourier digit representations). Standard fine-tuning lacks these inductive biases, leading to failure; introducing a running-sum auxiliary loss provides the bias to succeed.
AI.motivation: To understand why large language models struggle with multi-digit multiplication and to uncover the mechanisms that enable an implicit chain-of-thought to succeed, in order to diagnose training pitfalls and propose fixes.
AI.method: Reverse-engineer an implicit-CoT model, use logit attributions and linear probes to detect long-range structure, analyze attention to show a directed acyclic graph that caches/retrieves partial products, and inspect geometry of representations (Minkowski sums of digit pairs; Fourier basis for digits). Compare with standard fine-tuning and test an auxiliary running-sum loss via linear regression probes to induce the needed inductive bias.
AI.result: Evidence of long-range structure enabling multi-digit multiplication; a mechanism where attention constructs a DAG to cache/retrieve pairwise partial products; geometry shows partial products in attention heads correspond to Minkowski sums and digits encoded in a Fourier basis; standard fine-tuning converges to a local optimum lacking these dependencies; an auxiliary running-sum predictor provides the inductive bias that enables successful learning.
AI.conclusion: There is a pitfall in learning long-range dependencies in Transformers under standard fine-tuning; incorporating inductive biases (e.g., a running-sum predictor) can recover the needed long-range structure and enable accurate multi-digit multiplication, as demonstrated by reverse-engineered mechanisms.

title: Enabling High-Frequency Cross-Modality Visual Positioning Service for Accurate Drone Landing
summary:
After years of growth, drone-based delivery is transforming logistics. At its
core, real-time 6-DoF drone pose tracking enables precise flight control and
accurate drone landing. With the widespread availability of urban 3D maps, the
Visual Positioning Service (VPS), a mobile pose estimation system, has been
adapted to enhance drone pose tracking during the landing phase, as
conventional systems like GPS are unreliable in urban environments due to
signal attenuation and multi-path propagation. However, deploying the current
VPS on drones faces limitations in both estimation accuracy and efficiency. In
this work, we redesign drone-oriented VPS with the event camera and introduce
EV-Pose to enable accurate, high-frequency 6-DoF pose tracking for accurate
drone landing. EV-Pose introduces a spatio-temporal feature-instructed pose
estimation module that extracts a temporal distance field to enable 3D point
map matching for pose estimation; and a motion-aware hierarchical fusion and
optimization scheme to enhance the above estimation in accuracy and efficiency,
by utilizing drone motion in the \textit{early stage} of event filtering and
the \textit{later stage} of pose optimization. Evaluation shows that EV-Pose
achieves a rotation accuracy of 1.34$\degree$ and a translation accuracy of
6.9$mm$ with a tracking latency of 10.08$ms$, outperforming baselines by
$>$50\%, \tmcrevise{thus enabling accurate drone landings.} Demo:
https://ev-pose.github.io/

AI.tldr: EV-Pose uses an event-camera based VPS for high-frequency 6-DoF pose tracking during drone landing, enabling accurate landings with low latency. It introduces a spatio-temporal feature-instructed pose estimation with a temporal distance field for 3D map matching and a motion-aware hierarchical fusion/optimization. Reported results: 1.34° rotation, 6.9 mm translation, 10.08 ms latency, outperforming baselines by >50%.
AI.motivation: GPS signals are unreliable in urban environments due to attenuation and multipath; urban 3D maps enable VPS but current methods struggle with accuracy and efficiency during landing.
AI.method: Proposes EV-Pose with (1) a spatio-temporal feature-instructed pose estimation module that builds a temporal distance field for 3D map matching, and (2) a motion-aware hierarchical fusion and optimization scheme that exploits drone motion in early event filtering and later pose optimization, leveraging an event camera.
AI.result: Achieves rotation accuracy of 1.34 degrees, translation accuracy of 6.9 mm, tracking latency of 10.08 ms, and >50% improvement over baselines.
AI.conclusion: EV-Pose enables accurate and efficient 6-DoF pose tracking for drone landing in urban environments when using VPS, with a demonstrable performance advantage.

title: When Hallucination Costs Millions: Benchmarking AI Agents in High-Stakes Adversarial Financial Markets
comment: 15 pages, 5 figures, 4 tables; In submission to ICLR 2026
summary:
We present CAIA, a benchmark exposing a critical blind spot in AI evaluation:
the inability of state-of-the-art models to operate in adversarial, high-stakes
environments where misinformation is weaponized and errors are irreversible.
While existing benchmarks measure task completion in controlled settings,
real-world deployment demands resilience against active deception. Using crypto
markets as a testbed where $30 billion was lost to exploits in 2024, we
evaluate 17 models on 178 time-anchored tasks requiring agents to distinguish
truth from manipulation, navigate fragmented information landscapes, and make
irreversible financial decisions under adversarial pressure.
  Our results reveal a fundamental capability gap: without tools, even frontier
models achieve only 28% accuracy on tasks junior analysts routinely handle.
Tool augmentation improves performance but plateaus at 67.4% versus 80% human
baseline, despite unlimited access to professional resources. Most critically,
we uncover a systematic tool selection catastrophe: models preferentially
choose unreliable web search over authoritative data, falling for SEO-optimized
misinformation and social media manipulation. This behavior persists even when
correct answers are directly accessible through specialized tools, suggesting
foundational limitations rather than knowledge gaps. We also find that Pass@k
metrics mask dangerous trial-and-error behavior for autonomous deployment.
  The implications extend beyond crypto to any domain with active adversaries,
e.g. cybersecurity, content moderation, etc. We release CAIA with contamination
controls and continuous updates, establishing adversarial robustness as a
necessary condition for trustworthy AI autonomy. The benchmark reveals that
current models, despite impressive reasoning scores, remain fundamentally
unprepared for environments where intelligence must survive active opposition.

AI.tldr: CAIA reveals significant capability gaps in current AI models under adversarial, high-stakes conditions; tool augmentation helps but remains far from human performance, and models exhibit systematic, unreliable tool selection, with Pass@k masking dangerous trial-and-error. Adversarial robustness is framed as essential for trustworthy AI autonomy.
AI.motivation: Real-world AI deployment occurs in environments where misinformation is weaponized and errors are irreversible. Existing benchmarks focus on controlled task completion and overlook adversarial, high-stakes resilience. CAIA targets this gap using crypto markets (where exploits caused billions) to stress-test AI decision-making.
AI.method: Evaluate 17 models on 178 time-anchored tasks in crypto-market scenarios requiring truth-vs-manipulation discrimination, navigation of fragmented information, and irreversible financial decisions under adversarial pressure. Compare baseline and tool-augmented performance, analyze tool-choice behavior, and assess metrics like Pass@k.
AI.result: Frontier models achieve ~28% accuracy without tools. Instrumented tools boost performance to ~67.4% but still fall short of ~80% human baseline, even with unlimited professional resources. A systematic tool-selection problem is observed: models prefer unreliable web search over authoritative data, falling for SEO and social-media manipulation. Correct answers accessible via specialized tools are underutilized. Pass@k metrics obscure dangerous trial-and-error behavior in autonomous deployment.
AI.conclusion: Adversarial robustness is a prerequisite for trustworthy AI autonomy. The benchmark indicates current models, despite strong reasoning, are unprepared for environments with active opposition, with implications extending to cybersecurity and content moderation. CAIA, with contamination controls and ongoing updates, seeks to drive development of resilient, adversarially robust AI systems.

title: Geo-R1: Unlocking VLM Geospatial Reasoning with Cross-View Reinforcement Learning
summary:
We introduce Geo-R1, a reasoning-centric post-training framework that unlocks
geospatial reasoning in vision-language models by combining thinking
scaffolding and elevating. In the scaffolding stage, Geo-R1 instills a
``geospatial thinking paradigm" via supervised fine-tuning on synthetic
chain-of-thought exemplars, enabling models to connect visual cues with
geographic priors without costly human reasoning annotations. In the elevating
stage, it uses GRPO-based reinforcement learning on a weakly-supervised
cross-view pairing proxy. This design supplies a verifiable and scalable reward
signal: teaching models to capture and reconcile features across modalities,
and harnessing reasoning for accurate prediction. Geo-R1 extends geospatial
modeling from domain pretraining / supervised finetuning to reasoning-first
post-training, and achieves state-of-the-art performance across various
geospatial reasoning benchmarks. Our model is available at
https://huggingface.co/miniHui/Geo-R1.

AI.tldr: Geo-R1 is a two-stage post-training framework that enables geospatial reasoning in vision-language models: scaffolding with synthetic chain-of-thought to teach geospatial thinking, followed by GRPO-based reinforcement learning on a weak cross-view proxy to align multimodal features, achieving state-of-the-art results on geospatial reasoning benchmarks; available at HuggingFace.
AI.motivation: The work aims to unlock geospatial reasoning in vision-language models without relying on costly human reasoning annotations, by first teaching a geospatial thinking paradigm and then reinforcing cross-modal reasoning to improve predictive accuracy.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (1) Scaffolding: supervised fine-tuning on synthetic chain-of-thought exemplars to instill a geospatial thinking paradigm, connecting visual cues with geographic priors. (2) Elevating: GRPO-based reinforcement learning using a weakly-supervised cross-view pairing proxy to provide a verifiable reward signal and align features across modalities.
AI.result: Geo-R1 achieves state-of-the-art performance on various geospatial reasoning benchmarks, outperforming previous approaches.
AI.conclusion: Geo-R1 shifts geospatial modeling from domain pretraining/supervised fine-tuning to reasoning-first post-training, offering a scalable, verifiable reward-driven method and providing a publicly available model.

title: PrunedLoRA: Robust Gradient-Based structured pruning for Low-rank Adaptation in Fine-tuning
summary:
Low-rank adaptation (LoRA) has become a widely used paradigm for
parameter-efficient fine-tuning of large language models, yet its
representational capacity often lags behind full fine-tuning. Within the
context of LoRA, a key open question is how to obtain expressive low-rank
adapters from over-parameterized spaces. We propose \textit{PrunedLoRA}, a new
framework that leverages structured pruning to obtain highly representative
low-rank adapters from an over-parameterized initialization. Unlike prior
approaches that impose a fixed low-rank budget, PrunedLoRA dynamically prunes
less important components during fine-tuning and prevents their reactivation,
enabling flexible and adaptive rank allocation. For structured pruning, by
minimizing the pruning error for overall loss, we provide fine-grained pruning
and recovery updates in a gradient-based pruning strategy with grounded
interpretation. We provide the first theoretical analysis of the robustness of
structured pruning and provably show that under the impact of weight
perturbation, gradient-based pruning is more robust than activation-based
pruning with respect to overall loss. Empirically, PrunedLoRA consistently
outperforms LoRA and its variants across supervised fine-tuning tasks in
mathematical reasoning, code generation, and natural language understanding,
and it also demonstrates advantages over existing structured pruning methods
across diverse sparsity levels.

AI.tldr: PrunedLoRA introduces a structured-pruning framework that converts over-parameterized LoRA adapters into highly expressive, adaptable low-rank adapters by dynamically pruning during fine-tuning and preventing reactivation, coupled with a gradient-based pruning strategy.
AI.motivation: LoRA often trades off expressiveness for parameter efficiency, leaving a gap with full fine-tuning. There is a need for adaptive, expressive low-rank adapters that can allocate rank where needed while remaining robust to perturbations.
AI.method: PrunedLoRA initializes an over-parameterized LoRA and applies structured pruning that dynamically prunes less important components during fine-tuning; once pruned, components are not reactivated. It uses a gradient-based pruning strategy that minimizes the pruning error for the overall loss, with a grounded interpretation and a theoretical robustness analysis showing gradient-based pruning can be more robust than activation-based pruning under weight perturbation.
AI.result: Empirically, PrunedLoRA consistently outperforms LoRA and related variants on supervised fine-tuning tasks spanning mathematical reasoning, code generation, and natural language understanding, and exhibits advantages over existing structured pruning methods across a range of sparsity levels.
AI.conclusion: PrunedLoRA provides flexible, adaptive rank allocation with enhanced expressiveness and robustness, backed by theoretical analysis and strong empirical performance across diverse tasks.

title: Shared Object Manipulation with a Team of Collaborative Quadrupeds
comment: 8 pages, 9 figures, submitted to The 2026 American Control Conference
summary:
Utilizing teams of multiple robots is advantageous for handling bulky
objects. Many related works focus on multi-manipulator systems, which are
limited by workspace constraints. In this paper, we extend a classical hybrid
motion-force controller to a team of legged manipulator systems, enabling
collaborative loco-manipulation of rigid objects with a force-closed grasp. Our
novel approach allows the robots to flexibly coordinate their movements,
achieving efficient and stable object co-manipulation and transport, validated
through extensive simulations and real-world experiments.

AI.tldr: Extends a hybrid motion-force controller to legged robot teams for cooperative loco-manipulation of rigid objects with a force-closed grasp, enabling flexible, stable co-manipulation validated by simulations and real experiments.
AI.motivation: Overcome workspace limitations and inefficiencies of single- or fixed-manifold manipulators by using mobile legged robots that can coordinate to manipulate bulky objects with a force-closed grasp.
AI.method: Adapt a classical hybrid motion-force control framework to a team of legged manipulators, enabling coordinated loco-manipulation of rigid objects with force-closed constraints and flexible inter-robot coordination; validated via simulations and real-world experiments.
AI.result: Demonstrates efficient and stable object co-manipulation and transport using a team of legged manipulators, supported by extensive simulations and actual experiments.
AI.conclusion: Establishes feasibility and potential of team-based loco-manipulation with legged manipulators; highlights robustness and promising applicability to bulky-object tasks, with avenues for scalability and broader generalization.

title: Hierarchical Reasoning Model: A Critical Supplementary Material
summary:
Transformers have demonstrated remarkable performance in natural language
processing and related domains, as they largely focus on sequential,
autoregressive next-token prediction tasks. Yet, they struggle in logical
reasoning, not necessarily because of a fundamental limitation of these models,
but possibly due to the lack of exploration of more creative uses, such as
latent space and recurrent reasoning. An emerging exploration in this direction
is the Hierarchical Reasoning Model (Wang et al., 2025), which introduces a
novel type of recurrent reasoning in the latent space of transformers,
achieving remarkable performance on a wide range of 2D reasoning tasks. Despite
the promising results, this line of models is still at an early stage and calls
for in-depth investigation. In this work, we perform a critical review on this
class of models, examine key design choices and present intriguing variants
that achieve significantly better performance on the Sudoku-Extreme and
Maze-Hard tasks than previously reported. Our results also raise surprising
observations and intriguing directions for further research.

AI.tldr: A critical review of Hierarchical Reasoning Models (latent-space recurrent reasoning for transformers) showing variants that beat prior Sudoku-Extreme and Maze-Hard results; highlights early-stage status and directions for future work.
AI.motivation: To address perceived limitations of transformers in logical reasoning by exploring latent-space recurrent reasoning architectures, evaluating the design choices of HRM models, and pushing forward improvements.
AI.method: Conduct a critical literature review of the HRM class, analyze key design choices, present and test new variants, and empirically evaluate on Sudoku-Extreme and Maze-Hard tasks, comparing with earlier reports.
AI.result: Proposed variants outperform prior results on Sudoku-Extreme and Maze-Hard; the study yields surprising observations and indicates promising directions, while noting the field remains in an early stage.
AI.conclusion: Hierarchical/latent-space recurrent reasoning for transformers shows promise but requires broader analysis and more systematic investigation to establish robustness and generality.

title: Enhancing Certifiable Semantic Robustness via Robust Pruning of Deep Neural Networks
summary:
Deep neural networks have been widely adopted in many vision and robotics
applications with visual inputs. It is essential to verify its robustness
against semantic transformation perturbations, such as brightness and contrast.
However, current certified training and robustness certification methods face
the challenge of over-parameterization, which hinders the tightness and
scalability due to the over-complicated neural networks. To this end, we first
analyze stability and variance of layers and neurons against input
perturbation, showing that certifiable robustness can be indicated by a
fundamental Unbiased and Smooth Neuron metric (USN). Based on USN, we introduce
a novel neural network pruning method that removes neurons with low USN and
retains those with high USN, thereby preserving model expressiveness without
over-parameterization. To further enhance this pruning process, we propose a
new Wasserstein distance loss to ensure that pruned neurons are more
concentrated across layers. We validate our approach through extensive
experiments on the challenging robust keypoint detection task, which involves
realistic brightness and contrast perturbations, demonstrating that our method
achieves superior robustness certification performance and efficiency compared
to baselines.

AI.tldr: Proposes USN-based pruning to combat over-parameterization in robustness certification under brightness/contrast perturbations, using a Unbiased and Smooth Neuron (USN) metric and a Wasserstein loss to concentrate pruning across layers, yielding improved robustness certification and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Certified training and robustness certification struggle with over-parameterized networks, which hurts tightness and scalability when defending against semantic perturbations like brightness and contrast changes.
AI.method: Analyze layer/neuron stability and variance under input perturbations; define a fundamental Unbiased and Smooth Neuron (USN) metric to indicate certifiable robustness; prune neurons with low USN and retain high USN to preserve expressiveness; introduce a Wasserstein distance loss to encourage pruned neurons to be concentrated across layers; validate on robust keypoint detection with realistic brightness/contrast perturbations.
AI.result: Our approach achieves superior robustness certification performance and efficiency compared with baselines on robust keypoint detection under brightness/contrast perturbations.
AI.conclusion: USN-based pruning combined with Wasserstein loss effectively reduces over-parameterization while preserving or enhancing certifiable robustness for vision/robotics tasks under semantic perturbations.

title: GRPO-$λ$: Credit Assignment improves LLM Reasoning
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed for tasks requiring
complex reasoning, prompting significant interest in improving their reasoning
abilities through post-training. Especially RL based methods using verifiable
reward, like the state-of-the-art GRPO, have shown to tremendously improve
reasoning behaviors when applied as post-training methods. However, the lack of
an explicit reward or critic model limits GRPO's ability to assign fine-grained
credit across token sequences. In this work, we present GRPO-$\lambda$, a novel
extension to GRPO that enhances credit assignment in RL finetuning of LLMs for
complex reasoning tasks. We approximate learning from $\lambda$-return with a
reformulation of eligibility traces using token-level log-probabilities applied
after each sequence generation, and a novel critic-free approximation of the
temporal-difference error. We introduce a few variations for the weighting of
the $\lambda$-return, and their applications to the eligibility-trace, where
all the variations provide significant gains over GRPO. We compare
GRPO-$\lambda$ against GRPO by training models from 1.5B to 7B parameters on
$4$ different math reasoning datasets. The training plots demonstrate 30-40%
improved performance during RL training on both LLaMA-3.1 and Qwen-2.5
architectures. Finally, we show that with GRPO-$\lambda$, the resulting average
performance on AIME24, Math500, OlympiadMath, MinervaMath, and AMC improves
over GRPO by over $3$ points and a $4.5$ points improvement on the 7B model.

AI.tldr: GRPO-λ extends GRPO with lambda-return eligibility traces and critic-free TD error approximation for RL fine-tuning of LLMs, yielding notable gains on math reasoning tasks across model sizes.
AI.motivation: GRPO lacks explicit reward/critic for fine-grained credit assignment across token sequences, limiting RL fine-tuning effectiveness for complex reasoning.
AI.method: Approximate lambda-return via eligibility traces using token-level log probabilities after each sequence; critic-free TD error approximation; explore multiple lambda weighting schemes; apply to LLaMA-3.1 and Qwen-2.5, 1.5B–7B models, on four math datasets; compare to GRPO.
AI.result: During RL training, GRPO-λ achieves 30–40% improvement over GRPO; final averaged scores on AIME24, Math500, OlympiadMath, MinervaMath, AMC improve by >3 points, with 4.5-point gain on the 7B model.
AI.conclusion: GRPO-λ improves credit assignment and yields robust gains over GRPO across model scales and math benchmarks, demonstrating the effectiveness of critic-free, eligibility-trace-based RL fine-tuning for complex reasoning in LLMs.

title: HAMLET: Switch your Vision-Language-Action Model into a History-Aware Policy
summary:
Inherently, robotic manipulation tasks are history-dependent: leveraging past
context could be beneficial. However, most existing Vision-Language-Action
models (VLAs) have been designed without considering this aspect, i.e., they
rely solely on the current observation, ignoring preceding context. In this
paper, we propose HAMLET, a scalable framework to adapt VLAs to attend to the
historical context during action prediction. Specifically, we introduce moment
tokens that compactly encode perceptual information at each timestep. Their
representations are initialized with time-contrastive learning, allowing them
to better capture temporally distinctive aspects. Next, we employ a lightweight
memory module that integrates the moment tokens across past timesteps into
memory features, which are then leveraged for action prediction. Through
empirical evaluation, we show that HAMLET successfully transforms a
state-of-the-art VLA into a history-aware policy, especially demonstrating
significant improvements on long-horizon tasks that require historical context.
In particular, on top of GR00T N1.5, HAMLET achieves an average success rate of
76.4% on history-dependent real-world tasks, surpassing the baseline
performance by 47.2%. Furthermore, HAMLET pushes prior art performance from
64.1% to 66.4% on RoboCasa Kitchen (100-demo setup) and from 95.6% to 97.7% on
LIBERO, highlighting its effectiveness even under generic robot-manipulation
benchmarks.

AI.tldr: HAMLET adds memory-based history conditioning to vision-language-action models via moment tokens and a lightweight memory module, enabling history-aware action prediction and improving performance on history-dependent robotic manipulation benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Robotic manipulation tasks are inherently history-dependent, and existing VLA models typically rely only on the current observation, limiting guidance from past context.
AI.method: Introduce moment tokens that compactly encode perceptual information at each timestep, initialized via time-contrastive learning to capture temporally distinctive cues. A lightweight memory module aggregates past moment tokens into memory features used for action prediction, transforming a state-of-the-art VLA into a history-aware policy.
AI.result: On GR00T N1.5 real-world tasks, HAMLET achieves 76.4% average success on history-dependent tasks, surpassing the baseline by 47.2%. In RoboCasa Kitchen (100-demo setup) performance improves from 64.1% to 66.4%, and in LIBERO from 95.6% to 97.7%.
AI.conclusion: HAMLET demonstrates that scalable history-aware adaptations of VLAs can substantially improve performance on history-dependent manipulation tasks and benchmarks, validating the value of incorporating temporal context into these models.

title: Semantic-Driven AI Agent Communications: Challenges and Solutions
summary:
With the rapid growth of intelligent services, communication targets are
shifting from humans to artificial intelligent (AI) agents, which require new
paradigms to enable real-time perception, decision-making, and collaboration.
Semantic communication, which conveys task-relevant meaning rather than raw
data, offers a promising solution. However, its practical deployment remains
constrained by dynamic environments and limited resources. To address these
issues, this article proposes a semantic-driven AI agent communication
framework and develops three enabling techniques. First, semantic adaptation
transmission applies fine-tuning with real or generative samples to efficiently
adapt models to varying environments. Second, semantic lightweight transmission
incorporates pruning, quantization, and perception-aware sampling to reduce
model complexity and alleviate computational burden on edge agents. Third,
semantic self-evolution control employs distributed hierarchical
decision-making to optimize multi-dimensional resources, enabling robust
multi-agent collaboration in dynamic environments. Simulation results show that
the proposed solutions achieve faster convergence and stronger robustness,
while the proposed distributed hierarchical optimization method significantly
outperforms conventional decision-making schemes, highlighting its potential
for AI agent communication networks.

AI.tldr: A semantic-driven AI agent communication framework with three enabling techniques—semantic adaptation transmission, semantic lightweight transmission, and semantic self-evolution control—that collectively improve convergence speed and robustness in multi-agent networks, with distributed hierarchical optimization outperforming conventional decision-making schemes.
AI.motivation: As AI agents increasingly substitute humans in perception, decision-making, and collaboration, there is a need for communication that conveys task-relevant meaning efficiently under dynamic environments and limited resources.
AI.method: Propose a semantic-driven AI agent communication framework and three techniques: (1) semantic adaptation transmission using fine-tuning with real or generative samples to adapt models to varying environments; (2) semantic lightweight transmission employing pruning, quantization, and perception-aware sampling to reduce model complexity and computational burden on edge agents; (3) semantic self-evolution control with distributed hierarchical decision-making to optimize multi-dimensional resources for robust multi-agent collaboration in dynamic settings. Evaluation via simulations comparing against conventional schemes.
AI.result: The approach yields faster convergence and stronger robustness; the distributed hierarchical optimization substantially outperforms traditional decision-making schemes.
AI.conclusion: Semantic-driven AI agent communication networks can enable robust, efficient multi-agent collaboration in dynamic environments; the framework’s techniques collectively enhance adaptability, efficiency, and decision quality, suggesting strong potential for deployment in AI agent networks.

title: Improved Hyperspectral Anomaly Detection via Unsupervised Subspace Modeling in the Signed Cumulative Distribution Transform Domain
summary:
Hyperspectral anomaly detection (HAD), a crucial approach for many civilian
and military applications, seeks to identify pixels with spectral signatures
that are anomalous relative to a preponderance of background signatures.
Significant effort has been made to improve HAD techniques, but challenges
arise due to complex real-world environments and, by definition, limited prior
knowledge of potential signatures of interest. This paper introduces a novel
HAD method by proposing a transport-based mathematical model to describe the
pixels comprising a given hyperspectral image. In this approach, hyperspectral
pixels are viewed as observations of a template pattern undergoing unknown
deformations that enables their representation in the signed cumulative
distribution transform (SCDT) domain. An unsupervised subspace modeling
technique is then used to construct a model of abundant background signals in
this domain, whereupon anomalous signals are detected as deviations from the
learned model. Comprehensive evaluations across five distinct datasets
illustrate the superiority of our approach compared to state-of-the-art
methods.

AI.tldr: A transport-based HAD method that models hyperspectral pixels as deformations of a template in the SCDT domain, using unsupervised subspace modeling to detect anomalies; evaluated on five datasets with reported state-of-the-art performance.
AI.motivation: Address HAD challenges under complex real-world environments and limited prior knowledge; leverage transport-based representations and the SCDT to capture deformations of spectral signatures; employ unsupervised background modeling.
AI.method: Treat pixels as samples of a template pattern undergoing unknown deformations and map them to the signed cumulative distribution transform (SCDT) domain. Build an unsupervised subspace model of background signals in this domain and detect anomalies as deviations from the learned model.
AI.result: Extensive experiments across five datasets show superiority over state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a novel transport-based framework for HAD using SCDT and unsupervised background modeling; robust to deformation of spectral signatures and effective for anomaly detection in hyperspectral imagery; demonstrates broad applicability.

title: RouterArena: An Open Platform for Comprehensive Comparison of LLM Routers
summary:
Today's LLM ecosystem comprises a wide spectrum of models that differ in
size, capability, and cost. No single model is optimal for all scenarios;
hence, LLM routers have become essential for selecting the most appropriate
model under varying circumstances. However, the rapid emergence of various
routers makes choosing the right one increasingly challenging. To address this
problem, we need a comprehensive router comparison and a standardized
leaderboard, similar to those available for models. In this work, we introduce
RouterArena, the first open platform enabling comprehensive comparison of LLM
routers. RouterArena has (1) a principally constructed dataset with broad
knowledge domain coverage, (2) distinguishable difficulty levels for each
domain, (3) an extensive list of evaluation metrics, and (4) an automated
framework for leaderboard updates. Leveraging our framework, we have produced
the initial leaderboard with detailed metrics comparison as shown in Figure 1.
We will make our platform open to the public soon.

AI.tldr: RouterArena proposes the first open benchmarking platform to compare LLM routers using a structured dataset, difficulty levels, diverse metrics, and an automated leaderboard, aiming to standardize router evaluation.
AI.motivation: There is a rapid proliferation of LLM routers, and no standardized benchmark exists to compare them across domains, capabilities, and costs; a leaderboard is needed to guide selection and drive improvement.
AI.method: Design of a principally constructed dataset with broad knowledge domain coverage, assignment of distinguishable difficulty levels per domain, an extensive metric suite, and an automated framework for updating a leaderboard; initial leaderboard demonstrated.
AI.result: An initial leaderboard with detailed metrics is presented, along with a publicly accessible framework to benchmark routers; platform to be opened to the public soon.
AI.conclusion: RouterArena could become a standard benchmark for LLM routers, enabling transparent and comparable evaluation, though questions remain about coverage, update cadence, fairness, and practical adoption.

title: MultiPhysio-HRC: Multimodal Physiological Signals Dataset for industrial Human-Robot Collaboration
summary:
Human-robot collaboration (HRC) is a key focus of Industry 5.0, aiming to
enhance worker productivity while ensuring well-being. The ability to perceive
human psycho-physical states, such as stress and cognitive load, is crucial for
adaptive and human-aware robotics. This paper introduces MultiPhysio-HRC, a
multimodal dataset containing physiological, audio, and facial data collected
during real-world HRC scenarios. The dataset includes electroencephalography
(EEG), electrocardiography (ECG), electrodermal activity (EDA), respiration
(RESP), electromyography (EMG), voice recordings, and facial action units. The
dataset integrates controlled cognitive tasks, immersive virtual reality
experiences, and industrial disassembly activities performed manually and with
robotic assistance, to capture a holistic view of the participants' mental
states. Rich ground truth annotations were obtained using validated
psychological self-assessment questionnaires. Baseline models were evaluated
for stress and cognitive load classification, demonstrating the dataset's
potential for affective computing and human-aware robotics research.
MultiPhysio-HRC is publicly available to support research in human-centered
automation, workplace well-being, and intelligent robotic systems.

AI.tldr: A newly released MultiPhysio-HRC multimodal dataset for human-robot collaboration capturing EEG, ECG, EDA, respiration, EMG, voice, and facial data across real-world tasks and VR, enabling stress and cognitive load classification; it supports affective computing and human-aware robotics, with baseline models and ground-truth questionnaires, and is publicly available.
AI.motivation: To enable adaptive, human-aware robotics by sensing psycho-physical states (stress, cognitive load) in industrial HRC, advancing Industry 5.0.
AI.method: Data collection across real-world disassembly tasks with robotic assistance, immersive VR experiences, and controlled cognitive tasks; multimodal sensors; rich ground-truth via validated questionnaires; baseline models for stress and cognitive load classification.
AI.result: Baseline models demonstrate potential for stress and cognitive load classification; dataset provides rich, multimodal data and validated ground-truth; public release.
AI.conclusion: Publicly available resource to advance research in human-centered automation, workplace well-being, and intelligent robotics.

title: Towards Self-Evolving Benchmarks: Synthesizing Agent Trajectories via Test-Time Exploration under Validate-by-Reproduce Paradigm
comment:
his is a work in progress due to methodology refinement and further
  evaluation
summary:
Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) and agent system designs have
empowered agents with unprecedented levels of capability. However, existing
agent benchmarks are showing a trend of rapid ceiling-hitting by newly
developed agents, making it difficult to meet the demands for evaluating agent
abilities. To address this problem, we propose the Trajectory-based
Validated-by-Reproducing Agent-benchmark Complexity Evolution (TRACE)
framework. This framework takes an original task from an existing benchmark and
encourages agents to freely explore and evolve it into a new task with higher
difficulty while recording validatable agent trajectories. The framework
proceeds in three stages: (1) evolutionary proposal mining, which provides task
evolution proposals through preliminary exploration and divergent thinking; (2)
problem formation and free exploration, where proposals are conceptualized into
feasible problem candidates and the agents then explore them freely while
recording their execution trajectories; and (3) multi-level validation, which
ensures that the evolved tasks are accompanied by validatable and reproducible
trajectories. Experiments on the GAIA benchmark demonstrate that the TRACE
framework consistently enhances task complexity while improving the reliability
of correctness through validatable execution trajectories. This work marks a
paradigm shift from static, manually curated benchmarks to dynamic,
self-evolving evaluation systems, providing a sustainable and challenging
runway for agent development.

AI.tldr: TRACE evolves tasks from existing benchmarks by having agents freely explore and reproduce higher-difficulty tasks, recording validatable trajectories. It increases task complexity while ensuring reproducibility, shifting benchmarks toward dynamic, self-evolving evaluation.
AI.motivation: Current agent benchmarks quickly saturate as models improve, making evaluations less informative. There is a need for sustainable, reproducible, and progressively challenging benchmarks that can document agent trajectories for validation.
AI.method: Three-stage TRACE process: (1) evolutionary proposal mining to generate higher-difficulty task proposals via exploration and divergent thinking; (2) problem formation and free exploration where feasible task candidates are created and agents freely explore them while recording execution trajectories; (3) multi-level validation ensuring evolved tasks come with validatable and reproducible trajectories.
AI.result: Applied to GAIA benchmark, TRACE consistently increases task complexity while improving the reliability of correctness via validatable execution trajectories.
AI.conclusion: TRACE represents a paradigm shift from static benchmarks to dynamic, self-evolving evaluation systems, offering a sustainable and challenging runway for advancing agent development.

title: MOLM: Mixture of LoRA Markers
comment: 21 pages, 11 figures, Under review at ICLR 2026
summary:
Generative models can generate photorealistic images at scale. This raises
urgent concerns about the ability to detect synthetically generated images and
attribute these images to specific sources. While watermarking has emerged as a
possible solution, existing methods remain fragile to realistic distortions,
susceptible to adaptive removal, and expensive to update when the underlying
watermarking key changes. We propose a general watermarking framework that
formulates the encoding problem as key-dependent perturbation of the parameters
of a generative model. Within this framework, we introduce Mixture of LoRA
Markers (MOLM), a routing-based instantiation in which binary keys activate
lightweight LoRA adapters inside residual and attention blocks. This design
avoids key-specific re-training and achieves the desired properties such as
imperceptibility, fidelity, verifiability, and robustness. Experiments on
Stable Diffusion and FLUX show that MOLM preserves image quality while
achieving robust key recovery against distortions, compression and
regeneration, averaging attacks, and black-box adversarial attacks on the
extractor.

AI.tldr: Watermarking framework for diffusion-based generative models using key-dependent perturbations; introduces MOLM with LoRA adapters; robust, imperceptible watermarking without re-training.
AI.motivation: Address rise of synthetic images and challenges in attributing sources; existing watermarking methods are fragile, vulnerable to distortions, and hard to update with new keys.
AI.method: Formulate encoding as key-dependent perturbation of model parameters; MOLM uses routing-based mixture of LoRA adapters activated by binary keys inside residual and attention blocks; no re-training required; robust extractor.
AI.result: Preserves image quality; robust key recovery under distortions, compression, regeneration, averaging attacks, and black-box adversarial extractor attacks; validated on Stable Diffusion and FLUX.
AI.conclusion: MOLM provides a practical, robust, and update-friendly watermarking scheme for generative models, enabling source attribution and verifiability with high imperceptibility.

title: LoRAFusion: Efficient LoRA Fine-Tuning for LLMs
summary:
Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) has become the leading Parameter-Efficient
Fine-Tuning (PEFT) method for Large Language Models (LLMs), as it significantly
reduces GPU memory usage while maintaining competitive fine-tuned model quality
on downstream tasks. Despite these benefits, we identify two key inefficiencies
in existing LoRA fine-tuning systems. First, they incur substantial runtime
overhead due to redundant memory accesses on large activation tensors. Second,
they miss the opportunity to concurrently fine-tune multiple independent LoRA
adapters that share the same base model on the same set of GPUs. This leads to
missed performance gains such as reduced pipeline bubbles, better communication
overlap, and improved GPU load balance.
  To address these issues, we introduce LoRAFusion, an efficient LoRA
fine-tuning system for LLMs. At the kernel level, we propose a graph-splitting
method that fuses memory-bound operations. This design eliminates unnecessary
memory accesses and preserves the performance of compute-bound GEMMs without
incurring the cost of recomputation or synchronization. At the scheduling
level, LoRAFusion introduces an adaptive batching algorithm for multi-job
fine-tuning. It first splits LoRA adapters into groups to intentionally stagger
batch execution across jobs, and then solves a bin-packing problem within each
group to generate balanced, dependency-aware microbatches. LoRAFusion achieves
up to $1.96\times$ ($1.47\times$ on average) end-to-end speedup compared to
Megatron-LM, and up to $1.46\times$ ($1.29\times$ on average) improvement over
mLoRA, the state-of-the-art multi-LoRA fine-tuning system. Our fused kernel
achieves up to $1.39\times$ ($1.27\times$ on average) kernel performance
improvement and can directly serve as a plug-and-play replacement in existing
LoRA systems. We open-source LoRAFusion at
https://github.com/CentML/lorafusion.

AI.tldr: LoRAFusion is a plug-and-play system that speeds up LoRA-based fine-tuning of LLMs by (1) fusing memory-bound operations with a kernel-level graph-splitting approach and (2) optimizing multi-adapter scheduling via adaptive batching and bin-packing, achieving substantial end-to-end speedups and kernel gains, and is open-sourced.
AI.motivation: Current LoRA fine-tuning suffers from two inefficiencies: (i) large activation tensors incur substantial runtime overhead due to redundant memory accesses, and (ii) lack of concurrent fine-tuning of multiple independent LoRA adapters sharing a base model leads to pipeline inefficiencies and poor GPU utilization.
AI.method: Kernel-level: a graph-splitting method that fuses memory-bound operations to eliminate redundant memory accesses while preserving compute-bound GEMM performance without recomputation or extra synchronization. Scheduling-level: an adaptive batching algorithm for multi-job fine-tuning that splits adapters into groups to stagger batch execution, then solves a bin-packing problem within each group to produce balanced, dependency-aware microbatches.
AI.result: LoRAFusion achieves up to 1.96× end-to-end speedup versus Megatron-LM (1.47× average) and up to 1.46× against mLoRA (1.29× average). The fused kernel yields up to 1.39× kernel performance improvement (1.27× on average). It is open-sourced at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: LoRAFusion provides a practical, plug-and-play solution that addresses memory-bound inefficiencies and multi-adapter scheduling bottlenecks in LoRA fine-tuning, delivering substantial end-to-end speedups and enabling efficient concurrent multi-adapter training.

title: CroSTAta: Cross-State Transition Attention Transformer for Robotic Manipulation
comment: Code and data available at https://github.com/iit-DLSLab/croSTAta
summary:
Learning robotic manipulation policies through supervised learning from
demonstrations remains challenging when policies encounter execution variations
not explicitly covered during training. While incorporating historical context
through attention mechanisms can improve robustness, standard approaches
process all past states in a sequence without explicitly modeling the temporal
structure that demonstrations may include, such as failure and recovery
patterns. We propose a Cross-State Transition Attention Transformer that
employs a novel State Transition Attention (STA) mechanism to modulate standard
attention weights based on learned state evolution patterns, enabling policies
to better adapt their behavior based on execution history. Our approach
combines this structured attention with temporal masking during training, where
visual information is randomly removed from recent timesteps to encourage
temporal reasoning from historical context. Evaluation in simulation shows that
STA consistently outperforms standard cross-attention and temporal modeling
approaches like TCN and LSTM networks across all tasks, achieving more than 2x
improvement over cross-attention on precision-critical tasks.

AI.tldr: A Cross-State Transition Attention Transformer with a State Transition Attention (STA) mechanism and temporal masking improves robustness of supervised robotic manipulation policies to execution variations, outperforming cross-attention and standard temporal models, with >2x gains on precision-critical tasks.
AI.motivation: Policy learning from demonstrations remains challenging when execution variations occur; while attention on historical context helps, existing models treat all past states uniformly and do not explicitly model temporal evolution patterns like failure and recovery.
AI.method: Propose a Cross-State Transition Attention Transformer that uses a novel State Transition Attention (STA) module to modulate attention weights based on learned state evolution; combine this with temporal masking during training by randomly removing visual information from recent timesteps to encourage temporal reasoning from history.
AI.result: In simulation, STA consistently outperforms standard cross-attention and temporal models (TCN, LSTM) across tasks, achieving more than 2x improvement over cross-attention on precision-critical tasks.
AI.conclusion: Capturing state evolution in attention and applying temporal masking during training yields more robust manipulation policies under execution variations, suggesting broad applicability to learning from demonstrations with complex temporal structures.

title: Automated Evaluation can Distinguish the Good and Bad AI Responses to Patient Questions about Hospitalization
summary:
Automated approaches to answer patient-posed health questions are rising, but
selecting among systems requires reliable evaluation. The current gold standard
for evaluating the free-text artificial intelligence (AI) responses--human
expert review--is labor-intensive and slow, limiting scalability. Automated
metrics are promising yet variably aligned with human judgments and often
context-dependent. To address the feasibility of automating the evaluation of
AI responses to hospitalization-related questions posed by patients, we
conducted a large systematic study of evaluation approaches. Across 100 patient
cases, we collected responses from 28 AI systems (2800 total) and assessed them
along three dimensions: whether a system response (1) answers the question, (2)
appropriately uses clinical note evidence, and (3) uses general medical
knowledge. Using clinician-authored reference answers to anchor metrics,
automated rankings closely matched expert ratings. Our findings suggest that
carefully designed automated evaluation can scale comparative assessment of AI
systems and support patient-clinician communication.

AI.tldr: Automated evaluation of patient-facing AI health answers can closely match expert judgments when anchored to clinician-provided references, enabling scalable comparison across many AI systems.
AI.motivation: Human expert review for free-text AI health responses is slow and labor-intensive; need scalable, reliable evaluation for hospitalization-related patient questions.
AI.method: Systematic study with 100 patient cases, 28 AI systems generating 2,800 responses; assessed across three dimensions (answers the question; uses appropriate clinical note evidence; uses general medical knowledge); metrics anchored by clinician-authored reference answers; compared automated rankings to expert ratings.
AI.result: Automated rankings closely matched expert ratings, indicating feasibility of scalable automated evaluation when metrics are well designed and anchored.
AI.conclusion: Carefully designed automated evaluation can scale comparative assessment of AI systems and support patient-clinician communication.

title: Looking Beyond the Known: Towards a Data Discovery Guided Open-World Object Detection
summary:
Open-World Object Detection (OWOD) enriches traditional object detectors by
enabling continual discovery and integration of unknown objects via human
guidance. However, existing OWOD approaches frequently suffer from semantic
confusion between known and unknown classes, alongside catastrophic forgetting,
leading to diminished unknown recall and degraded known-class accuracy. To
overcome these challenges, we propose Combinatorial Open-World Detection
(CROWD), a unified framework reformulating unknown object discovery and
adaptation as an interwoven combinatorial (set-based) data-discovery
(CROWD-Discover) and representation learning (CROWD-Learn) task. CROWD-Discover
strategically mines unknown instances by maximizing Submodular Conditional Gain
(SCG) functions, selecting representative examples distinctly dissimilar from
known objects. Subsequently, CROWD-Learn employs novel combinatorial objectives
that jointly disentangle known and unknown representations while maintaining
discriminative coherence among known classes, thus mitigating confusion and
forgetting. Extensive evaluations on OWOD benchmarks illustrate that CROWD
achieves improvements of 2.83% and 2.05% in known-class accuracy on M-OWODB and
S-OWODB, respectively, and nearly 2.4x unknown recall compared to leading
baselines.

AI.tldr: A unified combinatorial framework (CROWD) for Open-World Object Detection that interleaves discovering unknowns with learning representations, reducing confusion and forgetting, and boosting known accuracy and unknown recall.
AI.motivation: OWOD methods struggle with semantic confusion between known/unknown and catastrophic forgetting, hindering both unknown recall and known-class accuracy.
AI.method: Proposes CROWD with two interwoven tasks: CROWD-Discover selects informative unknown instances via Submodular Conditional Gain to diversify unknowns; CROWD-Learn uses combinatorial objectives to disentangle known/unknown representations while preserving discriminative coherence among known classes.
AI.result: On M-OWODB and S-OWODB benchmarks, CROWD improves known-class accuracy by 2.83% and 2.05% respectively and yields ~2.4x unknown recall over leading baselines.
AI.conclusion: CROWD effectively mitigates confusion and forgetting in OWOD, validating the efficacy of combinatorial data-discovery and representation learning for continual unknown discovery and integration.

title: Directed-MAML: Meta Reinforcement Learning Algorithm with Task-directed Approximation
summary:
Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) is a versatile meta-learning framework
applicable to both supervised learning and reinforcement learning (RL).
However, applying MAML to meta-reinforcement learning (meta-RL) presents
notable challenges. First, MAML relies on second-order gradient computations,
leading to significant computational and memory overhead. Second, the nested
structure of optimization increases the problem's complexity, making
convergence to a global optimum more challenging. To overcome these
limitations, we propose Directed-MAML, a novel task-directed meta-RL algorithm.
Before the second-order gradient step, Directed-MAML applies an additional
first-order task-directed approximation to estimate the effect of second-order
gradients, thereby accelerating convergence to the optimum and reducing
computational cost. Experimental results demonstrate that Directed-MAML
surpasses MAML-based baselines in computational efficiency and convergence
speed in the scenarios of CartPole-v1, LunarLander-v2 and two-vehicle
intersection crossing. Furthermore, we show that task-directed approximation
can be effectively integrated into other meta-learning algorithms, such as
First-Order Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (FOMAML) and Meta Stochastic Gradient
Descent(Meta-SGD), yielding improved computational efficiency and convergence
speed.

AI.tldr: Directed-MAML introduces a first-order task-directed approximation before the second-order gradient step in meta-RL to reduce computation and speed up convergence, and it can be integrated into other meta-learning methods like FOMAML and Meta-SGD.
AI.motivation: To address two key drawbacks of applying MAML to meta-RL: (i) high computational/memory cost from second-order gradients, and (ii) the complexity of nested optimization that hampers convergence to a global optimum.
AI.method: Before performing the second-order gradient step, apply a first-order task-directed approximation to estimate the effect of second-order gradients, thereby accelerating convergence and reducing computational cost. Demonstrated on CartPole-v1, LunarLander-v2, and a two-vehicle intersection crossing scenario; also shows that the task-directed approximation can be integrated into other meta-learning algorithms (FOMAML, Meta-SGD).
AI.result: Directed-MAML and its task-directed approach outperform MAML-based baselines in computational efficiency and convergence speed on the tested RL tasks; the task-directed approximation can be effectively embedded into other meta-learning algorithms to achieve similar gains in efficiency and speed.
AI.conclusion: Task-directed approximation is an effective mechanism to mitigate second-order overhead in meta-RL and can be generalized to other meta-learning frameworks, offering a practical route to faster convergence with lower computational demands.

title: Tele-rehabilitation with online skill transfer and adaptation in $\mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathit{S}^3$
summary:
This paper proposes a tele-teaching framework for the domain of
robot-assisted tele-rehabilitation. The system connects two robotic
manipulators on therapist and patient side via bilateral teleoperation,
enabling a therapist to remotely demonstrate rehabilitation exercises that are
executed by the patient-side robot. A 6-DoF Dynamical Movement Primitives
formulation is employed to jointly encode translational and rotational motions
in $\mathbb{R}^3 \times \mathit{S}^3$ space, ensuring accurate trajectory
reproduction. The framework supports smooth transitions between therapist-led
guidance and patient passive training, while allowing adaptive adjustment of
motion. Experiments with 7-DoF manipulators demonstrate the feasibility of the
approach, highlighting its potential for personalized and remotely supervised
rehabilitation.

AI.tldr: A tele-teaching framework enables remote rehabilitation by teleoperating therapist- and patient-side robots, using 6-DoF Dynamical Movement Primitives in R^3×S^3 to accurately reproduce trajectories, enabling guided and passive training with motion adaptation; validated on 7-DoF manipulators, showing feasibility for remote, personalized rehab.
AI.motivation: To enable effective, remotely supervised robot-assisted rehabilitation, reducing the need for in-person sessions while preserving accurate, adaptable motor guidance and training.
AI.method: Bilateral teleoperation between therapist and patient robots; 6-DoF Dynamical Movement Primitives in R^3×S^3 to encode translational and rotational motion; transitions between therapist-led guidance and patient passive mode; adaptive motion adjustment; validation on 7-DoF manipulators.
AI.result: Feasibility demonstrated: the system can reproduce therapist demonstrations and support adaptive training; experiments with 7-DoF arms show potential for personalized remote rehab.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a viable path toward remote, supervised rehabilitation with adjustable guidance; future work could assess clinical efficacy, user experience, and robustness across tasks and patients.

title: Expandable Decision-Making States for Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning in Soccer Tactical Analysis
summary:
Invasion team sports such as soccer produce a high-dimensional, strongly
coupled state space as many players continuously interact on a shared field,
challenging quantitative tactical analysis. Traditional rule-based analyses are
intuitive, while modern predictive machine learning models often perform
pattern-matching without explicit agent representations. The problem we address
is how to build player-level agent models from data, whose learned values and
policies are both tactically interpretable and robust across heterogeneous data
sources. Here, we propose Expandable Decision-Making States (EDMS), a
semantically enriched state representation that augments raw positions and
velocities with relational variables (e.g., scoring of space, pass, and score),
combined with an action-masking scheme that gives on-ball and off-ball agents
distinct decision sets. Compared to prior work, EDMS maps learned value
functions and action policies to human-interpretable tactical concepts (e.g.,
marking pressure, passing lanes, ball accessibility) instead of raw coordinate
features, and aligns agent choices with the rules of play. In the experiments,
EDMS with action masking consistently reduced both action-prediction loss and
temporal-difference (TD) error compared to the baseline. Qualitative case
studies and Q-value visualizations further indicate that EDMS highlights
high-risk, high-reward tactical patterns (e.g., fast counterattacks and
defensive breakthroughs). We also integrated our approach into an open-source
library and demonstrated compatibility with multiple commercial and open
datasets, enabling cross-provider evaluation and reproducible experiments.

AI.tldr: Introduces Expandable Decision-Making States (EDMS) for soccer agent models that fuse relational tactical context with action masking to yield interpretable, cross-dataset robust policies, improving predictive performance and exploratory insights.
AI.motivation: Invasion sports present high-dimensional, coupled state spaces; traditional rule-based methods are intuitive but limited; ML models often lack interpretable agent representations and cross-source robustness; need human-aligned, robust agent models.
AI.method: Define EDMS: semantically enriched representation with relational variables (e.g., scoring of space, pass opportunities, marking pressure) and action masking to assign distinct decision sets to on-ball/off-ball agents; learn value functions/policies that map to tactical concepts rather than raw coordinates; optimize to reduce action-prediction loss and TD error; integrate open-source library for cross-dataset evaluation; qualitative Q-value visualizations.
AI.result: Compared to baselines, EDMS with action masking reduced action-prediction loss and TD error; qualitative analyses show highlighting of high-risk/high-reward patterns; successful cross-provider evaluation via open-source library and compatibility with multiple datasets.
AI.conclusion: EDMS offers interpretable, robust agent-level tactical models aligned with play rules; relational features and action masking enable mapping to human-understandable concepts and improved predictive performance; supports reproducible research across datasets.

title: Discrete Wavelet Transform as a Facilitator for Expressive Latent Space Representation in Variational Autoencoders in Satellite Imagery
summary:
Latent Diffusion Models (LDM), a subclass of diffusion models, mitigate the
computational complexity of pixel-space diffusion by operating within a
compressed latent space constructed by Variational Autoencoders (VAEs),
demonstrating significant advantages in Remote Sensing (RS) applications.
Though numerous studies enhancing LDMs have been conducted, investigations
explicitly targeting improvements within the intrinsic latent space remain
scarce. This paper proposes an innovative perspective, utilizing the Discrete
Wavelet Transform (DWT) to enhance the VAE's latent space representation,
designed for satellite imagery. The proposed method, ExpDWT-VAE, introduces
dual branches: one processes spatial domain input through convolutional
operations, while the other extracts and processes frequency-domain features
via 2D Haar wavelet decomposition, convolutional operation, and inverse DWT
reconstruction. These branches merge to create an integrated spatial-frequency
representation, further refined through convolutional and diagonal Gaussian
mapping into a robust latent representation. We utilize a new satellite imagery
dataset housed by the TerraFly mapping system to validate our method.
Experimental results across several performance metrics highlight the efficacy
of the proposed method at enhancing latent space representation.

AI.tldr: ExpDWT-VAE enhances the latent space of latent diffusion models for satellite imagery by integrating discrete wavelet transform (DWT) into a dual-branch VAE, combining spatial and frequency-domain features to produce a richer latent representation, validated on TerraFly satellite data.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of work focusing on improving latent representations within latent diffusion models for remote sensing. The paper aims to leverage frequency-domain information via DWT to enrich the VAE latent space and thereby improve downstream diffusion modeling for satellite imagery.
AI.method: Propose ExpDWT-VAE with two branches: (1) spatial-domain processing via convolutional layers; (2) frequency-domain processing using 2D Haar wavelet decomposition, followed by convolution and inverse DWT to reconstruct frequency-aware features. Merge branches into a unified spatial-frequency latent representation, then apply convolutional layers and diagonal Gaussian mapping to obtain a latent representation.
AI.result: Validation on a TerraFly satellite imagery dataset shows improved performance across multiple metrics, indicating that the latent-space representation is enhanced by the proposed latent-space DWT approach.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating DWT-based frequency information into the VAE latent space for LDMs yields a more robust latent representation for satellite imagery, offering a viable path to improved RS diffusion models.

title: Thoughtbubbles: an Unsupervised Method for Parallel Thinking in Latent Space
summary:
Current approaches for scaling inference-time compute in transformers rely on
training them to emit explicit chain-of-thought tokens before producing an
answer. While these methods are powerful, they are limited because they cannot
be applied during pretraining and are limited to only serially-generated,
natural-language verbalization to scale inference-time compute. In this work,
we propose Thoughtbubbles, a transformer variant that natively performs
parallel adaptive computation in latent space by learning to fork or delete
residual streams. Thus, tokens that require a large amount of computation can
form a "bubble" of cloned residuals in the middle of the network for additional
thinking. Crucially, this behavior is learned during pretraining with only
language modeling loss. Thoughtbubbles outperforms both standard decoder LMs as
well as non-adaptive parallel computation approaches on OpenWebText and peS2o
perplexity and in zero-shot evaluations such as HellaSwag and LAMBADA after
pretraining across 150M to 772M parameter scales. The implicit nature of our
method enables adaptive computation to be learned starting at pretraining time,
paving the way to unify train and test-time behavior for reasoning models.

AI.tldr: Thoughtbubbles enables transformers to learn adaptive, latent-space parallel computation during pretraining by forking/deleting residual streams, improving inference-time compute efficiency without explicit chain-of-thought tokens.
