AI.result: The Transformer component in hybrids tends to exploit shortcuts, harming length generalization; delaying attention-layer training mitigates this, yielding significant improvement with near-perfect (>90%) accuracy on sequences three times longer than those seen during training.
AI.conclusion: Delaying training of attention layers effectively mitigates shortcut reliance and improves length generalization in hybrid models, highlighting the importance of training schedules when combining architectures.

title: Compose Your Policies! Improving Diffusion-based or Flow-based Robot Policies via Test-time Distribution-level Composition
summary:
Diffusion-based models for robotic control, including vision-language-action
(VLA) and vision-action (VA) policies, have demonstrated significant
capabilities. Yet their advancement is constrained by the high cost of
acquiring large-scale interaction datasets. This work introduces an alternative
paradigm for enhancing policy performance without additional model training.
Perhaps surprisingly, we demonstrate that the composed policies can exceed the
performance of either parent policy. Our contribution is threefold. First, we
establish a theoretical foundation showing that the convex composition of
distributional scores from multiple diffusion models can yield a superior
one-step functional objective compared to any individual score. A
Gr\"onwall-type bound is then used to show that this single-step improvement
propagates through entire generation trajectories, leading to systemic
performance gains. Second, motivated by these results, we propose General
Policy Composition (GPC), a training-free method that enhances performance by
combining the distributional scores of multiple pre-trained policies via a
convex combination and test-time search. GPC is versatile, allowing for the
plug-and-play composition of heterogeneous policies, including VA and VLA
models, as well as those based on diffusion or flow-matching, irrespective of
their input visual modalities. Third, we provide extensive empirical
validation. Experiments on Robomimic, PushT, and RoboTwin benchmarks, alongside
real-world robotic evaluations, confirm that GPC consistently improves
performance and adaptability across a diverse set of tasks. Further analysis of
alternative composition operators and weighting strategies offers insights into
the mechanisms underlying the success of GPC. These results establish GPC as a
simple yet effective method for improving control performance by leveraging
existing policies.

AI.tldr: GPC is a training-free method that combines distributional scores from multiple diffusion-based policies via convex weights + test-time search to improve robotic control without retraining, backed by theory and benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Reduce data and training costs for diffusion-based robotic control by leveraging existing, pre-trained policies. Show that composing policies can outperform any single policy even in one step, and propagate gains along trajectories.
AI.method: Theoretically, convexly combine distributional scores from several diffusion models to obtain a better one-step objective; use a Grönwall-type bound to argue trajectory-level improvements. Introduce General Policy Composition (GPC): a plug-and-play method that, at test time, convexly weights scores from heterogeneous pre-trained policies (e.g., VA, VLA, diffusion, flow-matching) across modalities and performs search to select actions.
AI.result: Empirical validation on Robomimic, PushT, RoboTwin, and real-world robotics shows GPC consistently improves performance and adaptability across tasks. Analysis includes comparisons of alternative composition operators and weighting strategies to shed light on mechanisms behind GPC's success.
AI.conclusion: GPC provides a simple, effective, training-free pathway to boost control performance by leveraging existing policies, enabling cross-policy and cross-modality composition without additional training.

title: Collaborative-Distilled Diffusion Models (CDDM) for Accelerated and Lightweight Trajectory Prediction
summary:
Trajectory prediction is a fundamental task in Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) and
Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), supporting efficient motion planning
and real-time traffic safety management. Diffusion models have recently
demonstrated strong performance in probabilistic trajectory prediction, but
their large model size and slow sampling process hinder real-world deployment.
This paper proposes Collaborative-Distilled Diffusion Models (CDDM), a novel
method for real-time and lightweight trajectory prediction. Built upon
Collaborative Progressive Distillation (CPD), CDDM progressively transfers
knowledge from a high-capacity teacher diffusion model to a lightweight student
model, jointly reducing both the number of sampling steps and the model size
across distillation iterations. A dual-signal regularized distillation loss is
further introduced to incorporate guidance from both the teacher and
ground-truth data, mitigating potential overfitting and ensuring robust
performance. Extensive experiments on the ETH-UCY pedestrian benchmark and the
nuScenes vehicle benchmark demonstrate that CDDM achieves state-of-the-art
prediction accuracy. The well-distilled CDDM retains 96.2% and 95.5% of the
baseline model's ADE and FDE performance on pedestrian trajectories, while
requiring only 231K parameters and 4 or 2 sampling steps, corresponding to 161x
compression, 31x acceleration, and 9 ms latency. Qualitative results further
show that CDDM generates diverse and accurate trajectories under dynamic agent
behaviors and complex social interactions. By bridging high-performing
generative models with practical deployment constraints, CDDM enables
resource-efficient probabilistic prediction for AVs and ITS. Code is available
at https://github.com/bingzhangw/CDDM.

AI.tldr: CDDM introduces a lightweight, real-time diffusion-based trajectory predictor via Collaborative Progressive Distillation, transferring knowledge from a high-capacity teacher to a compact student with dual-signal regularized loss, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy with substantial speedups.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models offer strong probabilistic trajectory predictions but are large and slow, limiting real-world deployment in AVs/ITS. The work aims to enable real-time, resource-efficient probabilistic forecasting without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: Collaborative Progressive Distillation (CPD) transfers knowledge from a high-capacity teacher diffusion model to a lightweight student across distillation iterations, jointly reducing sampling steps and model size. A dual-signal regularized distillation loss incorporates guidance from both the teacher and ground-truth data to mitigate overfitting and improve robustness.
AI.result: CDDM achieves state-of-the-art prediction accuracy on ETH-UCY and nuScenes. It retains 96.2% ADE and 95.5% FDE of the baseline on pedestrian trajectories, while using only 231k parameters and 4 or 2 sampling steps (≈161× compression, ≈31× acceleration, ≈9 ms latency). Qualitative results demonstrate diverse, accurate trajectories under dynamic interactions.
AI.conclusion: By marrying high-performing diffusion models with deployment constraints, CDDM enables resource-efficient probabilistic trajectory prediction for AVs/ITS; code is released for reproducibility.

title: MathSticks: A Benchmark for Visual Symbolic Compositional Reasoning with Matchstick Puzzles
summary:
We introduce \textsc{MathSticks}, a benchmark for Visual Symbolic
Compositional Reasoning (VSCR), which unifies visual perception, symbolic
manipulation, and arithmetic consistency. Each task presents an incorrect
matchstick equation that must be corrected by moving one or two sticks under
strict conservation rules. The benchmark includes both text-guided and purely
visual settings, systematically covering digit scale, move complexity, solution
multiplicity, and operator variation, with 1.4M generated instances and a
curated test set. Evaluations of 14 vision--language models reveal substantial
limitations: closed-source models succeed only on simple cases, open-source
models fail in the visual regime, while humans exceed 90\% accuracy. These
findings establish \textsc{MathSticks} as a rigorous testbed for advancing
compositional reasoning across vision and symbols. Our code and dataset are
publicly available at https://github.com/Yuheng2000/MathSticks.

AI.tldr: New benchmark MathSticks for Visual Symbolic Compositional Reasoning (VSCR) integrates visual perception, symbolic manipulation, and arithmetic consistency; uses matchstick puzzles with 1–2 moves under conservation rules; large-scale data (1.4M instances) and test set; reveals limitations of vision-language models and shows humans >90% accuracy.
AI.motivation: There is a strong need to advance compositional reasoning across vision and symbols. Existing models struggle with tasks requiring accurate symbolic manipulation under strict constraints, such as conservation rules in matchstick puzzles. MathSticks unifies perception and symbolic reasoning to probe this capability, with both text-guided and pure-vision settings.
AI.method: Generate incorrect matchstick equations and require correcting them by moving one or two sticks under strict conservation rules. Include text-guided and purely visual settings. Systematically vary digit scale, move complexity, solution multiplicity, and operator variation. Assemble 1.4 million generated instances plus a curated test set. Evaluate 14 vision–language models, analyzing performance gaps between closed-source vs open-source models, in visual vs non-visual regimes, and compare against human performance.
AI.result: Vision–language models show substantial limitations: closed-source models succeed only on simple cases; open-source models fail in the visual regime; humans achieve >90% accuracy. MathSticks provides a rigorous testbed for evaluating cross-modal compositional reasoning. Code and dataset are publicly available.
AI.conclusion: MathSticks provides a robust, scalable benchmark to push progress in VSCR, highlighting current model gaps and offering a resource for developing methods that integrate visual understanding with symbolic/arithmetic reasoning; its public release enables broad adoption and replication.

title: Learning Energy-based Variational Latent Prior for VAEs
summary:
Variational Auto-Encoders (VAEs) are known to generate blurry and
inconsistent samples. One reason for this is the "prior hole" problem. A prior
hole refers to regions that have high probability under the VAE's prior but low
probability under the VAE's posterior. This means that during data generation,
high probability samples from the prior could have low probability under the
posterior, resulting in poor quality data. Ideally, a prior needs to be
flexible enough to match the posterior while retaining the ability to generate
samples fast. Generative models continue to address this tradeoff. This paper
proposes to model the prior as an energy-based model (EBM). While EBMs are
known to offer the flexibility to match posteriors (and also improving the
ELBO), they are traditionally slow in sample generation due to their dependency
on MCMC methods. Our key idea is to bring a variational approach to tackle the
normalization constant in EBMs, thus bypassing the expensive MCMC approaches.
The variational form can be approximated with a sampler network, and we show
that such an approach to training priors can be formulated as an alternating
optimization problem. Moreover, the same sampler reduces to an implicit
variational prior during generation, providing efficient and fast sampling. We
compare our Energy-based Variational Latent Prior (EVaLP) method to multiple
SOTA baselines and show improvements in image generation quality, reduced prior
holes, and better sampling efficiency.

AI.tldr: Proposes EVaLP, a variationally trained energy-based prior for VAEs that bypasses MCMC, improving sample quality and sampling speed by reducing prior holes.
AI.motivation: VAEs suffer from prior holes: regions of high prior probability but low posterior probability lead to low-quality samples and inconsistency. A flexible prior that matches the posterior while remaining fast to sample is desired. EBMs offer flexibility but are slow due to MCMC; a variational approach aims to make EBMs practical as priors.
AI.method: Model the latent prior as an energy-based model (EBM) and tackle the normalization constant variationally. Use a sampler network to approximate the variational form; train via alternating optimization. During generation, the same sampler acts as an implicit variational prior, enabling fast sampling.
AI.result: Compared to state-of-the-art baselines, EVaLP yields higher-quality image generation, reduces prior holes, and improves sampling efficiency.
AI.conclusion: EVaLP provides a practical, fast-sampling, flexible prior for VAEs by integrating an EBM with a variational normalization approach, mitigating the prior-hole issue and enhancing generation performance.

title: Real-Time Trajectory Generation and Hybrid Lyapunov-Based Control for Hopping Robots
summary:
The advent of rotor-based hopping robots has created very capable hopping
platforms with high agility and efficiency, and similar controllability, as
compared to their purely flying quadrotor counterparts. Advances in robot
performance have increased the hopping height to greater than 4 meters and
opened up the possibility for more complex aerial trajectories (i.e.,
behaviors). However, currently hopping robots do not directly control their
aerial trajectory or transition to flight, eliminating the efficiency benefits
of a hopping system. Here we show a real-time, computationally efficiency,
non-linear drag compensated, trajectory generation methodology and accompanying
Lyapunov-based controller. The combined system can create and follow complex
aerial trajectories from liftoff to touchdown on horizontal and vertical
surfaces, while maintaining strick control over the orientation at touchdown.
The computational efficiency provides broad applicability across all size
scales of hopping robots while maintaining applicability to quadrotors in
general.

AI.tldr: Real-time trajectory generation with non-linear drag compensation and a Lyapunov-based controller enables rotor-based hopping robots to execute and follow complex aerial trajectories from liftoff to touchdown, with stable orientation control, across size scales and applicable to quadrotors.
AI.motivation: Hopping robots currently cannot directly control their aerial trajectories or transitions to flight, which undermines the efficiency benefits of hopping. A real-time, efficient control-and-trajectory framework is needed to realize aerial maneuvers while preserving hopping advantages.
AI.method: A real-time, computationally efficient trajectory generation methodology that compensates non-linear drag, paired with a Lyapunov-based controller, enabling liftoff-to-touchdown trajectories on horizontal and vertical surfaces and strict orientation control at touchdown.
AI.result: The integrated system can create and follow complex aerial trajectories from liftoff to touchdown on horizontal and vertical surfaces, while maintaining strict orientation at touchdown, and it is computationally efficient enough to apply across size scales, with applicability to quadrotors.
AI.conclusion: This approach broadens the operational envelope of hopping robots by enabling direct, efficient aerial control and transitions, with general applicability across sizes and to quadrotor platforms.

title: Expected Attention: KV Cache Compression by Estimating Attention from Future Queries Distribution
summary:
Memory consumption of the Key-Value (KV) cache represents a major bottleneck
for efficient large language model inference. While attention-score-based KV
cache pruning shows promise, it faces critical practical limitations: attention
scores from future tokens are unavailable during compression, and modern
implementations like Flash Attention do not materialize the full attention
matrix, making past scores inaccessible. To overcome these challenges, we
introduce $\textbf{Expected Attention, a training-free compression method}$
that estimates KV pairs importance by predicting how future queries will attend
to them. Our approach leverages the distributional properties of LLM
activations to compute expected attention scores in closed form for each KV
pair. These scores enable principled ranking and pruning of KV pairs with
minimal impact on the residual stream, achieving effective compression without
performance degradation. Importantly, our method operates seamlessly across
both prefilling and decoding phases, consistently outperforming
state-of-the-art baselines in both scenarios. Finally, $\textbf{we release
KVPress, a comprehensive library to enable researchers to implement and
benchmark KV cache compression methods, already including more than 20
techniques}$.

AI.tldr: Training-free KV-cache compression via Expected Attention: estimates per-KV importance using closed-form expected attention scores, enabling principled pruning with minimal residual degradation; effective in both prefill and decoding; accompanied by the KVPress library.
AI.motivation: KV cache memory is a major bottleneck in large language model inference. Attention-score pruning relying on future tokens is impractical since future scores aren’t available during compression, and modern accelerators often don’t materialize full attention matrices, making past scores inaccessible.
AI.method: Compute expected attention scores for each KV pair using distributional properties of LLM activations, deriving closed-form expressions. Rank KV pairs by these scores and prune accordingly. The method is training-free and applies to both prefilling and decoding.
AI.result: Outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in both prefill and decoding, achieving effective KV-cache compression with minimal impact on the residual stream.
AI.conclusion: Presents a practical, training-free approach to KV-cache pruning that addresses key limitations of prior methods and is accompanied by KVPress, a library that includes 20+ techniques for benchmarking and implementation.

title: Normal-Abnormal Guided Generalist Anomaly Detection
summary:
Generalist Anomaly Detection (GAD) aims to train a unified model on an
original domain that can detect anomalies in new target domains. Previous GAD
methods primarily use only normal samples as references, overlooking the
valuable information contained in anomalous samples that are often available in
real-world scenarios. To address this limitation, we propose a more practical
approach: normal-abnormal-guided generalist anomaly detection, which leverages
both normal and anomalous samples as references to guide anomaly detection
across diverse domains. We introduce the Normal-Abnormal Generalist Learning
(NAGL) framework, consisting of two key components: Residual Mining (RM) and
Anomaly Feature Learning (AFL). RM extracts abnormal patterns from
normal-abnormal reference residuals to establish transferable anomaly
representations, while AFL adaptively learns anomaly features in query images
through residual mapping to identify instance-aware anomalies. Our approach
effectively utilizes both normal and anomalous references for more accurate and
efficient cross-domain anomaly detection. Extensive experiments across multiple
benchmarks demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing GAD
approaches. This work represents the first to adopt a mixture of normal and
abnormal samples as references in generalist anomaly detection. The code and
datasets are available at https://github.com/JasonKyng/NAGL.

AI.tldr: Introduces Normal-Abnormal Generalist Learning (NAGL) for Generalist Anomaly Detection (GAD) that uses both normal and anomalous references; proposes Residual Mining (RM) and Anomaly Feature Learning (AFL); demonstrates strong cross-domain performance and provides code.
AI.motivation: In real-world cross-domain anomaly detection, anomalous samples contain valuable information that is often ignored when methods rely solely on normal data; leveraging both normal and abnormal references can yield more transferable and robust anomaly representations across domains.
AI.method: NAGL comprises two components: (1) Residual Mining (RM), which extracts abnormal patterns from normal-abnormal reference residuals to build transferable anomaly representations; (2) Anomaly Feature Learning (AFL), which adaptively learns anomaly features in query images via residual mapping to identify instance-aware anomalies across domains.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple benchmarks show that NAGL significantly outperforms existing GAD methods. The approach is the first to use a mixture of normal and abnormal references for GAD, and code/datasets are released at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Normal-abnormal guided learning enables more accurate, efficient cross-domain anomaly detection by exploiting anomalous references and residual-based representation learning, advancing practical generalist anomaly detection.

title: SLogic: Subgraph-Informed Logical Rule Learning for Knowledge Graph Completion
summary:
Logical rule-based methods offer an interpretable approach to knowledge graph
completion by capturing compositional relationships in the form of
human-readable inference rules. However, current approaches typically treat
logical rules as universal, assigning each rule a fixed confidence score that
ignores query-specific context. This is a significant limitation, as a rule's
importance can vary depending on the query. To address this, we introduce
SLogic (Subgraph-Informed Logical Rule learning), a novel framework that
assigns query-dependent scores to logical rules. The core of SLogic is a
scoring function that utilizes the subgraph centered on a query's head entity,
allowing the significance of each rule to be assessed dynamically. Extensive
experiments on benchmark datasets show that by leveraging local subgraph
context, SLogic consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, including
both embedding-based and rule-based methods.

AI.tldr: Assigns query-dependent rule scores using subgraph context to improve KG completion.
AI.motivation: Rule-based KG completion is interpretable but uses universal fixed rule confidences; needs query-aware scoring.
AI.method: SLogic introduces a scoring function conditioned on the subgraph around the query head to dynamically rank rules per query.
AI.result: Empirical results on benchmarks show SLogic consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines (embedding-based and rule-based).
AI.conclusion: Subgraph-informed, query-dependent rule scoring enhances both accuracy and interpretability of logical rule-based KG completion.

title: Batch-CAM: Introduction to better reasoning in convolutional deep learning models
comment: 18 pages, 7 figures, submitted to SN Computer Science Springer Nature
summary:
Understanding the inner workings of deep learning models is crucial for
advancing artificial intelligence, particularly in high-stakes fields such as
healthcare, where accurate explanations are as vital as precision. This paper
introduces Batch-CAM, a novel training paradigm that fuses a batch
implementation of the Grad-CAM algorithm with a prototypical reconstruction
loss. This combination guides the model to focus on salient image features,
thereby enhancing its performance across classification tasks. Our results
demonstrate that Batch-CAM achieves a simultaneous improvement in accuracy and
image reconstruction quality while reducing training and inference times. By
ensuring models learn from evidence-relevant information,this approach makes a
relevant contribution to building more transparent, explainable, and
trustworthy AI systems.

AI.tldr: Batch-CAM fuses a batch Grad-CAM implementation with a prototypical reconstruction loss to steer models toward salient features, achieving higher accuracy and better reconstruction quality while cutting training and inference time, supporting more transparent, explainable AI.
AI.motivation: In high-stakes domains like healthcare, interpretable and trustworthy AI is crucial. Existing explainability methods (e.g., Grad-CAM) often trade off between model performance and interpretability. The paper aims to jointly improve accuracy, reconstruction quality, and efficiency while enhancing evidence-based explanations.
AI.method: Introduce Batch-CAM, a training paradigm that uses a batch-level Grad-CAM computation aligned with a prototypical reconstruction loss. The model is guided to attend to salient image regions through Grad-CAM while a reconstruction objective encourages latent representations to align with class prototypes, combining classification, explainability, and reconstructive constraints in a single objective.
AI.result: Empirical results indicate improvements in classification accuracy and image reconstruction quality, alongside reduced training and inference times. The approach also enhances evidence-relevant learning, contributing to more transparent and trustworthy models.
AI.conclusion: Batch-CAM represents a step toward explainable, efficient AI in critical domains by integrating Grad-CAM-based saliency with a prototypical reconstruction objective, promoting models that are both accurate and more interpretable.

title: Relative-Absolute Fusion: Rethinking Feature Extraction in Image-Based Iterative Method Selection for Solving Sparse Linear Systems
summary:
Iterative method selection is crucial for solving sparse linear systems
because these methods inherently lack robustness. Though image-based selection
approaches have shown promise, their feature extraction techniques might encode
distinct matrices into identical image representations, leading to the same
selection and suboptimal method. In this paper, we introduce RAF
(Relative-Absolute Fusion), an efficient feature extraction technique to
enhance image-based selection approaches. By simultaneously extracting and
fusing image representations as relative features with corresponding numerical
values as absolute features, RAF achieves comprehensive matrix representations
that prevent feature ambiguity across distinct matrices, thus improving
selection accuracy and unlocking the potential of image-based selection
approaches. We conducted comprehensive evaluations of RAF on SuiteSparse and
our developed BMCMat (Balanced Multi-Classification Matrix dataset),
demonstrating solution time reductions of 0.08s-0.29s for sparse linear
systems, which is 5.86%-11.50% faster than conventional image-based selection
approaches and achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance. BMCMat is
available at https://github.com/zkqq/BMCMat.

AI.tldr: RAF blends relative (image) features with absolute (numeric) features to enrich matrix representations for image-based method selection in sparse linear systems, reducing feature ambiguity and boosting accuracy and speed; validated on SuiteSparse and BMCMat with SOTA results.
AI.motivation: Iterative method selection for sparse linear systems is not robust. Image-based feature extraction can map distinct matrices to identical representations, leading to suboptimal method choices.
AI.method: Introduce Relative-Absolute Fusion (RAF): jointly extract and fuse image representations (relative features) with their corresponding numerical values (absolute features) to produce comprehensive matrix representations and improve selection accuracy.
AI.result: BMCMat and SuiteSparse evaluations show solution-time reductions of 0.08s–0.29s, 5.86%–11.50% faster than conventional image-based approaches, achieving state-of-the-art performance.
AI.conclusion: RAF enhances image-based selection by reducing feature ambiguity and improving both accuracy and efficiency; BMCMat dataset is available at the referenced GitHub repository.

title: Free Draft-and-Verification: Toward Lossless Parallel Decoding for Diffusion Large Language Models
summary:
Diffusion Large Language Models (DLLMs) have emerged as a new paradigm of
language modeling beyond autoregressive next-token prediction. Thanks to their
bidirectional attention mechanism, DLLMs are more capable of capturing the
connection of context, and thus show unique advantages in challenges like the
famous "reversal curse" or learning under data-constrained scenarios. However,
this bidirectional nature also brings an obstacle that DLLMs are not inherently
compatible with KV Cache, and consequently, the inference efficiency is not
competitive compared with autoregressive models. Taking advantage of their
inherent capability of multi-token prediction, existing parallel decoding
algorithms can speed up the DLLM inference, but at the cost of non-negligible
performance degradation. To overcome this challenge, we introduce Free
Draft-and-Verification (Freedave), a novel fast sampling algorithm tailored for
DLLMs that achieves lossless parallel decoding. Specifically, we propose a
pipeline of parallel-decoded candidate generation and verification, which is
guaranteed to reproduce the same sequence generated by static sampling, without
introducing extra model forward calls. By applying Freedave, the throughput of
DLLMs can be boosted up to $2.8\times$ without performance degradation on math
reasoning tasks.

AI.tldr: Freedave enables lossless parallel decoding for diffusion LLMs, boosting throughput up to 2.8x without accuracy loss by a parallel candidate generation and verification pipeline that reproduces static sampling results without extra forward passes.
AI.motivation: DLLMs' bidirectional attention improves context modeling but breaks KV caching; existing parallel decoding trades speed for accuracy. A fast, exact parallel sampling method is needed to close the speed-accuracy gap.
AI.method: A two-stage pipeline: (1) generate multiple candidate tokens/drafts in parallel using DLLM's multi-token prediction; (2) verify these candidates to ensure the final sequence matches static sampling; this verification is designed to require no additional model forward calls, preserving inference efficiency.
AI.result: Achieves up to 2.8x throughput improvement with no degradation in math reasoning tasks; claims lossless parallel decoding.
AI.conclusion: Freedave provides a practical, lossless speedup for DLLM inference, enabling efficient deployment without compromising quality; may generalize to other bidirectional LMs and tasks, while relying on a verification mechanism that avoids extra forward passes.

title: Relevance-Zone Reduction in Game Solving
comment: Accepted by the Advances in Computer Games (ACG 2025)
summary:
Game solving aims to find the optimal strategies for all players and
determine the theoretical outcome of a game. However, due to the exponential
growth of game trees, many games remain unsolved, even though methods like
AlphaZero have demonstrated super-human level in game playing. The
Relevance-Zone (RZ) is a local strategy reuse technique that restricts the
search to only the regions relevant to the outcome, significantly reducing the
search space. However, RZs are not unique. Different solutions may result in
RZs of varying sizes. Smaller RZs are generally more favorable, as they
increase the chance of reuse and improve pruning efficiency. To this end, we
propose an iterative RZ reduction method that repeatedly solves the same
position while gradually restricting the region involved, guiding the solver
toward smaller RZs. We design three constraint generation strategies and
integrate an RZ Pattern Table to fully leverage past solutions. In experiments
on 7x7 Killall-Go, our method reduces the average RZ size to 85.95% of the
original. Furthermore, the reduced RZs can be permanently stored as reusable
knowledge for future solving tasks, especially for larger board sizes or
different openings.

AI.tldr: Iterative Relevance-Zone reduction narrows the search region in game solving, achieving smaller RZs and reusable knowledge.
AI.motivation: Game trees grow exponentially; existing RZs are not unique and larger RZs hinder reuse and pruning. Reducing RZs can improve efficiency and enable knowledge reuse across board sizes/openings.
AI.method: Iteratively solve the same position while progressively tightening the region; design three constraint-generation strategies; introduce an RZ Pattern Table to exploit past solutions.
AI.result: On 7x7 Killall-Go, average RZ size reduced to 85.95% of the original (roughly 14.05% reduction). Reduced RZs can be stored as reusable knowledge for future solving tasks, aiding larger boards or different openings.
AI.conclusion: Iterative RZ reduction yields smaller, reusable regions, enhancing search efficiency and enabling knowledge transfer across tasks; it provides a practical approach to scale game solving.

title: Affordance-Guided Diffusion Prior for 3D Hand Reconstruction
summary:
How can we reconstruct 3D hand poses when large portions of the hand are
heavily occluded by itself or by objects? Humans often resolve such ambiguities
by leveraging contextual knowledge -- such as affordances, where an object's
shape and function suggest how the object is typically grasped. Inspired by
this observation, we propose a generative prior for hand pose refinement guided
by affordance-aware textual descriptions of hand-object interactions (HOI). Our
method employs a diffusion-based generative model that learns the distribution
of plausible hand poses conditioned on affordance descriptions, which are
inferred from a large vision-language model (VLM). This enables the refinement
of occluded regions into more accurate and functionally coherent hand poses.
Extensive experiments on HOGraspNet, a 3D hand-affordance dataset with severe
occlusions, demonstrate that our affordance-guided refinement significantly
improves hand pose estimation over both recent regression methods and
diffusion-based refinement lacking contextual reasoning.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based hand pose refinement method guided by affordance-aware textual descriptions of hand-object interactions, inferred from a vision-language model, to resolve severe occlusions and produce functionally coherent 3D hand poses; evaluated on HOGraspNet with significant improvements over regression and context-free diffusion baselines.
AI.motivation: Occluded 3D hand pose estimation is ill-posed; humans use contextual knowledge like object affordances to infer hand configuration. Prior methods often lack semantic context or rely on regression or context-free generation; there is a need to integrate affordance reasoning into pose refinement.
AI.method: Train a diffusion-based generative prior for hand pose conditioned on affordance descriptions. Infer affordances from a large vision-language model for each HOI scenario. Refine occluded hand regions to plausible, functionally coherent poses. Evaluate on HOGraspNet dataset with severe occlusions.
AI.result: Affordance-guided refinement yields notable improvements over state-of-the-art regression-based methods and diffusion refinement without contextual reasoning on HOGraspNet; models generate more realistic, functionally coherent hand poses under occlusion.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating affordance-aware textual priors via a diffusion model and VLM-based affordance inference enables robust, contextually grounded hand pose refinement under heavy occlusion, advancing 3D hand pose estimation in practical HOI scenarios.

title: Beyond Token Probes: Hallucination Detection via Activation Tensors with ACT-ViT
summary:
Detecting hallucinations in Large Language Model-generated text is crucial
for their safe deployment. While probing classifiers show promise, they operate
on isolated layer-token pairs and are LLM-specific, limiting their
effectiveness and hindering cross-LLM applications. In this paper, we introduce
a novel approach to address these shortcomings. We build on the natural
sequential structure of activation data in both axes (layers $\times$ tokens)
and advocate treating full activation tensors akin to images. We design
ACT-ViT, a Vision Transformer-inspired model that can be effectively and
efficiently applied to activation tensors and supports training on data from
multiple LLMs simultaneously. Through comprehensive experiments encompassing
diverse LLMs and datasets, we demonstrate that ACT-ViT consistently outperforms
traditional probing techniques while remaining extremely efficient for
deployment. In particular, we show that our architecture benefits substantially
from multi-LLM training, achieves strong zero-shot performance on unseen
datasets, and can be transferred effectively to new LLMs through fine-tuning.
Full code is available at https://github.com/BarSGuy/ACT-ViT.

AI.tldr: ACT-ViT applies a Vision Transformer to activation tensors (layers × tokens) to detect LLM hallucinations, enabling multi-LLM training, strong zero-shot transfer, and efficient deployment, outperforming traditional probing methods.
AI.motivation: Probing classifiers operate on isolated layer-token pairs and are LLM-specific, limiting cross-model generalization and practical deployment for hallucination detection in LLM outputs.
AI.method: Treat activation data as sequential images and use a ViT-inspired model (ACT-ViT) that processes activation tensors. Train on data from multiple LLMs and evaluate cross-LLM transfer, including zero-shot performance and fine-tuning to new LLMs.
AI.result: ACT-ViT consistently outperforms traditional probing methods and is highly efficient for deployment. It benefits from multi-LLM training, achieves strong zero-shot performance on unseen datasets, and can be transferred to new LLMs via fine-tuning. Code is released.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, cross-LLM hallucination-detection framework that surpasses prior probing methods, with robust transferability to new LLMs and practical deployment advantages.

title: ACPO: Adaptive Curriculum Policy Optimization for Aligning Vision-Language Models in Complex Reasoning
summary:
Aligning large-scale vision-language models (VLMs) for complex reasoning via
reinforcement learning is often hampered by the limitations of existing policy
optimization algorithms, such as static training schedules and the rigid,
uniform clipping mechanism in Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). In this work,
we introduce Adaptive Curriculum Policy Optimization (ACPO), a novel framework
that addresses these challenges through a dual-component adaptive learning
strategy. First, ACPO employs a dynamic curriculum that orchestrates a
principled transition from a stable, near on-policy exploration phase to an
efficient, off-policy exploitation phase by progressively increasing sample
reuse. Second, we propose an Advantage-Aware Adaptive Clipping (AAAC) mechanism
that replaces the fixed clipping hyperparameter with dynamic, sample-wise
bounds modulated by the normalized advantage of each token. This allows for
more granular and robust policy updates, enabling larger gradients for
high-potential samples while safeguarding against destructive ones. We conduct
extensive experiments on a suite of challenging multimodal reasoning
benchmarks, including MathVista, LogicVista, and MMMU-Pro. Results demonstrate
that ACPO consistently outperforms strong baselines such as DAPO and PAPO,
achieving state-of-the-art performance, accelerated convergence, and superior
training stability.

AI.tldr: ACPO introduces a dual adaptive framework for aligning large-scale vision-language models: a dynamic curriculum that shifts from near on-policy exploration to off-policy exploitation via increasing sample reuse, and an Advantage-Aware Adaptive Clipping (AAAC) that modulates clipping bounds per token based on normalized advantage. This leads to improved performance, faster convergence, and greater stability on multimodal reasoning benchmarks, surpassing DAPO and PAPO.
AI.motivation: Conventional policy optimization for large VLM alignment relies on static training schedules and fixed clipping (as in PPO), which hamper effective exploration-exploitation balance and sensitive gradient updates. There is a need for adaptive mechanisms that (1) gradually shift from stable on-policy learning to more sample-efficient off-policy updates, and (2) apply per-sample, advantage-aware clipping to preserve informative updates while controlling destructive updates.
AI.method: Introduce Adaptive Curriculum Policy Optimization (ACPO) with two components: (1) a dynamic curriculum that orchestrates a principled transition from a stable near on-policy exploration phase to an efficient off-policy exploitation phase by progressively increasing sample reuse; (2) an Advantage-Aware Adaptive Clipping (AAAC) mechanism that replaces fixed clipping with dynamic, sample-wise bounds modulated by each token's normalized advantage, enabling larger gradients for high-potential samples while guarding against harmful updates.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on challenging multimodal reasoning benchmarks MathVista, LogicVista, and MMMU-Pro shows ACPO outperforming strong baselines such as DAPO and PAPO, achieving state-of-the-art performance, faster convergence, and improved training stability.
AI.conclusion: ACPO effectively addresses core RL optimization challenges in aligning large-scale VLMs for complex multimodal reasoning. Its dynamic curriculum and per-sample AAAC enable more robust, efficient policy updates and better overall performance, suggesting broad applicability to other large-model alignment tasks.

title: Efficient Multi-modal Large Language Models via Progressive Consistency Distillation
summary:
Visual tokens consume substantial computational resources in multi-modal
large models (MLLMs), significantly compromising their efficiency. Recent works
have attempted to improve efficiency by compressing visual tokens during
training, either through modifications to model components or by introducing
additional parameters. However, they often overlook the increased learning
difficulty caused by such compression, as the model's parameter space struggles
to quickly adapt to the substantial perturbations in the feature space induced
by token compression. In this work, we propose to develop Efficient MLLMs via
Progressive Consistency Distillation (EPIC), a progressive learning framework.
Specifically, by decomposing the feature space perturbations introduced by
token compression along the token-wise and layer-wise dimensions, we introduce
token consistency distillation and layer consistency distillation,
respectively, aiming to reduce the training difficulty by leveraging guidance
from a teacher model and following a progressive learning trajectory. Extensive
experiments demonstrate the superior effectiveness, robustness, and
generalization capabilities of our proposed framework.

AI.tldr: Proposes Efficient MLLMs via Progressive Consistency Distillation (EPIC) to tackle computationally heavy visual tokens by progressively guiding learning.
AI.motivation: Visual tokens in multi-modal large models are costly, and existing token-compression methods worsen training difficulty by creating large perturbations in feature space that the model must adapt to quickly.
AI.method: Introduces Progressive Consistency Distillation (EPIC) which decomposes perturbations into token-wise and layer-wise components. It uses token consistency distillation and layer consistency distillation with a teacher model to guide learning along a progressive trajectory.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that EPIC achieves superior effectiveness, robustness, and generalization compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: EPIC provides an efficient training paradigm for compressed visual tokens in MLLMs by reducing learning difficulty through progressive, consistency-guided distillation.

title: Barriers for Learning in an Evolving World: Mathematical Understanding of Loss of Plasticity
summary:
Deep learning models excel in stationary data but struggle in non-stationary
environments due to a phenomenon known as loss of plasticity (LoP), the
degradation of their ability to learn in the future. This work presents a
first-principles investigation of LoP in gradient-based learning. Grounded in
dynamical systems theory, we formally define LoP by identifying stable
manifolds in the parameter space that trap gradient trajectories. Our analysis
reveals two primary mechanisms that create these traps: frozen units from
activation saturation and cloned-unit manifolds from representational
redundancy. Our framework uncovers a fundamental tension: properties that
promote generalization in static settings, such as low-rank representations and
simplicity biases, directly contribute to LoP in continual learning scenarios.
We validate our theoretical analysis with numerical simulations and explore
architectural choices or targeted perturbations as potential mitigation
strategies.

AI.tldr: LoP arises as dynamical traps in gradient-based learning parameter space, formed by stable manifolds that capture gradient trajectories; two main traps are frozen units from activation saturation and cloned-unit manifolds from representational redundancy; generalization-favoring properties (low-rank representations, simplicity biases) paradoxically promote LoP in continual learning; mitigation via architectural changes or perturbations, validated by simulations.
AI.motivation: To understand why deep nets struggle with non-stationary data (loss of plasticity) and to formalize LoP within a dynamical-systems framework, identifying the mechanisms that trap learning and how generalization biases contribute to non-stationary degradation.
AI.method: A first-principles dynamical-systems analysis of gradient-based learning. The authors define LoP via stable manifolds in parameter space that trap gradient trajectories. They diagnose two trap-generating mechanisms (frozen units due to activation saturation and cloned-unit manifolds from representational redundancy). They combine analytic framing with numerical simulations and explore architectural/perturbation-based mitigation strategies.
AI.result: Identification of two explicit trapping mechanisms causing LoP: (1) frozen units from activation saturation, (2) cloned-unit manifolds due to representational redundancy. The framework reveals a tension where properties that aid generalization in static settings (low-rank representations, simplicity biases) can worsen plasticity in continual/ non-stationary contexts. Numerical simulations validate the theory and suggest potential mitigation through architectural choices or targeted perturbations.
AI.conclusion: LoP is a fundamental tension in gradient-based learning: mechanisms that help static generalization can impede adaptation in non-stationary environments. The work provides a principled dynamical-systems basis for LoP, and points toward architecture/design perturbations as viable mitigation strategies, warranting further investigation.

title: KeySG: Hierarchical Keyframe-Based 3D Scene Graphs
summary:
In recent years, 3D scene graphs have emerged as a powerful world
representation, offering both geometric accuracy and semantic richness.
Combining 3D scene graphs with large language models enables robots to reason,
plan, and navigate in complex human-centered environments. However, current
approaches for constructing 3D scene graphs are semantically limited to a
predefined set of relationships, and their serialization in large environments
can easily exceed an LLM's context window. We introduce KeySG, a framework that
represents 3D scenes as a hierarchical graph consisting of floors, rooms,
objects, and functional elements, where nodes are augmented with multi-modal
information extracted from keyframes selected to optimize geometric and visual
coverage. The keyframes allow us to efficiently leverage VLM to extract scene
information, alleviating the need to explicitly model relationship edges
between objects, enabling more general, task-agnostic reasoning and planning.
Our approach can process complex and ambiguous queries while mitigating the
scalability issues associated with large scene graphs by utilizing a
hierarchical retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline to extract relevant
context from the graph. Evaluated across four distinct benchmarks -- including
3D object segmentation and complex query retrieval -- KeySG outperforms prior
approaches on most metrics, demonstrating its superior semantic richness and
efficiency.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical, keyframe-driven 3D scene graph (KeySG) integrates floors/rooms/objects/elements with multi-modal information, using vision-language models and retrieval-augmented generation to enable scalable, task-agnostic reasoning and planning in complex environments; it outperforms baselines on object segmentation and complex query retrieval.
AI.motivation: Current 3D scene graphs are semantically limited to predefined relations and struggle with large environments due to LLM context window limits. There is a need for a scalable, generalizable representation that supports reasoning and planning in human-centered environments.
AI.method: Build a hierarchical graph with floors, rooms, objects, and functional elements. Augment nodes with multi-modal data from keyframes selected to maximize geometric and visual coverage. Use keyframes with vision-language models to extract scene information. Avoid enumerating explicit object-edge relationships; rely on the graph plus VLM outputs. Employ a hierarchical retrieval-augmented generation pipeline to fetch relevant context from the graph for queries.
AI.result: KeySG achieves superior performance on most metrics across four benchmarks, including 3D object segmentation and complex query retrieval, indicating greater semantic richness and efficiency than prior approaches.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, semantically rich 3D scene representation enabling general reasoning and planning in human-centered environments, mitigating edge complexity and context-window issues via hierarchical RAG and keyframe-driven multi-modal information.

title: AttentionDep: Domain-Aware Attention for Explainable Depression Severity Assessment
summary:
In today's interconnected society, social media platforms provide a window
into individuals' thoughts, emotions, and mental states. This paper explores
the use of platforms like Facebook, X (formerly Twitter), and Reddit for
depression severity detection. We propose AttentionDep, a domain-aware
attention model that drives explainable depression severity estimation by
fusing contextual and domain knowledge. Posts are encoded hierarchically using
unigrams and bigrams, with attention mechanisms highlighting clinically
relevant tokens. Domain knowledge from a curated mental health knowledge graph
is incorporated through a cross-attention mechanism, enriching the contextual
features. Finally, depression severity is predicted using an ordinal regression
framework that respects the clinical-relevance and natural ordering of severity
levels. Our experiments demonstrate that AttentionDep outperforms
state-of-the-art baselines by over 5% in graded F1 score across datasets, while
providing interpretable insights into its predictions. This work advances the
development of trustworthy and transparent AI systems for mental health
assessment from social media.

AI.tldr: AttentionDep is a domain-aware, explainable model for depression severity estimation from social media that fuses contextual text with a mental health knowledge graph and uses ordinal regression, achieving >5% improvement in graded F1.
AI.motivation: There is a pressing need for trustworthy, interpretable AI in mental health assessment using social media data. By combining contextual information with curated clinical knowledge, the model aims to provide clinically meaningful and explainable severity predictions.
AI.method: Hierarchical encoding of posts with unigrams and bigrams; attention mechanisms highlight clinically relevant tokens; cross-attention with a curated mental health knowledge graph enriches contextual features; ordinal regression preserves natural severity ordering.
AI.result: The approach outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by over 5% in graded F1 across datasets and offers interpretable insights into predictions.
AI.conclusion: This work advances trustworthy and transparent AI for mental health assessment from social media by integrating domain knowledge and explainability, with potential clinical impact.

title: CardioBench: Do Echocardiography Foundation Models Generalize Beyond the Lab?
summary:
Foundation models (FMs) are reshaping medical imaging, yet their application
in echocardiography remains limited. While several echocardiography-specific
FMs have recently been introduced, no standardized benchmark exists to evaluate
them. Echocardiography poses unique challenges, including noisy acquisitions,
high frame redundancy, and limited public datasets. Most existing solutions
evaluate on private data, restricting comparability. To address this, we
introduce CardioBench, a comprehensive benchmark for echocardiography FMs.
CardioBench unifies eight publicly available datasets into a standardized suite
spanning four regression and five classification tasks, covering functional,
structural, diagnostic, and view recognition endpoints. We evaluate several
leading FM, including cardiac-specific, biomedical, and general-purpose
encoders, under consistent zero-shot, probing, and alignment protocols. Our
results highlight complementary strengths across model families: temporal
modeling is critical for functional regression, retrieval provides robustness
under distribution shift, and domain-specific text encoders capture
physiologically meaningful axes. General-purpose encoders transfer strongly and
often close the gap with probing, but struggle with fine-grained distinctions
like view classification and subtle pathology recognition. By releasing
preprocessing, splits, and public evaluation pipelines, CardioBench establishes
a reproducible reference point and offers actionable insights to guide the
design of future echocardiography foundation models.

AI.tldr: CardioBench offers a standardized, public benchmark for echocardiography foundation models by aggregating eight public datasets into four regression and five classification tasks, enabling zero-shot, probing, and alignment evaluations; reveals complementary strengths across model families and provides reproducible pipelines.
AI.motivation: There is no standard benchmark for echocardiography foundation models. Echocardiography presents challenges (noise, frame redundancy, limited public datasets) and most evaluations are on private data, hindering comparability. A unified benchmark across functional, structural, diagnostic, and view tasks is needed.
AI.method: Unifies eight public echocardiography datasets into a standardized suite with four regression and five classification tasks covering functional, structural, diagnostic, and view endpoints. Evaluates multiple encoders (temporal models, biomedical, and general-purpose) under zero-shot, probing, and alignment protocols. Provides preprocessing, splits, and public evaluation pipelines for reproducible comparisons.
AI.result: Temporal modeling is critical for functional regression; retrieval provides robustness under distribution shift; domain-specific text encoders capture physiologically meaningful axes. General-purpose encoders transfer strongly but struggle with fine-grained distinctions like view classification and subtle pathology recognition.
AI.conclusion: CardioBench provides a reproducible reference point and actionable insights to guide future echocardiography foundation-model design; releases preprocessing, dataset splits, and evaluation pipelines to foster community benchmarking.

title: Lipschitz Bandits with Stochastic Delayed Feedback
summary:
The Lipschitz bandit problem extends stochastic bandits to a continuous
action set defined over a metric space, where the expected reward function
satisfies a Lipschitz condition. In this work, we introduce a new problem of
Lipschitz bandit in the presence of stochastic delayed feedback, where the
rewards are not observed immediately but after a random delay. We consider both
bounded and unbounded stochastic delays, and design algorithms that attain
sublinear regret guarantees in each setting. For bounded delays, we propose a
delay-aware zooming algorithm that retains the optimal performance of the
delay-free setting up to an additional term that scales with the maximal delay
$\tau_{\max}$. For unbounded delays, we propose a novel phased learning
strategy that accumulates reliable feedback over carefully scheduled intervals,
and establish a regret lower bound showing that our method is nearly optimal up
to logarithmic factors. Finally, we present experimental results to demonstrate
the efficiency of our algorithms under various delay scenarios.

AI.tldr: Study Lipschitz bandits with stochastic delayed feedback; propose delay-aware optimization for bounded delays and a phased learning strategy for unbounded delays; prove sublinear regret (with additive delay terms) and near-optimal lower bounds; experiments validate efficiency across delay scenarios.
AI.motivation: Realistic bandit settings often have delayed rewards; extending Lipschitz bandits to accommodate stochastic delays (bounded or unbounded) fills a gap between theory and practical feedback systems.
AI.method: Bounded delays: delay-aware zooming algorithm that preserves delay-free optimal regret up to a term scaling with the maximal delay tau_max. Unbounded delays: phased learning strategy that collects reliable feedback over scheduled intervals; includes a regret analysis and a lower bound showing near-optimality up to logarithmic factors.
AI.result: Both settings achieve sublinear regret; for bounded delays, regret matches delay-free optimal up to additive tau_max-dependent term; for unbounded delays, the phased approach is near-optimal, with a proven lower bound matching up to log factors; experiments corroborate efficiency under various delay scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates effective algorithms for Lipschitz bandits with delays, highlighting practical viability and theoretical guarantees; suggests directions for tightening bounds and extending to other settings.

title: Strategic Fusion of Vision Language Models: Shapley-Credited Context-Aware Dawid-Skene for Multi-Label Tasks in Autonomous Driving
summary:
Large vision-language models (VLMs) are increasingly used in
autonomous-vehicle (AV) stacks, but hallucination limits their reliability in
safety-critical pipelines. We present Shapley-credited Context-Aware
Dawid-Skene with Agreement, a game-theoretic fusion method for multi-label
understanding of ego-view dashcam video. It learns per-model, per-label,
context-conditioned reliabilities from labelled history and, at inference,
converts each model's report into an agreement-guardrailed log-likelihood ratio
that is combined with a contextual prior and a public reputation state updated
via Shapley-based team credit. The result is calibrated, thresholdable
posteriors that (i) amplify agreement among reliable models, (ii) preserve
uniquely correct single-model signals, and (iii) adapt to drift. To specialise
general VLMs, we curate 1,000 real-world dashcam clips with structured
annotations (scene description, manoeuvre recommendation, rationale) via an
automatic pipeline that fuses HDD ground truth, vehicle kinematics, and YOLOv11
+ BoT-SORT tracking, guided by a three-step chain-of-thought prompt; three
heterogeneous VLMs are then fine-tuned with LoRA. We evaluate with Hamming
distance, Micro-Macro-F1, and average per-video latency. Empirically, the
proposed method achieves a 23% reduction in Hamming distance, 55% improvement
in Macro-F1, and 47% improvement in Micro-F1 when comparing with the best
single model, supporting VLM fusion as a calibrated, interpretable, and robust
decision-support component for AV pipelines.

AI.tldr: A Shapley-credited, context-aware Dawid-Skene fusion framework for multi-label ego-view dashcam understanding that calibrates posteriors via per-model, per-label reliabilities, improving AV perception by fusing multiple VLMs.
AI.motivation: Hallucination in large VLMs undermines safety in autonomous driving; need calibrated, robust fusion to leverage multiple models and context.
AI.method: Learns contextual reliabilities per model/label; converts reports into agreement-guardrailed log-likelihood ratios; combines with contextual prior and Shapley-based reputation; uses dataset of 1,000 dashcam clips with structured annotations; fine-tunes three VLMs with LoRA; uses HDD ground truth, YOLOv11 + BoT-SORT; evaluation metrics.
AI.result: 23% reduction in Hamming distance; 55% Macro-F1 improvement; 47% Micro-F1 improvement vs best single model; calibrated posteriors; interpretable and drift-adaptive fusion.
AI.conclusion: VLM fusion with Shapley-based credibility becomes calibrated, interpretable, robust for AV pipelines; preserves strong single-model signals while amplifying agreement among reliable models and adapting to drift.

title: EvolProver: Advancing Automated Theorem Proving by Evolving Formalized Problems via Symmetry and Difficulty
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) for formal theorem proving have shown
significant promise, yet they often lack generalizability and are fragile to
even minor transformations of problem statements. To address this limitation,
we introduce a novel data augmentation pipeline designed to enhance model
robustness from two perspectives: symmetry and difficulty. From the symmetry
perspective, we propose two complementary methods: EvolAST, an Abstract Syntax
Tree (AST) based approach that targets syntactic symmetry to generate
semantically equivalent problem variants, and EvolDomain, which leverages LLMs
to address semantic symmetry by translating theorems across mathematical
domains. From the difficulty perspective, we propose EvolDifficulty, which uses
carefully designed evolutionary instructions to guide LLMs in generating new
theorems with a wider range of difficulty. We then use the evolved data to
train EvolProver, a 7B-parameter non-reasoning theorem prover. EvolProver
establishes a new state-of-the-art (SOTA) on FormalMATH-Lite with a 53.8%
pass@32 rate, surpassing all models of comparable size, including
reasoning-based models. It also sets new SOTA records for non-reasoning models
on MiniF2F-Test (69.8% pass@32), Ineq-Comp-Seed (52.2% pass@32), and
Ineq-Comp-Transformed (34.0% pass@32). Ablation studies further confirm our
data augmentation pipeline's effectiveness across multiple benchmarks.

AI.tldr: A data augmentation pipeline improves robustness of LLMs for formal theorem proving by generating semantically equivalent variants and harder problems, enabling a 7B prover to achieve SOTA on multiple benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LLMs for formal theorem proving struggle with generalization and fragility to small changes in problem statements. Robust training data that captures symmetry (equivalence) and varying difficulty is needed to improve reliability across domains and transformations.
AI.method: Three components: EvolAST—AST-based syntactic symmetry to create semantically equivalent problem variants; EvolDomain—LLMs translating theorems across mathematical domains for semantic symmetry; EvolDifficulty—carefully designed evolutionary prompts to produce problems of wider difficulty. The evolved data trains EvolProver, a 7B non-reasoning prover.
AI.result: EvolProver achieves 53.8% pass@32 on FormalMATH-Lite (SOTA for comparable-size models, including reasoning-free). Also sets SOTA for non-reasoning models on MiniF2F-Test (69.8% pass@32), Ineq-Comp-Seed (52.2%), and Ineq-Comp-Transformed (34.0%). Ablation studies confirm the augmentation pipeline’s effectiveness across benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: A data augmentation framework exploiting symmetry and difficulty can substantially boost robustness and generalization of LLM-based provers, achieving leading performance with a relatively small (7B) model and improving non-reasoning baselines across multiple benchmarks.

title: Cascaded Diffusion Framework for Probabilistic Coarse-to-Fine Hand Pose Estimation
summary:
Deterministic models for 3D hand pose reconstruction, whether single-staged
or cascaded, struggle with pose ambiguities caused by self-occlusions and
complex hand articulations. Existing cascaded approaches refine predictions in
a coarse-to-fine manner but remain deterministic and cannot capture pose
uncertainties. Recent probabilistic methods model pose distributions yet are
restricted to single-stage estimation, which often fails to produce accurate 3D
reconstructions without refinement. To address these limitations, we propose a
coarse-to-fine cascaded diffusion framework that combines probabilistic
modeling with cascaded refinement. The first stage is a joint diffusion model
that samples diverse 3D joint hypotheses, and the second stage is a Mesh Latent
Diffusion Model (Mesh LDM) that reconstructs a 3D hand mesh conditioned on a
joint sample. By training Mesh LDM with diverse joint hypotheses in a learned
latent space, our framework learns distribution-aware joint-mesh relationships
and robust hand priors. Furthermore, the cascaded design mitigates the
difficulty of directly mapping 2D images to dense 3D poses, enhancing accuracy
through sequential refinement. Experiments on FreiHAND and HO3Dv2 demonstrate
that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance while effectively
modeling pose distributions.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-based coarse-to-fine cascaded framework for 3D hand reconstruction that models pose uncertainty and achieves state-of-the-art results on FreiHAND and HO3Dv2 by combining a joint diffusion stage with a Mesh Latent Diffusion Model (Mesh-LDM).
AI.motivation: Deterministic cascaded methods struggle with pose ambiguities from self-occlusions and complex articulations; single-stage probabilistic models lack refinement. The goal is to model distribution over poses and outputs via a cascaded, refinement-driven approach to improve accuracy and uncertainty handling.
AI.method: A two-stage diffusion framework: (1) a joint diffusion model that samples diverse 3D hand joint hypotheses, (2) a Mesh Latent Diffusion Model conditioned on a chosen joint sample to reconstruct a 3D hand mesh. Mesh-LDM is trained in a learned latent space using diverse joint hypotheses to capture distribution-aware joint–mesh relationships and robust hand priors. The cascaded design facilitates learning from 2D-to-3D mappings through sequential refinement.
AI.result: The approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on FreiHAND and HO3Dv2 and effectively models pose distributions.
AI.conclusion: Integrating probabilistic modeling with cascaded refinement yields distribution-aware joint–mesh relationships and robust hand priors, improving accuracy while handling pose uncertainties in 3D hand reconstruction.

title: Robust Federated Inference
summary:
Federated inference, in the form of one-shot federated learning, edge
ensembles, or federated ensembles, has emerged as an attractive solution to
combine predictions from multiple models. This paradigm enables each model to
remain local and proprietary while a central server queries them and aggregates
predictions. Yet, the robustness of federated inference has been largely
neglected, leaving them vulnerable to even simple attacks. To address this
critical gap, we formalize the problem of robust federated inference and
provide the first robustness analysis of this class of methods. Our analysis of
averaging-based aggregators shows that the error of the aggregator is small
either when the dissimilarity between honest responses is small or the margin
between the two most probable classes is large. Moving beyond linear averaging,
we show that problem of robust federated inference with non-linear aggregators
can be cast as an adversarial machine learning problem. We then introduce an
advanced technique using the DeepSet aggregation model, proposing a novel
composition of adversarial training and test-time robust aggregation to
robustify non-linear aggregators. Our composition yields significant
improvements, surpassing existing robust aggregation methods by 4.7 - 22.2% in
accuracy points across diverse benchmarks.

AI.tldr: Robust federated inference is achievable by combining adversarial training with robust aggregation, yielding large accuracy gains.
AI.motivation: Federated inference allows models to stay local and private while their predictions are aggregated; however robustness to simple attacks has been largely neglected, creating vulnerability in this paradigm.
AI.method: 1) Analyze robustness of averaging-based aggregators, showing small error when honest-response dissimilarity is low or class margin is large. 2) Formulate robustness for non-linear aggregators as an adversarial ML problem. 3) Use DeepSet as the aggregation model and propose a composition of adversarial training with test-time robust aggregation to defend non-linear aggregators.
AI.result: The proposed approach yields significant improvements, surpassing existing robust aggregation methods by 4.7–22.2 percentage points in accuracy across diverse benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: A practical recipe for robust federated inference: combine adversarial training with test-time robust aggregation for non-linear aggregators (e.g., DeepSet), achieving substantial accuracy gains over baselines.

title: DIA: The Adversarial Exposure of Deterministic Inversion in Diffusion Models
summary:
Diffusion models have shown to be strong representation learners, showcasing
state-of-the-art performance across multiple domains. Aside from accelerated
sampling, DDIM also enables the inversion of real images back to their latent
codes. A direct inheriting application of this inversion operation is real
image editing, where the inversion yields latent trajectories to be utilized
during the synthesis of the edited image. Unfortunately, this practical tool
has enabled malicious users to freely synthesize misinformative or deepfake
contents with greater ease, which promotes the spread of unethical and abusive,
as well as privacy-, and copyright-infringing contents. While defensive
algorithms such as AdvDM and Photoguard have been shown to disrupt the
diffusion process on these images, the misalignment between their objectives
and the iterative denoising trajectory at test time results in weak disruptive
performance.In this work, we present the DDIM Inversion Attack (DIA) that
attacks the integrated DDIM trajectory path. Our results support the effective
disruption, surpassing previous defensive methods across various editing
methods. We believe that our frameworks and results can provide practical
defense methods against the malicious use of AI for both the industry and the
research community. Our code is available here:
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/DIA-13419/.

AI.tldr: Introduces the DDIM Inversion Attack (DIA) to disrupt the integrated DDIM trajectory, providing stronger defense against diffusion-based real-image editing and misinformative content than prior methods; code released.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models enable real-image inversion for editing, which can be misused to create deepfakes and privacy- or copyright-infringing content. Existing defenses (e.g., AdvDM, Photoguard) fight the diffusion process but fail due to misalignment with the test-time denoising trajectory.
AI.method: Proposes an attack on the integrated DDIM trajectory path (DIA) to disrupt the inversion/editing process, and evaluates its effectiveness across multiple editing methods.
AI.result: DIA achieves effective disruption and outperforms previous defense methods across various editing methods, demonstrating stronger practical defense potential.
AI.conclusion: DIA provides a practical defense framework against malicious diffusion-based editing, with actionable results for industry and research; code is publicly available.

title: Forestpest-YOLO: A High-Performance Detection Framework for Small Forestry Pests
summary:
Detecting agricultural pests in complex forestry environments using remote
sensing imagery is fundamental for ecological preservation, yet it is severely
hampered by practical challenges. Targets are often minuscule, heavily
occluded, and visually similar to the cluttered background, causing
conventional object detection models to falter due to the loss of fine-grained
features and an inability to handle extreme data imbalance. To overcome these
obstacles, this paper introduces Forestpest-YOLO, a detection framework
meticulously optimized for the nuances of forestry remote sensing. Building
upon the YOLOv8 architecture, our framework introduces a synergistic trio of
innovations. We first integrate a lossless downsampling module, SPD-Conv, to
ensure that critical high-resolution details of small targets are preserved
throughout the network. This is complemented by a novel cross-stage feature
fusion block, CSPOK, which dynamically enhances multi-scale feature
representation while suppressing background noise. Finally, we employ
VarifocalLoss to refine the training objective, compelling the model to focus
on high-quality and hard-to-classify samples. Extensive experiments on our
challenging, self-constructed ForestPest dataset demonstrate that
Forestpest-YOLO achieves state-of-the-art performance, showing marked
improvements in detecting small, occluded pests and significantly outperforming
established baseline models.

AI.tldr: Forestpest-YOLO is a YOLOv8-based detector tailored for forestry pest detection that uses SPD-Conv, CSPOK, and VarifocalLoss to achieve state-of-the-art results on a self-collected ForestPest dataset, especially for small and occluded pests.
AI.motivation: Detect pests in complex forestry remote sensing imagery where targets are tiny, occluded, and in cluttered backgrounds with severe class imbalance; existing detectors lose fine-grained features and struggle with extreme data imbalance.
AI.method: Extend YOLOv8 with (1) SPD-Conv lossless downsampling to preserve high-resolution details, (2) CSPOK cross-stage feature fusion to boost multi-scale representation and suppress background noise, (3) VarifocalLoss to emphasize high-quality and hard-to-classify samples; evaluate on a self-constructed ForestPest dataset.
AI.result: Forestpest-YOLO achieves state-of-the-art performance, with notable gains in detecting small and occluded pests and substantial improvements over established baselines.
AI.conclusion: The integrated SPD-Conv, CSPOK, and VarifocalLoss effectively address small-target detection and data imbalance in forestry remote sensing, providing a practical tool for ecological monitoring.

title: DiSC-AMC: Token- and Parameter-Efficient Discretized Statistics In-Context Automatic Modulation Classification
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) can perform Automatic Modulation Classification
(AMC) in an open-set manner without LLM fine-tuning when equipped with
carefully designed in-context prompts~\cite{rostami2025plug}. Building on this
prior work, we target the practical bottlenecks of long prompt contexts and
large model sizes that impede in-the-loop deployment. We present Discretized
Statistics in-Context Automatic Modulation Classification (DiSC-AMC), a token-
and parameter-efficient variant that: (i) discretizes higher-order statistics
and cumulants into compact symbolic tokens, (ii) prunes the exemplar list via a
lightweight k-top neural prefilter and filters misleading/low-impact features
using rationales extracted from prior LLM responses, and (iii) enforces
label-only predictions through a calibrated prompt template. Together, these
changes reduce both input/output tokens and the model parameter footprint by
more than half while maintaining competitive accuracy. On synthetic AMC with
ten modulation types under noise, a 7B \textit{DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen}
baseline achieves 5.2% accuracy, whereas our system, using an approximately
5B-parameter \textit{Gemini-2.5-Flash}~\cite{comanici2025gemini} model, attains
45.5% accuracy. These results demonstrate that careful discretization and
context selection can cut inference cost by over 2x while preserving the
advantages of prompt-based AMC and enabling practical in-the-loop use.

AI.tldr: Token- and parameter-efficient in-context AMC via discretized statistics, exemplar pruning, and label-only prompting, achieving substantial efficiency gains with competitive accuracy (e.g., 45.5% on synthetic AMC with ten modulations using ~5B LLM).
AI.motivation: Open-set AMC with LLMs suffers from long prompt contexts and large model sizes, hindering in-the-loop deployment; a compact, efficient approach is needed.
AI.method: Discretize higher-order statistics and cumulants into compact symbolic tokens; prune exemplars with a lightweight k-top neural prefilter; filter features using rationales from prior LLM responses; enforce label-only predictions with a calibrated prompt template.
AI.result: Reduces input/output tokens and model footprint by >50% while maintaining competitive accuracy; baseline 7B DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen achieves 5.2% accuracy, while the proposed DiSC-AMC with ~5B Gemini-2.5-Flash attains 45.5% on synthetic AMC with ten modulations under noise; shows inference-cost savings >2x.
AI.conclusion: Careful discretization and context selection can preserve the advantages of prompt-based AMC while enabling practical in-the-loop deployment with smaller LLMs.

title: AI in data science education: experiences from the classroom
summary:
This study explores the integration of AI, particularly large language models
(LLMs) like ChatGPT, into educational settings, focusing on the implications
for teaching and learning. Through interviews with course coordinators from
data science courses at Wageningen University, this research identifies both
the benefits and challenges associated with AI in the classroom. While AI tools
can streamline tasks and enhance learning, concerns arise regarding students'
overreliance on these technologies, potentially hindering the development of
essential cognitive and problem solving skills. The study highlights the
importance of responsible AI usage, ethical considerations, and the need for
adapting assessment methods to ensure educational outcomes are met. With
careful integration, AI can be a valuable asset in education, provided it is
used to complement rather than replace fundamental learning processes.

AI.tldr: AI can aid teaching and learning with LLMs like ChatGPT in higher education, but requires careful integration to avoid overreliance; ethical considerations and assessment adaptation are needed.
AI.motivation: Assess the benefits and challenges of integrating AI/LLMs into university teaching, focusing on pedagogy, learning outcomes, and ethical implications.
AI.method: Qualitative study based on interviews with course coordinators in data science courses at Wageningen University, analyzed thematically to identify benefits, challenges, and recommendations.
AI.result: AI offers task automation and potential learning enhancements; concerns include student overreliance and possible erosion of cognitive/problem-solving skills; emphasizes responsible use, ethics, and need to adapt assessments to preserve learning outcomes.
