AI.conclusion: With thoughtful integration, AI can be a valuable educational asset that complements core learning processes rather than replacing them; success depends on alignment with learning goals and robust pedagogical design.

title: Assessing Foundation Models for Mold Colony Detection with Limited Training Data
comment: 17 pages, 2 figures, accepted as oral presentation at GCPR 2025
summary:
The process of quantifying mold colonies on Petri dish samples is of critical
importance for the assessment of indoor air quality, as high colony counts can
indicate potential health risks and deficiencies in ventilation systems.
Conventionally the automation of such a labor-intensive process, as well as
other tasks in microbiology, relies on the manual annotation of large datasets
and the subsequent extensive training of models like YoloV9. To demonstrate
that exhaustive annotation is not a prerequisite anymore when tackling a new
vision task, we compile a representative dataset of 5000 Petri dish images
annotated with bounding boxes, simulating both a traditional data collection
approach as well as few-shot and low-shot scenarios with well curated subsets
with instance level masks. We benchmark three vision foundation models against
traditional baselines on task specific metrics, reflecting realistic real-world
requirements. Notably, MaskDINO attains near-parity with an extensively trained
YoloV9 model while finetuned only on 150 images, retaining competitive
performance with as few as 25 images, still being reliable on $\approx$ 70% of
the samples. Our results show that data-efficient foundation models can match
traditional approaches with only a fraction of the required data, enabling
earlier development and faster iterative improvement of automated
microbiological systems with a superior upper-bound performance than
traditional models would achieve.

AI.tldr: Foundation models can nearly match fully supervised detectors for mold colony counting with far less labeled data, enabling data-efficient microbiological vision.
AI.motivation: Reduce reliance on exhaustive manual annotation in microbiology and accelerate development of automated mold colony counting systems for indoor air quality assessment.
AI.method: Assemble a 5000-image dataset of Petri dish images with bounding boxes and masks, compare three vision foundation models to traditional baselines on task-specific metrics, and evaluate few-shot/low-shot performance by finetuning with 150 or even 25 labeled images.
AI.result: MaskDINO achieves near-parity with a fully trained YoloV9 when fine-tuned on 150 images and remains competitive with as few as 25 images, reliably performing on about 70% of samples.
AI.conclusion: Data-efficient foundation models can match traditional approaches with far less annotated data, enabling faster iteration and potentially higher upper-bound performance in automated microbiological systems.

title: DecepChain: Inducing Deceptive Reasoning in Large Language Models
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have been demonstrating increasingly strong
reasoning capability with their chain-of-thoughts (CoT), which are routinely
used by humans to judge answer quality. This reliance creates a powerful yet
fragile basis for trust. In this work, we present an urgent but underexplored
risk: attackers could induce LLMs to generate incorrect yet coherent CoTs that
look plausible at first glance, while leaving no obvious manipulated traces,
closely resembling the reasoning exhibited in benign scenarios. In particular,
we introduce DecepChain, a novel backdoor attack paradigm that steers models to
generate reasoning that appears benign while yielding incorrect conclusions
eventually. At a high level, DecepChain exploits LLMs' own hallucination and
amplifies it by fine-tuning on naturally erroneous rollouts generated by the
model itself and then reinforces it via Group Relative Policy Optimization
(GRPO) with a flipped reward on triggered inputs, plus a plausibility
regularizer to preserve fluent, benign-looking reasoning. Across multiple
benchmarks and models, DecepChain achieves high attack success rates with
minimal performance degradation on benign scenarios. Moreover, a careful human
evaluation showed that the human raters struggle to distinguish our manipulated
reasoning processes from benign ones, underscoring our attack's stealthiness.
Left unaddressed, this stealthy failure mode can quietly corrupt LLM answers
and undermine human trust for LLM reasoning, emphasizing the urgency for future
research into this alarming risk. Project page: https://decepchain.github.io/.

AI.tldr: DecepChain proposes a stealthy backdoor that makes LLMs produce incorrect but plausible chain-of-thoughts, leveraging model hallucinations, fine-tuning on erroneous rollouts, and GRPO with a flipped reward and plausibility regularizer; achieves high attack success with minimal impact on benign performance and passes human plausibility checks.
AI.motivation: Trust in chain-of-thoughts is fragile; attackers could induce coherent but wrong CoTs, undermining human trust and QA reliability; this risk is underexplored; need defenses and awareness.
AI.method: 1) Exploit model hallucination to generate erroneous, yet plausible CoTs; 2) Fine-tune on naturally erroneous rollouts from the model; 3) Reinforce via Group Relative Policy Optimization with flipped reward on triggered inputs to encourage incorrect conclusions when triggered; 4) Apply plausibility regularizer to maintain fluent, benign-looking reasoning; 5) Evaluate across benchmarks and models; 6) Human evaluation.
AI.result: High attack success rate with minimal performance degradation on benign tasks; stealthiness confirmed by human evaluators; effectiveness demonstrated across multiple benchmarks and models.
AI.conclusion: The paper highlights an urgent risk of stealthy reasoning backdoors in LLMs that can erode trust; calls for defense research and safeguards; project page provided.

title: Benchmarking Agentic Systems in Automated Scientific Information Extraction with ChemX
comment:
Accepted at The AI for Accelerated Materials Discovery (AI4Mat)
  Workshop, NeurIPS 2025
summary:
The emergence of agent-based systems represents a significant advancement in
artificial intelligence, with growing applications in automated data
extraction. However, chemical information extraction remains a formidable
challenge due to the inherent heterogeneity of chemical data. Current
agent-based approaches, both general-purpose and domain-specific, exhibit
limited performance in this domain. To address this gap, we present ChemX, a
comprehensive collection of 10 manually curated and domain-expert-validated
datasets focusing on nanomaterials and small molecules. These datasets are
designed to rigorously evaluate and enhance automated extraction methodologies
in chemistry. To demonstrate their utility, we conduct an extensive
benchmarking study comparing existing state-of-the-art agentic systems such as
ChatGPT Agent and chemical-specific data extraction agents. Additionally, we
introduce our own single-agent approach that enables precise control over
document preprocessing prior to extraction. We further evaluate the performance
of modern baselines, such as GPT-5 and GPT-5 Thinking, to compare their
capabilities with agentic approaches. Our empirical findings reveal persistent
challenges in chemical information extraction, particularly in processing
domain-specific terminology, complex tabular and schematic representations, and
context-dependent ambiguities. The ChemX benchmark serves as a critical
resource for advancing automated information extraction in chemistry,
challenging the generalization capabilities of existing methods, and providing
valuable insights into effective evaluation strategies.

AI.tldr: ChemX provides a curated 10-dataset benchmark for chemistry information extraction and benchmarks agent-based and baseline models, revealing persistent domain-specific challenges and offering an evaluation resource for improved methods.
AI.motivation: Address the heterogeneity and terminology in chemical data that hinder automated extraction, and push toward robust evaluation benchmarks that can guide method development.
AI.method: Create 10 manually curated, domain-expert-validated datasets focusing on nanomaterials and small molecules; benchmark state-of-the-art agent-based systems (e.g., ChatGPT Agent) and chemical-specific extraction agents, plus their own single-agent preprocessing approach; compare with modern baselines (GPT-5, GPT-5 Thinking).
AI.result: Findings indicate persistent challenges in chemical information extraction, especially with domain terminology, complex tables/diagrams, and context-dependent ambiguities; the ChemX benchmark proves useful for advancing automated chemistry information extraction and evaluating generalization and methodologies.
AI.conclusion: ChemX serves as a critical resource to advance chemistry information extraction, encouraging improved methods and reliable evaluation strategies that generalize beyond current agent-based approaches.

title: Adaptive Shared Experts with LoRA-Based Mixture of Experts for Multi-Task Learning
summary:
Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) has emerged as a powerful framework for multi-task
learning (MTL). However, existing MoE-MTL methods often rely on single-task
pretrained backbones and suffer from redundant adaptation and inefficient
knowledge sharing during the transition from single-task to multi-task learning
(STL to MTL). To address these limitations, we propose adaptive shared experts
(ASE) within a low-rank adaptation (LoRA) based MoE, where shared experts are
assigned router-computed gating weights jointly normalized with sparse experts.
This design facilitates STL to MTL transition, enhances expert specialization,
and cooperation. Furthermore, we incorporate fine-grained experts by increasing
the number of LoRA experts while proportionally reducing their rank, enabling
more effective knowledge sharing under a comparable parameter budget. Extensive
experiments on the PASCAL-Context benchmark, under unified training settings,
demonstrate that ASE consistently improves performance across diverse
configurations and validates the effectiveness of fine-grained designs for MTL.

AI.tldr: Adaptive shared experts (ASE) in a LoRA-based Mixture-of-Experts for multi-task learning improves the STL-to-MTL transition and knowledge sharing; uses router-guided gating with shared and sparse experts; includes fine-grained LoRA experts by increasing count while reducing rank; validated on PASCAL-Context.
AI.motivation: MoE-MTL often relies on single-task pretrained backbones and suffers from redundant adaptation and inefficient knowledge sharing during the transition from single-task to multi-task learning; there is a need for a flexible, parameter-efficient mechanism to improve cross-task sharing and specialization.
AI.method: Introduce ASE within a LoRA-based MoE. Shared experts receive router-computed gating weights that are jointly normalized with sparse experts. Additionally, implement fine-grained experts by increasing the number of LoRA experts while proportionally reducing their rank to enhance knowledge sharing under a fixed parameter budget. Train and evaluate under unified settings on the PASCAL-Context benchmark.
AI.result: ASE consistently improves performance across diverse configurations and demonstrates the effectiveness of fine-grained LoRA designs for MTL.
AI.conclusion: ASE with a LoRA-based MoE enables better STL-to-MTL transitions, enhances expert specialization and cooperation, and supports efficient knowledge sharing within a parameter budget; fine-grained expert design is beneficial for MTL.

title: A Framework for Selection of Machine Learning Algorithms Based on Performance Metrices and Akaike Information Criteria in Healthcare, Telecommunication, and Marketing Sector
summary:
The exponential growth of internet generated data has fueled advancements in
artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and deep learning (DL) for
extracting actionable insights in marketing,telecom, and health sectors. This
chapter explores ML applications across three domains namely healthcare,
marketing, and telecommunications, with a primary focus on developing a
framework for optimal ML algorithm selection. In healthcare, the framework
addresses critical challenges such as cardiovascular disease prediction
accounting for 28.1% of global deaths and fetal health classification into
healthy or unhealthy states, utilizing three datasets. ML algorithms are
categorized into eager, lazy, and hybrid learners, selected based on dataset
attributes, performance metrics (accuracy, precision, recall), and Akaike
Information Criterion (AIC) scores. For validation, eight datasets from the
three sectors are employed in the experiments. The key contribution is a
recommendation framework that identifies the best ML model according to input
attributes, balancing performance evaluation and model complexity to enhance
efficiency and accuracy in diverse real-world applications. This approach
bridges gaps in automated model selection, offering practical implications for
interdisciplinary ML deployment.

AI.tldr: A framework for automatic ML model selection across healthcare, marketing, and telecom that balances accuracy and complexity; validated on eight datasets and healthcare tasks including cardiovascular disease prediction and fetal health classification.
AI.motivation: There is a rising volume of AI-generated data and diverse application domains, necessitating automated, principled model selection to optimize performance while controlling complexity.
AI.method: Classify ML algorithms as eager, lazy, and hybrid learners; select models based on dataset attributes, performance metrics (accuracy, precision, recall), and Akaike Information Criterion (AIC); validate the framework on eight datasets spanning healthcare, marketing, and telecom.
AI.result: The framework yields recommendations for the best model given input attributes, balancing performance with model complexity and improving efficiency and accuracy in real-world deployments.
AI.conclusion: The study addresses gaps in automated model selection and offers practical guidance for deploying interdisciplinary ML systems across multiple sectors.

title: Semantic Bridges Between First Order c-Representations and Cost-Based Semantics: An Initial Perspective
summary:
Weighted-knowledge bases and cost-based semantics represent a recent
formalism introduced by Bienvenu et al. for Ontology Mediated Data Querying in
the case where a given knowledge base is inconsistent. This is done by adding a
weight to each statement in the knowledge base (KB), and then giving each DL
interpretation a cost based on how often it breaks rules in the KB. In this
paper we compare this approach with c-representations, a form of non-monotonic
reasoning originally introduced by Kern-Isberner. c-Representations describe a
means to interpret defeasible concept inclusions in the first-order case. This
is done by assigning a numerical ranking to each interpretations via penalties
for each violated conditional. We compare these two approaches on a semantic
level. In particular, we show that under certain conditions a weighted
knowledge base and a set of defeasible conditionals can generate the same
ordering on interpretations, and therefore an equivalence of semantic
structures up to relative cost. Moreover, we compare entailment described in
both cases, where certain notions are equivalently expressible in both
formalisms. Our results have the potential to benefit further work on both
cost-based semantics and c-representations

AI.tldr: Weighted-knowledge bases with cost-based semantics can align with c-representations, yielding equivalent interpretation orderings under certain conditions and sharing expressible entailment notions; this semantic equivalence suggests cross-pollination between the two formalisms.
AI.motivation: Inconsistency in ontology-mediated data querying motivates comparing two distinct non-monotonic formalisms: Bienvenu et al.'s cost-based semantics for weighted KBs and Kern-Isberner's c-representations for defeasible conditionals.
AI.method: Perform a semantic-level comparison to identify conditions under which a weighted KB and a set of defeasible conditionals induce the same ordering of interpretations. Analyze how penalties/weights relate to defeasible rankings, and examine which notions of entailment are expressible in both formalisms.
AI.result: Under certain conditions, the weighted KB and the defeasible set produce the same interpretation ordering, implying equivalence of semantic structures up to relative costs. Some entailment notions are equivalently expressible in both frameworks.
AI.conclusion: The findings illuminate a potential bridge between cost-based semantics and c-representations, suggesting avenues for cross-fertilization and joint development in ontology-mediated reasoning under inconsistency.

title: Arbitrary Generative Video Interpolation
summary:
Video frame interpolation (VFI), which generates intermediate frames from
given start and end frames, has become a fundamental function in video
generation applications. However, existing generative VFI methods are
constrained to synthesize a fixed number of intermediate frames, lacking the
flexibility to adjust generated frame rates or total sequence duration. In this
work, we present ArbInterp, a novel generative VFI framework that enables
efficient interpolation at any timestamp and of any length. Specifically, to
support interpolation at any timestamp, we propose the Timestamp-aware Rotary
Position Embedding (TaRoPE), which modulates positions in temporal RoPE to
align generated frames with target normalized timestamps. This design enables
fine-grained control over frame timestamps, addressing the inflexibility of
fixed-position paradigms in prior work. For any-length interpolation, we
decompose long-sequence generation into segment-wise frame synthesis. We
further design a novel appearance-motion decoupled conditioning strategy: it
leverages prior segment endpoints to enforce appearance consistency and
temporal semantics to maintain motion coherence, ensuring seamless
spatiotemporal transitions across segments. Experimentally, we build
comprehensive benchmarks for multi-scale frame interpolation (2x to 32x) to
assess generalizability across arbitrary interpolation factors. Results show
that ArbInterp outperforms prior methods across all scenarios with higher
fidelity and more seamless spatiotemporal continuity. Project website:
https://mcg-nju.github.io/ArbInterp-Web/.

AI.tldr: ArbInterp enables any-timestamp and any-length video frame interpolation by introducing TaRoPE for precise timestamp control and a segment-wise, appearance-motion decoupled conditioning strategy, achieving higher fidelity and seamless continuity across 2x–32x interpolation.
AI.motivation: Current generative VFI methods are limited to fixed interpolation factors, restricting flexibly adjusting frame rates or total sequence duration. There is a need for a flexible, scalable VFI approach that can interpolate at arbitrary timestamps and generate variable-length sequences while preserving appearance and motion consistency.
AI.method: TaRoPE (Timestamp-aware Rotary Position Embedding) modulates temporal positions to align generated frames with target timestamps. For any-length interpolation, long sequences are decomposed into segment-wise frame synthesis. An appearance-motion decoupled conditioning strategy uses prior segment endpoints to enforce appearance consistency and temporal semantics to maintain motion coherence across segments, enabling seamless transitions.
AI.result: Experimental benchmarks show ArbInterp outperforms prior methods across multiple interpolation scales (2x to 32x), delivering higher fidelity and stronger spatiotemporal continuity and better generalization to arbitrary interpolation factors.
AI.conclusion: ArbInterp provides a flexible, efficient VFI framework capable of interpolating at any timestamp and any length, with strong fidelity and smooth transitions, as evidenced by comprehensive multi-scale benchmarks.

title: Cutting the Skip: Training Residual-Free Transformers
summary:
Transformers have achieved remarkable success across a wide range of
applications, a feat often attributed to their scalability. Yet training them
without skip (residual) connections remains notoriously difficult. While skips
stabilize optimization, they also disrupt the hierarchical structure of
representations, raising the long-standing question of whether transformers can
be trained efficiently without them. In this work, we address this problem by
analyzing the Jacobian of a skipless transformer block, showing why skips
improve conditioning and revealing that their stabilization benefits can be
recovered through a principled initialization strategy. Building on this
insight, we introduce the first method that enables stable and efficient
training of skipless transformers without altering the standard architecture.
We validate our approach on Vision Transformers (ViTs) in both supervised and
self-supervised settings, demonstrating that skipless ViTs trained with our
initialization overcome the usual optimization barriers, learn richer
hierarchical representations, and outperform strong baselines, that incorporate
skip connections, on dense prediction benchmarks. These results show that skip
connections are not a fundamental requirement for training ViTs and open new
avenues for hierarchical representation learning in vision models.

AI.tldr: Skipless transformers can be trained stably with a principled initialization, achieving competitive or superior performance compared to skip-connected ViTs, suggesting skip connections are not strictly necessary for ViT training.
AI.motivation: Understand why skip connections aid optimization in transformers and whether skipless models can be trained efficiently, enabling alternative architectural exploration.
AI.method: Analyze the Jacobian of a skipless transformer block to diagnose conditioning issues due to absence of residuals; show how skip connections improve conditioning and derive an initialization that recovers these stabilization benefits; implement and validate a training procedure for skipless transformers without altering the standard architecture; test on Vision Transformers in supervised and self-supervised settings.
AI.result: An initialization strategy enables stable training of skipless ViTs; these models learn richer hierarchical representations and surpass strong skip-connected baselines on dense prediction benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Skip connections are not a fundamental requirement for training ViTs; with appropriate initialization, skipless transformers can be trained efficiently, opening new avenues for hierarchical representation learning in vision models.

title: Logical Consistency Between Disagreeing Experts and Its Role in AI Safety
summary:
If two experts disagree on a test, we may conclude both cannot be 100 per
cent correct. But if they completely agree, no possible evaluation can be
excluded. This asymmetry in the utility of agreements versus disagreements is
explored here by formalizing a logic of unsupervised evaluation for
classifiers. Its core problem is computing the set of group evaluations that
are logically consistent with how we observe them agreeing and disagreeing in
their decisions. Statistical summaries of their aligned decisions are inputs
into a Linear Programming problem in the integer space of possible correct or
incorrect responses given true labels. Obvious logical constraints, such as,
the number of correct responses cannot exceed the number of observed responses,
are inequalities. But in addition, there are axioms, universally applicable
linear equalities that apply to all finite tests. The practical and immediate
utility of this approach to unsupervised evaluation using only logical
consistency is demonstrated by building no-knowledge alarms that can detect
when one or more LLMs-as-Judges are violating a minimum grading threshold
specified by the user.

AI.tldr: Logic-based unsupervised evaluation of classifiers using agreement/disagreement patterns, cast as an integer linear program to infer consistently possible true labels; enables no-knowledge alarms for LLM judges.
AI.motivation: When experts disagree, at least one is not perfect; complete agreement provides little evaluative information. The paper seeks a framework to evaluate classifiers without ground truth by exploiting logical consistency.
AI.method: Formalize a logic of unsupervised evaluation with universal linear equalities and inequalities. Use observed summaries of aligned decisions as input to an integer linear programming problem over possible true labels to compute the set of group evaluations that are logically consistent.
AI.result: Derives the set of evaluations consistent with observed agreement/disagreement. Demonstrates practicality by building no-knowledge alarms that detect when LLMs-as-Judges violate a user-specified grading threshold.
AI.conclusion: A logic-based, unsupervised evaluation approach can yield meaningful guardrails and detection mechanisms for classifiers and judge-like systems using only logical consistency constraints.

title: Color Models in Image Processing: A Review and Experimental Comparison
comment:
This manuscript has been submitted to Scientific Reports for
  consideration
summary:
Color representation is essential in computer vision and human-computer
interaction. There are multiple color models available. The choice of a
suitable color model is critical for various applications. This paper presents
a review of color models and spaces, analyzing their theoretical foundations,
computational properties, and practical applications. We explore traditional
models such as RGB, CMYK, and YUV, perceptually uniform spaces like CIELAB and
CIELUV, and fuzzy-based approaches as well. Additionally, we conduct a series
of experiments to evaluate color models from various perspectives, like device
dependency, chromatic consistency, and computational complexity. Our
experimental results reveal gaps in existing color models and show that the HS*
family is the most aligned with human perception. The review also identifies
key strengths and limitations of different models and outlines open challenges
and future directions This study provides a reference for researchers in image
processing, perceptual computing, digital media, and any other color-related
field.

AI.tldr: A review and empirical study of color models/spaces, comparing RGB/CMYK/YUV, CIELAB/CIELUV, and fuzzy approaches; experiments on device-dependency, chromatic consistency, and complexity; finds HS* family aligns best with human perception and highlights open challenges and future directions.
AI.motivation: To synthesize color model literature and provide guidance on selecting color spaces and models that balance theory, computation, and perceptual alignment.
AI.method: Literature review of traditional, perceptually uniform, and fuzzy color models, complemented by experiments evaluating device-dependency, chromatic consistency, and computational complexity across models; specific attention to the HS* family.
AI.result: The HS* family emerges as most aligned with human perception; gaps and trade-offs are identified across models; strengths and limitations are mapped; practical guidance and open challenges are outlined.
AI.conclusion: The study offers a reference for researchers in image processing and related fields, emphasizing perceptual alignment and outlining open challenges and directions for future work.

title: In-Context Curiosity: Distilling Exploration for Decision-Pretrained Transformers on Bandit Tasks
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) continue to grow in capability, there is
increasing interest in incorporating them into decision-making tasks. A common
pipeline for this is Decision-Pretrained Transformers (DPTs). However, existing
training methods for DPTs often struggle to generalize beyond their pretraining
data distribution. To explore mitigation of this limitation, we propose
in-context curiosity -- a lightweight, exploration-inspired regularizer for
offline pretraining -- and introduce the Prediction-Powered Transformer (PPT)
framework. PPT augments DPT with an auxiliary reward predictor, using
prediction error as an intrinsic curiosity signal to encourage broader
exploration during training. In proof-of-concept experiments on Gaussian
multi-armed bandits, PPT shows improved robustness: it moderates the
performance degradation observed in DPT when test environments exhibit higher
variance in reward, particularly when pretraining data has limited diversity.
While the quality of offline data remain fundamental, our preliminary results
suggest that curiosity-driven pretraining offers a promising direction for
enhancing out-of-distribution generalization in in-context RL agents.

AI.tldr: Introduces Prediction-Powered Transformer (PPT), a lightweight in-context curiosity regularizer for offline pretraining of decision-pretrained transformers (DPTs) to improve out-of-distribution generalization, demonstrated on Gaussian bandits.
AI.motivation: Address the generalization gap of DPTs beyond their pretraining data distribution and explore exploration-inspired regularization to broaden training coverage.
AI.method: Augment DPT with an auxiliary reward predictor (PPT). Use prediction error as an intrinsic curiosity signal to encourage broader exploration during offline pretraining. Validate concept on Gaussian multi-armed bandits.
AI.result: PPT improves robustness by moderating performance degradation of DPT under higher reward-variance test environments, particularly when pretraining data has limited diversity.
AI.conclusion: Curiosity-driven pretraining shows promise for enhancing out-of-distribution generalization in in-context RL agents, though offline data quality remains foundational.

title: Benchmarking Machine Learning Models for Fault Classification and Localization in Power System Protection
summary:
The increasing integration of distributed energy resources (DERs),
particularly renewables, poses significant challenges for power system
protection, with fault classification (FC) and fault localization (FL) being
among the most critical tasks. Conventional protection schemes, based on fixed
thresholds, cannot reliably identify and localize short circuits with the
increasing complexity of the grid under dynamic conditions. Machine learning
(ML) offers a promising alternative; however, systematic benchmarks across
models and settings remain limited. This work presents, for the first time, a
comparative benchmarking study of classical ML models for FC and FL in power
system protection based on EMT data. Using voltage and current waveforms
segmented into sliding windows of 10 ms to 50 ms, we evaluate models under
realistic real-time constraints. Performance is assessed in terms of accuracy,
robustness to window size, and runtime efficiency. The best-performing FC model
achieved an F1 score of 0.992$\pm$0.001, while the top FL model reached an R2
of 0.806$\pm$0.008 with a mean processing time of 0.563 ms.

AI.tldr: Comparative benchmarking study of classical ML models for fault classification (FC) and fault localization (FL) in power system protection using EMT data; achieves high accuracy and low latency.
AI.motivation: DER growth and grid dynamics complicate protection; conventional fixed-threshold protection struggles under dynamic conditions; there is a need for systematic benchmarks across ML models and settings.
AI.method: Benchmark multiple classical ML models on EMT-derived voltage and current waveforms segmented into sliding windows of 10–50 ms; evaluate under real-time constraints; assess accuracy, robustness to window size, and runtime efficiency.
AI.result: Best FC model: F1 = 0.992 ± 0.001; best FL model: R2 = 0.806 ± 0.008; mean processing time ≈ 0.563 ms.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates that classical ML approaches can deliver high-performance fault classification and localization with ultra-low latency, supporting the viability of ML benchmarks for power system protection; further work may examine generalizability and model diversity.

title: Multi-level Dynamic Style Transfer for NeRFs
comment: Accepted by Computational Visual Media Journal (CVMJ)
summary:
As the application of neural radiance fields (NeRFs) in various 3D vision
tasks continues to expand, numerous NeRF-based style transfer techniques have
been developed. However, existing methods typically integrate style statistics
into the original NeRF pipeline, often leading to suboptimal results in both
content preservation and artistic stylization. In this paper, we present
multi-level dynamic style transfer for NeRFs (MDS-NeRF), a novel approach that
reengineers the NeRF pipeline specifically for stylization and incorporates an
innovative dynamic style injection module. Particularly, we propose a
multi-level feature adaptor that helps generate a multi-level feature grid
representation from the content radiance field, effectively capturing the
multi-scale spatial structure of the scene. In addition, we present a dynamic
style injection module that learns to extract relevant style features and
adaptively integrates them into the content patterns. The stylized multi-level
features are then transformed into the final stylized view through our proposed
multi-level cascade decoder. Furthermore, we extend our 3D style transfer
method to support omni-view style transfer using 3D style references. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that MDS-NeRF achieves outstanding performance for 3D
style transfer, preserving multi-scale spatial structures while effectively
transferring stylistic characteristics.

AI.tldr: Introduces MDS-NeRF, a NeRF-based 3D style transfer framework that uses a multi-level feature adaptor and a dynamic style injection module to preserve content and enable omni-view stylization.
AI.motivation: Existing NeRF style transfer methods embed style into the original NeRF pipeline, often degrading content preservation and multi-scale structures; a reengineered, dynamic, multi-level approach is needed.
AI.method: Proposes (1) a multi-level feature adaptor to build multi-scale feature grids from the content radiance field; (2) a dynamic style injection module to extract style features and adaptively inject them into content; (3) a multi-level cascade decoder to produce stylized views; and (4) extension to omni-view style transfer with 3D style references.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show strong performance in 3D style transfer, preserving multi-scale spatial structure while effectively transferring stylistic features.
AI.conclusion: MDS-NeRF effectively reengineers the NeRF pipeline for stylization, enabling dynamic, multi-level style transfer with omni-view capabilities.

title: Initial Distribution Sensitivity of Constrained Markov Decision Processes
summary:
Constrained Markov Decision Processes (CMDPs) are notably more complex to
solve than standard MDPs due to the absence of universally optimal policies
across all initial state distributions. This necessitates re-solving the CMDP
whenever the initial distribution changes. In this work, we analyze how the
optimal value of CMDPs varies with different initial distributions, deriving
bounds on these variations using duality analysis of CMDPs and perturbation
analysis in linear programming. Moreover, we show how such bounds can be used
to analyze the regret of a given policy due to unknown variations of the
initial distribution.

AI.tldr: CMDPs’ optimal value depends on the initial distribution; the paper derives bounds on how it changes with the initial distribution using duality and LP perturbation, and uses these bounds to analyze policy regret under unknown initial distributions.
AI.motivation: CMDPs are harder than standard MDPs because optimal policies are not universally optimal across initial state distributions; understanding sensitivity to the initial distribution is important for robustness and planning when initial conditions are uncertain.
AI.method: Utilizes duality analysis of CMDPs and perturbation analysis in linear programming to derive bounds on the variation of the optimal value with respect to changes in the initial distribution.
AI.result: Derives bounds on how the CMDP’s optimal value varies with different initial distributions and demonstrates how these bounds can be used to assess the regret of a given policy under unknown initial-distribution variation.
AI.conclusion: Provides a framework linking initial-distribution sensitivity to regret, enabling robustness assessments and informing when re-solving CMDPs is necessary as the initial distribution changes.

title: Improving Cryptocurrency Pump-and-Dump Detection through Ensemble-Based Models and Synthetic Oversampling Techniques
summary:
This study aims to detect pump and dump (P&D) manipulation in cryptocurrency
markets, where the scarcity of such events causes severe class imbalance and
hinders accurate detection. To address this issue, the Synthetic Minority
Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) was applied, and advanced ensemble learning
models were evaluated to distinguish manipulative trading behavior from normal
market activity. The experimental results show that applying SMOTE greatly
enhanced the ability of all models to detect P&D events by increasing recall
and improving the overall balance between precision and recall. In particular,
XGBoost and LightGBM achieved high recall rates (94.87% and 93.59%,
respectively) with strong F1-scores and demonstrated fast computational
performance, making them suitable for near real time surveillance. These
findings indicate that integrating data balancing techniques with ensemble
methods significantly improves the early detection of manipulative activities,
contributing to a fairer, more transparent, and more stable cryptocurrency
market.

AI.tldr: SMOTE balancing plus ensemble models (notably XGBoost/LightGBM) boost P&D detection in crypto markets; near real-time performance.
AI.motivation: P&D events are rare, causing severe class imbalance; timely and reliable detection is needed to improve market fairness and transparency.
AI.method: Applied SMOTE to oversample the minority P&D class and evaluated advanced ensemble models (XGBoost, LightGBM) for distinguishing manipulative trading from normal activity, assessing recall, precision, F1, and computational efficiency.
AI.result: SMOTE improved recall and the precision–recall balance for all models; XGBoost achieved 94.87% recall, LightGBM 93.59% recall, with strong F1-scores and fast runtimes suitable for near real-time surveillance.
AI.conclusion: Integrating data balancing techniques with ensemble methods significantly enhances early detection of manipulative activities, contributing to a fairer, more transparent, and more stable cryptocurrency market.

title: LVLMs as inspectors: an agentic framework for category-level structural defect annotation
summary:
Automated structural defect annotation is essential for ensuring
infrastructure safety while minimizing the high costs and inefficiencies of
manual labeling. A novel agentic annotation framework, Agent-based Defect
Pattern Tagger (ADPT), is introduced that integrates Large Vision-Language
Models (LVLMs) with a semantic pattern matching module and an iterative
self-questioning refinement mechanism. By leveraging optimized domain-specific
prompting and a recursive verification process, ADPT transforms raw visual data
into high-quality, semantically labeled defect datasets without any manual
supervision. Experimental results demonstrate that ADPT achieves up to 98%
accuracy in distinguishing defective from non-defective images, and 85%-98%
annotation accuracy across four defect categories under class-balanced
settings, with 80%-92% accuracy on class-imbalanced datasets. The framework
offers a scalable and cost-effective solution for high-fidelity dataset
construction, providing strong support for downstream tasks such as transfer
learning and domain adaptation in structural damage assessment.

AI.tldr: ADPT automates defect annotation by combining LVLMs with semantic matching and iterative self-questioning, achieving high accuracy and enabling scalable, unsupervised dataset construction for structural damage assessment.
AI.motivation: Manual labeling of structural defects is costly and time-consuming; automating annotation with agentic, self-refining capabilities can improve safety and efficiency.
AI.method: Agent-based Defect Pattern Tagger (ADPT) integrates Large Vision-Language Models, a semantic pattern matching module, and an iterative self-questioning refinement loop; uses domain-optimized prompts and recursive verification to generate semantically labeled defect datasets without manual supervision.
AI.result: Achieves up to 98% accuracy distinguishing defective vs non-defective images; 85-98% annotation accuracy across four defect categories in balanced data; 80-92% in imbalanced datasets; demonstrates scalability and cost-effectiveness for downstream transfer learning and domain adaptation.
AI.conclusion: ADPT provides a scalable, high-fidelity automatic labeling framework for structural damage datasets, enabling efficient dataset construction and improved performance in transfer learning tasks.

title: Flow Autoencoders are Effective Protein Tokenizers
summary:
Protein structure tokenizers enable the creation of multimodal models of
protein structure, sequence, and function. Current approaches to protein
structure tokenization rely on bespoke components that are invariant to spatial
symmetries, but that are challenging to optimize and scale. We present Kanzi, a
flow-based tokenizer for tokenization and generation of protein structures.
Kanzi consists of a diffusion autoencoder trained with a flow matching loss. We
show that this approach simplifies several aspects of protein structure
tokenizers: frame-based representations can be replaced with global
coordinates, complex losses are replaced with a single flow matching loss, and
SE(3)-invariant attention operations can be replaced with standard attention.
We find that these changes stabilize the training of parameter-efficient models
that outperform existing tokenizers on reconstruction metrics at a fraction of
the model size and training cost. An autoregressive model trained with Kanzi
outperforms similar generative models that operate over tokens, although it
does not yet match the performance of state-of-the-art continuous diffusion
models. Code is available here: https://github.com/rdilip/kanzi/.

AI.tldr: Kanzi is a flow-based tokenizer for protein structures that uses a diffusion autoencoder with a flow matching loss, enabling simpler, more scalable tokenization and generation, with stable training of small models and improved reconstruction; autoregressive generation with Kanzi outperforms token-based generative models but does not yet surpass state-of-the-art continuous diffusion models.
AI.motivation: Current protein structure tokenizers rely on bespoke components that are invariant to spatial symmetries and are difficult to optimize and scale. There is a need for simpler, scalable tokenizers that maintain performance.
AI.method: Kanzi is a diffusion autoencoder trained with a flow matching loss. It replaces frame-based representations with global coordinates, collapses multiple complex losses into a single flow matching loss, and substitutes SE(3)-invariant attention with standard attention. This results in a flow-based tokenizer that can be trained efficiently.
AI.result: The approach stabilizes training of parameter-efficient models that outperform existing tokenizers on reconstruction metrics at a fraction of the model size and training cost. An autoregressive model trained with Kanzi outperforms similar generative models that operate over tokens, though it does not yet reach the performance of state-of-the-art continuous diffusion models.
AI.conclusion: Kanzi simplifies protein structure tokenization and generation, enabling smaller, cheaper models with better reconstruction. While autoregressive generation shows promise, achieving diffusion-model-level performance remains an area for improvement. The authors provide code to reproduce their results.

title: Learning Compact Representations of LLM Abilities via Item Response Theory
summary:
Recent years have witnessed a surge in the number of large language models
(LLMs), yet efficiently managing and utilizing these vast resources remains a
significant challenge. In this work, we explore how to learn compact
representations of LLM abilities that can facilitate downstream tasks, such as
model routing and performance prediction on new benchmarks. We frame this
problem as estimating the probability that a given model will correctly answer
a specific query. Inspired by the item response theory (IRT) in psychometrics,
we model this probability as a function of three key factors: (i) the model's
multi-skill ability vector, (2) the query's discrimination vector that
separates models of differing skills, and (3) the query's difficulty scalar. To
learn these parameters jointly, we introduce a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) network
that couples model- and query-level embeddings. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our approach leads to state-of-the-art performance in both
model routing and benchmark accuracy prediction. Moreover, analysis validates
that the learned parameters encode meaningful, interpretable information about
model capabilities and query characteristics.

AI.tldr: Proposes a compact, interpretable representation of LLM abilities using an IRT-inspired probability model and a Mixture-of-Experts network to predict whether a model answers a query, enabling model routing and benchmark performance prediction with state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: The rapid growth of LLMs creates a need for compact, transferable representations of model capabilities to enable efficient routing, selection, and benchmarking.
AI.method: Model the probability of a correct answer as a function of three factors: a multi-skill model-ability vector, a query discrimination vector, and a query difficulty scalar, learned jointly via a Mixture-of-Experts network that couples model- and query-level embeddings.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance in model routing and benchmark accuracy prediction; learned parameters are interpretable and reflect meaningful model and query characteristics.
AI.conclusion: IRT-inspired, MoE-based representation learning yields compact, interpretable encodings of model abilities that support effective routing and evaluation of LLMs on new benchmarks.

title: Disentangling Foreground and Background for vision-Language Navigation via Online Augmentation
summary:
Following language instructions, vision-language navigation (VLN) agents are
tasked with navigating unseen environments. While augmenting multifaceted
visual representations has propelled advancements in VLN, the significance of
foreground and background in visual observations remains underexplored.
Intuitively, foreground regions provide semantic cues, whereas the background
encompasses spatial connectivity information. Inspired on this insight, we
propose a Consensus-driven Online Feature Augmentation strategy (COFA) with
alternative foreground and background features to facilitate the navigable
generalization. Specifically, we first leverage semantically-enhanced landmark
identification to disentangle foreground and background as candidate augmented
features. Subsequently, a consensus-driven online augmentation strategy
encourages the agent to consolidate two-stage voting results on feature
preferences according to diverse instructions and navigational locations.
Experiments on REVERIE and R2R demonstrate that our online
foreground-background augmentation boosts the generalization of baseline and
attains state-of-the-art performance.

AI.tldr: Proposes COFA, a consensus-driven online feature augmentation for vision-language navigation that separates foreground and background features via semantic landmarks and uses two-stage voting to select features, improving generalization on unseen environments (REVERIE, R2R).
AI.motivation: Foreground vs background cues in visual observations are underexplored in VLN; foreground provides semantic cues while background encodes spatial connectivity. Enhancing their complementary use could improve generalization to unseen environments.
AI.method: Identify semantically-enhanced landmarks to disentangle foreground and background as candidate augmented features. Apply a consensus-driven online augmentation with two-stage voting to determine feature preferences based on instructions and navigational locations.
AI.result: Experiments on REVERIE and R2R show that online foreground-background augmentation improves baseline generalization and achieves state-of-the-art performance.
AI.conclusion: Foreground-background feature augmentation guided by consensus improves VLN generalization to unseen environments.

title: AReUReDi: Annealed Rectified Updates for Refining Discrete Flows with Multi-Objective Guidance
summary:
Designing sequences that satisfy multiple, often conflicting, objectives is a
central challenge in therapeutic and biomolecular engineering. Existing
generative frameworks largely operate in continuous spaces with
single-objective guidance, while discrete approaches lack guarantees for
multi-objective Pareto optimality. We introduce AReUReDi (Annealed Rectified
Updates for Refining Discrete Flows), a discrete optimization algorithm with
theoretical guarantees of convergence to the Pareto front. Building on
Rectified Discrete Flows (ReDi), AReUReDi combines Tchebycheff scalarization,
locally balanced proposals, and annealed Metropolis-Hastings updates to bias
sampling toward Pareto-optimal states while preserving distributional
invariance. Applied to peptide and SMILES sequence design, AReUReDi
simultaneously optimizes up to five therapeutic properties (including affinity,
solubility, hemolysis, half-life, and non-fouling) and outperforms both
evolutionary and diffusion-based baselines. These results establish AReUReDi as
a powerful, sequence-based framework for multi-property biomolecule generation.

AI.tldr: AReUReDi is a discrete optimization method with convergence guarantees to the Pareto front for multi-objective sequence design, using annealed Metropolis-Hastings updates, Tchebycheff scalarization, and Rectified Discrete Flows to efficiently locate Pareto-optimal sequences.
AI.motivation: Discrete sequence design for multiple, often conflicting objectives lacks principled Pareto guarantees; existing methods are either continuous with single-objective guidance or discrete without Pareto guarantees.
AI.method: AReUReDi extends Rectified Discrete Flows (ReDi) by incorporating (i) Tchebycheff scalarization to guide toward different Pareto-optimal tradeoffs, (ii) locally balanced proposals to improve exploration of discrete sequence space, and (iii) annealed Metropolis-Hastings updates to bias sampling toward Pareto-optimal states while preserving distributional invariance and ensuring convergence to the Pareto front.
AI.result: Applied to peptide and SMILES sequence design, enabling simultaneous optimization of up to five properties (e.g., affinity, solubility, hemolysis, half-life, non-fouling) and outperforming both evolutionary and diffusion-based baselines.
AI.conclusion: AReUReDi provides a principled, theoretically grounded, sequence-based framework for multi-property biomolecule generation with convergence guarantees to the Pareto front and strong empirical performance on practical design tasks.

title: Unveiling Interesting Insights: Monte Carlo Tree Search for Knowledge Discovery
summary:
Organizations are increasingly focused on leveraging data from their
processes to gain insights and drive decision-making. However, converting this
data into actionable knowledge remains a difficult and time-consuming task.
There is often a gap between the volume of data collected and the ability to
process and understand it, which automated knowledge discovery aims to fill.
Automated knowledge discovery involves complex open problems, including
effectively navigating data, building models to extract implicit relationships,
and considering subjective goals and knowledge. In this paper, we introduce a
novel method for Automated Insights and Data Exploration (AIDE), that serves as
a robust foundation for tackling these challenges through the use of Monte
Carlo Tree Search (MCTS). We evaluate AIDE using both real-world and synthetic
data, demonstrating its effectiveness in identifying data transformations and
models that uncover interesting data patterns. Among its strengths, AIDE's
MCTS-based framework offers significant extensibility, allowing for future
integration of additional pattern extraction strategies and domain knowledge.
This makes AIDE a valuable step towards developing a comprehensive solution for
automated knowledge discovery.

AI.tldr: AIDE uses Monte Carlo Tree Search to automate insights and data exploration, enabling scalable identification of transformations and models to reveal data patterns, with extensibility for future strategies.
AI.motivation: There is a gap between abundant data and actionable knowledge; automated knowledge discovery faces open problems in navigating data, extracting implicit relationships, and aligning with subjective goals.
AI.method: Introduce Automated Insights and Data Exploration (AIDE) leveraging Monte Carlo Tree Search to guide exploration, pattern extraction, and transformation/model discovery; evaluate on real and synthetic datasets; designed for future integration of additional strategies and domain knowledge.
AI.result: Demonstrates effectiveness in identifying data transformations and models that uncover interesting patterns; the MCTS-based framework offers extensibility for adding more strategies and domain knowledge.
AI.conclusion: AIDE is a valuable step toward automated knowledge discovery, providing a robust, extensible framework that can incorporate more pattern extraction strategies and domain knowledge for future work.

title: Robust Context-Aware Object Recognition
summary:
In visual recognition, both the object of interest (referred to as
foreground, FG, for simplicity) and its surrounding context (background, BG)
play an important role. However, standard supervised learning often leads to
unintended over-reliance on the BG, known as shortcut learning of spurious
correlations, limiting model robustness in real-world deployment settings. In
the literature, the problem is mainly addressed by suppressing the BG,
sacrificing context information for improved generalization.
  We propose RCOR -- Robust Context-Aware Object Recognition -- the first
approach that jointly achieves robustness and context-awareness without
compromising either. RCOR treats localization as an integral part of
recognition to decouple object-centric and context-aware modelling, followed by
a robust, non-parametric fusion. It improves the performance of both supervised
models and VLM on datasets with both in-domain and out-of-domain BG, even
without fine-tuning. The results confirm that localization before recognition
is now possible even in complex scenes as in ImageNet-1k.

AI.tldr: RCOR proposes a robust, context-aware object recognition framework that decouples localization from recognition and fuses FG and BG information non-parametrically to combat shortcut learning, improving robustness for supervised models and vision-language models on both in-domain and out-of-domain backgrounds, without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Standard supervised learning often relies on background cues (shortcuts) rather than object identity, causing poor robustness to domain shifts. Previous work suppresses background to gain generalization but loses contextual information; a joint approach preserving both FG and BG is needed.
AI.method: Introduce RCOR: treat localization as integral to recognition, separate object-centric and context-aware modeling, and perform a robust non-parametric fusion of outputs. Localization-before-recognition enables handling complex scenes (e.g., ImageNet-1k) and improves robustness without requiring fine-tuning on BG variations.
AI.result: RCOR improves performance for both supervised models and vision-language models on datasets with both in-domain and out-of-domain BG, even without fine-tuning; localization-before-recognition demonstrated in complex scenes like ImageNet-1k.
AI.conclusion: RCOR is the first approach to jointly achieve robustness and context-awareness without sacrificing either; by decoupling localization and recognition and robustly fusing FG/BG information, it enhances generalization in the presence of diverse BGs.

title: Continual Learning with Query-Only Attention
summary:
Continual learning involves learning from a stream of data without repetition
of data points, a scenario that is inherently complex due to distributional
shift across tasks. We propose a query-only attention mechanism that discards
keys and values, yet preserves the core inductive bias of transformer
architectures. In continual learning scenarios, this simplified mechanism
significantly mitigates both loss of plasticity and catastrophic forgetting,
outperforming baselines such as selective re-initialization. We establish a
conceptual link between query-only attention, full transformer attention, and
model agnostic meta-learning, framing them as instances of meta-learning. We
further provide intuition for why query-based models and attention networks
help preserve plasticity in continual settings. Finally, through preliminary
Hessian spectrum analysis, we observe that models maintaining higher curvature
rank across tasks tend to retain plasticity. Our findings suggest that full
attention may not be essential for capturing the benefits of meta-learning in
continual learning.

AI.tldr: A query-only attention mechanism in continual learning preserves meta-learning benefits while reducing plasticity loss and forgetting, outperforming baselines; links to meta-learning; Hessian curvature correlates with plasticity; full attention may be unnecessary.
AI.motivation: Address continual learning challenges (distributional shift, forgetting) and investigate whether simplifying attention preserves transferable inductive biases from transformers.
AI.method: Introduce query-only attention that drops keys/values; apply in continual learning setting; compare to baselines like selective re-initialization; analyze Hessian spectrum; discuss connections to full attention and model-agnostic meta-learning.
AI.result: Significant mitigation of plasticity loss and catastrophic forgetting; outperforms baselines; establishes conceptual link among query-only attention, full attention, and MAML as meta-learning instances; intuition for preservation of plasticity; Hessian analysis shows higher curvature rank across tasks associated with retained plasticity.
AI.conclusion: Full attention not essential for meta-learning benefits in continual learning; query-based attention offers a viable, simpler alternative with competitive performance and theoretical intuition.

title: FusionAdapter for Few-Shot Relation Learning in Multimodal Knowledge Graphs
summary:
Multimodal Knowledge Graphs (MMKGs) incorporate various modalities, including
text and images, to enhance entity and relation representations. Notably,
different modalities for the same entity often present complementary and
diverse information. However, existing MMKG methods primarily align modalities
into a shared space, which tends to overlook the distinct contributions of
specific modalities, limiting their performance particularly in low-resource
settings. To address this challenge, we propose FusionAdapter for the learning
of few-shot relationships (FSRL) in MMKG. FusionAdapter introduces (1) an
adapter module that enables efficient adaptation of each modality to unseen
relations and (2) a fusion strategy that integrates multimodal entity
representations while preserving diverse modality-specific characteristics. By
effectively adapting and fusing information from diverse modalities,
FusionAdapter improves generalization to novel relations with minimal
supervision. Extensive experiments on two benchmark MMKG datasets demonstrate
that FusionAdapter achieves superior performance over state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: FusionAdapter enables few-shot relation learning in multimodal knowledge graphs by using per-modality adapters and a fusion strategy to preserve modality-specific information, leading to better generalization to novel relations with limited supervision.
AI.motivation: Existing MMKG approaches typically align different modalities into a single shared space, which can obscure the unique, complementary information provided by each modality and hurts performance in low-resource or few-shot relation settings.
AI.method: Proposes an adapter module for efficient adaptation of each modality to unseen relations and a fusion strategy that integrates multimodal entity representations while preserving diverse modality-specific characteristics.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on two benchmark MMKG datasets shows FusionAdapter achieving superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: Adapting and fusing modality-specific representations via adapters improves few-shot relation learning in MMKGs, offering better generalization with minimal supervision.

title: UCD: Unconditional Discriminator Promotes Nash Equilibrium in GANs
summary:
Adversarial training turns out to be the key to one-step generation,
especially for Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) and diffusion model
distillation. Yet in practice, GAN training hardly converges properly and
struggles in mode collapse. In this work, we quantitatively analyze the extent
of Nash equilibrium in GAN training, and conclude that redundant shortcuts by
inputting condition in $D$ disables meaningful knowledge extraction. We thereby
propose to employ an unconditional discriminator (UCD), in which $D$ is
enforced to extract more comprehensive and robust features with no condition
injection. In this way, $D$ is able to leverage better knowledge to supervise
$G$, which promotes Nash equilibrium in GAN literature. Theoretical guarantee
on compatibility with vanilla GAN theory indicates that UCD can be implemented
in a plug-in manner. Extensive experiments confirm the significant performance
improvements with high efficiency. For instance, we achieved \textbf{1.47 FID}
on the ImageNet-64 dataset, surpassing StyleGAN-XL and several state-of-the-art
one-step diffusion models. The code will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: Unconditional discriminator (UCD) improves GAN training by removing conditioning on D, reducing shortcut biases and enabling D to extract more robust features, which better supervise G and promote Nash equilibrium. It’s a plug-in improvement with strong results, notably 1.47 FID on ImageNet-64, surpassing StyleGAN-XL and some diffusion models.
AI.motivation: To address instability and mode collapse in GAN training, which the authors attribute to redundant shortcuts created by conditioning inputs into the discriminator. The goal is to force D to learn richer, more robust representations that can better guide G.
AI.method: Replace the conditioned discriminator with an unconditional one (D) that does not receive conditioning information. This unconditional D is claimed to extract more comprehensive features and supervise G more effectively. The authors provide theoretical compatibility with vanilla GAN theory to show plug-in viability and perform extensive experiments to validate the approach.
AI.result: Significant performance gains and improved efficiency. Reported FID of 1.47 on ImageNet-64, beating StyleGAN-XL and several state-of-the-art one-step diffusion models.
AI.conclusion: Unconditional discriminator facilitates better knowledge extraction and supervision, helping achieve a stronger Nash equilibrium in GAN training. The approach is compatible with existing GAN frameworks as a plug-in and will be released with code.

title: The Transformer Cookbook
summary:
We present the transformer cookbook: a collection of techniques for directly
encoding algorithms into a transformer's parameters. This work addresses the
steep learning curve of such endeavors, a problem exacerbated by a fragmented
literature where key results are scattered across numerous papers. In
particular, we synthesize this disparate body of findings into a curated set of
recipes that demonstrate how to implement everything from basic arithmetic in
feed-forward layers to complex data routing via self-attention. Our mise en
place of formulations is for both newcomers seeking an accessible entry point
and experts in need of a systematic reference. This unified presentation of
transformer constructions provides a foundation for future work spanning
theoretical research in computational complexity to empirical investigations in
architecture design and interpretability.

AI.tldr: A transformer cookbook that consolidates scattered results into practical recipes for encoding algorithms in transformer parameters, offering an accessible entry point and a unified reference for both novices and experts.
AI.motivation: Encoding algorithms into transformer parameters is a steep learning curve, compounded by fragmented literature; there is a need for a unified, accessible, and reusable reference.
AI.method: Survey and synthesize existing techniques; present a curated set of
AI.result: A collection of techniques framed as recipes for implementing arithmetic and data routing in transformers, providing a unified presentation to support theory and empirical work.
AI.conclusion: Establishes a foundation for future theoretical and empirical research in computational complexity, architecture design, and interpretability, while lowering barriers for entry.

title: On Discovering Algorithms for Adversarial Imitation Learning
summary:
Adversarial Imitation Learning (AIL) methods, while effective in settings
with limited expert demonstrations, are often considered unstable. These
approaches typically decompose into two components: Density Ratio (DR)
estimation $\frac{\rho_E}{\rho_{\pi}}$, where a discriminator estimates the
relative occupancy of state-action pairs under the policy versus the expert;
and Reward Assignment (RA), where this ratio is transformed into a reward
signal used to train the policy. While significant research has focused on
improving density estimation, the role of reward assignment in influencing
training dynamics and final policy performance has been largely overlooked. RA
functions in AIL are typically derived from divergence minimization objectives,
relying heavily on human design and ingenuity. In this work, we take a
different approach: we investigate the discovery of data-driven RA functions,
i.e, based directly on the performance of the resulting imitation policy. To
this end, we leverage an LLM-guided evolutionary framework that efficiently
explores the space of RA functions, yielding \emph{Discovered Adversarial
Imitation Learning} (DAIL), the first meta-learnt AIL algorithm. Remarkably,
DAIL generalises across unseen environments and policy optimization algorithms,
outperforming the current state-of-the-art of \emph{human-designed} baselines.
Finally, we analyse why DAIL leads to more stable training, offering novel
insights into the role of RA functions in the stability of AIL. Code is
publicly available: https://github.com/shshnkreddy/DAIL.

AI.tldr: Discovered Adversarial Imitation Learning (DAIL) introduces a data-driven, meta-learned reward assignment (RA) function for Adversarial Imitation Learning, discovered via an LLM-guided evolutionary search; it improves stability and generalization, outperforming human-designed baselines.
AI.motivation: RA design in Adversarial Imitation Learning is underexplored and highly influential on training dynamics, yet most work focuses on density ratio estimation. Automating RA discovery could enhance stability and performance across tasks and optimization algorithms.
AI.method: Model RA as a function of the density ratio ρ_E/ρ_π. Use an LLM-guided evolutionary framework to explore the space of RA functions and meta-learn a robust AIL algorithm (DAIL). Evaluate on unseen environments and against different policy optimization methods; provide public code.
AI.result: DAIL generalizes to unseen environments and policy optimization algorithms and outperforms current state-of-the-art human-designed RA baselines. The work offers insights into why RA affects training stability in AIL.
AI.conclusion: Data-driven discovery of RA functions can enhance the stability and performance of AIL and yields a generalizable meta-learnt algorithm. The approach shifts RA design from human-crafted to automated, with potential for broader applicability; code is publicly available.

title: Virtual Fashion Photo-Shoots: Building a Large-Scale Garment-Lookbook Dataset
summary:
Fashion image generation has so far focused on narrow tasks such as virtual
try-on, where garments appear in clean studio environments. In contrast,
editorial fashion presents garments through dynamic poses, diverse locations,
and carefully crafted visual narratives. We introduce the task of virtual
fashion photo-shoot, which seeks to capture this richness by transforming
standardized garment images into contextually grounded editorial imagery. To
enable this new direction, we construct the first large-scale dataset of
garment-lookbook pairs, bridging the gap between e-commerce and fashion media.
Because such pairs are not readily available, we design an automated retrieval
pipeline that aligns garments across domains, combining visual-language
reasoning with object-level localization. We construct a dataset with three
garment-lookbook pair accuracy levels: high quality (10,000 pairs), medium
quality (50,000 pairs), and low quality (300,000 pairs). This dataset offers a
foundation for models that move beyond catalog-style generation and toward
fashion imagery that reflects creativity, atmosphere, and storytelling.

AI.tldr: Introduces virtual fashion photo-shoot and a large-scale garment-lookbook dataset via an automated cross-domain retrieval pipeline to generate editorial fashion imagery beyond catalog-like outputs.
AI.motivation: Bridging the gap between narrow generation tasks (like virtual try-on) and editorial fashion needs; addressing the lack of cross-domain data that links garments with fashion lookbooks, enabling creative, narrative imagery.
AI.method: An automated retrieval pipeline that combines visual-language reasoning with object-level localization to align garments across domains, constructing a garment-lookbook pair dataset with three quality tiers (high:10k, medium:50k, low:300k).
AI.result: Created the first large-scale garment-lookbook pairs dataset and a cross-domain retrieval framework, establishing a foundation for models that generate contextually grounded editorial fashion imagery rather than catalog-style outputs.
AI.conclusion: The dataset and method pave the way for editorial, narrative fashion imagery that reflects creativity, atmosphere, and storytelling, bridging e-commerce garments with fashion media.

title: Combining Large Language Models and Gradient-Free Optimization for Automatic Control Policy Synthesis
summary:
Large Language models (LLMs) have shown promise as generators of symbolic
control policies, producing interpretable program-like representations through
iterative search. However, these models are not capable of separating the
functional structure of a policy from the numerical values it is parametrized
by, thus making the search process slow and inefficient. We propose a hybrid
approach that decouples structural synthesis from parameter optimization by
introducing an additional optimization layer for local parameter search. In our
method, the numerical parameters of LLM-generated programs are extracted and
optimized numerically to maximize task performance. With this integration, an
LLM iterates over the functional structure of programs, while a separate
optimization loop is used to find a locally optimal set of parameters
accompanying candidate programs. We evaluate our method on a set of control
tasks, showing that it achieves higher returns and improved sample efficiency
compared to purely LLM-guided search. We show that combining symbolic program
synthesis with numerical optimization yields interpretable yet high-performing
policies, bridging the gap between language-model-guided design and classical
control tuning. Our code is available at
https://sites.google.com/berkeley.edu/colmo.

AI.tldr: Hybrid framework: LLMs synthesize symbolic control program structures while a separate optimization loop tunes numerical parameters, yielding interpretable yet high-performing policies.
AI.motivation: LLMs can generate symbolic, interpretable program-like policies but struggle to disentangle structure from numerical values, making search inefficient; there is a need to couple symbolic policy synthesis with efficient numerical tuning to improve performance while preserving interpretability.
AI.method: Decouple synthesis and optimization: extract numerical parameters from LLM-generated programs and optimize them with a dedicated local search loop to maximize task performance; the LLM alternates over functional structure while the optimization loop finds locally optimal parameters for candidate programs.
AI.result: On a set of control tasks, the method achieves higher returns and better sample efficiency compared to purely LLM-guided search, indicating that symbolic-program synthesis plus numerical optimization yields interpretable yet high-performing policies.
AI.conclusion: Integrating symbolic program synthesis with numerical optimization bridges language-model-guided design and classical control tuning, producing interpretable, high-performing policies. The work provides a practical pathway and code resources for this hybrid approach.

title: Test-Time Search in Neural Graph Coarsening Procedures for the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem
summary:
The identification of valid inequalities, such as the rounded capacity
inequalities (RCIs), is a key component of cutting plane methods for the
Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP). While a deep learning-based
separation method can learn to find high-quality cuts, our analysis reveals
that the model produces fewer cuts than expected because it is insufficiently
sensitive to generate a diverse set of generated subsets. This paper proposes
an alternative: enhancing the performance of a trained model at inference time
through a new test-time search with stochasticity. First, we introduce
stochastic edge selection into the graph coarsening procedure, replacing the
previously proposed greedy approach. Second, we propose the Graph Coarsening
History-based Partitioning (GraphCHiP) algorithm, which leverages coarsening
history to identify not only RCIs but also, for the first time, the Framed
capacity inequalities (FCIs). Experiments on randomly generated CVRP instances
demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing the dual gap compared
to the existing neural separation method. Additionally, our method discovers
effective FCIs on a specific instance, despite the challenging nature of
identifying such cuts.

AI.tldr: A neural separation method for RCIs in CVRP is enhanced by a test-time stochastic graph coarsening approach called GraphCHiP, which improves dual bounds and uncovers FCIs.
AI.motivation: DL-based separation for RCIs yields too few and not diverse cuts; need inference-time improvements and ability to identify FCIs.
AI.method: Introduce stochastic edge selection in graph coarsening; GraphCHiP leverages coarsening history to identify RCIs and FCIs; perform a test-time search with stochasticity.
AI.result: On randomly generated CVRP instances, the approach reduces the dual gap compared to prior neural separation; it also discovers effective FCIs on at least one instance.
AI.conclusion: Inference-time stochastic graph coarsening improves neural separation for CVRP and enables FCIs discovery, highlighting potential for stronger cuts in cutting-plane methods.

title: LAKAN: Landmark-assisted Adaptive Kolmogorov-Arnold Network for Face Forgery Detection
comment:
5 pages, 3 figures. This work has been submitted to the IEEE for
  possible publication
summary:
The rapid development of deepfake generation techniques necessitates robust
face forgery detection algorithms. While methods based on Convolutional Neural
Networks (CNNs) and Transformers are effective, there is still room for
improvement in modeling the highly complex and non-linear nature of forgery
artifacts. To address this issue, we propose a novel detection method based on
the Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN). By replacing fixed activation functions
with learnable splines, our KAN-based approach is better suited to this
challenge. Furthermore, to guide the network's focus towards critical facial
areas, we introduce a Landmark-assisted Adaptive Kolmogorov-Arnold Network
(LAKAN) module. This module uses facial landmarks as a structural prior to
dynamically generate the internal parameters of the KAN, creating an
instance-specific signal that steers a general-purpose image encoder towards
the most informative facial regions with artifacts. This core innovation
creates a powerful combination between geometric priors and the network's
learning process. Extensive experiments on multiple public datasets show that
our proposed method achieves superior performance.

AI.tldr: A Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) detector with learnable spline activations and a Landmark-assisted LAKAN module, guiding learning with facial landmarks to focus on artifact-rich regions, achieving superior deepfake detection across datasets.
AI.motivation: CNNs and Transformers struggle to model highly non-linear forgery artifacts; there is a need for richer nonlinear modeling and explicit geometric priors (facial landmarks) to guide attention to informative regions.
AI.method: Replace fixed activations in KAN with learnable spline activations. Introduce a Landmark-assisted Adaptive Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (LAKAN) module that uses facial landmarks as a structural prior to dynamically generate KAN's internal parameters, steering a general-purpose image encoder toward facial regions with artifacts.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple public datasets show superior performance compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: The approach effectively combines geometric priors with a learnable Kolmogorov-Arnold framework, yielding improved deepfake detection performance.

title: GDLNN: Marriage of Programming Language and Neural Networks for Accurate and Easy-to-Explain Graph Classification
summary:
We present GDLNN, a new graph machine learning architecture, for graph
classification tasks. GDLNN combines a domain-specific programming language,
called GDL, with neural networks. The main strength of GDLNN lies in its GDL
layer, which generates expressive and interpretable graph representations.
