Since the graph representation is interpretable, existing model explanation
techniques can be directly applied to explain GDLNN's predictions. Our
evaluation shows that the GDL-based representation achieves high accuracy on
most graph classification benchmark datasets, outperforming dominant graph
learning methods such as GNNs. Applying an existing model explanation technique
also yields high-quality explanations of GDLNN's predictions. Furthermore, the
cost of GDLNN is low when the explanation cost is included.

AI.tldr: GDLNN is a graph classification model that uses a domain-specific language layer (GDL) to create interpretable graph representations, achieving strong accuracy and enabling direct explanations; it outperforms GNNs on benchmarks and becomes cheaper overall when explanation costs are included.
AI.motivation: There is a demand for interpretable, explainable graph learning. By combining a domain-specific language with neural networks, GDLNN aims to produce expressive, interpretable graph representations and leverage existing explanation techniques.
AI.method: Introduce GDLNN architecture with a GDL layer that generates graph representations; train end-to-end; apply existing model explanation techniques to explanations of predictions; benchmark against dominant graph learning methods (e.g., GNNs) and perform cost analysis including explanation costs.
AI.result: GDL-based representations achieve high accuracy on graph classification benchmarks, outperforming dominant methods such as GNNs; explanations are of high quality when using existing techniques; including explanation cost lowers overall cost.
AI.conclusion: GDLNN delivers expressive and interpretable graph representations, enabling straightforward explanations and competitive performance, with cost advantages when explanation costs are considered.

title: A Neuro-Fuzzy System for Interpretable Long-Term Stock Market Forecasting
comment:
Published in: ERK 2025 -- 34th International Electrotechnical and
  Computer Science Conference, Portoro\v{z}, Slovenia, Sept. 25--26, 2025.
  Proceedings published by Dru\v{s}tvo Slovenska sekcija IEEE. ISSN: 2591-0442
  (online). 4 pages, 2 figures
summary:
In the complex landscape of multivariate time series forecasting, achieving
both accuracy and interpretability remains a significant challenge. This paper
introduces the Fuzzy Transformer (Fuzzformer), a novel recurrent neural network
architecture combined with multi-head self-attention and fuzzy inference
systems to analyze multivariate stock market data and conduct long-term time
series forecasting. The method leverages LSTM networks and temporal attention
to condense multivariate data into interpretable features suitable for fuzzy
inference systems. The resulting architecture offers comparable forecasting
performance to conventional models such as ARIMA and LSTM while providing
meaningful information flow within the network. The method was examined on the
real world stock market index S\&P500. Initial results show potential for
interpretable forecasting and identify current performance tradeoffs,
suggesting practical application in understanding and forecasting stock market
behavior.

AI.tldr: A fuzzy transformer (Fuzzformer) combines LSTM-based recurrence, temporal attention, and fuzzy inference to forecast multivariate stock time series, aiming for interpretability with comparable accuracy to ARIMA/LSTM on S&P 500 data.
AI.motivation: To address the persistent tradeoff between forecasting accuracy and interpretability in multivariate time series, particularly in finance, by integrating fuzzy inference with neural attention mechanisms.
AI.method: A hybrid architecture that uses LSTM networks with temporal attention to condense multivariate inputs into interpretable features, which are then processed by fuzzy inference systems within a transformer-like framework aimed at long-term forecasting of stock data (S&P 500).
AI.result: The model achieves forecasting performance comparable to traditional models such as ARIMA and LSTM while enabling meaningful information flow and interpretability within the network; evaluated on the S&P 500 index with initial results highlighting interpretability gains and tradeoffs between accuracy and explainability.
AI.conclusion: Fuzzformer shows potential for interpretable long-term forecasting in financial multivariate time series, offering a usable balance between accuracy and interpretability, but with ongoing tradeoffs to optimize; practical application appears feasible given current results.

title: Erased, But Not Forgotten: Erased Rectified Flow Transformers Still Remain Unsafe Under Concept Attack
summary:
Recent advances in text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have enabled
impressive generative capabilities, but they also raise significant safety
concerns due to the potential to produce harmful or undesirable content. While
concept erasure has been explored as a mitigation strategy, most existing
approaches and corresponding attack evaluations are tailored to Stable
Diffusion (SD) and exhibit limited effectiveness when transferred to
next-generation rectified flow transformers such as Flux. In this work, we
present ReFlux, the first concept attack method specifically designed to assess
the robustness of concept erasure in the latest rectified flow-based T2I
framework. Our approach is motivated by the observation that existing concept
erasure techniques, when applied to Flux, fundamentally rely on a phenomenon
known as attention localization. Building on this insight, we propose a simple
yet effective attack strategy that specifically targets this property. At its
core, a reverse-attention optimization strategy is introduced to effectively
reactivate suppressed signals while stabilizing attention. This is further
reinforced by a velocity-guided dynamic that enhances the robustness of concept
reactivation by steering the flow matching process, and a
consistency-preserving objective that maintains the global layout and preserves
unrelated content. Extensive experiments consistently demonstrate the
effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed attack method, establishing a
reliable benchmark for evaluating the robustness of concept erasure strategies
in rectified flow transformers.

AI.tldr: Introduces ReFlux, a reverse-attention attack on concept erasure for Flux T2I models, achieving robust reactivation of erased concepts via velocity-guided dynamics and a consistency objective, with strong experimental results.
AI.motivation: Safety concerns in text-to-image generation; existing concept erasure methods are largely tuned to Stable Diffusion and do not transfer well to newer rectified-flow transformers like Flux, necessitating a robust evaluation framework.
AI.method: Reverse-attention optimization that reactivates suppressed signals while stabilizing attention, combined with velocity-guided dynamics to steer the flow-matching process, and a consistency-preserving objective to maintain global layout and unrelated content.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the attack, establishing a reliable benchmark for evaluating the robustness of concept erasure strategies in rectified flow transformers.
AI.conclusion: ReFlux provides a practical tool to evaluate and stress-test concept erasure in Flux, highlights vulnerabilities of attention-localization-based erasure in rectified-flow models, and calls for stronger defenses and broader benchmarking.

title: Multidimensional Bayesian Active Machine Learning of Working Memory Task Performance
summary:
While adaptive experimental design has outgrown one-dimensional,
staircase-based adaptations, most cognitive experiments still control a single
factor and summarize performance with a scalar. We show a validation of a
Bayesian, two-axis, active-classification approach, carried out in an immersive
virtual testing environment for a 5-by-5 working-memory reconstruction task.
Two variables are controlled: spatial load L (number of occupied tiles) and
feature-binding load K (number of distinct colors) of items. Stimulus
acquisition is guided by posterior uncertainty of a nonparametric Gaussian
Process (GP) probabilistic classifier, which outputs a surface over (L, K)
rather than a single threshold or max span value. In a young adult population,
we compare GP-driven Adaptive Mode (AM) with a traditional adaptive staircase
Classic Mode (CM), which varies L only at K = 3. Parity between the methods is
achieved for this cohort, with an intraclass coefficient of 0.755 at K = 3.
Additionally, AM reveals individual differences in interactions between spatial
load and feature binding. AM estimates converge more quickly than other
sampling strategies, demonstrating that only about 30 samples are required for
accurate fitting of the full model.

AI.tldr: A Bayesian, two-axis adaptive design using a GP classifier maps performance over spatial load (L) and feature-binding load (K) in a VR memory task, enabling faster, more informative sampling and revealing interactions that single-factor methods miss.
AI.motivation: To advance adaptive experimental designs beyond single-factor staircases by modeling a two-dimensional performance surface, capturing interactions between spatial load and feature-binding load, and improving efficiency in data collection.
AI.method: Employ a Bayesian active-classification framework with a nonparametric Gaussian Process classifier to produce a surface over (L, K) rather than a scalar threshold. Compare GP-driven Adaptive Mode (AM) to Classic Mode (CM) in young adults on a 5×5 working-memory reconstruction task in immersive VR. AM guides stimulus acquisition via posterior uncertainty to select informative (L,K) conditions.
AI.result: AM and CM are parity at K=3 (ICC = 0.755). AM uncovers individual differences in L–K interactions, and AM converges faster, needing roughly 30 samples to fit the full model.
AI.conclusion: Two-axis Bayesian adaptive design with a GP classifier is effective for multi-factor cognitive tasks, enabling quicker, richer estimation of the performance surface and revealing individual differences not captured by single-factor approaches.

title: QUASAR: Quantum Assembly Code Generation Using Tool-Augmented LLMs via Agentic RL
summary:
Designing and optimizing task-specific quantum circuits are crucial to
leverage the advantage of quantum computing. Recent large language model
(LLM)-based quantum circuit generation has emerged as a promising automatic
solution. However, the fundamental challenges remain unaddressed: (i)
parameterized quantum gates require precise numerical values for optimal
performance, which also depend on multiple aspects, including the number of
quantum gates, their parameters, and the layout/depth of the circuits. (ii)
LLMs often generate low-quality or incorrect quantum circuits due to the lack
of quantum domain-specific knowledge. We propose QUASAR, an agentic
reinforcement learning (RL) framework for quantum circuits generation and
optimization based on tool-augmented LLMs. To align the LLM with
quantum-specific knowledge and improve the generated quantum circuits, QUASAR
designs (i) a quantum circuit verification approach with external quantum
simulators and (ii) a sophisticated hierarchical reward mechanism in RL
training. Extensive evaluation shows improvements in both syntax and semantic
performance of the generated quantum circuits. When augmenting a 4B LLM, QUASAR
has achieved the validity of 99.31% in Pass@1 and 100% in Pass@10,
outperforming industrial LLMs of GPT-4o, GPT-5 and DeepSeek-V3 and several
supervised-fine-tuning (SFT)-only and RL-only baselines.

AI.tldr: QUASAR is an agentic reinforcement learning framework that uses tool-augmented LLMs to generate and optimize quantum circuits. It employs external quantum simulators for verification and a hierarchical reward mechanism, achieving near-perfect validity on a 4B LLM and outperforming GPT-4o, GPT-5, DeepSeek-V3, and several baselines.
AI.motivation: Current LLM-based quantum circuit generation suffers from two main issues: (1) parameterized quantum gates require precise numerical values influenced by circuit size, depth, and layout; (2) LLMs lack deep quantum-domain knowledge, leading to syntactically or semantically incorrect circuits. There is a need to align LLMs with quantum-specific knowledge and to verify generated circuits using real quantum simulators.
AI.method: QUASAR integrates an agentic reinforcement learning framework with tool-augmented LLMs. It (i) uses external quantum simulators to verify circuit correctness, (ii) employs a sophisticated hierarchical reward mechanism during RL training to align generated circuits with quantum-domain requirements, and (iii) leverages tool augmentation to provide LLMs with simulator feedback and quantum-domain guidance.
AI.result: The framework yields improvements in both syntax and semantic quality of generated circuits. In experiments augmenting a 4B LLM, QUASAR achieves Pass@1 of 99.31% and Pass@10 of 100%, outperforming industrial LLMs (GPT-4o, GPT-5, DeepSeek-V3) and multiple SFT-only or RL-only baselines.
AI.conclusion: QUASAR effectively aligns LLMs with quantum-domain knowledge and validates circuits via external simulators, demonstrating that agentic RL with tool-augmented LLMs can produce high-quality task-specific quantum circuits and scale to competitive LLMs. This approach may generalize to other domains requiring precise parameterization and domain-specific verification.

title: FIN: Fast Inference Network for Map Segmentation
summary:
Multi-sensor fusion in autonomous vehicles is becoming more common to offer a
more robust alternative for several perception tasks. This need arises from the
unique contribution of each sensor in collecting data: camera-radar fusion
offers a cost-effective solution by combining rich semantic information from
cameras with accurate distance measurements from radar, without incurring
excessive financial costs or overwhelming data processing requirements. Map
segmentation is a critical task for enabling effective vehicle behaviour in its
environment, yet it continues to face significant challenges in achieving high
accuracy and meeting real-time performance requirements. Therefore, this work
presents a novel and efficient map segmentation architecture, using cameras and
radars, in the \acrfull{bev} space. Our model introduces a real-time map
segmentation architecture considering aspects such as high accuracy, per-class
balancing, and inference time. To accomplish this, we use an advanced loss set
together with a new lightweight head to improve the perception results. Our
results show that, with these modifications, our approach achieves results
comparable to large models, reaching 53.5 mIoU, while also setting a new
benchmark for inference time, improving it by 260\% over the strongest baseline
models.

AI.tldr: A real-time BEV map segmentation model that fuses cameras and radar for accurate, fast perception, achieving 53.5 mIoU with significantly faster inference than baselines.
AI.motivation: Map segmentation is essential for autonomous driving and must balance high accuracy with real-time performance; camera–radar fusion provides rich semantics and accurate depth at a lower cost.
AI.method: A novel, lightweight BEV architecture using camera and radar inputs, a new lightweight head, and an advanced loss set with per-class balancing to improve perception results and inference speed.
AI.result: Achieves 53.5 mIoU, comparable to large models, while delivering a new benchmark in inference speed with a 260% speedup over the strongest baselines.
AI.conclusion: The proposed camera–radar BEV map segmentation framework delivers high accuracy and real-time performance, validating the usefulness of multi-sensor fusion and a compact design for perception tasks.

title: Composer: A Search Framework for Hybrid Neural Architecture Design
summary:
Hybrid model architectures that combine computational primitives (e.g.,
Attention, MLP) in different ratios have shown promising performance beyond
Transformers. Some studies have shown that different interleavings of
primitives can affect model quality as well. However, prior works explore the
hybrid model architecture design space manually. Due to the large design space
and training costs, discovering hybrid models that combine key computational
primitives for pre-training is challenging. In this work, we take a principled
approach in designing a modular hybrid model architecture search framework --
Composer. Composer explores model architectures at a small scale and
extrapolates the top-performing model architectures to a larger scale using our
proposed scaling strategies. Using Composer, we discover new hybrid LLM
architectures that outperform Llama 3.2. Compared to Llama 3.2 and previous
state-of-the-art baselines, the new model architectures consistently reduce
validation loss at parameter scales of 350M-3B and improve evaluation accuracy
on the downstream tasks by up to 2.8-8.3% (1.1-3.1% on average) while improving
both training and inference efficiency.

AI.tldr: Composer: a modular hybrid-model architecture search framework that automatically discovers hybrid LLMs by exploring primitive interleavings at small scale and extrapolating to larger scales, achieving improvements over Llama 3.2 in validation loss and downstream accuracy with better training/inference efficiency.
AI.motivation: Hybrid architectures combining different computational primitives (e.g., Attention, MLP) can surpass standard Transformers, but manual design is infeasible due to a large design space and high training costs. A principled, scalable search framework is needed to identify effective hybrids at pre-training scales.
AI.method: A two-stage approach: perform architecture search on small-scale models to identify top-performing primitive interleavings, then apply proposed scaling strategies to extrapolate these architectures to larger scales. The framework, Composer, is used to discover hybrid LLMs and compare them against baselines like Llama 3.2.
AI.result: New hybrid LLM architectures discovered by Composer consistently reduce validation loss at parameter scales of 350M–3B and improve downstream task accuracy by up to 2.8–8.3% (average 1.1–3.1%), outperforming Llama 3.2 and previous baselines, while also improving training and inference efficiency.
AI.conclusion: A principled, scalable modular architecture search framework can effectively design hybrid models that outperform existing transformers and improve efficiency. Composer demonstrates strong empirical gains at moderate parameter scales and provides a viable path for automated hybrid-model discovery in pre-training.

title: Adaptive Federated Few-Shot Rare-Disease Diagnosis with Energy-Aware Secure Aggregation
summary:
Rare-disease diagnosis remains one of the most pressing challenges in digital
health, hindered by extreme data scarcity, privacy concerns, and the limited
resources of edge devices. This paper proposes the Adaptive Federated Few-Shot
Rare-Disease Diagnosis (AFFR) framework, which integrates three pillars: (i)
few-shot federated optimization with meta-learning to generalize from limited
patient samples, (ii) energy-aware client scheduling to mitigate device
dropouts and ensure balanced participation, and (iii) secure aggregation with
calibrated differential privacy to safeguard sensitive model updates. Unlike
prior work that addresses these aspects in isolation, AFFR unifies them into a
modular pipeline deployable on real-world clinical networks. Experimental
evaluation on simulated rare-disease detection datasets demonstrates up to 10%
improvement in accuracy compared with baseline FL, while reducing client
dropouts by over 50% without degrading convergence. Furthermore,
privacy-utility trade-offs remain within clinically acceptable bounds. These
findings highlight AFFR as a practical pathway for equitable and trustworthy
federated diagnosis of rare conditions.

AI.tldr: An integrated federated learning framework (AFFR) for rare-disease diagnosis that combines few-shot meta-learning, energy-aware client scheduling, and calibrated DP-secure aggregation to enable privacy-preserving, robust edge-device deployment with limited data.
AI.motivation: Tackle extreme data scarcity, privacy concerns, and device constraints in rare-disease diagnosis, where centralized data sharing is impractical.
AI.method: Three-pillared modular pipeline: (i) few-shot federated optimization with meta-learning to generalize from small patient samples; (ii) energy-aware client scheduling to reduce dropouts and balance participation; (iii) secure aggregation with calibrated differential privacy to protect model updates; evaluated on simulated datasets; achieves better accuracy and robustness than baseline FL.
AI.result: Up to 10% accuracy improvement over baseline FL; >50% reduction in client dropouts; privacy-utility trade-offs within clinically acceptable bounds.
AI.conclusion: AFFR provides a practical, equitable, and trustworthy framework for federated rare-disease diagnosis that can be deployed in real-world clinical networks.

title: OTTER: Open-Tagging via Text-Image Representation for Multi-modal Understanding
summary:
We introduce OTTER, a unified open-set multi-label tagging framework that
harmonizes the stability of a curated, predefined category set with the
adaptability of user-driven open tags. OTTER is built upon a large-scale,
hierarchically organized multi-modal dataset, collected from diverse online
repositories and annotated through a hybrid pipeline combining automated
vision-language labeling with human refinement. By leveraging a multi-head
attention architecture, OTTER jointly aligns visual and textual representations
with both fixed and open-set label embeddings, enabling dynamic and
semantically consistent tagging. OTTER consistently outperforms competitive
baselines on two benchmark datasets: it achieves an overall F1 score of 0.81 on
Otter and 0.75 on Favorite, surpassing the next-best results by margins of 0.10
and 0.02, respectively. OTTER attains near-perfect performance on open-set
labels, with F1 of 0.99 on Otter and 0.97 on Favorite, while maintaining
competitive accuracy on predefined labels. These results demonstrate OTTER's
effectiveness in bridging closed-set consistency with open-vocabulary
flexibility for multi-modal tagging applications.

AI.tldr: OTTER introduces a unified open-set multi-label tagging framework that blends fixed predefined categories with open-set tags using a multi-head attention model over a large hierarchical multi-modal dataset, achieving strong closed-set and near-perfect open-set results on two benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To reconcile the stability of predefined label vocabularies with the flexibility of open-set tagging in multi-modal scenarios, addressing limitations of purely closed or open vocabulary approaches.
AI.method: OTTER uses a hierarchical, large-scale multimodal dataset annotated by automated vision-language labeling with human refinement; a multi-head attention architecture jointly aligns visual and textual features with both fixed and open-set label embeddings to enable dynamic, semantically consistent tagging.
AI.result: Outperforms competitive baselines on Otter (F1 0.81) and Favorite (F1 0.75; margins 0.10 and 0.02). Open-set F1 near-perfect (0.99 on Otter, 0.97 on Favorite). Maintains competitive accuracy on predefined labels.
AI.conclusion: OTTER demonstrates that it is possible to bridge closed-set consistency with open-vocabulary flexibility in multi-modal tagging, enabling robust open-set tagging applications.

title: Efficient Probabilistic Tensor Networks
summary:
Tensor networks (TNs) enable compact representations of large tensors through
shared parameters. Their use in probabilistic modeling is particularly
appealing, as probabilistic tensor networks (PTNs) allow for tractable
computation of marginals. However, existing approaches for learning parameters
of PTNs are either computationally demanding and not fully compatible with
automatic differentiation frameworks, or numerically unstable. In this work, we
propose a conceptually simple approach for learning PTNs efficiently, that is
numerically stable. We show our method provides significant improvements in
time and space complexity, achieving 10x reduction in latency for generative
modeling on the MNIST dataset. Furthermore, our approach enables learning of
distributions with 10x more variables than previous approaches when applied to
a variety of density estimation benchmarks. Our code is publicly available at
github.com/marawangamal/ptn.

AI.tldr: A simple, numerically stable learning method for probabilistic tensor networks (PTNs) that dramatically improves efficiency and scalability, enabling larger-scale density estimation and faster generative modeling.
AI.motivation: PTNs promise tractable marginals, but existing learning methods are slow or unstable and are not fully compatible with automatic differentiation frameworks; there is a need for a stable, scalable, differentiable training approach.
AI.method: A conceptually simple, automatic-differentiation-friendly learning approach for PTNs that improves time and space complexity and numerical stability.
AI.result: Significant improvements in time and space complexity; 10x reduction in latency for generative modeling on MNIST; enables learning distributions with 10x more variables on density estimation benchmarks; code released.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method makes PTNs practical for large-scale probabilistic modeling by delivering stability and efficiency gains, enabling broader adoption and scalability.

title: Integrating AI and Ensemble Forecasting: Explainable Materials Planning with Scorecards and Trend Insights for a Large-Scale Manufacturer
summary:
This paper presents a practical architecture for after-sales demand
forecasting and monitoring that unifies a revenue- and cluster-aware ensemble
of statistical, machine-learning, and deep-learning models with a role-driven
analytics layer for scorecards and trend diagnostics. The framework ingests
exogenous signals (installed base, pricing, macro indicators, life cycle,
seasonality) and treats COVID-19 as a distinct regime, producing country-part
forecasts with calibrated intervals. A Pareto-aware segmentation forecasts
high-revenue items individually and pools the long tail via clusters, while
horizon-aware ensembling aligns weights with business-relevant losses (e.g.,
WMAPE). Beyond forecasts, a performance scorecard delivers decision-focused
insights: accuracy within tolerance thresholds by revenue share and count, bias
decomposition (over- vs under-forecast), geographic and product-family
hotspots, and ranked root causes tied to high-impact part-country pairs. A
trend module tracks trajectories of MAPE/WMAPE and bias across recent months,
flags entities that are improving or deteriorating, detects change points
aligned with known regimes, and attributes movements to lifecycle and seasonal
factors. LLMs are embedded in the analytics layer to generate role-aware
narratives and enforce reporting contracts. They standardize business
definitions, automate quality checks and reconciliations, and translate
quantitative results into concise, explainable summaries for planners and
executives. The system exposes a reproducible workflow -- request
specification, model execution, database-backed artifacts, and AI-generated
narratives -- so planners can move from "How accurate are we now?" to "Where is
accuracy heading and which levers should we pull?", closing the loop between
forecasting, monitoring, and inventory decisions across more than 90 countries
and about 6,000 parts.

AI.tldr: A practical, end-to-end forecasting and monitoring framework for after-sales demand that unifies diverse models, segmentation, and AI narratives to support inventory decisions across 90+ countries and ~6k parts.
AI.motivation: To deliver calibrated, actionable forecasts with explainability and governance that tie forecasting performance to business impact and enable proactive inventory management in a global, regime-shifting environment (e.g., COVID-19).
AI.method: A revenue- and cluster-aware ensemble of statistical, ML, and deep-learning models; exogenous signals; regime-aware handling of COVID-19; Pareto-aware segmentation with high-revenue items forecasted individually and long tail pooled in clusters; horizon-aware ensemble weighting by business losses; performance scorecard with accuracy, bias, and hotspot metrics; trend module tracking MAPE/WMAPE and bias; LLMs for role-aware narratives and reporting contracts; reproducible workflow with request spec, model execution, artifacts, AI narratives; deployment across 90+ countries and 6,000 parts.
AI.result: Country-part forecasts with calibrated intervals; improved focus on high-revenue items; interpretable insights (bias, hotspots, root causes); trend tracking and regime-change detection; AI-generated narratives; an end-to-end workflow enabling data-driven inventory decisions.
AI.conclusion: The framework delivers scalable, explainable, and decision-focused forecasting and monitoring that connects forecasting accuracy to business levers, enabling planners to identify where accuracy is heading and which actions to take.

title: Weakly Supervised Cloud Detection Combining Spectral Features and Multi-Scale Deep Network
summary:
Clouds significantly affect the quality of optical satellite images, which
seriously limits their precise application. Recently, deep learning has been
widely applied to cloud detection and has achieved satisfactory results.
However, the lack of distinctive features in thin clouds and the low quality of
training samples limit the cloud detection accuracy of deep learning methods,
leaving space for further improvements. In this paper, we propose a weakly
supervised cloud detection method that combines spectral features and
multi-scale scene-level deep network (SpecMCD) to obtain highly accurate
pixel-level cloud masks. The method first utilizes a progressive training
framework with a multi-scale scene-level dataset to train the multi-scale
scene-level cloud detection network. Pixel-level cloud probability maps are
then obtained by combining the multi-scale probability maps and cloud thickness
map based on the characteristics of clouds in dense cloud coverage and large
cloud-area coverage images. Finally, adaptive thresholds are generated based on
the differentiated regions of the scene-level cloud masks at different scales
and combined with distance-weighted optimization to obtain binary cloud masks.
Two datasets, WDCD and GF1MS-WHU, comprising a total of 60 Gaofen-1
multispectral (GF1-MS) images, were used to verify the effectiveness of the
proposed method. Compared to the other weakly supervised cloud detection
methods such as WDCD and WSFNet, the F1-score of the proposed SpecMCD method
shows an improvement of over 7.82%, highlighting the superiority and potential
of the SpecMCD method for cloud detection under different cloud coverage
conditions.

AI.tldr: A weakly supervised, multi-scale scene-level cloud detection network (SpecMCD) detects pixel-level clouds by fusing spectral features, multi-scale probability maps, and cloud-thickness cues with adaptive thresholds and distance-weighted optimization, outperforming baselines (WDCD/WSFNet) by ~7.8% F1 on WDCD and GF1MS-WHU datasets.
AI.motivation: Cloud contamination degrades optical satellite imagery; thin clouds lack distinctive spectral cues and high-quality labeled data is scarce. A weakly supervised, multi-scale approach leveraging scene-level context could improve cloud detection accuracy.
AI.method: A progressive training framework for a multi-scale scene-level cloud detection network. Pixel-level cloud probability maps are created by combining multi-scale probability maps with a cloud thickness map. Adaptive thresholds are generated per region and scale, then fused with distance-weighted optimization to yield binary cloud masks. Evaluated on two datasets (WDCD and GF1MS-WHU) comprising 60 GF1-MS images.
AI.result: The SpecMCD method achieves higher accuracy than other weakly supervised methods such as WDCD and WSFNet, with an F1-score improvement of over 7.82%.
AI.conclusion: SpecMCD demonstrates strong performance for cloud detection under varying cloud coverage and showcases the potential of weakly supervised, multi-scale approaches for improving pixel-level cloud masks.

title: Learning Passive Continuous-Time Dynamics with Multistep Port-Hamiltonian Gaussian Processes
summary:
We propose the multistep port-Hamiltonian Gaussian process (MS-PHS GP) to
learn physically consistent continuous-time dynamics and a posterior over the
Hamiltonian from noisy, irregularly-sampled trajectories. By placing a GP prior
on the Hamiltonian surface $H$ and encoding variable-step multistep integrator
constraints as finite linear functionals, MS-PHS GP enables closed-form
conditioning of both the vector field and the Hamiltonian surface without
latent states, while enforcing energy balance and passivity by design. We state
a finite-sample vector-field bound that separates the estimation and
variable-step discretization terms. Lastly, we demonstrate improved
vector-field recovery and well-calibrated Hamiltonian uncertainty on
mass-spring, Van der Pol, and Duffing benchmarks.

AI.tldr: Introduces a multistep port-Hamiltonian Gaussian process (MS-PHS GP) to learn physically consistent continuous-time dynamics from noisy, irregular data by placing a GP prior on the Hamiltonian and enforcing multistep discretization constraints, enabling closed-form conditioning without latent states and yielding calibrated uncertainty.
AI.motivation: Learn physically consistent continuous-time dynamics from irregular, noisy trajectories while enforcing energy balance and passivity, without introducing latent state representations.
AI.method: Place a Gaussian process prior on the Hamiltonian surface H and impose variable-step multistep integrator constraints as finite linear functionals, enabling closed-form conditioning of both the vector field and H without latent states; derive a finite-sample bound separating estimation and discretization terms.
AI.result: Improved vector-field recovery and well-calibrated Hamiltonian uncertainty demonstrated on mass-spring, Van der Pol, and Duffing benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: MS-PHS GP provides a tractable framework for learning energy-consistent continuous-time dynamics from irregular data, with a clear separation of estimation and discretization effects and reliable uncertainty over the Hamiltonian.

title: Shape Happens: Automatic Feature Manifold Discovery in LLMs via Supervised Multi-Dimensional Scaling
summary:
The linear representation hypothesis states that language models (LMs) encode
concepts as directions in their latent space, forming organized,
multidimensional manifolds. Prior efforts focus on discovering specific
geometries for specific features, and thus lack generalization. We introduce
Supervised Multi-Dimensional Scaling (SMDS), a model-agnostic method to
automatically discover feature manifolds. We apply SMDS to temporal reasoning
as a case study, finding that different features form various geometric
structures such as circles, lines, and clusters. SMDS reveals many insights on
these structures: they consistently reflect the properties of the concepts they
represent; are stable across model families and sizes; actively support
reasoning in models; and dynamically reshape in response to context changes.
Together, our findings shed light on the functional role of feature manifolds,
supporting a model of entity-based reasoning in which LMs encode and transform
structured representations.

AI.tldr: SMDS is a model-agnostic method to automatically discover and analyze feature manifolds in language models. Applied to temporal reasoning, it reveals diverse geometric structures (circles, lines, clusters) that reflect concept properties, are stable across models, support reasoning, and reshape with context, suggesting LMs use structured, entity-based representations.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitation of prior work that learns geometry for individual features without generalization. The paper seeks a general, model-agnostic method to uncover how concepts are organized in latent spaces and to understand the functional role of these feature manifolds in reasoning.
AI.method: Introduce Supervised Multi-Dimensional Scaling (SMDS), a model-agnostic approach that jointly learns low-dimensional manifolds for multiple features. Apply SMDS to temporal reasoning as a case study, analyzing the geometry and stability of the discovered manifolds across model families and sizes, and observe how manifolds adapt to contextual changes.
AI.result: SMDS discovers diverse geometric structures for different features (circles, lines, clusters). The manifolds consistently reflect concept properties, remain stable across model families and sizes, actively support reasoning in models, and dynamically reshape in response to context changes.
AI.conclusion: The findings illuminate the functional role of feature manifolds in LMs, supporting a view that entities are encoded and transformed within structured representations, and that such manifolds underlie entity-based reasoning across models.

title: Align Your Tangent: Training Better Consistency Models via Manifold-Aligned Tangents
summary:
With diffusion and flow matching models achieving state-of-the-art generating
performance, the interest of the community now turned to reducing the inference
time without sacrificing sample quality. Consistency Models (CMs), which are
trained to be consistent on diffusion or probability flow ordinary differential
equation (PF-ODE) trajectories, enable one or two-step flow or diffusion
sampling. However, CMs typically require prolonged training with large batch
sizes to obtain competitive sample quality. In this paper, we examine the
training dynamics of CMs near convergence and discover that CM tangents -- CM
output update directions -- are quite oscillatory, in the sense that they move
parallel to the data manifold, not towards the manifold. To mitigate
oscillatory tangents, we propose a new loss function, called the manifold
feature distance (MFD), which provides manifold-aligned tangents that point
toward the data manifold. Consequently, our method -- dubbed Align Your Tangent
(AYT) -- can accelerate CM training by orders of magnitude and even out-perform
the learned perceptual image patch similarity metric (LPIPS). Furthermore, we
find that our loss enables training with extremely small batch sizes without
compromising sample quality. Code: https://github.com/1202kbs/AYT

AI.tldr: Proposes Align Your Tangent (AYT) with a manifold feature distance (MFD) loss to correct oscillatory CM tangents, accelerating training by orders of magnitude and enabling tiny-batch training, while achieving competitive or better sample quality than LPIPS.
AI.motivation: Consistence Models (CMs) require long training and large batches for high-quality samples; CM tangents near convergence are oscillatory and parallel to the data manifold rather than pointing toward it, hindering efficient optimization.
AI.method: Introduce the manifold feature distance (MFD) loss to align CM tangents with the data manifold and train CMs with the AYT framework, enabling 1–2-step sampling with faster convergence and small-batch training.
AI.result: Training accelerates by orders of magnitude; achieved competitive or superior sample quality compared to LPIPS; capable of effective learning with extremely small batch sizes.
AI.conclusion: MFD-based tangent alignment in AYT substantially improves CM training efficiency and sample quality, reducing data/batch requirements and enabling faster diffusion-model training.

title: Train on Validation (ToV): Fast data selection with applications to fine-tuning
summary:
State-of-the-art machine learning often follows a two-stage process:
$(i)$~pre-training on large, general-purpose datasets; $(ii)$~fine-tuning on
task-specific data. In fine-tuning, selecting training examples that closely
reflect the target distribution is crucial. However, it is often the case that
only a few samples are available from the target distribution. Existing data
selection methods treat these target samples as a validation set and estimate
the effect of adding or removing a single sample from the training pool by
performing inference on the validation set.
  We propose a simpler and faster alternative that inverts the usual role of
train and validation: we perform inference on the training pool before and
after fine-tuning on the validation set. We then select samples whose
predictions change the most. Our key insight is that the training samples most
affected by fine-tuning on a small validation set tend to be the most
beneficial for reducing test loss on the target distribution. Experiments on
instruction tuning and named entity recognition tasks show that, in most cases,
our method achieves lower test log-loss than state-of-the-art approaches. We
support our findings with theoretical analysis.

AI.tldr: A simple, fast data-sampling method for fine-tuning: invert train/validation by measuring how training samples’ predictions change when fine-tuning on a small validation set, and select those with the largest changes. It targets samples most affected by fine-tuning to yield better test loss on the target distribution; demonstrated on instruction tuning and NER with theoretical support.
AI.motivation: To improve fine-tuning when target-distribution data is scarce. Selecting training samples that most align with the target distribution can reduce test loss, but existing methods treat target samples as validation and estimate sample-level effects via validation-inference.
AI.method: Invert the usual train/validation roles. For the training pool, compare model predictions before and after fine-tuning on a small validation set. Rank samples by how much their predictions change due to the validation-driven fine-tuning, and select top samples for training.
AI.result: In most cases, the method achieves lower test log-loss than state-of-the-art approaches on instruction-tuning and NER tasks.
AI.conclusion: A simple, faster alternative to traditional data-selection methods with theoretical justification; effective for improving generalization on target distributions under limited target data.

title: Uncovering the Computational Ingredients of Human-Like Representations in LLMs
summary:
The ability to translate diverse patterns of inputs into structured patterns
of behavior has been thought to rest on both humans' and machines' ability to
learn robust representations of relevant concepts. The rapid advancement of
transformer-based large language models (LLMs) has led to a diversity of
computational ingredients -- architectures, fine tuning methods, and training
datasets among others -- but it remains unclear which of these ingredients are
most crucial for building models that develop human-like representations.
Further, most current LLM benchmarks are not suited to measuring
representational alignment between humans and models, making benchmark scores
unreliable for assessing if current LLMs are making progress towards becoming
useful cognitive models. We address these limitations by first evaluating a set
of over 70 models that widely vary in their computational ingredients on a
triplet similarity task, a method well established in the cognitive sciences
for measuring human conceptual representations, using concepts from the THINGS
database. Comparing human and model representations, we find that models that
undergo instruction-finetuning and which have larger dimensionality of
attention heads are among the most human aligned, while multimodal pretraining
and parameter size have limited bearing on alignment. Correlations between
alignment scores and scores on existing benchmarks reveal that while some
benchmarks (e.g., MMLU) are better suited than others (e.g., MUSR) for
capturing representational alignment, no existing benchmark is capable of fully
accounting for the variance of alignment scores, demonstrating their
insufficiency in capturing human-AI alignment. Taken together, our findings
help highlight the computational ingredients most essential for advancing LLMs
towards models of human conceptual representation and address a key
benchmarking gap in LLM evaluation.

AI.tldr: A broad evaluation of 70+ LLMs across architectures and training methods shows that instruction-tuning and larger attention head dimensionality align models more with human conceptual representations on a triplet similarity task, while multimodal pretraining and overall parameter count have limited impact; benchmarks vary in capturing alignment, with none fully accounting for human-AI representational variance; underscores a benchmarking gap and points to key ingredients for human-like representations.
AI.motivation: To determine which computational ingredients of LLMs drive human-like representations and to assess whether current benchmarks capture representational alignment between humans and models, addressing a gap where models may appear strong on benchmarks but not align with human concepts.
AI.method: Evaluate over 70 diverse models on a triplet similarity task derived from the THINGS database to measure human conceptual representations. Compare model representations to human data to compute alignment. Analyze how architectural features (e.g., instruction-finetuning, attention head dimensionality, multimodal pretraining, parameter size) relate to alignment. Correlate alignment with existing benchmarks (e.g., MMLU, MUSR) to assess their adequacy.
AI.result: Instruction-finetuned models with larger dimensionality of attention heads show higher human-model alignment. Multimodal pretraining and larger parameter counts have limited impact on alignment. Some benchmarks better capture alignment than others, but no current benchmark fully accounts for the variance in alignment, indicating insufficiency for measuring human-AI representational similarity.
AI.conclusion: To advance toward models with human-like conceptual representations, focus on instruction-tuning and increasing the dimensionality of attention mechanisms. Develop or adopt benchmarks that more accurately assess representational alignment, as existing benchmarks do not fully capture the variance in human-model representations.

title: Unsupervised Unfolded rPCA (U2-rPCA): Deep Interpretable Clutter Filtering for Ultrasound Microvascular Imaging
summary:
High-sensitivity clutter filtering is a fundamental step in ultrasound
microvascular imaging. Singular value decomposition (SVD) and robust principal
component analysis (rPCA) are the main clutter filtering strategies. However,
both strategies are limited in feature modeling and tissue-blood flow
separation for high-quality microvascular imaging. Recently, deep
learning-based clutter filtering has shown potential in more thoroughly
separating tissue and blood flow signals. However, the existing supervised
filters face the challenges of interpretability and lack of in-vitro and
in-vivo ground truths. While the interpretability issue can be addressed by
algorithm deep unfolding, the training ground truth remains unsolved. To this
end, this paper proposes an unsupervised unfolded rPCA (U2-rPCA) method that
preserves mathematical interpretability and is insusceptible to learning
labels. Specifically, U2-rPCA is unfolded from an iteratively reweighted least
squares (IRLS) rPCA baseline with intrinsic low-rank and sparse regularization.
A sparse-enhancement unit is added to the network to strengthen its capability
to capture the sparse micro-flow signals. U2-rPCA is like an adaptive filter
that is trained with part of the image sequence and then used for the following
frames. Experimental validations on a in-silico dataset and public in-vivo
datasets demonstrated the outperformance of U2-rPCA when compared with the
SVD-based method, the rPCA baseline, and another deep learning-based filter.
Particularly, the proposed method improved the contrastto-noise ratio (CNR) of
the power Doppler image by 2 dB to 10 dB when compared with other methods.
Furthermore, the effectiveness of the building modules of U2-rPCA was validated
through ablation studies.

AI.tldr: An unsupervised unfolded rPCA (U2-rPCA) for ultrasound clutter filtering is proposed. It preserves interpretability while removing the need for ground-truth labels by unfolding an IRLS-based rPCA, adding a sparse-enhancement unit, and training on partial sequences. It outperforms SVD, traditional rPCA, and a DL-based filter, boosting CNR by 2–10 dB in in-silico and in-vivo datasets, with ablation studies validating module contributions.
AI.motivation: High-sensitivity clutter filtering is essential for ultrasound microvascular imaging. SVD and rPCA are limited in feature modeling and tissue–blood separation. Deep learning offers promise but struggles with interpretability and lack of ground truths. An interpretable, unsupervised approach is needed to leverage the benefits of unfolding while avoiding labeled data.
AI.method: Unfolded rPCA (U2-rPCA) derived from an iteratively reweighted least squares (IRLS) rPCA baseline, incorporating intrinsic low-rank and sparse regularization. A sparse-enhancement unit strengthens capture of sparse micro-flow signals. The model acts as an adaptive filter trained on part of the image sequence and applied to subsequent frames, enabling unsupervised training without explicit labels.
AI.result: U2-rPCA outperforms the SVD-based method, the rPCA baseline, and another deep learning-based filter in both in-silico and public in-vivo datasets. It achieves notable improvements in contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) for power Doppler imaging, ranging from 2 dB to 10 dB over competing methods. Ablation studies confirm the contribution of each module.
AI.conclusion: An interpretable, unsupervised unfolded network (U2-rPCA) provides effective clutter filtering for ultrasound microvascular imaging, bridging traditional priors with deep learning benefits. It delivers significant CNR gains and validates the utility of the proposed modules via ablation.

title: Bayesian Distributional Models of Executive Functioning
summary:
Estimation (IMLE). DLVM integrates observations across multiple executive
function tasks and individuals, allowing parameter estimation even under sparse
or incomplete data conditions. DLVM consistently outperformed IMLE, especially
under with smaller amounts of data, and converges faster to highly accurate
estimates of the true distributions. In a second set of analyses, DALE
adaptively guided sampling to maximize information gain, outperforming random
sampling and fixed test batteries, particularly within the first 80 trials.
These findings establish the advantages of combining DLVMs cross-task inference
with DALEs optimal adaptive sampling, providing a principled basis for more
efficient cognitive assessments.

AI.tldr: Cross-task DLVM with DALE adaptive sampling improves estimation and cognitive assessment efficiency over IMLE, especially with sparse data.
AI.motivation: Address sparse/incomplete data in cognitive assessment by integrating cross-task information and optimizing data collection.
AI.method: Use a deep latent variable model (DLVM) to fuse observations across executive function tasks and participants; compare against IMLE; apply DALE to adaptively select informative trials; evaluate in data-limited regimes and through information-gain metrics.
AI.result: DLVM consistently outperforms IMLE, particularly with smaller datasets, and converges faster to accurate distribution estimates; DALE achieves higher information gain than random or fixed batteries, especially in early trials; combining DLVM with DALE yields an efficient assessment framework.
AI.conclusion: Cross-task DLVM inference combined with DALE's adaptive sampling offers a principled, more efficient framework for cognitive assessment under data constraints.

title: Activation-Deactivation: A General Framework for Robust Post-hoc Explainable AI
summary:
Black-box explainability methods are popular tools for explaining the
decisions of image classifiers. A major drawback of these tools is their
reliance on mutants obtained by occluding parts of the input, leading to
out-of-distribution images. This raises doubts about the quality of the
explanations. Moreover, choosing an appropriate occlusion value often requires
domain knowledge. In this paper we introduce a novel forward-pass paradigm
Activation-Deactivation (AD), which removes the effects of occluded input
features from the model's decision-making by switching off the parts of the
model that correspond to the occlusions. We introduce ConvAD, a drop-in
mechanism that can be easily added to any trained Convolutional Neural Network
(CNN), and which implements the AD paradigm. This leads to more robust
explanations without any additional training or fine-tuning. We prove that the
ConvAD mechanism does not change the decision-making process of the network. We
provide experimental evaluation across several datasets and model
architectures. We compare the quality of AD-explanations with explanations
achieved using a set of masking values, using the proxies of robustness, size,
and confidence drop-off. We observe a consistent improvement in robustness of
AD explanations (up to 62.5%) compared to explanations obtained with
occlusions, demonstrating that ConvAD extracts more robust explanations without
the need for domain knowledge.

AI.tldr: Proposes a forward-pass Activation-Deactivation (AD) paradigm implemented as ConvAD to produce robust CNN explanations by deactivating model components corresponding to occluded input, avoiding input occlusion artifacts and retraining; shows robustness gains (up to 62.5%) while preserving predictions.
AI.motivation: Occlusion-based, black-box explainers rely on occluding input which creates out-of-distribution artifacts and requires domain knowledge to choose occlusion values; a method that yields robust explanations without altering decisions is desirable.
AI.method: Introduce Activation-Deactivation (AD) forward-pass paradigm and ConvAD, a drop-in module for CNNs that deactivates parts of the model tied to occluded input during the forward pass. No additional training. Compare AD explanations to occlusion-based baselines using proxies for robustness, size, and confidence drop-off across multiple datasets and architectures.
AI.result: AD-based explanations are more robust than occlusion-based explanations, with robustness improvements reported up to 62.5%. ConvAD does not change the network's decisions and provides more robust explanations without domain knowledge or retraining.
AI.conclusion: ConvAD enables robust, training-free explanations via a straightforward model augmentation, mitigating issues with input occlusions and improving explanation quality across datasets and architectures.

title: Multi-Domain Brain Vessel Segmentation Through Feature Disentanglement
comment:
19 pages, 7 figures, 3 tables. Joint first authors: Francesco Galati
  and Daniele Falcetta. Accepted for publication at the Journal of Machine
  Learning for Biomedical Imaging (MELBA) https://melba-journal.org/2025:021.
  Code available at https://github.com/i-vesseg/MultiVesSeg
summary:
The intricate morphology of brain vessels poses significant challenges for
automatic segmentation models, which usually focus on a single imaging
modality. However, accurately treating brain-related conditions requires a
comprehensive understanding of the cerebrovascular tree, regardless of the
specific acquisition procedure. Our framework effectively segments brain
arteries and veins in various datasets through image-to-image translation while
avoiding domain-specific model design and data harmonization between the source
and the target domain. This is accomplished by employing disentanglement
techniques to independently manipulate different image properties, allowing
them to move from one domain to another in a label-preserving manner.
Specifically, we focus on manipulating vessel appearances during adaptation
while preserving spatial information, such as shapes and locations, which are
crucial for correct segmentation. Our evaluation effectively bridges large and
varied domain gaps across medical centers, image modalities, and vessel types.
Additionally, we conduct ablation studies on the optimal number of required
annotations and other architectural choices. The results highlight our
framework's robustness and versatility, demonstrating the potential of domain
adaptation methodologies to perform cerebrovascular image segmentation in
multiple scenarios accurately. Our code is available at
https://github.com/i-vesseg/MultiVesSeg.

AI.tldr: A domain-adaptive image-to-image translation framework using disentanglement to segment brain arteries and veins across modalities without domain-specific models, preserving spatial structure while altering vessel appearance.
AI.motivation: Segmentation of brain vasculature is challenging due to complex morphology and variability across imaging modalities and centers; existing models are often modality-specific, requiring harmonization or retraining.
AI.method: Disentanglement-based image-to-image translation that independently manipulates image properties (vessel appearance) while preserving spatial information (shapes/locations) to move data across domains in a label-preserving, modality-agnostic way; no domain-specific design or data harmonization; ablation studies on annotations and architectural choices.
AI.result: Effective segmentation across large and varied domain gaps (centers, modalities, vessel types); robust and versatile performance demonstrated; code released for reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: Shows the potential of domain adaptation approaches for cerebrovascular segmentation across multiple scenarios and modalities, highlighting robustness and versatility.

title: Graph2Region: Efficient Graph Similarity Learning with Structure and Scale Restoration
comment: Accepted by IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
summary:
Graph similarity is critical in graph-related tasks such as graph retrieval,
where metrics like maximum common subgraph (MCS) and graph edit distance (GED)
are commonly used. However, exact computations of these metrics are known to be
NP-Hard. Recent neural network-based approaches approximate the similarity
score in embedding spaces to alleviate the computational burden, but they
either involve expensive pairwise node comparisons or fail to effectively
utilize structural and scale information of graphs. To tackle these issues, we
propose a novel geometric-based graph embedding method called Graph2Region
(G2R). G2R represents nodes as closed regions and recovers their adjacency
patterns within graphs in the embedding space. By incorporating the node
features and adjacency patterns of graphs, G2R summarizes graph regions, i.e.,
graph embeddings, where the shape captures the underlying graph structures and
the volume reflects the graph size. Consequently, the overlap between graph
regions can serve as an approximation of MCS, signifying similar node regions
and adjacency patterns. We further analyze the relationship between MCS and GED
and propose using disjoint parts as a proxy for GED similarity. This analysis
enables concurrent computation of MCS and GED, incorporating local and global
structural information. Experimental evaluation highlights G2R's competitive
performance in graph similarity computation. It achieves up to a 60.0\%
relative accuracy improvement over state-of-the-art methods in MCS similarity
learning, while maintaining efficiency in both training and inference.
Moreover, G2R showcases remarkable capability in predicting both MCS and GED
similarities simultaneously, providing a holistic assessment of graph
similarity. Code available at https://github.com/liuzhouyang/Graph2Region.

AI.tldr: G2R introduces a geometric graph embedding where nodes are closed regions; region overlaps approximate MCS and disjoint parts proxy GED, enabling simultaneous MCS/GED estimation with competitive accuracy and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Graph similarity metrics like MCS and GED are NP-hard to compute exactly and existing neural approximations either rely on costly pairwise node comparisons or fail to leverage graph structure effectively; there is a need for an efficient method that uses structural and scale information.
AI.method: Represent nodes as closed regions in embedding space to capture adjacency patterns; derive graph embeddings (regions) whose shapes reflect structure and volumes reflect graph size; use region overlaps as an approximation of MCS; analyze the MCS-GED relationship and use disjoint parts as a GED proxy; enable concurrent computation of MCS and GED incorporating local and global information.
AI.result: G2R achieves up to 60% relative accuracy improvement over state-of-the-art methods in MCS similarity learning while maintaining training and inference efficiency; it can predict both MCS and GED similarities simultaneously, offering a holistic graph similarity assessment.
AI.conclusion: G2R provides competitive performance by effectively encoding structural information into geometric region embeddings, enabling efficient and concurrent estimation of MCS and GED similarities; code is available for replication.

title: Typed Chain-of-Thought: A Curry-Howard Framework for Verifying LLM Reasoning
summary:
While Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting enhances the reasoning capabilities of
large language models, the faithfulness of the generated rationales remains an
open problem for model interpretability. We propose a novel theoretical lens
for this problem grounded in the Curry-Howard correspondence, which posits a
direct relationship between formal proofs and computer programs. Under this
paradigm, a faithful reasoning trace is analogous to a well-typed program,
where each intermediate step corresponds to a typed logical inference. We
operationalise this analogy, presenting methods to extract and map the
informal, natural language steps of CoT into a formal, typed proof structure.
Successfully converting a CoT trace into a well-typed proof serves as a strong,
verifiable certificate of its computational faithfulness, moving beyond
heuristic interpretability towards formal verification. Our framework provides
a methodology to transform plausible narrative explanations into formally
verifiable programs, offering a path towards building more reliable and
trustworthy AI systems.

AI.tldr: A theoretical framework using Curry-Howard to turn chain-of-thought traces into well-typed proofs, providing verifiable faithfulness certificates for model reasoning.
AI.motivation: Faithfulness of Chain-of-Thought (CoT) rationales is crucial for interpretability but remains unverifiable; the Curry-Howard correspondence offers a principled link between formal proofs and programs, enabling formal verification of reasoning traces.
AI.method: Propose a mapping from informal CoT steps to typed logical inferences, and an extraction/mapping pipeline to convert CoT narratives into a formal, well-typed proof structure. Treat plausible reasoning steps as typed rules to produce verifiable certificates, outlining a pipeline for converting narratives into formal proofs.
AI.result: Conceptual framework introducing a pipeline to transform CoT narratives into formal proofs; claims a strong certificate of computational faithfulness and a path toward formal verification rather than heuristic interpretability.
AI.conclusion: This Curry-Howard-based approach shifts interpretability toward formal verification, offering a route to more reliable and trustworthy AI systems.

title: A Geometric Unification of Generative AI with Manifold-Probabilistic Projection Models
summary:
The foundational premise of generative AI for images is the assumption that
images are inherently low-dimensional objects embedded within a
high-dimensional space. Additionally, it is often implicitly assumed that
thematic image datasets form smooth or piecewise smooth manifolds. Common
approaches overlook the geometric structure and focus solely on probabilistic
methods, approximating the probability distribution through universal
approximation techniques such as the kernel method. In some generative models,
the low dimensional nature of the data manifest itself by the introduction of a
lower dimensional latent space. Yet, the probability distribution in the latent
or the manifold coordinate space is considered uninteresting and is predefined
or considered uniform. This study unifies the geometric and probabilistic
perspectives by providing a geometric framework and a kernel-based
probabilistic method simultaneously. The resulting framework demystifies
diffusion models by interpreting them as a projection mechanism onto the
manifold of ``good images''. This interpretation leads to the construction of a
new deterministic model, the Manifold-Probabilistic Projection Model (MPPM),
which operates in both the representation (pixel) space and the latent space.
We demonstrate that the Latent MPPM (LMPPM) outperforms the Latent Diffusion
Model (LDM) across various datasets, achieving superior results in terms of
image restoration and generation.

AI.tldr: The paper unifies geometry and probabilistic modeling for image generation with the Manifold-Probabilistic Projection Model (MPPM); introduces a Latent variant (LMPPM) and shows it outperforms Latent Diffusion Models (LDM) in restoration and generation by viewing diffusion as projection onto the manifold of good images.
AI.motivation: Current generative image methods often ignore the underlying geometric structure of data (manifolds) and treat distributions probabilistically without geometry. There is a need to unify geometry with probabilistic approaches, reinterpret diffusion as a projection onto a manifold of good images, and develop deterministic yet probabilistic-capable models to improve performance.
AI.method: Develop a geometric framework combined with a kernel-based probabilistic method and construct the Manifold-Probabilistic Projection Model (MPPM) that operates in both pixel and latent spaces. Interpret diffusion models as projection operators onto the manifold of good images and derive a Latent MPPM (LMPPM).
AI.result: Latent MPPM (LMPPM) outperforms Latent Diffusion Models (LDM) across various datasets, achieving superior results in image restoration and generation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed MPPM framework successfully unifies geometric and probabilistic perspectives in generative imaging, offering a deterministic projection-based model that enhances performance and provides a new interpretation of diffusion models.

title: Can Mamba Learn In Context with Outliers? A Theoretical Generalization Analysis
summary:
The Mamba model has gained significant attention for its computational
advantages over Transformer-based models, while achieving comparable
performance across a wide range of language tasks. Like Transformers, Mamba
exhibits in-context learning (ICL) capabilities, i.e., making predictions for
new tasks based on a prompt containing input-label pairs and a query, without
requiring fine-tuning. Despite its empirical success, the theoretical
understanding of Mamba remains limited, largely due to the nonlinearity
introduced by its gating mechanism. To the best of our knowledge, this paper
presents the first theoretical analysis of the training dynamics of a one-layer
Mamba model, which consists of a linear attention component followed by a
nonlinear gating layer, and its ICL generalization on unseen binary
classification tasks, even when the prompt includes additive outliers. Our
analysis shows that Mamba leverages the linear attention layer to select
informative context examples and uses the nonlinear gating layer to suppress
the influence of outliers. By establishing and comparing to the analysis of
linear Transformers under the same setting, we show that although Mamba may
require more training iterations to converge, it maintains accurate predictions
even when the proportion of outliers exceeds the threshold that a linear
Transformer can tolerate. These theoretical findings are supported by empirical
experiments.

AI.tldr: This work analyzes the training dynamics of a one-layer Mamba model for in-context learning (ICL) on binary classification with additive outliers, showing linear attention helps pick informative context while the nonlinear gating suppresses outliers; compared to linear Transformers, Mamba may need more training iterations but tolerates higher outlier fractions; empirical results validate theory.
AI.motivation: To understand the theoretical behavior of Mamba, particularly the nonlinear gating’s role in robustness and how it compares to linear Transformers under ICL and data contamination.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of a one-layer Mamba: linear attention followed by a nonlinear gating layer; study of ICL generalization on unseen binary classification tasks with prompts containing additive outliers; derive dynamics and robustness guarantees; compare to linear Transformers under the same setup; validate with experiments.
AI.result: The linear attention layer helps select informative context examples; the nonlinear gating suppresses the influence of outliers; Mamba achieves accurate predictions even when outlier proportion exceeds the threshold tolerated by a linear Transformer; may require more training iterations to converge.
AI.conclusion: Theoretical findings align with empirical results, highlighting Mamba’s robustness and the distinct roles of its components; gating enhances outlier robustness, and linear attention aids context selection, providing insights into Mamba's ICL and training dynamics.

title: Safety Instincts: LLMs Learn to Trust Their Internal Compass for Self-Defense
summary:
Ensuring Large Language Model (LLM) safety remains challenging due to the
absence of universal standards and reliable content validators, making it
difficult to obtain effective training signals. We discover that aligned models
already possess robust internal safety beliefs: they consistently produce
high-confidence refusals to harmful requests while exhibiting high entropy when
generating potentially dangerous content. This entropy gap reveals an untapped
signal--models intrinsically "know" when to refuse. We introduce Safety
Instincts Reinforcement Learning (SIRL), which transforms this internal
confidence into a self-generated reward signal, eliminating dependence on
external validators or human annotations. SIRL teaches models to trust their
safety instincts by reinforcing low-entropy refusal behaviors. Evaluated on
Llama and Qwen models, SIRL maintains 89%+ Defense Success Rates (DSRs) against
20+ jailbreak methods, from static prompts to adaptive attacks. Using only
15,000 unlabeled prompts, SIRL surpasses resource-intensive supervised methods
while preserving performance on mathematics, coding, and conversation
benchmarks. Our work demonstrates that effective alignment can emerge from
within, paving the way for more autonomous and robust AI safety mechanisms that
scale without extensive human oversight.

AI.tldr: SIRL uses the model’s own safety instincts as a self-generated reward, reinforcing low-entropy refusals to harmful prompts and leveraging high-entropy risky outputs as signals, yielding robust jailbreak resistance with minimal unlabeled data.
AI.motivation: Safety in LLMs lacks universal standards and reliable validators; external supervision is expensive and inconsistent. The authors observe that aligned models already encode strong internal safety beliefs (confident refusals, high entropy for risky content) and propose exploiting this intrinsic signal to enable autonomous, scalable safety training without external annotations.
AI.method: Introduce Safety Instincts Reinforcement Learning (SIRL), which translates internal confidence signals into a self-generated reward. The model is trained to reinforce low-entropy refusals on harmful prompts using only ~15,000 unlabeled prompts, applied to Llama and Qwen, with no reliance on external validators or human annotations.
AI.result: SIRL achieves 89%+ Defense Success Rates (DSRs) against 20+ jailbreak methods, spanning static prompts to adaptive attacks. It matches or surpasses resource-intensive supervised methods while preserving performance on mathematics, coding, and conversation benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Effective alignment can emerge from within the model’s own safety instincts, enabling more autonomous and scalable AI safety mechanisms that scale without extensive human oversight.

title: Beyond one-hot encoding? Journey into compact encoding for large multi-class segmentation
summary:
This work presents novel methods to reduce computational and memory
requirements for medical image segmentation with a large number of classes. We
curiously observe challenges in maintaining state-of-the-art segmentation
performance with all of the explored options. Standard learning-based methods
typically employ one-hot encoding of class labels. The computational complexity
and memory requirements thus increase linearly with the number of classes. We
propose a family of binary encoding approaches instead of one-hot encoding to
reduce the computational complexity and memory requirements to logarithmic in
the number of classes. In addition to vanilla binary encoding, we investigate
the effects of error-correcting output codes (ECOCs), class weighting,
hard/soft decoding, class-to-codeword assignment, and label embedding trees. We
apply the methods to the use case of whole brain parcellation with 108 classes
based on 3D MRI images. While binary encodings have proven efficient in
so-called extreme classification problems in computer vision, we faced
challenges in reaching state-of-the-art segmentation quality with binary
encodings. Compared to one-hot encoding (Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) =
82.4 (2.8)), we report reduced segmentation performance with the binary
segmentation approaches, achieving DSCs in the range from 39.3 to 73.8.
Informative negative results all too often go unpublished. We hope that this
work inspires future research of compact encoding strategies for large
multi-class segmentation tasks.

AI.tldr: Binary encoding approaches can reduce complexity from linear to logarithmic in the number of classes for large-class medical image segmentation, but they underperform compared to one-hot encoding on a 108-class brain MRI parcellation.
AI.motivation: To curb computational and memory demands of large-class segmentation by replacing one-hot with binary encodings and exploring ECOCs and related strategies, motivated by strong results in extreme classification.
AI.method: Investigates vanilla binary encoding, ECOCs, class weighting, hard/soft decoding, class-to-codeword assignment, and label embedding trees; applies these to 108-class whole-brain MRI parcellation; evaluates using Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC).
AI.result: All binary-encoding approaches underperform relative to one-hot, with DSCs ranging from 39.3 to 73.8 compared to 82.4 (with std 2.8) for one-hot; reveals informative negative results, indicating challenges in achieving state-of-the-art segmentation with binary encodings.
AI.conclusion: Binary encodings reduce computational/memory demands but struggle to reach top-tier segmentation accuracy in large-class medical segmentation; suggests further research is needed to bridge the gap and refine compact encoding strategies for such tasks.

title: Hierarchy-Aware Neural Subgraph Matching with Enhanced Similarity Measure
comment: Accepted by IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
summary:
Subgraph matching is challenging as it necessitates time-consuming
combinatorial searches. Recent Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based approaches
address this issue by employing GNN encoders to extract graph information and
hinge distance measures to ensure containment constraints in the embedding
space. These methods significantly shorten the response time, making them
promising solutions for subgraph retrieval. However, they suffer from scale
differences between graph pairs during encoding, as they focus on feature
counts but overlook the relative positions of features within node-rooted
subtrees, leading to disturbed containment constraints and false predictions.
Additionally, their hinge distance measures lack discriminative power for
matched graph pairs, hindering ranking applications. We propose NC-Iso, a novel
GNN architecture for neural subgraph matching. NC-Iso preserves the relative
positions of features by building the hierarchical dependencies between
adjacent echelons within node-rooted subtrees, ensuring matched graph pairs
maintain consistent hierarchies while complying with containment constraints in
feature counts. To enhance the ranking ability for matched pairs, we introduce
a novel similarity dominance ratio-enhanced measure, which quantifies the
dominance of similarity over dissimilarity between graph pairs. Empirical
results on nine datasets validate the effectiveness, generalization ability,
scalability, and transferability of NC-Iso while maintaining time efficiency,
offering a more discriminative neural subgraph matching solution for subgraph
retrieval. Code available at https://github.com/liuzhouyang/NC-Iso.

AI.tldr: NC-Iso is a GNN-based neural subgraph matching model that preserves hierarchical feature positions in node-rooted subtrees and introduces a similarity dominance ratio to boost ranking, achieving scalable, transferable performance on nine datasets with competitive accuracy and time efficiency.
AI.motivation: Subgraph matching is computationally hard due to combinatorial searches. Existing GNN-based approaches reduce latency but ignore scale differences and the relative positions of features within node-rooted subtrees, leading to disturbed containment constraints and poor ranking. There is a need for methods that maintain containment constraints while providing discriminative ranking in embedding space.
AI.method: Introduce NC-Iso, a novel GNN architecture for neural subgraph matching that preserves the relative positions of features by building hierarchical dependencies between adjacent echelons within node-rooted subtrees, ensuring matched graphs maintain consistent hierarchies while satisfying containment constraints in feature counts. Also propose a similarity dominance ratio-enhanced measure to improve ranking by quantifying how much similarity dominates dissimilarity for graph pairs.
AI.result: Empirical results on nine datasets validate NC-Iso's effectiveness, generalization ability, scalability, and transferability, while maintaining time efficiency and offering a more discriminative neural subgraph matching solution for subgraph retrieval.
AI.conclusion: NC-Iso provides a more discriminative neural subgraph matching solution that preserves hierarchical feature relationships and improves ranking, achieving scalable, transferable performance; code available at the provided GitHub URL.

title: Optimizing Fairness in Production Planning: A Human-Centric Approach to Machine and Workforce Allocation
summary:
This work presents a two-layer, human-centric production planning framework
