shortcut classes (positive PD). Masking the patch improves accuracy for CL
methods while slightly reducing Scratch-T2, yielding negative SFR_rel. This
pattern indicates the patch acted as a distractor for CL models in this setting
rather than a helpful shortcut.

AI.tldr: Introduction of the Einstellung Rigidity Index (ERI) to diagnose transfer vs shortcut reliance in continual learning; evaluates adaptation delay, performance deficit, and relative suboptimal feature reliance on a CIFAR-100 two-phase task with a spurious magenta patch; findings show CL methods adapt quickly but may incur final deficits on patched classes; patch masking can reduce reliance on shortcuts.
AI.motivation: Shortcuts are incidental correlations that undermine robustness; in continual learning, inherited biases from earlier tasks can cause Einstellung-like rigidity, hindering acquisition of new tasks. A compact diagnostic is needed to disentangle genuine transfer from cue-driven performance.
AI.method: Propose ERI with three interpretable facets (AD, PD, SFR_rel); evaluate on a two-phase CIFAR-100 CL benchmark with a deliberately spurious magenta patch in Phase 2; compare Naive SGD, online EWC, DER++, GPM, and DGR; assess whether CL methods rely on shortcuts and how masking affects performance.
AI.result: Across CL methods, they reach accuracy thresholds earlier than Scratch-T2 but achieve slightly lower final accuracy on patched shortcut classes (positive PD). Masking the patch improves CL accuracy and yields negative SFR_rel, indicating the patch acted as a distractor rather than a helpful shortcut in this setting.
AI.conclusion: ERI provides a compact diagnostic to separate genuine transfer from shortcut-inflated performance. In this experiment, shortcut cues are not beneficial for CL and masking mitigates their effect; these results emphasize the need to address shortcut reliance to improve CL robustness under distribution shifts.

title: Solar PV Installation Potential Assessment on Building Facades Based on Vision and Language Foundation Models
summary:
Building facades represent a significant untapped resource for solar energy
generation in dense urban environments, yet assessing their photovoltaic (PV)
potential remains challenging due to complex geometries and semantic com
ponents. This study introduces SF-SPA (Semantic Facade Solar-PV Assessment), an
automated framework that transforms street-view photographs into quantitative
PV deployment assessments. The approach combines com puter vision and
artificial intelligence techniques to address three key challenges: perspective
distortion correction, semantic understanding of facade elements, and spatial
reasoning for PV layout optimization. Our four-stage pipeline processes images
through geometric rectification, zero-shot semantic segmentation, Large
Language Model (LLM) guided spatial reasoning, and energy simulation.
Validation across 80 buildings in four countries demonstrates ro bust
performance with mean area estimation errors of 6.2% ± 2.8% compared to
expert annotations. The auto mated assessment requires approximately 100
seconds per building, a substantial gain in efficiency over manual methods.
Simulated energy yield predictions confirm the method's reliability and
applicability for regional poten tial studies, urban energy planning, and
building-integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) deployment. Code is available at:
https:github.com/CodeAXu/Solar-PV-Installation

AI.tldr: An automated SF-SPA framework converts street-view photos into quantitative PV deployment estimates for building facades, addressing perspective correction, semantic understanding, and spatial reasoning; achieves ~6.2% mean area error, ~100s per building; validated on 80 buildings across 4 countries; code available.
AI.motivation: Urban facades offer a significant but underutilized source of solar energy. Assessing their PV potential is hard due to complex geometries, occlusions, and semantic components; there is a need for scalable, automated methods for accurate PV deployment estimates to support urban energy planning and BIPV deployment.
AI.method: A four-stage pipeline: (1) geometric rectification of street-view images to correct perspective, (2) zero-shot semantic segmentation to identify facade components, (3) LLM-guided spatial reasoning to layout PV installations, and (4) energy simulation to predict yields. The approach processes images end-to-end to produce quantitative PV deployment estimates.
AI.result: Validated on 80 buildings across four countries with mean area estimation error 6.2% ± 2.8%. Approximately 100 seconds per building, reflecting substantial efficiency gains over manual methods. Simulated energy yields corroborate the method’s reliability for regional potential studies and BIPV planning. Code is available at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: SF-SPA enables automated, robust assessment of facade-based PV potential from street-view imagery, supporting urban energy planning, regional PV potential studies, and BIPV deployment decisions.

title: Vicinity-Guided Discriminative Latent Diffusion for Privacy-Preserving Domain Adaptation
comment:
32 pages, 6 figures, 39th Conference on Neural Information Processing
  Systems (NeurIPS 2025)
summary:
Recent work on latent diffusion models (LDMs) has focused almost exclusively
on generative tasks, leaving their potential for discriminative transfer
largely unexplored. We introduce Discriminative Vicinity Diffusion (DVD), a
novel LDM-based framework for a more practical variant of source-free domain
adaptation (SFDA): the source provider may share not only a pre-trained
classifier but also an auxiliary latent diffusion module, trained once on the
source data and never exposing raw source samples. DVD encodes each source
feature's label information into its latent vicinity by fitting a Gaussian
prior over its k-nearest neighbors and training the diffusion network to drift
noisy samples back to label-consistent representations. During adaptation, we
sample from each target feature's latent vicinity, apply the frozen diffusion
module to generate source-like cues, and use a simple InfoNCE loss to align the
target encoder to these cues, explicitly transferring decision boundaries
without source access. Across standard SFDA benchmarks, DVD outperforms
state-of-the-art methods. We further show that the same latent diffusion module
enhances the source classifier's accuracy on in-domain data and boosts
performance in supervised classification and domain generalization experiments.
DVD thus reinterprets LDMs as practical, privacy-preserving bridges for
explicit knowledge transfer, addressing a core challenge in source-free domain
adaptation that prior methods have yet to solve.

AI.tldr: A latent diffusion model-based discriminative transfer method for source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) that uses latent vicinity diffusion to generate source-like cues and aligns target features with an InfoNCE loss, achieving state-of-the-art performance and broader benefits.
AI.motivation: SFDA lacks access to source data and raw samples; latent diffusion models can provide privacy-preserving, source-probability transfer; encode label information into latent vicinity to transfer decision boundaries without source exposure.
AI.method: Train a diffusion network to drift noisy samples back to label-consistent representations by fitting a Gaussian prior over the k-nearest neighbors of each source feature. During adaptation, sample around each target feature's latent vicinity, apply the frozen diffusion module to generate source-like cues, and optimize with InfoNCE to align the target encoder to these cues.
AI.result: Outperforms state-of-the-art SFDA methods on standard benchmarks; also improves in-domain accuracy of the source classifier and enhances supervised classification and domain generalization.
AI.conclusion: DVD reframes LDMs as privacy-preserving bridges for explicit knowledge transfer, addressing a core SFDA challenge by transferring decision boundaries without access to source data.

title: From Seeing to Predicting: A Vision-Language Framework for Trajectory Forecasting and Controlled Video Generation
summary:
Current video generation models produce physically inconsistent motion that
violates real-world dynamics. We propose TrajVLM-Gen, a two-stage framework for
physics-aware image-to-video generation. First, we employ a Vision Language
Model to predict coarse-grained motion trajectories that maintain consistency
with real-world physics. Second, these trajectories guide video generation
through attention-based mechanisms for fine-grained motion refinement. We build
a trajectory prediction dataset based on video tracking data with realistic
motion patterns. Experiments on UCF-101 and MSR-VTT demonstrate that
TrajVLM-Gen outperforms existing methods, achieving competitive FVD scores of
545 on UCF-101 and 539 on MSR-VTT.

AI.tldr: A two-stage, physics-aware image-to-video generation method (TrajVLM-Gen) that uses a vision-language model to predict coarse motion trajectories aligned with real-world dynamics and attention-based refinement for fine motion; evaluated on UCF-101 and MSR-VTT with competitive FVD scores.
AI.motivation: Current video generation models produce physically inconsistent motion that violates real-world dynamics. There is a need to enforce physics-consistent motion in synthesized videos by combining perception-guided trajectory prediction with physics-aware generation.
AI.method: Stage 1: Use a Vision Language Model to predict coarse-grained, physics-consistent motion trajectories. Stage 2: Use these trajectories to guide video generation via attention-based mechanisms for fine-grained motion refinement. A trajectory-prediction dataset is built from video-tracking data to capture realistic motion patterns. Evaluation on UCF-101 and MSR-VTT.
AI.result: TrajVLM-Gen outperforms existing methods, achieving competitive Fréchet Video Distance (FVD) scores of 545 on UCF-101 and 539 on MSR-VTT, indicating improved temporal coherence and physical plausibility relative to baselines.
AI.conclusion: The proposed two-stage framework demonstrates promise for physics-aware video synthesis by combining language-guided trajectory prediction with attention-based refinement and a physics-aware trajectory dataset. Further work should include broader physics scenarios, ablations, and clearer baselines to validate the reported gains.

title: Black-Box Time-Series Domain Adaptation via Cross-Prompt Foundation Models
summary:
The black-box domain adaptation (BBDA) topic is developed to address the
privacy and security issues where only an application programming interface
(API) of the source model is available for domain adaptations. Although the
BBDA topic has attracted growing research attentions, existing works mostly
target the vision applications and are not directly applicable to the
time-series applications possessing unique spatio-temporal characteristics. In
addition, none of existing approaches have explored the strength of foundation
model for black box time-series domain adaptation (BBTSDA). This paper proposes
a concept of Cross-Prompt Foundation Model (CPFM) for the BBTSDA problems. CPFM
is constructed under a dual branch network structure where each branch is
equipped with a unique prompt to capture different characteristics of data
distributions. In the domain adaptation phase, the reconstruction learning
phase in the prompt and input levels is developed. All of which are built upon
a time-series foundation model to overcome the spatio-temporal dynamic. Our
rigorous experiments substantiate the advantage of CPFM achieving improved
results with noticeable margins from its competitors in three time-series
datasets of different application domains.

AI.tldr: Proposes Cross-Prompt Foundation Model (CPFM) for BBTSDA, using dual-branch prompts and reconstruction learning on a time-series foundation model to handle spatio-temporal dynamics; shows improved results across three time-series datasets.
AI.motivation: Privacy and security constraints where only an API of the source model is available; BBDA has focused on vision and not well-suited to time-series; lack of exploration of foundation models for black-box time-series domain adaptation; need methods that leverage spatio-temporal structure under black-box access.
AI.method: Dual-branch network with each branch equipped with a unique prompt to capture different data distribution characteristics; domain adaptation phase includes reconstruction learning at both prompt and input levels; built on a time-series foundation model to handle spatio-temporal dynamics.
AI.result: Rigorous experiments on three time-series datasets from different domains show CPFM achieves improved results with noticeable margins over competitive approaches.
AI.conclusion: CPFM effectively enables BBTSDA by leveraging a prompt-based dual-branch architecture and reconstruction learning atop a time-series foundation model, addressing privacy constraints and spatio-temporal dynamics with demonstrated gains.

title: What You See is What You Ask: Evaluating Audio Descriptions
summary:
Audio descriptions (ADs) narrate important visual details in movies, enabling
Blind and Low Vision (BLV) users to understand narratives and appreciate visual
details. Existing works in automatic AD generation mostly focus on few-second
trimmed clips, and evaluate them by comparing against a single ground-truth
reference AD. However, writing ADs is inherently subjective. Through alignment
and analysis of two independent AD tracks for the same movies, we quantify the
subjectivity in when and whether to describe, and what and how to highlight.
Thus, we show that working with trimmed clips is inadequate. We propose ADQA, a
QA benchmark that evaluates ADs at the level of few-minute long, coherent video
segments, testing whether they would help BLV users understand the story and
appreciate visual details. ADQA features visual appreciation (VA) questions
about visual facts and narrative understanding (NU) questions based on the
plot. Through ADQA, we show that current AD generation methods lag far behind
human-authored ADs. We conclude with several recommendations for future work
and introduce a public leaderboard for benchmarking.

AI.tldr: Subjectivity in audio descriptions (ADs) is substantial and trimming clips is inadequate for evaluating ADs. Introduces ADQA, a benchmark for few-minute, coherent segments with visual appreciation (VA) and narrative understanding (NU) questions; finds current AD generation lags behind human-authored ADs and presents a public leaderboard with recommendations for future work.
AI.motivation: ADs enable blind/low-vision users to understand films. Existing automatic AD work focuses on short clips and single ground-truth references, neglecting subjectivity and coherence across longer segments. This work aims to quantify subjectivity and evaluate ADs at a longer, story-consistent scale.
AI.method: Align and analyze two independent AD tracks for the same movies to quantify when/what/how to describe (subjectivity). Propose ADQA, a QA benchmark for few-minute long, coherent video segments. ADQA includes Visual Appreciation (VA) questions about visual facts and Narrative Understanding (NU) questions about the plot. Evaluate current AD methods against human-authored ADs and provide public leaderboard and recommendations.
AI.result: Showing substantial subjectivity in AD writing and documenting inadequacies of trimmed clip evaluation. ADQA reveals that current automatic AD generation approaches lag behind human-authored descriptions in both VA and NU tasks across longer video segments; highlights gaps and informs future directions.
AI.conclusion: Encourages modeling and accounting for subjectivity, shifting evaluation to longer, coherent segments. Presents recommendations for future work and releases a public leaderboard to benchmark AD quality for BLV users.

title: Exploring System 1 and 2 communication for latent reasoning in LLMs
summary:
Should LLM reasoning live in a separate module, or within a single model's
forward pass and representational space? We study dual-architecture latent
reasoning, where a fluent Base exchanges latent messages with a Coprocessor,
and test two hypotheses aimed at improving latent communication over Liu et al.
(2024): (H1) increase channel capacity; (H2) learn communication via joint
finetuning. Under matched latent-token budgets on GPT-2 and Qwen-3, H2 is
consistently strongest while H1 yields modest gains. A unified soft-embedding
baseline, a single model with the same forward pass and shared representations,
using the same latent-token budget, nearly matches H2 and surpasses H1,
suggesting current dual designs mostly add compute rather than qualitatively
improving reasoning. Across GSM8K, ProsQA, and a Countdown stress test with
increasing branching factor, scaling the latent-token budget beyond small
values fails to improve robustness. Latent analyses show overlapping subspaces
with limited specialization, consistent with weak reasoning gains. We conclude
dual-model latent reasoning remains promising in principle, but likely requires
objectives and communication mechanisms that explicitly shape latent spaces for
algorithmic planning.

AI.tldr: Dual-architecture latent reasoning (Base + Coprocessor) shows joint finetuning (H2) outperforms simply increasing latent-channel capacity (H1); a single unified soft-embedding baseline nearly matches H2 and beats H1, suggesting dual designs mainly add compute rather than improve reasoning. Scaling latent-token budgets beyond small values does not boost robustness; latent spaces are overlapping with limited specialization. Conclusion: dual-model latent reasoning is promising but requires objectives and communication mechanisms that shape latent spaces for algorithmic planning.
AI.motivation: Evaluate whether latent reasoning should reside in a separate module or within a single model, by testing dual-architecture latent reasoning and two hypotheses to improve latent communication, across multiple benchmarks and analyses.
AI.method: 1) Compare H1 (increase channel capacity) vs H2 (joint finetuning) in a dual-model setup with Base and Coprocessor on GPT-2 and Qwen-3 under matched latent-token budgets. 2) Include a unified soft-embedding baseline (single model with shared representations and same latent-token budget). 3) Evaluate on GSM8K, ProsQA, and a Countdown stress test with increasing branching factor. 4) Conduct latent-space analyses to assess subspace overlap and specialization.
AI.result: Under matched budgets, H2 is consistently strongest; H1 yields modest gains. The unified soft-embedding baseline nearly matches H2 and surpasses H1. Scaling latent-token budget beyond small values fails to improve robustness across tasks. Latent analyses reveal overlapping subspaces with limited specialization, indicating weak gains from latent reasoning. Dual-model latent reasoning remains promising but likely requires objectives and communication mechanisms that explicitly shape latent spaces for algorithmic planning.
AI.conclusion: Dual-model latent reasoning is plausible and potentially beneficial, but current designs add compute with limited qualitative gains. Realizing benefits likely requires objective functions and communication protocols that actively shape latent spaces for effective algorithmic planning.

title: PhraseStereo: The First Open-Vocabulary Stereo Image Segmentation Dataset
comment:
Accepted to X-Sense Ego-Exo Sensing for Smart Mobility Workshop at
  ICCV 2025 Conference
summary:
Understanding how natural language phrases correspond to specific regions in
images is a key challenge in multimodal semantic segmentation. Recent advances
in phrase grounding are largely limited to single-view images, neglecting the
rich geometric cues available in stereo vision. For this, we introduce
PhraseStereo, the first novel dataset that brings phrase-region segmentation to
stereo image pairs. PhraseStereo builds upon the PhraseCut dataset by
leveraging GenStereo to generate accurate right-view images from existing
single-view data, enabling the extension of phrase grounding into the stereo
domain. This new setting introduces unique challenges and opportunities for
multimodal learning, particularly in leveraging depth cues for more precise and
context-aware grounding. By providing stereo image pairs with aligned
segmentation masks and phrase annotations, PhraseStereo lays the foundation for
future research at the intersection of language, vision, and 3D perception,
encouraging the development of models that can reason jointly over semantics
and geometry. The PhraseStereo dataset will be released online upon acceptance
of this work.

AI.tldr: Introduces PhraseStereo, a stereo-phrase grounding dataset that extends phrase-region segmentation to stereo image pairs by generating right views from single-view data using GenStereo, enabling depth-aware grounding and joint language-geometry reasoning.
AI.motivation: Current phrase grounding mostly handles single-view imagery and misses rich geometric cues from stereo. PhraseStereo aims to bridge language and 3D perception by providing aligned stereo pairs with phrase-level segmentation masks.
AI.method: Builds on PhraseCut; uses GenStereo to synthesize accurate right-view images from existing single-view data; produces stereo image pairs with aligned segmentation masks and phrase annotations; lays groundwork for stereo-aware grounding models.
AI.result: First dataset to bring phrase-region segmentation to stereo images; enables exploration of depth cues in grounding; dataset will be released online upon acceptance.
AI.conclusion: PhraseStereo enables joint reasoning over semantics and geometry, encouraging models that utilize depth cues for more precise and context-aware grounding in multimodal learning.

title: Diffusion Alignment as Variational Expectation-Maximization
summary:
Diffusion alignment aims to optimize diffusion models for the downstream
objective. While existing methods based on reinforcement learning or direct
backpropagation achieve considerable success in maximizing rewards, they often
suffer from reward over-optimization and mode collapse. We introduce Diffusion
Alignment as Variational Expectation-Maximization (DAV), a framework that
formulates diffusion alignment as an iterative process alternating between two
complementary phases: the E-step and the M-step. In the E-step, we employ
test-time search to generate diverse and reward-aligned samples. In the M-step,
we refine the diffusion model using samples discovered by the E-step. We
demonstrate that DAV can optimize reward while preserving diversity for both
continuous and discrete tasks: text-to-image synthesis and DNA sequence design.

AI.tldr: DAV reframes diffusion alignment as a variational EM process that alternates E-step test-time search for diverse, reward-aligned samples and M-step diffusion-model refinement, achieving reward optimization while maintaining diversity on continuous and discrete tasks (text-to-image and DNA sequence design).
AI.motivation: To address reward over-optimization and mode collapse common in RL-based or direct backprop methods, by enforcing a principled EM-like alternation that preserves sample diversity while improving downstream rewards.
AI.method: Iterative E-step and M-step: E-step performs test-time search to produce diverse, reward-aligned samples; M-step updates/refines the diffusion model using those samples.
AI.result: Empirically demonstrates effective reward optimization without sacrificing diversity across both continuous (text-to-image synthesis) and discrete (DNA sequence design) domains.
AI.conclusion: An EM-inspired framework for diffusion alignment (DAV) that balances reward maximization and sample diversity across modalities.

title: NSARM: Next-Scale Autoregressive Modeling for Robust Real-World Image Super-Resolution
summary:
Most recent real-world image super-resolution (Real-ISR) methods employ
pre-trained text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models to synthesize the high-quality
image either from random Gaussian noise, which yields realistic results but is
slow due to iterative denoising, or directly from the input low-quality image,
which is efficient but at the price of lower output quality. These approaches
train ControlNet or LoRA modules while keeping the pre-trained model fixed,
which often introduces over-enhanced artifacts and hallucinations, suffering
from the robustness to inputs of varying degradations. Recent visual
autoregressive (AR) models, such as pre-trained Infinity, can provide strong
T2I generation capabilities while offering superior efficiency by using the
bitwise next-scale prediction strategy. Building upon next-scale prediction, we
introduce a robust Real-ISR framework, namely Next-Scale Autoregressive
Modeling (NSARM). Specifically, we train NSARM in two stages: a transformation
network is first trained to map the input low-quality image to preliminary
scales, followed by an end-to-end full-model fine-tuning. Such a comprehensive
fine-tuning enhances the robustness of NSARM in Real-ISR tasks without
compromising its generative capability. Extensive quantitative and qualitative
evaluations demonstrate that as a pure AR model, NSARM achieves superior visual
results over existing Real-ISR methods while maintaining a fast inference
speed. Most importantly, it demonstrates much higher robustness to the quality
of input images, showing stronger generalization performance. Project page:
https://github.com/Xiangtaokong/NSARM

AI.tldr: NSARM is a two-stage Next-Scale Autoregressive Model for Real-ISR that uses a transformation network to produce preliminary scales from a low-quality input, followed by end-to-end fine-tuning with a pure autoregressive next-scale prediction. It delivers robust, high-quality, fast inference, outperforming diffusion-based and other Real-ISR methods and shows strong generalization across degradations.
AI.motivation: Real-world image super-resolution (Real-ISR) must handle diverse degradations and robustness is a major challenge. Diffusion-based methods are either slow (iterative denoising from noise) or rely on input-driven generation that can produce artifacts. ControlNet/LoRA adaptations can cause over-enhancement and hallucinations, and autoregressive (AR) models offer efficiency but need robustness. There is a need for a robust, fast AR-based Real-ISR method.
AI.method: Train NSARM in two stages: (1) a transformation network maps the input low-quality image to preliminary scales, (2) end-to-end full-model fine-tuning. The model uses a pure autoregressive next-scale prediction (bitwise) approach, enabling robust generation without restricting the pre-trained diffusion models. The two-stage training aims to improve robustness to input degradations while preserving generative capability.
AI.result: Extensive quantitative and qualitative evaluations show that NSARM, as a pure AR model, achieves superior visual results compared with existing Real-ISR methods, while maintaining fast inference speed. It demonstrates high robustness to input quality and strong generalization across degradations.
AI.conclusion: NSARM demonstrates that a two-stage, pure autoregressive Real-ISR framework with next-scale prediction can offer robust, high-quality, and efficient image SR, addressing limitations of diffusion-based methods and diffusion-free AR approaches. The approach shows promise for real-world applicability and generalization.

title: Understanding Sensitivity of Differential Attention through the Lens of Adversarial Robustness
summary:
Differential Attention (DA) has been proposed as a refinement to standard
attention, suppressing redundant or noisy context through a subtractive
structure and thereby reducing contextual hallucination. While this design
sharpens task-relevant focus, we show that it also introduces a structural
fragility under adversarial perturbations. Our theoretical analysis identifies
negative gradient alignment-a configuration encouraged by DA's subtraction-as
the key driver of sensitivity amplification, leading to increased gradient
norms and elevated local Lipschitz constants. We empirically validate this
Fragile Principle through systematic experiments on ViT/DiffViT and evaluations
of pretrained CLIP/DiffCLIP, spanning five datasets in total. These results
demonstrate higher attack success rates, frequent gradient opposition, and
stronger local sensitivity compared to standard attention. Furthermore,
depth-dependent experiments reveal a robustness crossover: stacking DA layers
attenuates small perturbations via depth-dependent noise cancellation, though
this protection fades under larger attack budgets. Overall, our findings
uncover a fundamental trade-off: DA improves discriminative focus on clean
inputs but increases adversarial vulnerability, underscoring the need to
jointly design for selectivity and robustness in future attention mechanisms.

AI.tldr: Differential Attention sharpens focus by subtracting context but makes models more vulnerable to adversarial perturbations due to negative gradient alignment; depth helps only against small perturbations and the gain is lost with larger attacks, revealing a selectivity-robustness trade-off.
AI.motivation: To understand whether subtractive Differential Attention (DA), intended to suppress noisy context, introduces fragile behavior under adversarial perturbations, and to quantify the mechanisms (gradient alignment, Lipschitz properties) and practical robustness across vision transformers and CLIP-based models.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of gradient alignment and local Lipschitz constants; empirical evaluation on ViT, DiffViT and pretrained CLIP/DiffCLIP across five datasets; depth-varying experiments to study robustness as DA layers stack.
AI.result: Negative gradient alignment induced by subtraction drives sensitivity amplification; DA exhibits higher gradient norms, larger local Lipschitz constants; increased attack success rates, more gradient opposition, and stronger local sensitivity compared with standard attention; depth stacking provides some noise-cancellation to small perturbations but loses protection under larger attack budgets.
AI.conclusion: DA improves discriminative focus on clean inputs but increases adversarial vulnerability; future attention designs should balance selectivity and robustness rather than optimize only for clean-data performance.

title: Feature Identification for Hierarchical Contrastive Learning
summary:
Hierarchical classification is a crucial task in many applications, where
objects are organized into multiple levels of categories. However, conventional
classification approaches often neglect inherent inter-class relationships at
different hierarchy levels, thus missing important supervisory signals. Thus,
we propose two novel hierarchical contrastive learning (HMLC) methods. The
first, leverages a Gaussian Mixture Model (G-HMLC) and the second uses an
attention mechanism to capture hierarchy-specific features (A-HMLC), imitating
human processing. Our approach explicitly models inter-class relationships and
imbalanced class distribution at higher hierarchy levels, enabling fine-grained
clustering across all hierarchy levels. On the competitive CIFAR100 and
ModelNet40 datasets, our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in linear
evaluation, outperforming existing hierarchical contrastive learning methods by
2 percentage points in terms of accuracy. The effectiveness of our approach is
backed by both quantitative and qualitative results, highlighting its potential
for applications in computer vision and beyond.

AI.tldr: Introduces two hierarchical contrastive learning methods (G-HMLC and A-HMLC) that model inter-class, hierarchy-level relationships and handle imbalanced distributions, achieving state-of-the-art linear evaluation on CIFAR100 and ModelNet40 and outperforming prior hierarchical contrastive methods by about 2 percentage points.
AI.motivation: Conventional classification often ignores the inherent inter-class relationships across hierarchy levels, missing supervisory signals. Hierarchical data exhibit inter-class relations and class imbalance at higher levels, which can hinder fine-grained clustering and representation learning.
AI.method: G-HMLC uses a Gaussian Mixture Model to explicitly model inter-class relationships across hierarchy levels. A-HMLC employs an attention mechanism to capture hierarchy-specific features, mimicking human processing. Both approaches address imbalance and hierarchical relationships to enable fine-grained clustering across all levels.
AI.result: On CIFAR100 and ModelNet40, the methods achieve state-of-the-art performance in linear evaluation, outperforming existing hierarchical contrastive learning methods by approximately 2 percentage points in accuracy. Quantitative and qualitative analyses support the effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hierarchical contrastive learning framework demonstrates strong potential for hierarchical representation learning in computer vision and beyond, offering improved clustering and downstream performance by explicitly modeling hierarchy-aware relationships.

title: Spectral Scaling Laws in Language Models: How Effectively Do Feed-Forward Networks Use Their Latent Space?
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) scale, the question is not only how large
they become, but how much of their capacity is effectively utilized. Existing
scaling laws relate model size to loss, yet overlook how components exploit
their latent space. We study feed-forward networks (FFNs) and recast width
selection as a spectral utilization problem. Using a lightweight diagnostic
suite -- Hard Rank (participation ratio), Soft Rank (Shannon rank), Spectral
Concentration, and the composite Spectral Utilization Index (SUI) -- we
quantify how many latent directions are meaningfully activated across LLaMA,
GPT-2, and nGPT families. Our key finding is an asymmetric spectral scaling
law: soft rank follows an almost perfect power law with FFN width, while hard
rank grows only sublinearly and with high variance. This asymmetry suggests
that widening FFNs mostly adds low-energy tail directions, while dominant-mode
subspaces saturate early. Moreover, at larger widths, variance further
collapses into a narrow subspace, leaving much of the latent space
under-utilized. These results recast FFN width selection as a principled
trade-off between tail capacity and dominant-mode capacity, offering concrete
guidance for inference-efficient LLM design.

AI.tldr: FFN width scaling in LLMs exhibits asymmetric spectral utilization: soft rank scales nearly perfectly with width, hard rank grows sublinearly with high variance; widening mainly adds low-energy directions and eventually narrows the active latent subspace, suggesting a trade-off between tail capacity and dominant-mode capacity for inference-efficient design.
AI.motivation: Existing scaling laws tie model size to loss but ignore how latent directions are actually utilized. Understanding spectral utilization of FFNs can guide width selection for efficiency.
AI.method: Introduce a lightweight diagnostic suite: Hard Rank (participation ratio), Soft Rank (Shannon rank), Spectral Concentration, and the composite Spectral Utilization Index (SUI). Apply these diagnostics to FFNs across LLaMA, GPT-2, and nGPT model families to quantify the number of meaningfully activated latent directions.
AI.result: Soft rank follows an almost perfect power-law with FFN width; hard rank grows sublinearly with high variance. Widening FFNs largely adds low-energy tail directions while dominant-mode subspaces saturate early. At larger widths, variance collapses into a narrow subspace, leaving much of the latent space under-utilized. This yields a clear asymmetry in spectral scaling and a practical trade-off between tail capacity and dominant-mode capacity.
AI.conclusion: FFN width selection should balance tail and dominant-mode capacity, guiding the design of inference-efficient LLMs by quantifying how width affects latent-space utilization.

title: Can World Models Benefit VLMs for World Dynamics?
summary:
Trained on internet-scale video data, generative world models are
increasingly recognized as powerful world simulators that can generate
consistent and plausible dynamics over structure, motion, and physics. This
raises a natural question: with the advent of strong video foundational models,
might they supplant conventional vision encoder paradigms for general-purpose
multimodal understanding? While recent studies have begun to explore the
potential of world models on common vision tasks, these explorations typically
lack a systematic investigation of generic, multimodal tasks. In this work, we
strive to investigate the capabilities when world model priors are transferred
into Vision-Language Models: we re-purpose a video diffusion model as a
generative encoder to perform a single denoising step and treat the resulting
latents as a set of visual embedding. We empirically investigate this class of
models, which we refer to as World-Language Models (WorldLMs), and we find that
generative encoders can capture latents useful for downstream understanding
that show distinctions from conventional encoders. Naming our best-performing
variant Dynamic Vision Aligner (DyVA), we further discover that this method
significantly enhances spatial reasoning abilities and enables single-image
models to perform multi-frame reasoning. Through the curation of a suite of
visual reasoning tasks, we find DyVA to surpass both open-source and
proprietary baselines, achieving state-of-the-art or comparable performance. We
attribute these gains to WorldLM's inherited motion-consistency internalization
from video pre-training. Finally, we systematically explore extensive model
designs to highlight promising directions for future work. We hope our study
can pave the way for a new family of VLMs that leverage priors from world
models and are on a promising path towards generalist vision learners.

AI.tldr: WorldLMs repurpose video-based generative priors as a single-step generative encoder to produce visual embeddings for Vision-Language Models (VLMs). The resulting DyVA variant enhances spatial and multi-frame reasoning, surpassing baselines on visual reasoning tasks and suggesting a path toward generalist vision learners.
AI.motivation: To systematically investigate whether priors learned from large-scale video world models can improve multimodal understanding by serving as encoders for Vision-Language Models, addressing gaps where prior work has lacked broad, multimodal evaluation.
AI.method: Convert a video diffusion model into a one-step generative encoder; treat the denoised latent as a visual embedding; create WorldLM family with Dynamic Vision Aligner (DyVA) as the best variant; evaluate on a curated suite of visual reasoning tasks; analyze motion-consistency and compare to open-source and proprietary baselines; perform design-space exploration to identify promising directions.
AI.result: DyVA achieves state-of-the-art or comparable performance on the visual reasoning suite, improves spatial reasoning and enables single-image models to perform multi-frame reasoning, and exhibits latents that encode useful downstream information distinct from conventional encoders. The gains are attributed to motion-consistency priors learned from video pre-training.
AI.conclusion: WorldLMs offer a promising direction toward generalist vision learners by leveraging priors from world models; extensive design-space exploration and broader multimodal evaluation appear beneficial for future work.

title: Interpretable Machine Learning for Life Expectancy Prediction: A Comparative Study of Linear Regression, Decision Tree, and Random Forest
summary:
Life expectancy is a fundamental indicator of population health and
socio-economic well-being, yet accurately forecasting it remains challenging
due to the interplay of demographic, environmental, and healthcare factors.
This study evaluates three machine learning models -- Linear Regression (LR),
Regression Decision Tree (RDT), and Random Forest (RF), using a real-world
dataset drawn from World Health Organization (WHO) and United Nations (UN)
sources. After extensive preprocessing to address missing values and
inconsistencies, each model's performance was assessed with $R^2$, Mean
Absolute Error (MAE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). Results show that RF
achieves the highest predictive accuracy ($R^2 = 0.9423$), significantly
outperforming LR and RDT. Interpretability was prioritized through p-values for
LR and feature importance metrics for the tree-based models, revealing
immunization rates (diphtheria, measles) and demographic attributes (HIV/AIDS,
adult mortality) as critical drivers of life-expectancy predictions. These
insights underscore the synergy between ensemble methods and transparency in
addressing public-health challenges. Future research should explore advanced
imputation strategies, alternative algorithms (e.g., neural networks), and
updated data to further refine predictive accuracy and support evidence-based
policymaking in global health contexts.

AI.tldr: Random Forest (RF) best predicts life expectancy on WHO/UN data, outperforming Linear Regression (LR) and Regression Decision Tree (RDT); key drivers include immunization rates (diphtheria, measles) and demographic factors (HIV/AIDS, adult mortality); suggests combining ensemble methods with transparent interpretation; future work includes advanced imputation and exploring neural networks for potential gains.
AI.motivation: Accurately forecasting life expectancy is hard due to interactions among demographic, environmental, and healthcare factors, and reliable predictions are essential for public-health policy and resource allocation.
AI.method: Comparative evaluation of three ML models: LR, RDT, RF on a real-world dataset from WHO/UN; extensive preprocessing for missing values; performance measured by R^2, MAE, RMSE; interpretability via p-values for LR and feature importances for tree-based models.
AI.result: RF achieved the highest predictive accuracy with R^2 = 0.9423, outperforming LR and RDT. Interpretability highlighted immunization rates and demographic attributes as critical drivers.
AI.conclusion: Ensemble methods + transparent interpretation can address public-health challenges; future work: better imputation strategies, exploration of alternative algorithms (e.g., neural networks), updated data to improve accuracy for evidence-based policymaking in global health.

title: Gather-Scatter Mamba: Accelerating Propagation with Efficient State Space Model
summary:
State Space Models (SSMs)-most notably RNNs-have historically played a
central role in sequential modeling. Although attention mechanisms such as
Transformers have since dominated due to their ability to model global context,
their quadratic complexity and limited scalability make them less suited for
long sequences. Video super-resolution (VSR) methods have traditionally relied
on recurrent architectures to propagate features across frames. However, such
approaches suffer from well-known issues including vanishing gradients, lack of
parallelism, and slow inference speed. Recent advances in selective SSMs like
Mamba offer a compelling alternative: by enabling input-dependent state
transitions with linear-time complexity, Mamba mitigates these issues while
maintaining strong long-range modeling capabilities. Despite this potential,
Mamba alone struggles to capture fine-grained spatial dependencies due to its
causal nature and lack of explicit context aggregation. To address this, we
propose a hybrid architecture that combines shifted window self-attention for
spatial context aggregation with Mamba-based selective scanning for efficient
temporal propagation. Furthermore, we introduce Gather-Scatter Mamba (GSM), an
alignment-aware mechanism that warps features toward a center anchor frame
within the temporal window before Mamba propagation and scatters them back
afterward, effectively reducing occlusion artifacts and ensuring effective
redistribution of aggregated information across all frames. The official
implementation is provided at: https://github.com/Ko-Lani/GSMamba.

AI.tldr: Hybrid GSMamba for video super-resolution: combines shifted window attention for spatial context with Mamba's linear-time selective temporal propagation, and introduces Gather-Scatter Mamba (GSM) to align/redistribute features around a center anchor frame, reducing occlusion and maintaining efficiency.
AI.motivation: Transformers offer strong global context but have quadratic complexity and poor scalability for long sequences; standard SSMs (e.g., Mamba) enable input-dependent, linear-time temporal transitions but lack fine-grained spatial context due to causality. Video super-resolution requires both long-range temporal modeling and rich spatial detail, so an architecture that fuses efficient temporal propagation with spatial context aggregation and occlusion mitigation is desirable.
AI.method: Propose a hybrid architecture that (1) uses shifted window self-attention to aggregate spatial context within local windows, (2) employs Mamba-based selective scanning for efficient temporal propagation, and (3) introduces Gather-Scatter Mamba (GSM) — an alignment-aware mechanism that warps features toward a center anchor frame within the temporal window before Mamba propagation and scatters them back afterward to reduce occlusion and improve redistribution of aggregated information across frames.
AI.result: The abstract does not report quantitative results. It asserts that the approach mitigates Mamba’s spatial limitations, reduces occlusion artifacts, and provides an implementation (GitHub link) for reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: GSMamba presents a practical, alignment-aware VSR framework that combines spatial context aggregation with efficient temporal propagation, aiming to achieve good long-range modeling with linear-time complexity; code is released for evaluation.

title: On Predictability of Reinforcement Learning Dynamics for Large Language Models
summary:
Recent advances in reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs) are
largely driven by reinforcement learning (RL), yet the underlying parameter
dynamics during RL training remain poorly understood. This work identifies two
fundamental properties of RL-induced parameter updates in LLMs: (1) Rank-1
Dominance, where the top singular subspace of the parameter update matrix
nearly fully determines reasoning improvements, recovering over 99\% of
performance gains; and (2) Rank-1 Linear Dynamics, where this dominant subspace
evolves linearly throughout training, enabling accurate prediction from early
checkpoints. Extensive experiments across 8 LLMs and 7 algorithms validate the
generalizability of these properties. More importantly, based on these
findings, we propose AlphaRL, a plug-in acceleration framework that
extrapolates the final parameter update using a short early training window,
achieving up to 2.5 speedup while retaining \textgreater 96\% of reasoning
performance without extra modules or hyperparameter tuning. This positions our
finding as a versatile and practical tool for large-scale RL, opening a path
toward principled, interpretable, and efficient training paradigm for LLMs.

AI.tldr: RL training in LLMs is dominated by a Rank-1 update: a single dominant subspace largely drives gains and evolves linearly; this enables AlphaRL to extrapolate final updates from early training, achieving substantial speedups with minimal performance loss.
AI.motivation: To understand parameter dynamics during RL fine-tuning of large language models and to identify predictive, generalizable patterns that enable faster, more interpretable training.
AI.method: Empirical analysis across 8 LLMs and 7 RL algorithms. Perform singular value decomposition on parameter update matrices to measure the explained variance of the top singular vector. Track the evolution of the dominant subspace over training to test Rank-1 Linear Dynamics. Develop AlphaRL as a plug-in that extrapolates the final parameter update from a short early training window without additional modules or tuned hyperparameters.
AI.result: Rank-1 Dominance: the top singular subspace nearly fully determines reasoning improvements, explaining >99% of gains. Rank-1 Linear Dynamics: the dominant subspace evolves linearly throughout training, enabling accurate prediction from early checkpoints. Generalization across 8 LLMs and 7 RL algorithms. AlphaRL achieves up to 2.5x speedup while preserving >96% of reasoning performance, with no extra modules or hyperparameter tuning.
AI.conclusion: Reveals a simple, interpretable structure in RL-driven parameter updates for LLMs and offers a practical acceleration framework. This supports a principled, efficient, and interpretable RL paradigm for LLMs, with AlphaRL as a plug-in method to accelerate training.

title: AI-CNet3D: An Anatomically-Informed Cross-Attention Network with Multi-Task Consistency Fine-tuning for 3D Glaucoma Classification
comment:
Accepted for publication at the Journal of Machine Learning for
  Biomedical Imaging (MELBA) https://melba-journal.org/2025:018
summary:
Glaucoma is a progressive eye disease that leads to optic nerve damage,
causing irreversible vision loss if left untreated. Optical coherence
tomography (OCT) has become a crucial tool for glaucoma diagnosis, offering
high-resolution 3D scans of the retina and optic nerve. However, the
conventional practice of condensing information from 3D OCT volumes into 2D
reports often results in the loss of key structural details. To address this,
we propose a novel hybrid deep learning model that integrates cross-attention
mechanisms into a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN), enabling the
extraction of critical features from the superior and inferior hemiretinas, as
well as from the optic nerve head (ONH) and macula, within OCT volumes. We
introduce Channel Attention REpresentations (CAREs) to visualize
cross-attention outputs and leverage them for consistency-based multi-task
fine-tuning, aligning them with Gradient-Weighted Class Activation Maps
(Grad-CAMs) from the CNN's final convolutional layer to enhance performance,
interpretability, and anatomical coherence. We have named this model AI-CNet3D
(AI-`See'-Net3D) to reflect its design as an Anatomically-Informed
Cross-attention Network operating on 3D data. By dividing the volume along two
axes and applying cross-attention, our model enhances glaucoma classification
by capturing asymmetries between the hemiretinal regions while integrating
information from the optic nerve head and macula. We validate our approach on
two large datasets, showing that it outperforms state-of-the-art attention and
convolutional models across all key metrics. Finally, our model is
computationally efficient, reducing the parameter count by one-hundred--fold
compared to other attention mechanisms while maintaining high diagnostic
performance and comparable GFLOPS.

AI.tldr: An anatomically-informed 3D cross-attention network for OCT glaucoma diagnosis that jointly analyzes the superior/inferior hemiretinas, optic nerve head, and macula. It uses Channel Attention Representations (CAREs) to visualize cross-attention and aligns them with Grad-CAMs for interpretability, achieving superior performance with ~100x fewer parameters than other attention models while maintaining efficiency, validated on two large datasets.
AI.motivation: Condensing 3D OCT volumes into 2D reports loses crucial structural details. There is a need for models that (1) exploit 3D anatomical structure across hemiretinas, ONH, and macula; (2) provide interpretable visualizations of attention; and (3) do so efficiently for practical clinical deployment.
AI.method: A 3D CNN with cross-attention integrated across two axes to compare the superior and inferior hemiretinas while incorporating information from the optic nerve head and macula. Introduces Channel Attention Representations (CAREs) to visualize cross-attention outputs. Employs consistency-based multi-task fine-tuning to align CAREs with Grad-CAMs from the CNN’s final convolutional layer. The model, named AI-CNet3D (AI-'See'-Net3D), divides volumes along two axes to capture inter-hemiretinal asymmetries and fuses information from ONH and macula. The approach emphasizes anatomical coherence and interpretability while maintaining computational efficiency (significantly reduced parameters with comparable GFLOPS).
AI.result: The model outperforms state-of-the-art attention-based and CNN architectures on two large glaucoma OCT datasets across key metrics, demonstrating higher diagnostic performance with a substantial reduction in parameter count (≈100× fewer parameters) while preserving GFLOPS and interpretability through CAREs aligned with Grad-CAMs.
AI.conclusion: AI-CNet3D offers a more accurate, interpretable, and efficient solution for glaucoma classification from 3D OCT data by leveraging anatomically informed cross-attention across relevant retinal structures and providing visualization via CAREs that align with Grad-CAMs.

title: Memory Determines Learning Direction: A Theory of Gradient-Based Optimization in State Space Models
summary:
State space models (SSMs) have gained attention by showing potential to
outperform Transformers. However, previous studies have not sufficiently
addressed the mechanisms underlying their high performance owing to a lack of
theoretical explanation of SSMs' learning dynamics. In this study, we provide
such an explanation and propose an improved training strategy. The memory
capacity of SSMs can be evaluated by examining how input time series are stored
in their current state. Such an examination reveals a tradeoff between memory
accuracy and length, as well as the theoretical equivalence between the
structured state space sequence model (S4) and a simplified S4 with diagonal
recurrent weights. This theoretical foundation allows us to elucidate the
learning dynamics, proving the importance of initial parameters. Our analytical
results suggest that successful learning requires the initial memory structure
to be the longest possible even if memory accuracy may deteriorate or the
gradient lose the teacher information. Experiments on tasks requiring long
memory confirmed that extending memory is difficult, emphasizing the importance
of initialization. Furthermore, we found that fixing recurrent weights can be
more advantageous than adapting them because it achieves comparable or even
higher performance with faster convergence. Our results provide a new
theoretical foundation for SSMs and potentially offer a novel optimization
strategy.

AI.tldr: The paper provides a theoretical foundation for state space models (SSMs), linking memory capacity to state storage, revealing a memory-length tradeoff and an equivalence with a diagonal-recurrent S4; it also shows initialization and fixed recurrent weights can accelerate learning and improve performance.
AI.motivation: To explain why SSMs can outperform Transformers by deriving their learning dynamics and memory mechanisms, addressing the lack of theoretical understanding and guiding optimization.
AI.method: Analytical analysis of how input time series are stored in the current state to quantify memory capacity, derivation of a memory-length tradeoff, demonstration of the theoretical equivalence between S4 and a diagonal-recurrent variant, and investigation of learning dynamics with emphasis on initialization; experimental validation on long-memory tasks comparing strategies like fixing vs training recurrent weights.
AI.result: Memory capacity is tied to the longest memory structure in initialization; extending memory is difficult yet crucial for performance. Fixing recurrent weights can achieve similar or better performance with faster convergence, and learning dynamics reveal that initial parameters play a key role.
AI.conclusion: Provides a theoretical foundation for SSMs, explains their strong performance, and suggests practical optimization strategies (e.g., favorable initialization and possibly fixed recurrent weights) to improve training dynamics and efficiency.

title: Intuitions of Machine Learning Researchers about Transfer Learning for Medical Image Classification
summary:
Transfer learning is crucial for medical imaging, yet the selection of source
datasets - which can impact the generalizability of algorithms, and thus
patient outcomes - often relies on researchers' intuition rather than
systematic principles. This study investigates these decisions through a
task-based survey with machine learning practitioners. Unlike prior work that
benchmarks models and experimental setups, we take a human-centered HCI
perspective on how practitioners select source datasets. Our findings indicate
that choices are task-dependent and influenced by community practices, dataset
properties, and computational (data embedding), or perceived visual or semantic
similarity. However, similarity ratings and expected performance are not always
aligned, challenging a traditional "more similar is better" view. Participants
often used ambiguous terminology, which suggests a need for clearer definitions
and HCI tools to make them explicit and usable. By clarifying these heuristics,
this work provides practical insights for more systematic source selection in
transfer learning.

AI.tldr: A task-based survey reveals human factors in transfer learning source dataset selection for medical imaging; decisions are task-dependent and influenced by community norms, dataset properties, and perceived similarity, but similarity doesn't always predict performance; highlights need for clearer definitions and HCI tools.
AI.motivation: Transfer learning in medical imaging is highly sensitive to the choice of source datasets, which affects generalizability and patient outcomes. Decisions are often intuitive; this work seeks systematic, human-centered insights to improve source selection.
AI.method: Task-based survey with machine learning practitioners, adopting a human-computer interaction (HCI) perspective to understand how practitioners select source datasets, contrasting with model- and setup-focused benchmarks.
AI.result: Findings show task-dependent choices influenced by community practices, dataset properties, and computational/data-embedding aspects; perceived visual/semantic similarity does not always align with expected performance; practitioners use ambiguous terminology, underscoring the need for clearer definitions and HCI tools to make heuristics explicit.
AI.conclusion: Clarifying heuristics and developing practical HCI aids can enable more systematic and reliable source dataset selection in transfer learning for medical imaging.

title: Panorama: Fast-Track Nearest Neighbors
summary:
Approximate Nearest-Neighbor Search (ANNS) efficiently finds data items whose
embeddings are close to that of a given query in a high-dimensional space,
aiming to balance accuracy with speed. Used in recommendation systems, image
and video retrieval, natural language processing, and retrieval-augmented
generation (RAG), ANNS algorithms such as IVFPQ, HNSW graphs, Annoy, and MRPT
utilize graph, tree, clustering, and quantization techniques to navigate large
vector spaces. Despite this progress, ANNS systems spend up to 99\% of query
time to compute distances in their final refinement phase. In this paper, we
present PANORAMA, a machine learning-driven approach that tackles the ANNS
verification bottleneck through data-adaptive learned orthogonal transforms
that facilitate the accretive refinement of distance bounds. Such transforms
compact over 90\% of signal energy into the first half of dimensions, enabling
early candidate pruning with partial distance computations. We integrate
PANORAMA into state-of-the-art ANNS methods, namely IVFPQ/Flat, HNSW, MRPT, and
Annoy, without index modification, using level-major memory layouts,
SIMD-vectorized partial distance computations, and cache-aware access patterns.
Experiments across diverse datasets -- from image-based CIFAR-10 and GIST to
modern embedding spaces including OpenAI's Ada 2 and Large 3 -- demonstrate
that PANORAMA affords a 2--30$\times$ end-to-end speedup with no recall loss.

AI.tldr: PANORAMA uses data-adaptive learned orthogonal transforms to accelerate the verification phase of ANNS by concentrating energy in the first half of dimensions, enabling early pruning with partial distances. It integrates with major ANNS backbones without index changes and delivers 2–30x end-to-end speedups with no recall loss on diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: The final refinement stage of ANNS spends the vast majority of query time computing distances, creating a verification bottleneck. A data-adaptive transform that tightens distance bounds can prune candidates earlier without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: Train orthogonal transforms that compact >90% of signal energy into the first half of dimensions, enabling accretive refinement of distance bounds. Integrate PANORAMA into IVFPQ/Flat, HNSW, MRPT, and Annoy using level-major memory layouts, SIMD-vectorized partial distances, and cache-aware access, with no changes to existing indices.
AI.result: End-to-end speedups of 2× to 30× with no recall loss across diverse datasets (CIFAR-10, GIST, OpenAI Ada 2, OpenAI Large 3 embeddings).
AI.conclusion: PANORAMA provides a practical, ML-driven solution to the ANNS verification bottleneck, compatible with multiple backbones and datasets, delivering substantial speedups while preserving recall.

title: PAL-Net: A Point-Wise CNN with Patch-Attention for 3D Facial Landmark Localization
summary:
Manual annotation of anatomical landmarks on 3D facial scans is a
time-consuming and expertise-dependent task, yet it remains critical for
clinical assessments, morphometric analysis, and craniofacial research. While
several deep learning methods have been proposed for facial landmark
localization, most focus on pseudo-landmarks or require complex input
representations, limiting their clinical applicability. This study presents a
fully automated deep learning pipeline (PAL-Net) for localizing 50 anatomical
landmarks on stereo-photogrammetry facial models. The method combines coarse
alignment, region-of-interest filtering, and an initial approximation of
landmarks with a patch-based pointwise CNN enhanced by attention mechanisms.
Trained and evaluated on 214 annotated scans from healthy adults, PAL-Net
achieved a mean localization error of 3.686 mm and preserves relevant
anatomical distances with a 2.822 mm average error, comparable to
intra-observer variability. To assess generalization, the model was further
evaluated on 700 subjects from the FaceScape dataset, achieving a point-wise
error of 0.41\,mm and a distance-wise error of 0.38\,mm. Compared to existing
methods, PAL-Net offers a favorable trade-off between accuracy and
computational cost. While performance degrades in regions with poor mesh
quality (e.g., ears, hairline), the method demonstrates consistent accuracy
across most anatomical regions. PAL-Net generalizes effectively across datasets
and facial regions, outperforming existing methods in both point-wise and
structural evaluations. It provides a lightweight, scalable solution for
high-throughput 3D anthropometric analysis, with potential to support clinical
workflows and reduce reliance on manual annotation. Source code can be found at
https://github.com/Ali5hadman/PAL-Net-A-Point-Wise-CNN-with-Patch-Attention

AI.tldr: PAL-Net is a fully automated deep learning pipeline that localizes 50 anatomical landmarks on stereo-photogrammetry facial models, achieving accuracy comparable to intra-observer variability and strong generalization across datasets while remaining lightweight and scalable.
AI.motivation: Manual landmark annotation on 3D facial scans is slow, expert-dependent, and limits high-throughput craniofacial research; existing deep-learning methods either rely on pseudo-landmarks or require complex inputs, hindering clinical applicability.
AI.method: A pipeline combining coarse alignment, ROI filtering, initial landmark approximation, and a patch-based pointwise CNN with attention mechanisms (PAL-Net). Trained on 214 annotated healthy adult scans; evaluated on 700 FaceScape subjects.
AI.result: Mean localization error: 3.686 mm; average distance error: 2.822 mm (comparable to intra-observer variability). On FaceScape: point-wise error 0.41 mm; distance-wise error 0.38 mm. Degrades in regions with poor mesh quality (ears, hairline) but generally accurate across regions; outperforms existing methods in both point-wise and structural metrics; lightweight and scalable.
AI.conclusion: PAL-Net generalizes well across datasets and facial regions, offering a favorable accuracy-cost trade-off for high-throughput 3D anthropometric analysis and potential clinical workflow integration; code available at GitHub.

title: Private Online Learning against an Adaptive Adversary: Realizable and Agnostic Settings
summary:
We revisit the problem of private online learning, in which a learner
receives a sequence of $T$ data points and has to respond at each time-step a
hypothesis. It is required that the entire stream of output hypotheses should
satisfy differential privacy. Prior work of Golowich and Livni [2021]
established that every concept class $\mathcal{H}$ with finite Littlestone
dimension $d$ is privately online learnable in the realizable setting. In
particular, they proposed an algorithm that achieves an $O_{d}(\log T)$ mistake
bound against an oblivious adversary. However, their approach yields a
suboptimal $\tilde{O}_{d}(\sqrt{T})$ bound against an adaptive adversary. In
this work, we present a new algorithm with a mistake bound of $O_{d}(\log T)$
against an adaptive adversary, closing this gap. We further investigate the
problem in the agnostic setting, which is more general than the realizable
setting as it does not impose any assumptions on the data. We give an algorithm
that obtains a sublinear regret of $\tilde{O}_d(\sqrt{T})$ for generic
Littlestone classes, demonstrating that they are also privately online
learnable in the agnostic setting.

AI.tldr: Private online learning for Littlestone classes: new adaptive-adversary optimal log T mistake bound and sublinear agnostic regret, extending private learnability to both realizable and agnostic settings.
AI.motivation: Secure private online learning under differential privacy remains challenging, especially against adaptive adversaries. Prior work achieved log T mistakes for oblivious adversaries, but ad-infinitum sqrt(T) bounds remained for adaptive adversaries. The goal is to close this gap and extend privateness to the agnostic setting.
AI.method: Introduce a new online-private learning algorithm achieving O_d(log T) mistakes against an adaptive adversary. Develop an agnostic-private online learner with sublinear regret tilde O_d(sqrt(T)) for generic Littlestone classes.
AI.result: Adaptive-adversary mistake bound improved to O_d(log T) (from ~√T). In the agnostic setting, obtain sublinear regret tilde O_d(√T) for generic Littlestone classes, establishing private online learnability in both realizable and agnostic contexts.
AI.conclusion: The paper closes the gap for adaptive adversaries in private online learning and demonstrates privateness-based online learnability for Littlestone classes beyond realizable assumptions, including the agnostic setting.

title: Equivariant Splitting: Self-supervised learning from incomplete data
summary:
Self-supervised learning for inverse problems allows to train a
reconstruction network from noise and/or incomplete data alone. These methods
have the potential of enabling learning-based solutions when obtaining
ground-truth references for training is expensive or even impossible. In this
paper, we propose a new self-supervised learning strategy devised for the
challenging setting where measurements are observed via a single incomplete
observation model. We introduce a new definition of equivariance in the context
of reconstruction networks, and show that the combination of self-supervised
splitting losses and equivariant reconstruction networks results in unbiased
estimates of the supervised loss. Through a series of experiments on image
inpainting, accelerated magnetic resonance imaging, and compressive sensing, we
demonstrate that the proposed loss achieves state-of-the-art performance in
settings with highly rank-deficient forward models.

AI.tldr: A self-supervised framework for inverse problems using a single incomplete observation; introduces an equivariance notion for reconstruction networks and shows that combining self-supervised splitting losses with equivariant networks yields unbiased supervised-loss estimates and state-of-the-art results on inpainting, MRI, and compressive sensing under highly rank-deficient forward models.
AI.motivation: Ground-truth data for training is expensive or unavailable; need learning-based reconstructions from noisy or incomplete measurements; current methods struggle with highly incomplete forward models; aims to enable self-supervised training with unbiased loss estimates.
AI.method: Define an equivariance concept for reconstruction networks; combine self-supervised splitting losses with equivariant reconstruction networks; prove unbiased estimation of supervised loss; validate on image inpainting, accelerated MRI, and compressive sensing.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance in settings with highly rank-deficient forward models across multiple tasks; demonstrates robust reconstruction quality under challenging forward models.
AI.conclusion: Self-supervised learning with equivariant reconstruction networks provides unbiased loss estimates and strong performance for inverse problems with incomplete measurements, enabling effective learning without ground-truth references.

title: Eyes-on-Me: Scalable RAG Poisoning through Transferable Attention-Steering Attractors
summary:
Existing data poisoning attacks on retrieval-augmented generation (RAG)
systems scale poorly because they require costly optimization of poisoned
documents for each target phrase. We introduce Eyes-on-Me, a modular attack
that decomposes an adversarial document into reusable Attention Attractors and
Focus Regions. Attractors are optimized to direct attention to the Focus
Region. Attackers can then insert semantic baits for the retriever or malicious
instructions for the generator, adapting to new targets at near zero cost. This
is achieved by steering a small subset of attention heads that we empirically
identify as strongly correlated with attack success. Across 18 end-to-end RAG
settings (3 datasets $\times$ 2 retrievers $\times$ 3 generators), Eyes-on-Me
raises average attack success rates from 21.9 to 57.8 (+35.9 points,
2.6$\times$ over prior work). A single optimized attractor transfers to unseen
black box retrievers and generators without retraining. Our findings establish
a scalable paradigm for RAG data poisoning and show that modular, reusable
components pose a practical threat to modern AI systems. They also reveal a
strong link between attention concentration and model outputs, informing
interpretability research.

AI.tldr: Eyes-on-Me introduces modular, reusable Attention Attractors and Focus Regions to perform scalable data poisoning attacks on retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) systems. It achieves higher attack success, transferable to unseen components, with near-zero cost per target.
AI.motivation: RAG data poisoning attacks currently require costly optimization of poisoned documents for each target; scalable, transferable attacks threaten modern AI deployments and reveal links between attention and outputs.
AI.method: Decompose adversarial content into Attention Attractors (optimized to lure attention) and Focus Regions (the target region). A small set of attention heads are steered to influence outputs. Attackers can insert semantic baits or malicious instructions at the Focus Region. The attractors are reusable across targets; a single attractor transfers to unseen retrievers/generators without retraining.
AI.result: Across 18 end-to-end RAG settings, Eyes-on-Me raises average attack success from 21.9 to 57.8 ( +35.9 points, 2.6x over prior work ). A single optimized attractor transfers to unseen black-box retrievers and generators. Demonstrates a scalable threat model for RAG data poisoning and links attention concentration to model outputs.
AI.conclusion: Modular, reusable components enable scalable RAG data poisoning and pose practical threats to modern AI systems. Findings inform both security considerations and interpretability research on attention concentration.

title: Looking Alike From Far to Near: Enhancing Cross-Resolution Re-Identification via Feature Vector Panning
summary:
In surveillance scenarios, varying camera distances cause significant
differences among pedestrian image resolutions, making it hard to match
low-resolution (LR) images with high-resolution (HR) counterparts, limiting the
performance of Re-Identification (ReID) tasks. Most existing Cross-Resolution
ReID (CR-ReID) methods rely on super-resolution (SR) or joint learning for
feature compensation, which increases training and inference complexity and has
reached a performance bottleneck in recent studies. Inspired by semantic
directions in the word embedding space, we empirically discover that semantic
directions implying resolution differences also emerge in the feature space of
ReID, and we substantiate this finding from a statistical perspective using
Canonical Correlation Analysis and Pearson Correlation Analysis. Based on this
interesting finding, we propose a lightweight and effective Vector Panning
Feature Alignment (VPFA) framework, which conducts CR-ReID from a novel
perspective of modeling the resolution-specific feature discrepancy. Extensive
experimental results on multiple CR-ReID benchmarks show that our method
significantly outperforms previous state-of-the-art baseline models while
obtaining higher efficiency, demonstrating the effectiveness and superiority of
our model based on the new finding in this paper.

AI.tldr: A lightweight VPFA framework for Cross-Resolution ReID that identifies and compensates resolution-induced feature discrepancies along a semantic direction in feature space, avoiding super-resolution and achieving state-of-the-art performance with higher efficiency.
AI.motivation: Cross-Resolution ReID suffers from irregular image resolutions due to varying camera distances. Traditional SR-based or joint-learning methods add complexity and hit performance bottlenecks. The authors hypothesize that resolution differences correspond to semantic directions in ReID feature space, similar to word-embedding semantics, and seek to exploit this for efficient alignment.
AI.method: The authors first validate the existence of resolution-related semantic directions using Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) and Pearson correlation. Based on this, they propose Vector Panning Feature Alignment (VPFA), a lightweight framework that models and compensates resolution-specific feature discrepancy by moving features along a targeted semantic direction to align LR and HR representations without performing SR.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on multiple CR-ReID benchmarks show VPFA significantly outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines while offering higher efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Modeling resolution-specific feature discrepancies as semantic directions in ReID feature space is effective. VPFA provides a simple, lightweight, and efficient solution to CR-ReID without heavy SR, achieving strong performance improvements.

title: Probability calibration for precipitation nowcasting
comment:
Submitted to NeurIPS 2025 Workshop: Tackling Climate Change with
  Machine Learning
summary:
Reliable precipitation nowcasting is critical for weather-sensitive
decision-making, yet neural weather models (NWMs) can produce poorly calibrated
probabilistic forecasts. Standard calibration metrics such as the expected
calibration error (ECE) fail to capture miscalibration across precipitation
thresholds. We introduce the expected thresholded calibration error (ETCE), a
new metric that better captures miscalibration in ordered classes like
precipitation amounts. We extend post-processing techniques from computer
vision to the forecasting domain. Our results show that selective scaling with
lead time conditioning reduces model miscalibration without reducing the
forecast quality.

AI.tldr: Introduces ETCE, a calibration metric for ordered precipitation classes, and demonstrates lead-time conditioned selective scaling to improve calibration without harming forecast quality.
AI.motivation: Standard metrics like ECE miss miscalibration across precipitation thresholds in neural weather models. A threshold-aware calibration metric and domain-specific post-processing are needed to improve probabilistic forecasts for precipitation.
AI.method: Define the Expected Thresholded Calibration Error (ETCE) for ordered precipitation classes and adapt selective scaling/lead-time conditioning post-processing from computer vision to weather forecasting.
AI.result: ETCE better captures miscalibration across precipitation thresholds than ECE; lead-time conditioned selective scaling reduces miscalibration while preserving forecast quality.
AI.conclusion: ETCE provides a more appropriate calibration diagnostic for precipitation forecasts, and lead-time conditioned selective scaling offers practical calibration improvement without degrading forecast performance.

title: InfVSR: Breaking Length Limits of Generic Video Super-Resolution
comment: Code will be available at https://github.com/Kai-Liu001/InfVSR
summary:
Real-world videos often extend over thousands of frames. Existing video
super-resolution (VSR) approaches, however, face two persistent challenges when
processing long sequences: (1) inefficiency due to the heavy cost of multi-step
denoising for full-length sequences; and (2) poor scalability hindered by
temporal decomposition that causes artifacts and discontinuities. To break
these limits, we propose InfVSR, which novelly reformulates VSR as an
autoregressive-one-step-diffusion paradigm. This enables streaming inference
while fully leveraging pre-trained video diffusion priors. First, we adapt the
pre-trained DiT into a causal structure, maintaining both local and global
coherence via rolling KV-cache and joint visual guidance. Second, we distill
the diffusion process into a single step efficiently, with patch-wise pixel
supervision and cross-chunk distribution matching. Together, these designs
enable efficient and scalable VSR for unbounded-length videos. To fill the gap
in long-form video evaluation, we build a new benchmark tailored for extended
sequences and further introduce semantic-level metrics to comprehensively
assess temporal consistency. Our method pushes the frontier of long-form VSR,
achieves state-of-the-art quality with enhanced semantic consistency, and
delivers up to 58x speed-up over existing methods such as MGLD-VSR. Code will
be available at https://github.com/Kai-Liu001/InfVSR.
