AI.tldr: InfVSR reframes video super-resolution as an autoregressive one-step diffusion process for streaming long-form videos, leveraging pre-trained diffusion priors with a causal DiT, rolling KV-cache, and patch-wise one-step diffusion distillation to enable efficient, scalable VSR with improved temporal coherence. A new long-sequence benchmark and semantic metrics accompany the method, achieving state-of-the-art quality and up to 58x speed-up over MGLD-VSR.
AI.motivation: Real-world videos are extremely long, making existing VSR approaches inefficient due to multi-step denoising and suffer from artifacts when temporally decomposed. There is a need for scalable, efficient, and coherent long-form VSR that can operate on unbounded sequences.
AI.method: Transform VSR into an autoregressive-one-step-diffusion framework. Adapt pre-trained DiT into a causal structure with rolling KV-cache and joint visual guidance for local and global coherence. Distill the diffusion process into a single step using patch-wise pixel supervision and cross-chunk distribution matching, enabling streaming inference and unbounded-length video processing.
AI.result: The approach yields state-of-the-art quality with enhanced semantic temporal consistency and achieves up to 58x speed-up compared to existing methods like MGLD-VSR.
AI.conclusion: InfVSR enables efficient, scalable long-form VSR by reformulating diffusion priors into an autoregressive one-step paradigm, achieving strong quality and coherence while dramatically improving speed and extending evaluation to long sequences.

title: Designing Ambiguity Sets for Distributionally Robust Optimization Using Structural Causal Optimal Transport
summary:
Distributionally robust optimization tackles out-of-sample issues like
overfitting and distribution shifts by adopting an adversarial approach over a
range of possible data distributions, known as the ambiguity set. To balance
conservatism and accuracy, these sets must include realistic probability
distributions by leveraging information from the nominal distribution. Assuming
that nominal distributions arise from a structural causal model with a directed
acyclic graph $\mathcal{G}$ and structural equations, previous methods such as
adapted and $\mathcal{G}$-causal optimal transport have only utilized causal
graph information in designing ambiguity sets. In this work, we propose
incorporating structural equations, which include causal graph information, to
enhance ambiguity sets, resulting in more realistic distributions. We introduce
structural causal optimal transport and its associated ambiguity set,
demonstrating their advantages and connections to previous methods. A key
benefit of our approach is a relaxed version, where a regularization term
replaces the complex causal constraints, enabling an efficient algorithm via
difference-of-convex programming to solve structural causal optimal transport.
We also show that when structural information is absent and must be estimated,
our approach remains effective and provides finite sample guarantees. Lastly,
we address the radius of ambiguity sets, illustrating how our method overcomes
the curse of dimensionality in optimal transport problems, achieving faster
shrinkage with dimension-free order.

AI.tldr: Introduce structural causal optimal transport (SCOT) for distributionally robust optimization by leveraging structural causal equations and DAGs to form more realistic ambiguity sets; provide a regularized, difference-of-convex programming algorithm; offer finite-sample guarantees and dimension-free ambiguity-set shrinkage.
AI.motivation: Standard ambiguity sets in DRO can be overly conservative or fail to reflect how real data respond to interventions and shifts. By incorporating structural causal information (DAGs and structural equations) into ambiguity sets, the method aims to capture more realistic distributional changes, reduce overfitting, and mitigate the curse of dimensionality inherent in optimal transport.
AI.method: Define structural causal optimal transport using structural equations that encode causal graph information to construct ambiguity sets. Relate to existing approaches (adapted and G-causal OT). Propose a regularized version replacing hard causal constraints with a penalty, enabling an efficient difference-of-convex (DC) programming algorithm. Provide finite-sample guarantees when causal information is partially unknown and discuss estimation. Analyze how the radius of the ambiguity set scales with dimension, achieving dimension-free shrinkage.
AI.result: The approach yields more realistic ambiguity sets that reflect structural relations, connects to prior causal-OT methods, and provides a scalable DC-programming algorithm. It offers finite-sample guarantees and demonstrates a dimension-free rate for ambiguity-set shrinkage, reducing the curse of dimensionality in OT-based DRO.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating structural equations and causal graph information into ambiguity sets enhances distributional robustness by producing more faithful distributions, while maintaining computational efficiency through a regularized, DC-programming approach; the method remains effective even with estimated causal information and mitigates high-dimensional OT challenges.

title: JEPA-T: Joint-Embedding Predictive Architecture with Text Fusion for Image Generation
summary:
Modern Text-to-Image (T2I) generation increasingly relies on token-centric
architectures that are trained with self-supervision, yet effectively fusing
text with visual tokens remains a challenge. We propose \textbf{JEPA-T}, a
unified multimodal framework that encodes images and captions into discrete
visual and textual tokens, processed by a joint-embedding predictive
Transformer. To enhance fusion, we incorporate cross-attention after the
feature predictor for conditional denoising while maintaining a task-agnostic
backbone. Additionally, raw texts embeddings are injected prior to the flow
matching loss to improve alignment during training. During inference, the same
network performs both class-conditional and free-text image generation by
iteratively denoising visual tokens conditioned on text. Evaluations on
ImageNet-1K demonstrate that JEPA-T achieves strong data efficiency,
open-vocabulary generalization, and consistently outperforms non-fusion and
late-fusion baselines. Our approach shows that late architectural fusion
combined with objective-level alignment offers an effective balance between
conditioning strength and backbone generality in token-based T2I.The code is
now available: https://github.com/justin-herry/JEPA-T.git

AI.tldr: Token-based multimodal T2I model (JEPA-T) using joint-embedding tokens and late fusion; supports class-conditional and free-text generation with improved alignment and data efficiency.
AI.motivation: Text–image fusion remains difficult in token-centric T2I; need effective conditioning that preserves backbone generality and enables open-vocabulary generation.
AI.method: Encode images and captions into discrete tokens; use a joint-embedding predictive Transformer; add cross-attention after the feature predictor for conditional denoising; inject raw text embeddings prior to the flow-matching loss; same network supports class-conditional and free-text generation via iterative denoising of visual tokens conditioned on text.
AI.result: Outperforms non-fusion and late-fusion baselines on ImageNet-1K; demonstrates strong data efficiency and open-vocabulary generalization.
AI.conclusion: Late architectural fusion plus objective-level alignment provides a good balance between conditioning strength and backbone generality; code released.

title: Multi-Agent Stage-wise Conservative Linear Bandits
summary:
In many real-world applications such as recommendation systems, multiple
learning agents must balance exploration and exploitation while maintaining
safety guarantees to avoid catastrophic failures. We study the stochastic
linear bandit problem in a multi-agent networked setting where agents must
satisfy stage-wise conservative constraints. A network of $N$ agents
collaboratively maximizes cumulative reward while ensuring that the expected
reward at every round is no less than $(1-\alpha)$ times that of a baseline
policy. Each agent observes local rewards with unknown parameters, but the
network optimizes for the global parameter (average of local parameters).
Agents communicate only with immediate neighbors, and each communication round
incurs additional regret. We propose MA-SCLUCB (Multi-Agent Stage-wise
Conservative Linear UCB), an episodic algorithm alternating between action
selection and consensus-building phases. We prove that MA-SCLUCB achieves
regret
$\tilde{O}\left(\frac{d}{\sqrt{N}}\sqrt{T}\cdot\frac{\log(NT)}{\sqrt{\log(1/|\lambda_2|)}}\right)$
with high probability, where $d$ is the dimension, $T$ is the horizon, and
$|\lambda_2|$ is the network's second largest eigenvalue magnitude. Our
analysis shows: (i) collaboration yields $\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}$ improvement
despite local communication, (ii) communication overhead grows only
logarithmically for well-connected networks, and (iii) stage-wise safety adds
only lower-order regret. Thus, distributed learning with safety guarantees
achieves near-optimal performance in reasonably connected networks.

AI.tldr: A distributed stochastic linear bandit with stage-wise conservative safety constraints is studied in a network of agents who collaboratively learn a global parameter. The paper introduces a multi-agent algorithm MA-SCLUCB and shows near-optimal regret with favorable scaling in network size and connectivity.
AI.motivation: In many real-world systems (e.g., recommender systems), multiple agents must explore while exploiting and ensuring safety to avoid catastrophic outcomes. The authors study a networked setting where agents share a global objective (the average parameter) and must satisfy per-round safety constraints that the expected reward is at least a fraction (1-α) of a baseline policy.
AI.method: An episodic algorithm MA-SCLUCB that alternates between action selection and consensus-building. Each agent uses local rewards with unknown parameters; communication occurs with immediate neighbors, incurring regret. The network facilitates learning of the global parameter via consensus, and stage-wise constraints are enforced across rounds.
AI.result: The algorithm achieves high-probability regret of ṫO(d/√N · √T · log(NT) / √(log(1/|λ2|))). Collaboration yields a 1/√N improvement; communication overhead grows only logarithmically for well-connected networks; stage-wise safety contributes only lower-order regret.
AI.conclusion: Distributed learning with safety constraints attains near-optimal performance in reasonably connected networks, with substantial gains from collaboration and manageable communication cost.

title: A Scene is Worth a Thousand Features: Feed-Forward Camera Localization from a Collection of Image Features
summary:
Visually localizing an image, i.e., estimating its camera pose, requires
building a scene representation that serves as a visual map. The representation
we choose has direct consequences towards the practicability of our system.
Even when starting from mapping images with known camera poses,
state-of-the-art approaches still require hours of mapping time in the worst
case, and several minutes in the best. This work raises the question whether we
can achieve competitive accuracy much faster. We introduce FastForward, a
method that creates a map representation and relocalizes a query image
on-the-fly in a single feed-forward pass. At the core, we represent multiple
mapping images as a collection of features anchored in 3D space. FastForward
utilizes these mapping features to predict image-to-scene correspondences for
the query image, enabling the estimation of its camera pose. We couple
FastForward with image retrieval and achieve state-of-the-art accuracy when
compared to other approaches with minimal map preparation time. Furthermore,
FastForward demonstrates robust generalization to unseen domains, including
challenging large-scale outdoor environments.

AI.tldr: FastForward performs fast, on-the-fly visual localization by building a 3D-anchored feature map from mapping images and predicting image-to-scene correspondences in a single feed-forward pass, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy with minimal mapping time and good generalization to unseen domains.
AI.motivation: Reduce mating time and computational cost of camera relocalization while maintaining high accuracy, enabling practical real-time localization in large-scale and unseen environments.
AI.method: Represents multiple mapping images as a collection of features anchored in 3D space. Uses these mapping features to predict image-to-scene correspondences for a query image and estimate its camera pose. Combines with image retrieval to improve pose estimation in a single feed-forward pass.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art accuracy relative to methods with minimal map preparation time. Demonstrates robust generalization to unseen domains, including challenging large-scale outdoor environments.
AI.conclusion: FastForward offers a fast, generalizable approach to visual localization that reduces map-building time and enables accurate pose estimation in new domains, including large-scale outdoor scenes.

title: FAME: Adaptive Functional Attention with Expert Routing for Function-on-Function Regression
summary:
Functional data play a pivotal role across science and engineering, yet their
infinite-dimensional nature makes representation learning challenging.
Conventional statistical models depend on pre-chosen basis expansions or
kernels, limiting the flexibility of data-driven discovery, while many
deep-learning pipelines treat functions as fixed-grid vectors, ignoring
inherent continuity. In this paper, we introduce Functional Attention with a
Mixture-of-Experts (FAME), an end-to-end, fully data-driven framework for
function-on-function regression. FAME forms continuous attention by coupling a
bidirectional neural controlled differential equation with MoE-driven vector
fields to capture intra-functional continuity, and further fuses change to
inter-functional dependencies via multi-head cross attention. Extensive
experiments on synthetic and real-world functional-regression benchmarks show
that FAME achieves state-of-the-art accuracy, strong robustness to arbitrarily
sampled discrete observations of functions.

AI.tldr: FAME introduces a data-driven, end-to-end function-on-function regression framework that preserves functional continuity using continuous attention via neural CDEs and mixture-of-experts, with inter-function cross-attention, achieving state-of-the-art results and robustness to irregular sampling.
AI.motivation: Functional data are infinite-dimensional; fixed basis or kernel methods limit flexibility and may fail to capture intra- and inter-function dependencies; there is a need for end-to-end models that respect functional continuity and can handle irregularly sampled observations.
AI.method: FAME uses a bidirectional neural controlled differential equation to create continuous attention, coupled with MoE-driven vector fields to capture intra-functional continuity; it also employs multi-head cross-attention to fuse inter-functional dependencies; trained end-to-end for function-on-function regression.
AI.result: Empirical results on synthetic and real-world benchmarks show state-of-the-art accuracy and robustness to arbitrarily sampled discrete observations.
AI.conclusion: FAME provides a flexible, data-driven function-on-function regression framework that respects functional continuity and improves performance over traditional basis/kernel-based methods and fixed-grid representations.

title: Visual Self-Refinement for Autoregressive Models
summary:
Autoregressive models excel in sequential modeling and have proven to be
effective for vision-language data. However, the spatial nature of visual
signals conflicts with the sequential dependencies of next-token prediction,
leading to suboptimal results. This work proposes a plug-and-play refinement
module to enhance the complex spatial correspondence modeling within the
generated visual sequence. This module operates as a post-pretraining step to
jointly refine all generated tokens of autoregressive model, enhancing
vision-language modeling under a shared sequential prediction framework. By
leveraging global context and relationship across the tokens, our method
mitigates the error accumulation issue within the sequential generation.
Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method improves the generation
quality, enhancing the model's ability to produce semantically consistent
results.

AI.tldr: A plug-and-play refinement module improves autoregressive vision–language generation by better modeling spatial relations, applied as a post-pretraining step to jointly refine all tokens and reduce error accumulation, yielding more semantically consistent outputs.
AI.motivation: Autoregressive models handle sequential data well but treat visual signals as a sequence, ignoring spatial structure and correlations among tokens, which causes suboptimal generation and error accumulation in vision–language tasks.
AI.method: Introduce a post-pretraining refinement module that jointly refines all generated tokens of the autoregressive model. The module leverages global context and token relationships to enhance spatial correspondence modeling within the generated visual sequence, operating within a shared sequential prediction framework while mitigating error propagation.
AI.result: Empirical results show improved generation quality and semantically consistent outputs, demonstrating the effectiveness of refining tokens with global context to better align visual and language signals.
AI.conclusion: A plug-and-play refinement step can substantially improve spatial–sequential alignment in autoregressive vision–language models, offering a lightweight post-training augmentation that reduces error accumulation and enhances semantic consistency.

title: Error Feedback for Muon and Friends
summary:
Recent optimizers like Muon, Scion, and Gluon have pushed the frontier of
large-scale deep learning by exploiting layer-wise linear minimization oracles
(LMOs) over non-Euclidean norm balls, capturing neural network structure in
ways traditional algorithms cannot. Yet, no principled distributed framework
exists for these methods, and communication bottlenecks remain unaddressed. The
very few distributed variants are heuristic, with no convergence guarantees in
sight. We introduce EF21-Muon, the first communication-efficient, non-Euclidean
LMO-based optimizer with rigorous convergence guarantees. EF21-Muon supports
stochastic gradients, momentum, and bidirectional compression with error
feedback-marking the first extension of error feedback beyond the Euclidean
setting. It recovers Muon/Scion/Gluon when compression is off and specific
norms are chosen, providing the first efficient distributed implementation of
this powerful family. Our theory covers non-Euclidean smooth and the more
general $(L^0, L^1)$-smooth setting, matching best-known Euclidean rates and
enabling faster convergence under suitable norm choices. We further extend the
analysis to layer-wise (generalized) smoothness regimes, capturing the
anisotropic structure of deep networks. Experiments on NanoGPT benchmarking
EF21-Muon against uncompressed Muon/Scion/Gluon demonstrate up to $7\times$
communication savings with no accuracy degradation.

AI.tldr: First principled, communication-efficient non-Euclidean LMO-based distributed optimizer with convergence guarantees (EF21-Muon), unifying Muon/Scion/Gluon and delivering up to 7x communication savings without accuracy loss.
AI.motivation: There is no principled distributed framework for non-Euclidean LMO-based optimizers like Muon/Scion/Gluon. Existing distributed variants are heuristic and lack convergence guarantees, while communication bottlenecks hinder large-scale training.
AI.method: Introduce EF21-Muon, a compression-enabled, error-feedback-based extension of the Muon/Scion/Gluon family to non-Euclidean norm balls. It supports stochastic gradients, momentum, and bidirectional compression with error feedback. It recovers Muon/Scion/Gluon when compression is off and specific norms are chosen. The theory covers non-Euclidean smoothness and the broader (L^0, L^1)-smooth setting, with layer-wise (generalized) smoothness to capture neural network anisotropy.
AI.result: The work provides convergence guarantees under non-Euclidean smoothness and (L^0, L^1)-smoothness, with rates matching the best-known Euclidean results. Empirically, NanoGPT experiments show up to 7× communication savings with no accuracy degradation; EF21-Muon reduces to Muon/Scion/Gluon in the uncompressed/appropriate-norm limit, enabling an efficient distributed implementation of the family.
AI.conclusion: EF21-Muon delivers the first communication-efficient, non-Euclidean LMO-based distributed optimizer with rigorous convergence guarantees, extending error-feedback to non-Euclidean spaces and enabling faster convergence via layer-wise smoothness modeling. It unifies and practically accelerates Muon/Scion/Gluon under compression while preserving accuracy.

title: SoftCFG: Uncertainty-guided Stable Guidance for Visual autoregressive Model
summary:
Autoregressive (AR) models have emerged as powerful tools for image
generation by modeling images as sequences of discrete tokens. While
Classifier-Free Guidance (CFG) has been adopted to improve conditional
generation, its application in AR models faces two key issues: guidance
diminishing, where the conditional-unconditional gap quickly vanishes as
decoding progresses, and over-guidance, where strong conditions distort visual
coherence. To address these challenges, we propose SoftCFG, an
uncertainty-guided inference method that distributes adaptive perturbations
across all tokens in the sequence. The key idea behind SoftCFG is to let each
generated token contribute certainty-weighted guidance, ensuring that the
signal persists across steps while resolving conflicts between text guidance
and visual context. To further stabilize long-sequence generation, we introduce
Step Normalization, which bounds cumulative perturbations of SoftCFG. Our
method is training-free, model-agnostic, and seamlessly integrates with
existing AR pipelines. Experiments show that SoftCFG significantly improves
image quality over standard CFG and achieves state-of-the-art FID on ImageNet
256 among autoregressive models.

AI.tldr: SoftCFG extends classifier-free guidance for autoregressive image generation by distributing uncertainty-guided perturbations across tokens and stabilizing long sequences with Step Normalization; training-free and model-agnostic, achieving state-of-the-art FID on ImageNet-256 among AR models.
AI.motivation: Classifier-Free Guidance (CFG) helps conditional generation but autoregressive (AR) image models face guidance diminishing (conditional-unconditional gap shrinks during decoding) and over-guidance (strong conditions distort visual coherence).
AI.method: SoftCFG performs uncertainty-guided inference that distributes adaptive, certainty-weighted perturbations across all generated tokens, so each token contributes to guidance while maintaining coherence with visual context. Step Normalization bounds cumulative perturbations to stabilize long-sequence generation. The approach is training-free and model-agnostic, compatible with existing AR pipelines.
AI.result: Significant image quality gains over standard CFG; achieves state-of-the-art FID on ImageNet-256 among autoregressive models.
AI.conclusion: SoftCFG provides a simple, training-free enhancement for conditional AR image generation, improving stability and quality and enabling effective guidance across long sequences.

title: Physics-Informed Extreme Learning Machine (PIELM) for Tunnelling-Induced Soil-Pile Interactions
summary:
Physics-informed machine learning has been a promising data-driven and
physics-informed approach in geotechnical engineering. This study proposes a
physics-informed extreme learning machine (PIELM) framework for analyzing
tunneling-induced soil-pile interactions. The pile foundation is modeled as an
Euler-Bernoulli beam, and the surrounding soil is modeled as a Pasternak
foundation. The soil-pile interaction is formulated into a fourth-order
ordinary differential equation (ODE) that constitutes the physics-informed
component, while measured data are incorporated into PIELM as the data-driven
component. Combining physics and data yields a loss vector of the extreme
learning machine (ELM) network, which is trained within 1 second by the least
squares method. After validating the PIELM approach by the boundary element
method (BEM) and finite difference method (FDM), parametric studies are carried
out to examine the effects of ELM network architecture, data monitoring
locations and numbers on the performance of PIELM. The results indicate that
monitored data should be placed at positions where the gradients of pile
deflections are significant, such as at the pile tip/top and near tunneling
zones. Two application examples highlight the critical role of physics-informed
and data-driven approach for tunnelling-induced soil-pile interactions. The
proposed approach shows great potential for real-time monitoring and safety
assessment of pile foundations, and benefits for intelligent early-warning
systems in geotechnical engineering.

AI.tldr: A physics-informed extreme learning machine (PIELM) is developed to analyze tunneling-induced soil–pile interaction, modeling the pile as an Euler–Bernoulli beam and the soil as a Pasternak foundation. The physics (a fourth-order ODE) and data form a loss function, trained by least squares in about 1 s. Validated against BEM and FDM; data-monitoring locations affect performance. Demonstrates potential for real-time monitoring and intelligent early-warning in geotechnical engineering.
AI.motivation: The work aims to enable fast, physics-consistent, data-driven analysis of soil–pile interaction under tunneling, enabling real-time monitoring and safety assessment, addressing the computational burden of purely numerical or purely data-driven approaches.
AI.method: Formulate the soil–pile system as a fourth-order ODE by coupling an Euler–Bernoulli pile with a Pasternak soil foundation. Use a physics-informed extreme learning machine (PIELM) where the physics-based ODE forms part of the loss, and measured data form the data-driven loss. Train the model via least squares in about 1 s. Validate by comparing with boundary element method (BEM) and finite difference method (FDM); perform parametric studies on ELM architecture, monitoring locations, and data quantity.
AI.result: PIELM achieves accurate predictions comparable to BEM/FDM. The training is extremely fast (≈1 s) via LS. Key finding: monitoring locations where pile deflection gradients are high—pile tip/top and near tunneling zones—improve performance. The approach yields insights through two application examples, highlighting potential for real-time monitoring and intelligent early-warning systems.
AI.conclusion: PIELM shows strong potential for real-time monitoring and safety assessment of pile foundations under tunneling, offering a computationally efficient, physics-consistent framework that blends data with governing equations. It can support intelligent early-warning systems in geotechnical engineering.

title: TextCAM: Explaining Class Activation Map with Text
summary:
Deep neural networks (DNNs) have achieved remarkable success across domains
but remain difficult to interpret, limiting their trustworthiness in
high-stakes applications. This paper focuses on deep vision models, for which a
dominant line of explainability methods are Class Activation Mapping (CAM) and
its variants working by highlighting spatial regions that drive predictions. We
figure out that CAM provides little semantic insight into what attributes
underlie these activations. To address this limitation, we propose TextCAM, a
novel explanation framework that enriches CAM with natural languages. TextCAM
combines the precise spatial localization of CAM with the semantic alignment of
vision-language models (VLMs). Specifically, we derive channel-level semantic
representations using CLIP embeddings and linear discriminant analysis, and
aggregate them with CAM weights to produce textual descriptions of salient
visual evidence. This yields explanations that jointly specify where the model
attends and what visual attributes likely support its decision. We further
extend TextCAM to generate feature channels into semantically coherent groups,
enabling more fine-grained visual-textual explanations. Experiments on
ImageNet, CLEVR, and CUB demonstrate that TextCAM produces faithful and
interpretable rationales that improve human understanding, detect spurious
correlations, and preserve model fidelity.

AI.tldr: TextCAM combines CAM with vision-language alignment to produce textual descriptions of salient visual attributes, yielding spatial and semantic explanations for DNNs in vision.
AI.motivation: CAM explanations lack semantic attributes; there is a need for interpretable, semantically grounded rationales for deep vision models to improve trust and detect spurious correlations in high-stakes tasks.
AI.method: Derive channel-level semantic representations using CLIP embeddings and linear discriminant analysis; aggregate them with CAM weights to generate textual descriptions of salient evidence; extend to group feature channels for finer-grained explanations.
AI.result: On ImageNet, CLEVR, and CUB, TextCAM yields faithful and interpretable rationales that improve human understanding, help detect spurious correlations, and preserve model fidelity.
AI.conclusion: TextCAM offers a semantically grounded, faithful expansion of CAM explanations by integrating vision-language representations, providing richer, human-aligned explanations without sacrificing accuracy.

title: Comparison of Machine Learning Models to Classify Documents on Digital Development
comment:
16 pages, 4 figures, 4 tables, presented at First International
  Conference, DSAI 2023, Bangkok
summary:
Automated document classification is a trending topic in Natural Language
Processing (NLP) due to the extensive growth in digital databases. However, a
model that fits well for a specific classification task might perform weakly
for another dataset due to differences in the context. Thus, training and
evaluating several models is necessary to optimise the results. This study
employs a publicly available document database on worldwide digital development
interventions categorised under twelve areas. Since digital interventions are
still emerging, utilising NLP in the field is relatively new. Given the
exponential growth of digital interventions, this research has a vast scope for
improving how digital-development-oriented organisations report their work. The
paper examines the classification performance of Machine Learning (ML)
algorithms, including Decision Trees, k-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector
Machine, AdaBoost, Stochastic Gradient Descent, Naive Bayes, and Logistic
Regression. Accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score are utilised to evaluate
the performance of these models, while oversampling is used to address the
class-imbalanced nature of the dataset. Deviating from the traditional approach
of fitting a single model for multiclass classification, this paper
investigates the One vs Rest approach to build a combined model that optimises
the performance. The study concludes that the amount of data is not the sole
factor affecting the performance; features like similarity within classes and
dissimilarity among classes are also crucial.

AI.tldr: A comparative study of ML approaches for multiclass document classification on a public dataset of digital development interventions; it uses one-vs-rest, oversampling, and evaluates multiple algorithms; concludes that dataset size alone does not determine performance and class structure (similarity within classes and dissimilarity between classes) significantly influence results.
AI.motivation: The rapid growth of digital development interventions necessitates effective NLP-based classification to help organisations report their work; with diverse datasets and inherent class imbalance, it is important to compare multiple models and strategies across contexts.
AI.method: Evaluate several ML algorithms (Decision Trees, k-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, AdaBoost, Stochastic Gradient Descent, Naive Bayes, Logistic Regression) on a publicly available twelve-class dataset of worldwide digital development interventions. Address class imbalance with oversampling. Instead of fitting a single multiclass model, implement a One-vs-Rest approach to build a combined model aimed at optimizing performance. Performance assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
AI.result: The study utilizes a One-vs-Rest strategy to combine models, demonstrating that performance depends not only on data quantity but also on class structure; within-class similarity and between-class dissimilarity play crucial roles. Oversampling helps mitigate imbalance, but the abstract does not declare a single best model across all classes; the emphasis is on the impact of class structure and data characteristics on performance.
AI.conclusion: Beyond increasing data size, thoughtful feature and model design that accounts for inter-class relationships are essential. Future work should explore feature engineering to capture class similarity/dissimilarity, possibly more sophisticated ensembling or task-specific representations to further improve multiclass performance.

title: POVQA: Preference-Optimized Video Question Answering with Rationales for Data Efficiency
summary:
Video Question Answering (VQA) with Large Vision Language Models (LVLMs) has
gained significant traction in research ever since the Flamingo was introduced
by Deepmind. Recent advancements in large context/long video question answering
have allowed VQA tasks to have context window of 1500+ frames. However, this
only leads to 50 seconds of video footage without losing any significant
information. We introduce POVQA, a data-efficient pipeline that compresses each
second of video into a single temporally pooled image (via motion blur and
weighted averaging variants) and then align LVLMs with lightweight supervision.
Concretely, we build 1 fps input sources using Blend Blur with Last Frame,
Weighted Average, Exponential and Ramp pooling and fine-tune QWEN-2.5-VL 7B
with supervised two turn target including reasoning and final answer. We apply
Supervised Fine Tuning (SFT) and Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) on our
novel dataset ReasonVQA consisting of 12 movies with 239 human annotated
question-answer with reasoning prompts. On our ReasonVQA dataset, this method
dramatically improves performance over pooled baselines: F1 score improves from
0.212 to 0.543, BLEU-4 from 0.031 to 0.291, and ROUGE-L from 0.196 to 0.528.
Rationale quality also significantly increases. Cross-evaluation of SFT + DPO
on various pooling functions show that the gains persist regardless of the
pooling scheme used at train or test time, indicating strong robustness on
summarization of temporal evidence. Similar observations were made on zero-shot
in TVQA.

AI.tldr: POVQA compresses long videos into 1fps pooled frames to efficiently align LVLMs with supervision, achieving large gains on ReasonVQA with SFT+DPO and showing robustness across pooling schemes.
AI.motivation: Long video question answering with large context is costly; existing long-context VQA still struggles to preserve temporal information. The paper proposes a data-efficient pipeline to summarize temporal evidence and enable LVLM-based VQA.
AI.method: Convert video into 1fps inputs using pooling variants (Blend Blur with Last Frame, Weighted Average, Exponential, Ramp). Fine-tune QWEN-2.5-VL 7B with supervised two-turn prompts (reasoning + final answer). Train with SFT and DPO on a new ReasonVQA dataset (12 movies, 239 QA pairs with reasoning prompts). Evaluate across pooling schemes and on zero-shot TVQA.
AI.result: On ReasonVQA, F1 improved from 0.212 to 0.543; BLEU-4 from 0.031 to 0.291; ROUGE-L from 0.196 to 0.528; rationale quality also improved. Gains persisted across pooling methods, indicating robustness. Similar improvements observed in zero-shot TVQA.
AI.conclusion: The approach yields robust, data-efficient VQA for long videos by compressing temporal information and leveraging supervised fine-tuning with LVLMs; pooling-agnostic gains suggest good generalization to temporal summarization tasks; applicable to other long-video VQA settings.

title: Neural Diffusion Processes for Physically Interpretable Survival Prediction
summary:
We introduce DeepFHT, a survival-analysis framework that couples deep neural
networks with first hitting time (FHT) distributions from stochastic process
theory. Time to event is represented as the first passage of a latent diffusion
process to an absorbing boundary. A neural network maps input variables to
physically meaningful parameters including initial condition, drift, and
diffusion, within a chosen FHT process such as Brownian motion, both with drift
and driftless. This yields closed-form survival and hazard functions and
captures time-varying risk without assuming proportional-hazards.
  We compare DeepFHT with Cox regression and other existing parametric survival
models, using synthetic and real-world datasets. The method achieves predictive
accuracy on par with state-of-the-art approaches, while maintaining a
physics-based interpretable parameterization that elucidates the relation
between input features and risk. This combination of stochastic process theory
and deep learning provides a principled avenue for modeling survival phenomena
in complex systems.

AI.tldr: DeepFHT blends deep learning with first hitting time distributions to model survival as the first passage time of a latent diffusion to an absorbing boundary, giving closed-form survival/hazard functions and non-proportional hazards with interpretable, physics-based parameters.
AI.motivation: Create a principled, interpretable survival model that captures time-varying risk by marrying stochastic-process theory with deep learning, addressing limitations of Cox (PH assumption) and some parametric models.
AI.method: Use a neural network to map inputs to latent FHT parameters (initial condition, drift, diffusion) of a chosen diffusion process (e.g., Brownian motion with or without drift). This yields closed-form survival and hazard functions; train to fit data; compare to Cox and other parametric models on synthetic and real datasets.
AI.result: Achieves predictive accuracy on par with state-of-the-art approaches while providing a physics-based, interpretable parameterization that links input features to risk.
AI.conclusion: Integrating stochastic-process theory with deep learning offers a principled framework for modeling survival in complex systems, enabling non-proportional hazards and interpretable insights into risk dynamics.

title: ImageDoctor: Diagnosing Text-to-Image Generation via Grounded Image Reasoning
summary:
The rapid advancement of text-to-image (T2I) models has increased the need
for reliable human preference modeling, a demand further amplified by recent
progress in reinforcement learning for preference alignment. However, existing
approaches typically quantify the quality of a generated image using a single
scalar, limiting their ability to provide comprehensive and interpretable
feedback on image quality. To address this, we introduce ImageDoctor, a unified
multi-aspect T2I model evaluation framework that assesses image quality across
four complementary dimensions: plausibility, semantic alignment, aesthetics,
and overall quality. ImageDoctor also provides pixel-level flaw indicators in
the form of heatmaps, which highlight misaligned or implausible regions, and
can be used as a dense reward for T2I model preference alignment. Inspired by
the diagnostic process, we improve the detail sensitivity and reasoning
capability of ImageDoctor by introducing a "look-think-predict" paradigm, where
the model first localizes potential flaws, then generates reasoning, and
finally concludes the evaluation with quantitative scores. Built on top of a
vision-language model and trained through a combination of supervised
fine-tuning and reinforcement learning, ImageDoctor demonstrates strong
alignment with human preference across multiple datasets, establishing its
effectiveness as an evaluation metric. Furthermore, when used as a reward model
for preference tuning, ImageDoctor significantly improves generation quality --
achieving an improvement of 10% over scalar-based reward models.

AI.tldr: Introduces ImageDoctor, a multi-aspect evaluation and reward framework for text-to-image models, with four quality dimensions, pixel heatmaps, and a look-think-predict reasoning process, achieving strong human alignment and ~10% quality gain when used as a dense reward.
AI.motivation: To overcome reliance on a single scalar score for image quality and provide interpretable, comprehensive feedback and dense rewards for preference alignment in T2I models.
AI.method: Builds a vision-language model-based evaluator (ImageDoctor) with four dimensions (plausibility, semantic alignment, aesthetics, overall quality), produces pixel-level flaw heatmaps, uses a look-think-predict paradigm, trained via supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement learning.
AI.result: Demonstrates strong alignment with human preferences across multiple datasets; using as a reward model yields ~10% improvement in generation quality over scalar-based rewards.
AI.conclusion: ImageDoctor is effective as both an evaluation metric and a dense reward model, enabling more interpretable feedback and improved T2I performance through better preference modeling.

title: TD-JEPA: Latent-predictive Representations for Zero-Shot Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Latent prediction--where agents learn by predicting their own latents--has
emerged as a powerful paradigm for training general representations in machine
learning. In reinforcement learning (RL), this approach has been explored to
define auxiliary losses for a variety of settings, including reward-based and
unsupervised RL, behavior cloning, and world modeling. While existing methods
are typically limited to single-task learning, one-step prediction, or
on-policy trajectory data, we show that temporal difference (TD) learning
enables learning representations predictive of long-term latent dynamics across
multiple policies from offline, reward-free transitions. Building on this, we
introduce TD-JEPA, which leverages TD-based latent-predictive representations
into unsupervised RL. TD-JEPA trains explicit state and task encoders, a
policy-conditioned multi-step predictor, and a set of parameterized policies
directly in latent space. This enables zero-shot optimization of any reward
function at test time. Theoretically, we show that an idealized variant of
TD-JEPA avoids collapse with proper initialization, and learns encoders that
capture a low-rank factorization of long-term policy dynamics, while the
predictor recovers their successor features in latent space. Empirically,
TD-JEPA matches or outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on locomotion,
navigation, and manipulation tasks across 13 datasets in ExoRL and OGBench,
especially in the challenging setting of zero-shot RL from pixels.

AI.tldr: TD-JEPA introduces a TD-based latent-prediction framework that learns long-horizon latent dynamics from offline, reward-free transitions across multiple policies, enabling zero-shot RL from pixels; it matches or exceeds state-of-the-art baselines across locomotion, navigation, and manipulation tasks (ExoRL and OGBench).
AI.motivation: Existing latent-prediction methods are typically single-task, one-step, or on-policy, limiting generalization. There is a need to learn long-term latent dynamics across multiple policies from offline, reward-free data to enable zero-shot reinforcement learning from pixels.
AI.method: TD-JEPA trains explicit state and task encoders, along with a policy-conditioned multi-step latent predictor, using temporal-difference based learning to predict long-term latent dynamics across multiple policies. The approach operates entirely in latent space and supports zero-shot optimization for any reward function at test time. The paper provides theoretical analysis showing an idealized variant avoids collapse with proper initialization and learns a low-rank factorization of long-term policy dynamics, with the predictor recovering successor features in latent space.
AI.result: Empirically, TD-JEPA matches or outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on locomotion, navigation, and manipulation tasks across 13 datasets in ExoRL and OGBench, particularly excelling in zero-shot RL from pixels. The theory shows the encoders capture a low-rank representation of long-term dynamics and the predictor recovers successor features; in practice, this yields strong zero-shot transfer.
AI.conclusion: TD-JEPA extends latent-prediction to offline, multi-policy, long-horizon RL by leveraging TD-based latent predictions, enabling zero-shot reward optimization and robust, generalizable representations. The combination of theoretical guarantees and strong empirical results across diverse tasks indicates a promising direction for unsupervised RL via latent TD learning.

title: Towards Adversarial Training under Hyperspectral Images
summary:
Recent studies have revealed that hyperspectral classification models based
on deep learning are highly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which pose
significant security risks. Although several approaches have attempted to
enhance adversarial robustness by modifying network architectures, these
methods often rely on customized designs that limit scalability and fail to
defend effectively against strong attacks. To address these challenges, we
introduce adversarial training to the hyperspectral domain, which is widely
regarded as one of the most effective defenses against adversarial attacks.
Through extensive empirical analyses, we demonstrate that while adversarial
training does enhance robustness across various models and datasets,
hyperspectral data introduces unique challenges not seen in RGB images.
Specifically, we find that adversarial noise and the non-smooth nature of
adversarial examples can distort or eliminate important spectral semantic
information. To mitigate this issue, we employ data augmentation techniques and
propose a novel hyperspectral adversarial training method, termed AT-RA. By
increasing the diversity of spectral information and ensuring spatial
smoothness, AT-RA preserves and corrects spectral semantics in hyperspectral
images. Experimental results show that AT-RA improves adversarial robustness by
21.34% against AutoAttack and 18.78% against PGD-50 while boosting benign
accuracy by 2.68%.

AI.tldr: Adversarial training in hyperspectral data (AT-RA) enhances robustness and preserves spectral semantics, addressing domain-specific challenges with data augmentation and spatial-smoothness constraints.
AI.motivation: Hyperspectral models are highly vulnerable to adversarial attacks; existing defenses based on network architecture are not scalable and struggle against strong attacks; hyperspectral data have unique spectral semantics and non-smooth adversarial perturbations that can distort information.
AI.method: Proposes AT-RA, a hyperspectral adversarial training framework augmented with data augmentation to diversify spectral information and enforce spatial smoothness, aimed at preserving spectral semantics during training.
AI.result: AT-RA yields substantial robustness gains (≈21.34% against AutoAttack and ≈18.78% against PGD-50) and a modest benign accuracy improvement of ≈2.68%.
AI.conclusion: AT-RA is effective for improving adversarial robustness in hyperspectral classification by addressing hyperspectral-specific challenges, demonstrating that spectral-aware training with augmentation can outperform baseline defenses.

title: How Foundational are Foundation Models for Time Series Forecasting?
comment:
Accepted at NeurIPS 2025 Workshop on Recent Advances in Time Series
  Foundation Models (BERT2S)
summary:
Foundation Models are designed to serve as versatile embedding machines, with
strong zero shot capabilities and superior generalization performance when
fine-tuned on diverse downstream tasks. While this is largely true for language
and vision foundation models, we argue that the inherent diversity of time
series data makes them less suited for building effective foundation models. We
demonstrate this using forecasting as our downstream task. We show that the
zero-shot capabilities of a time series foundation model are significantly
influenced and tied to the specific domains it has been pretrained on.
Furthermore, when applied to unseen real-world time series data, fine-tuned
foundation models do not consistently yield substantially better results,
relative to their increased parameter count and memory footprint, than smaller,
dedicated models tailored to the specific forecasting task at hand.

AI.tldr: Time series foundation models struggle with universal zero-shot transfer; zero-shot performance is largely domain-specific, and fine-tuned large models do not consistently outperform smaller, task-specific models on unseen real-world forecasting tasks despite higher resource demands.
AI.motivation: Foundation models show strong zero-shot generalization in language/vision, but time series data are highly diverse across domains. This paper questions whether a single, large foundation model can effectively forecast time series across domains with minimal task-specific training.
AI.method: The study evaluates zero-shot capabilities of time series foundation models across different domains, then fine-tunes them on forecasting tasks and compares performance against smaller, dedicated forecasting models. Real-world unseen data are used to assess generalization, considering model size and memory footprint.
AI.result: Zero-shot performance is strongly influenced by the domains the model was pretrained on, limiting true cross-domain generalization. On unseen real-world data, fine-tuned foundation models do not consistently outperform smaller, specialized forecasting models, despite having more parameters and memory usage.
AI.conclusion: Time series foundation models are not universally superior for forecasting. Domain diversity limits zero-shot transfer; for forecasting on unseen data, smaller, domain-tuned models can offer better efficiency and comparable or better performance. Careful evaluation is needed before adopting foundation models in time-series forecasting.

title: Secure and reversible face anonymization with diffusion models
summary:
Face images processed by computer vision algorithms contain sensitive
personal information that malicious actors can capture without consent. These
privacy and security risks highlight the need for effective face anonymization
methods. Current methods struggle to propose a good trade-off between a secure
scheme with high-quality image generation and reversibility for later person
authentication. Diffusion-based approaches produce high-quality anonymized
images but lack the secret key mechanism to ensure that only authorized parties
can reverse the process. In this paper, we introduce, to our knowledge, the
first secure, high-quality reversible anonymization method based on a diffusion
model. We propose to combine the secret key with the latent faces
representation of the diffusion model. To preserve identity-irrelevant
features, generation is constrained by a facial mask, maintaining high-quality
images. By using a deterministic forward and backward diffusion process, our
approach enforces that the original face can be recovered with the correct
secret key. We also show that the proposed method produces anonymized faces
that are less visually similar to the original faces, compared to other
previous work.

AI.tldr: A secure, high-quality reversible face anonymization method using diffusion models with a secret key and facial masks to enable reversible anonymization for authorized parties.
AI.motivation: Face images reveal sensitive information; existing methods trade off security, image quality, and reversibility. Diffusion models offer high-quality anonymization but lack reversible key-based control. The work introduces a secure reversible workflow.
AI.method: Integrates a secret key with the latent face representation in a diffusion model, constrains generation with a facial mask to preserve non-identity features, and uses deterministic forward/backward diffusion to enable recovery of the original face with the correct key.
AI.result: Produces anonymized faces that are less visually similar to original faces than prior methods while maintaining high image quality and allowing reversible recovery when supplied with the secret key.
AI.conclusion: Presents a novel secure, high-quality reversible face anonymization approach based on diffusion, combining key-based reversibility with identity-irrelevant feature preservation via masking.

title: LEAP: Local ECT-Based Learnable Positional Encodings for Graphs
summary:
Graph neural networks (GNNs) largely rely on the message-passing paradigm,
where nodes iteratively aggregate information from their neighbors. Yet,
standard message passing neural networks (MPNNs) face well-documented
theoretical and practical limitations. Graph positional encoding (PE) has
emerged as a promising direction to address these limitations. The Euler
Characteristic Transform (ECT) is an efficiently computable
geometric-topological invariant that characterizes shapes and graphs. In this
work, we combine the differentiable approximation of the ECT (DECT) and its
local variant ($\ell$-ECT) to propose LEAP, a new end-to-end trainable local
structural PE for graphs. We evaluate our approach on multiple real-world
datasets as well as on a synthetic task designed to test its ability to extract
topological features. Our results underline the potential of LEAP-based
encodings as a powerful component for graph representation learning pipelines.

AI.tldr: LEAP introduces a differentiable, local Euler Characteristic Transform-based graph positional encoding for end-to-end graph learning, aimed at enhancing representation by capturing topology.
AI.motivation: Standard message-passing neural networks (MPNNs) have known theoretical and practical limitations. Graph positional encodings that capture topology, such as the Euler Characteristic Transform (ECT), offer a promising way to augment GNNs. A differentiable, local variant is needed for end-to-end training.
AI.method: Combine the differentiable approximation of the ECT (DECT) with its local variant (l-ECT) to construct LEAP, a trainable local structural graph positional encoding integrated into GNNs. Evaluate on real-world datasets and a synthetic task designed to probe topological feature extraction.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation demonstrates LEAP-based encodings as a powerful component for graph representation learning, capable of capturing topological features and improving representation quality on the tested datasets and tasks.
AI.conclusion: LEAP is a promising local-topological graph encoding that can enhance GNN pipelines and help address limitations of standard MPNNs, warranting further exploration and integration into graph learning workflows.

title: Authentic Discrete Diffusion Model
summary:
We propose an Authentic Discrete Diffusion (ADD) framework that fundamentally
redefines prior pseudo-discrete approaches by preserving core diffusion
characteristics directly in the one-hot space through a suite of coordinated
mechanisms. Unlike conventional "pseudo" discrete diffusion (PDD) methods, ADD
reformulates the diffusion input by directly using float-encoded one-hot class
data, without relying on diffusing in the continuous latent spaces or masking
policies. At its core, a timestep-conditioned cross-entropy loss is introduced
between the diffusion model's outputs and the original one-hot labels. This
synergistic design establishes a bridge between discriminative and generative
learning. Our experiments demonstrate that ADD not only achieves superior
performance on classification tasks compared to the baseline, but also exhibits
excellent text generation capabilities on Image captioning. Extensive ablations
validate the measurable gains of each component.

AI.tldr: A discrete diffusion framework (ADD) that operates directly in one-hot space using a float-encoded one-hot input and a timestep-conditioned cross-entropy loss, surpassing pseudo-discrete diffusion baselines in classification and enabling strong image-caption generation; ablations validate component gains.
AI.motivation: To preserve core diffusion characteristics within discrete label space, avoiding diffusion in continuous latent spaces, and to bridge discriminative and generative learning for improved discrete diffusion tasks such as classification and captioning.
AI.method: Use float-encoded one-hot class data as the diffusion input, avoiding diffusion in continuous latent spaces or masking policies. Introduce a timestep-conditioned cross-entropy loss between the diffusion model outputs and the original one-hot labels. Employ coordinated mechanisms to maintain diffusion characteristics directly in the one-hot space, creating a linkage between discriminative and generative learning.
AI.result: ADD achieves superior classification performance compared to the baseline PDD approaches and demonstrates excellent text generation capabilities for image captioning. Ablation studies show measurable gains from each component.
AI.conclusion: ADD provides a fundamental shift from pseudo-discrete diffusion to authentic discrete diffusion by operating in one-hot space with a timestep-conditioned cross-entropy objective; this yields improved classification and captioning performance, with component-wise gains validated by extensive ablations.

title: Downgrade to Upgrade: Optimizer Simplification Enhances Robustness in LLM Unlearning
summary:
Large language model (LLM) unlearning aims to surgically remove the influence
of undesired data or knowledge from an existing model while preserving its
utility on unrelated tasks. This paradigm has shown promise in addressing
privacy and safety concerns. However, recent findings reveal that unlearning
effects are often fragile: post-unlearning manipulations such as weight
quantization or fine-tuning can quickly neutralize the intended forgetting.
Prior efforts to improve robustness primarily reformulate unlearning objectives
by explicitly assuming the role of vulnerability sources. In this work, we take
a different perspective by investigating the role of the optimizer, independent
of unlearning objectives and formulations, in shaping unlearning robustness. We
show that the 'grade' of the optimizer, defined by the level of information it
exploits, ranging from zeroth-order (gradient-free) to first-order
(gradient-based) to second-order (Hessian-based), is tightly linked to the
resilience of unlearning. Surprisingly, we find that downgrading the optimizer,
such as using zeroth-order methods or compressed-gradient variants (e.g.,
gradient sign-based optimizers), often leads to stronger robustness. While
these optimizers produce noisier and less precise updates, they encourage
convergence to harder-to-disturb basins in the loss landscape, thereby
resisting post-training perturbations. By connecting zeroth-order methods with
randomized smoothing, we further highlight their natural advantage for robust
unlearning. Motivated by these insights, we propose a hybrid optimizer that
combines first-order and zeroth-order updates, preserving unlearning efficacy
while enhancing robustness. Extensive experiments on the MUSE and WMDP
benchmarks, across multiple LLM unlearning algorithms, validate that our
approach achieves more resilient forgetting without sacrificing unlearning
quality.

AI.tldr: Optimizer grade is key to robust LLM unlearning. Downgrading to zeroth-order or compressed-gradient updates increases resistance to post-unlearning perturbations, and a hybrid 1st+0th order optimizer preserves forgetting quality while boosting robustness, as validated on MUSE and WMDP across several unlearning methods.
AI.motivation: Unlearning effectiveness is often fragile: post-unlearning perturbations like quantization or fine-tuning can undo forgetting. Most prior work focuses on reformulating objectives; this work investigates how the optimizer’s information usage influences unlearning robustness, seeking a fundamental factor beyond objectives.
AI.method: Systematic analysis of optimizer grade (zeroth-, first-, and second-order) in LLM unlearning; introduce a hybrid optimizer that blends first-order and zeroth-order updates; connect zeroth-order methods with randomized smoothing; empirical evaluation on MUSE and WMDP benchmarks across multiple LLM unlearning algorithms.
AI.result: Lower-grade optimizers (zeroth-order or compressed-gradient variants) tend to yield stronger robustness, guiding convergence to harder-to-disturb basins and resisting post-training perturbations. The proposed hybrid optimizer preserves unlearning efficacy while enhancing robustness. Experiments on MUSE and WMDP across several unlearning methods show more resilient forgetting without sacrificing unlearning quality.
AI.conclusion: Optimizer design, particularly reducing reliance on gradient information, can enhance robustness of unlearning. A hybrid first-/zeroth-order approach offers practical gains by maintaining forgetting efficacy while improving resistance to post-training perturbations; results align with links between zeroth-order methods and randomized smoothing.

title: In-Place Feedback: A New Paradigm for Guiding LLMs in Multi-Turn Reasoning
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly studied in the context of
multi-turn reasoning, where models iteratively refine their outputs based on
user-provided feedback. Such settings are crucial for tasks that require
complex reasoning, yet existing feedback paradigms often rely on issuing new
messages. LLMs struggle to integrate these reliably, leading to inconsistent
improvements. In this work, we introduce in-place feedback, a novel interaction
paradigm in which users directly edit an LLM's previous response, and the model
conditions on this modified response to generate its revision. Empirical
evaluations on diverse reasoning-intensive benchmarks reveal that in-place
feedback achieves better performance than conventional multi-turn feedback
while using $79.1\%$ fewer tokens. Complementary analyses on controlled
environments further demonstrate that in-place feedback resolves a core
limitation of multi-turn feedback: models often fail to apply feedback
precisely to erroneous parts of the response, leaving errors uncorrected and
sometimes introducing new mistakes into previously correct content. These
findings suggest that in-place feedback offers a more natural and effective
mechanism for guiding LLMs in reasoning-intensive tasks.

AI.tldr: In-place feedback—edit the model's prior answer to guide revision, achieving higher reasoning performance with ~79% fewer tokens than multi-turn feedback.
AI.motivation: Traditional multi-turn feedback is inefficient and unreliable; feedback may not be applied to the exact errors, leaving mistakes and sometimes introducing new ones. An editing-based paradigm could provide precise, economical guidance.
AI.method: Propose in-place feedback: users directly edit the model's previous response; the model conditions on the edited response to produce a revision. Evaluate on diverse reasoning benchmarks; compare to conventional multi-turn feedback; report token savings (79.1%). Include controlled analyses to diagnose feedback application.
AI.result: In-place feedback yields better performance than conventional multi-turn feedback and uses 79.1% fewer tokens. Analyses show it addresses the core limitation of not applying feedback precisely to erroneous parts, reducing residual errors and preventing new mistakes.
AI.conclusion: In-place feedback offers a more natural and effective mechanism for guiding LLMs in reasoning-intensive tasks, combining superior performance with higher efficiency.

title: Instant4D: 4D Gaussian Splatting in Minutes
summary:
Dynamic view synthesis has seen significant advances, yet reconstructing
scenes from uncalibrated, casual video remains challenging due to slow
optimization and complex parameter estimation. In this work, we present
Instant4D, a monocular reconstruction system that leverages native 4D
representation to efficiently process casual video sequences within minutes,
without calibrated cameras or depth sensors. Our method begins with geometric
recovery through deep visual SLAM, followed by grid pruning to optimize scene
representation. Our design significantly reduces redundancy while maintaining
geometric integrity, cutting model size to under 10% of its original footprint.
To handle temporal dynamics efficiently, we introduce a streamlined 4D Gaussian
representation, achieving a 30x speed-up and reducing training time to within
two minutes, while maintaining competitive performance across several
benchmarks. Our method reconstruct a single video within 10 minutes on the
Dycheck dataset or for a typical 200-frame video. We further apply our model to
in-the-wild videos, showcasing its generalizability. Our project website is
published at https://instant4d.github.io/.

AI.tldr: Instant4D is a fast, calibration-free monocular dynamic scene reconstruction system that processes casual videos using a native 4D representation, achieving minute-scale training and ~10-minute reconstructions with a dramatically smaller model footprint.
AI.motivation: Reconstructing dynamic scenes from uncalibrated, casual video is hard due to slow optimization, complex parameter estimation, and lack of depth sensors; a fast, robust, calibration-free solution is needed.
AI.method: Pipeline: deep visual SLAM for geometric recovery, grid pruning to reduce redundancy, and a streamlined 4D Gaussian representation for temporal dynamics; monocular input, no depth sensors; efficient processing within minutes.
AI.result: 30x speed-up vs prior methods; training in under 2 minutes; single video reconstruction under 10 minutes on Dycheck or ~200 frames; model footprint reduced to under 10% of original; demonstrated on in-the-wild videos with good generalization.
AI.conclusion: Instant4D offers a practical, fast, and scalable solution for dynamic view synthesis from casual video, combining SLAM-based initialization, pruning, and a compact 4D representation to deliver competitive performance on benchmarks and real-world footage.

title: Complex System Exploration with Interactive Human Guidance
summary:
The diversity of patterns that emerge from complex systems motivates their
use for scientific or artistic purposes. When exploring these systems, the
challenges faced are the size of the parameter space and the strongly
non-linear mapping between parameters and emerging patterns. In addition,
artists and scientists who explore complex systems do so with an expectation of
particular patterns. Taking these expectations into account adds a new set of
challenges, which the exploration process must address. We provide design
choices and their implementation to address these challenges; enabling the
maximization of the diversity of patterns discovered in the user's region of
interest -- which we call the constrained diversity -- in a sample-efficient
manner. The region of interest is expressed in the form of explicit
constraints. These constraints are formulated by the user in a system-agnostic
way, and their addition enables interactive system exploration leading to
constrained diversity, while maintaining global diversity.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a framework to explore complex systems by enforcing user-defined constraints to focus on a region of interest, enabling constrained diversity (local diversity) while preserving global diversity, and doing so in a sample-efficient way.
AI.motivation: To tackle the large, high-dimensional parameter spaces and the highly non-linear mapping from parameters to emergent patterns, while accommodating user expectations for particular patterns.
AI.method: Present design choices and their implementation that support interactive exploration with explicit, system-agnostic constraints expressed by the user. This constrains exploration to a region of interest and maximizes diversity there without sacrificing global diversity.
AI.result: Demonstrates how constrained diversity can be maximized in the user-defined region of interest in a sample-efficient manner.
AI.conclusion: Constraint-driven exploration enables interactive discovery of diverse patterns by balancing local (region of interest) and global diversity, guided by user-specified constraints expressed in a system-agnostic way.

title: Guiding Evolutionary Molecular Design: Adding Reinforcement Learning for Mutation Selection
comment:
8 pages, 3 figures, Accepted for publication in the proceedings of
  ICTAI 2025
summary:
The efficient exploration of chemical space remains a central challenge, as
many generative models still produce unstable or non-synthesizable compounds.
To address these limitations, we present EvoMol-RL, a significant extension of
the EvoMol evolutionary algorithm that integrates reinforcement learning to
guide molecular mutations based on local structural context. By leveraging
Extended Connectivity Fingerprints (ECFPs), EvoMol-RL learns context-aware
mutation policies that prioritize chemically plausible transformations. This
approach significantly improves the generation of valid and realistic
molecules, reducing the frequency of structural artifacts and enhancing
optimization performance. The results demonstrate that EvoMol-RL consistently
outperforms its baseline in molecular pre-filtering realism. These results
emphasize the effectiveness of combining reinforcement learning with molecular
fingerprints to generate chemically relevant molecular structures.

AI.tldr: EvoMol-RL uses reinforcement learning guided by Extended Connectivity Fingerprints to steer mutations in EvoMol, yielding more valid, realistic molecules and better optimization than the baseline.
AI.motivation: Generative models often produce unstable or non-synthesizable compounds; there is a need for context-aware, chemically plausible mutation strategies to reduce artifacts and improve pre-filtering realism.
AI.method: Extend EvoMol with reinforcement learning to guide molecular mutations based on local structural context; use ECFP fingerprints to inform context-aware mutation policies; train policies to prioritize chemically plausible transformations.
AI.result: Significant improvements in generating valid, realistic molecules; fewer structural artifacts; improved optimization performance; EvoMol-RL consistently outperforms EvoMol baseline in molecular pre-filtering realism.
AI.conclusion: Combining reinforcement learning with molecular fingerprints is effective for generating chemically relevant molecular structures and enhances chemical space exploration.

title: Code2Video: A Code-centric Paradigm for Educational Video Generation
summary:
While recent generative models advance pixel-space video synthesis, they
remain limited in producing professional educational videos, which demand
disciplinary knowledge, precise visual structures, and coherent transitions,
limiting their applicability in educational scenarios. Intuitively, such
requirements are better addressed through the manipulation of a renderable
environment, which can be explicitly controlled via logical commands (e.g.,
code). In this work, we propose Code2Video, a code-centric agent framework for
generating educational videos via executable Python code. The framework
comprises three collaborative agents: (i) Planner, which structures lecture
content into temporally coherent flows and prepares corresponding visual
assets; (ii) Coder, which converts structured instructions into executable
Python codes while incorporating scope-guided auto-fix to enhance efficiency;
and (iii) Critic, which leverages vision-language models (VLM) with visual
anchor prompts to refine spatial layout and ensure clarity. To support
systematic evaluation, we build MMMC, a benchmark of professionally produced,
discipline-specific educational videos. We evaluate MMMC across diverse
dimensions, including VLM-as-a-Judge aesthetic scores, code efficiency, and
particularly, TeachQuiz, a novel end-to-end metric that quantifies how well a
VLM, after unlearning, can recover knowledge by watching the generated videos.
Our results demonstrate the potential of Code2Video as a scalable,
interpretable, and controllable approach, achieving 40% improvement over direct
code generation and producing videos comparable to human-crafted tutorials. The
code and datasets are available at https://github.com/showlab/Code2Video.

AI.tldr: Code2Video presents a code-centric, three-agent framework for generating educational videos from executable Python code, enabling controllable visuals, evaluated on a new discipline-specific MMMC benchmark and TeachQuiz metric; shows ~40% improvement over direct code generation and comparability to human tutorials; codebase released.
AI.motivation: Educational videos require precise visuals and coherent structure that are difficult for pixel-space generative models to reliably provide. A renderable, code-controlled environment offers explicit control over content and visuals, enabling scalable, interpretable educational video production.
AI.method: Three collaboratively agents: Planner structures lecture content and assets; Coder translates instructions into executable Python code with scope-guided auto-fix for efficiency; Critic uses vision-language models with visual anchor prompts to refine spatial layout and clarity. Evaluation on MMMC benchmark with diverse metrics (VLM-based aesthetics, code efficiency) and TeachQuiz, an end-to-end metric assessing knowledge recovery from generated videos. Benchmark and code/datasets released.
AI.result: Code2Video achieves about 40% improvement over direct code generation and produces videos comparable to human-crafted tutorials; demonstrates scalability, interpretability, and controllability in educational video generation; establishes MMMC benchmark and TeachQuiz as evaluation tools.
AI.conclusion: Code-centric video generation via collaborative agents is a promising path for producing professional educational videos, offering greater control and potential alignment with experts’ expectations; future work may enhance alignment, evaluation, and broader subject coverage.

title: Online Minimization of Polarization and Disagreement via Low-Rank Matrix Bandits
summary:
We study the problem of minimizing polarization and disagreement in the
Friedkin-Johnsen opinion dynamics model under incomplete information. Unlike
prior work that assumes a static setting with full knowledge of users' innate
opinions, we address the more realistic online setting where innate opinions
are unknown and must be learned through sequential observations. This novel
setting, which naturally mirrors periodic interventions on social media
platforms, is formulated as a regret minimization problem, establishing a key
connection between algorithmic interventions on social media platforms and
theory of multi-armed bandits. In our formulation, a learner observes only a
scalar feedback of the overall polarization and disagreement after an
intervention. For this novel bandit problem, we propose a two-stage algorithm
based on low-rank matrix bandits. The algorithm first performs subspace
estimation to identify an underlying low-dimensional structure, and then
employs a linear bandit algorithm within the compact dimensional representation
derived from the estimated subspace. We prove that our algorithm achieves an $
\widetilde{O}(\sqrt{T}) $ cumulative regret over any time horizon $T$.
Empirical results validate that our algorithm significantly outperforms a
linear bandit baseline in terms of both cumulative regret and running time.

AI.tldr: A bandit-based framework learns unknown innate opinions in Friedkin–Johsen opinion dynamics to minimize polarization, using a two-stage low-rank matrix bandit that first estimates a low-dimensional subspace and then performs linear bandits in that reduced space; achieves alse, the text shows ~O~(sqrt(T)) regret (up to polylog factors) and outperforms a linear bandit baseline empirically.
AI.motivation: Realistic online interventions on social platforms require learning user-by-innate opinions that govern polarization, rather than assuming full knowledge of these opinions in a static setting. The work links social-media interventions with regret-minimization and multi-armed bandits.
AI.method: Formulates the problem as a two-stage low-rank matrix bandit. Stage 1 performs subspace estimation to reveal an underlying low-dimensional representation of the system; Stage 2 runs a linear bandit algorithm in this reduced space using scalar feedback of overall polarization and disagreement after each intervention.
AI.result: The proposed algorithm achieves alse(}, the text is messy; I need to be careful. The original: \widetilde{O}(\sqrt{T}) cumulative regret over horizon T. Empirical results show significant improvement over a linear bandit baseline in cumulative regret and running time.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, theoretically-grounded approach to learning innate opinions for intervention in social networks, connecting platform-level interventions with bandit theory and enabling efficient, regret-bounded control of polarization.

title: EvoWorld: Evolving Panoramic World Generation with Explicit 3D Memory
summary:
Humans possess a remarkable ability to mentally explore and replay 3D
environments they have previously experienced. Inspired by this mental process,
we present EvoWorld: a world model that bridges panoramic video generation with
evolving 3D memory to enable spatially consistent long-horizon exploration.
Given a single panoramic image as input, EvoWorld first generates future video
frames by leveraging a video generator with fine-grained view control, then
evolves the scene's 3D reconstruction using a feedforward plug-and-play
transformer, and finally synthesizes futures by conditioning on geometric
reprojections from this evolving explicit 3D memory. Unlike prior
state-of-the-arts that synthesize videos only, our key insight lies in
exploiting this evolving 3D reconstruction as explicit spatial guidance for the
video generation process, projecting the reconstructed geometry onto target
viewpoints to provide rich spatial cues that significantly enhance both visual
realism and geometric consistency. To evaluate long-range exploration
capabilities, we introduce the first comprehensive benchmark spanning synthetic
outdoor environments, Habitat indoor scenes, and challenging real-world
scenarios, with particular emphasis on loop-closure detection and spatial
