coherence over extended trajectories. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
our evolving 3D memory substantially improves visual fidelity and maintains
spatial scene coherence compared to existing approaches, representing a
significant advance toward long-horizon spatially consistent world modeling.

AI.tldr: EvoWorld combines evolving 3D memory with panoramic video generation to achieve long-horizon, spatially coherent exploration from a single panorama, outperforming prior video-only models in realism and geometry consistency.
AI.motivation: Humans mentally simulate 3D environments; existing approaches lack explicit dynamic 3D memory to guide long-range video synthesis; EvoWorld aims to couple 3D memory evolution with view-conditioned video generation to improve spatial coherence across extended trajectories, evaluated across synthetic, indoor, and real-world scenes with a focus on loop closure and geometric consistency.
AI.method: A three-stage pipeline: (1) from a single panoramic image, generate future frames using a video generator with fine-grained view control; (2) evolve the scene's 3D reconstruction using a feedforward plug-and-play transformer; (3) synthesize futures conditioned on geometric reprojections from the evolving 3D memory, projecting the geometry onto target views to provide rich spatial cues for generation.
AI.result: The evolving 3D memory substantially improves visual fidelity and spatial coherence over long trajectories. A new benchmark spanning synthetic outdoor environments, Habitat indoor scenes, and real-world data shows improved loop-closure detection and geometric consistency compared to state-of-the-art video-only methods.
AI.conclusion: This work advances long-horizon, spatially consistent world modeling by tightly coupling evolving explicit 3D memory with video generation, offering a significant step toward more realistic and coherent long-range scene synthesis.

title: MG2FlowNet: Accelerating High-Reward Sample Generation via Enhanced MCTS and Greediness Control
summary:
Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) have emerged as a powerful tool for
generating diverse and high-reward structured objects by learning to sample
from a distribution proportional to a given reward function. Unlike
conventional reinforcement learning (RL) approaches that prioritize
optimization of a single trajectory, GFlowNets seek to balance diversity and
reward by modeling the entire trajectory distribution. This capability makes
them especially suitable for domains such as molecular design and combinatorial
optimization. However, existing GFlowNets sampling strategies tend to
overexplore and struggle to consistently generate high-reward samples,
particularly in large search spaces with sparse high-reward regions. Therefore,
improving the probability of generating high-reward samples without sacrificing
diversity remains a key challenge under this premise. In this work, we
integrate an enhanced Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) into the GFlowNets
sampling process, using MCTS-based policy evaluation to guide the generation
toward high-reward trajectories and Polynomial Upper Confidence Trees (PUCT) to
balance exploration and exploitation adaptively, and we introduce a
controllable mechanism to regulate the degree of greediness. Our method
enhances exploitation without sacrificing diversity by dynamically balancing
exploration and reward-driven guidance. The experimental results show that our
method can not only accelerate the speed of discovering high-reward regions but
also continuously generate high-reward samples, while preserving the diversity
of the generative distribution. All implementations are available at
https://github.com/ZRNB/MG2FlowNet.

AI.tldr: MG2FlowNet: integrates enhanced Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) with Polynomial Upper Confidence Trees (PUCT) into Generative Flow Networks, plus a controllable greediness mechanism, to boost high-reward sample generation while preserving diversity; shows faster discovery of high-reward regions and sustained high-reward sampling; code released.
AI.motivation: GFlowNets aim to sample diverse objects with probabilities proportional to reward, but in large, sparse search spaces they tend to over-explore or struggle to consistently generate high-reward samples. There is a need to improve exploitation of high-reward trajectories without sacrificing diversity.
AI.method: Incorporate enhanced MCTS-based policy evaluation into the GFlowNet sampling process, use PUCT to balance exploration and exploitation adaptively, and introduce a controllable greediness parameter to regulate how greedily the agent pursues high rewards. This yields a dynamic balance that improves high-reward generation while maintaining distribution diversity.
AI.result: Experimental results show accelerated discovery of high-reward regions and the ability to continuously generate high-reward samples, with preserving diversity of the generative distribution.
AI.conclusion: MG2FlowNet effectively enhances exploitation in GFlowNets without sacrificing diversity, providing practical gains in sample quality and diversity; a configurable mechanism to control greediness is valuable for applications like molecular design and combinatorial optimization; code is available at the provided repository.

title: IMAGEdit: Let Any Subject Transform
summary:
In this paper, we present IMAGEdit, a training-free framework for any number
of video subject editing that manipulates the appearances of multiple
designated subjects while preserving non-target regions, without finetuning or
retraining. We achieve this by providing robust multimodal conditioning and
precise mask sequences through a prompt-guided multimodal alignment module and
a prior-based mask retargeting module. We first leverage large models'
understanding and generation capabilities to produce multimodal information and
mask motion sequences for multiple subjects across various types. Then, the
obtained prior mask sequences are fed into a pretrained mask-driven video
generation model to synthesize the edited video. With strong generalization
capability, IMAGEdit remedies insufficient prompt-side multimodal conditioning
and overcomes mask boundary entanglement in videos with any number of subjects,
thereby significantly expanding the applicability of video editing. More
importantly, IMAGEdit is compatible with any mask-driven video generation
model, significantly improving overall performance. Extensive experiments on
our newly constructed multi-subject benchmark MSVBench verify that IMAGEdit
consistently surpasses state-of-the-art methods. Code, models, and datasets are
publicly available at https://github.com/XWH-A/IMAGEdit.

AI.tldr: A training-free framework for editing any number of subjects in video frames by conditioning and mask retargeting, compatible with any mask-driven video generator, achieving state-of-the-art results on MSVBench.
AI.motivation: To enable scalable, training-free, multi-subject video editing that preserves non-target regions and handles arbitrary numbers of subjects, addressing limitations of fine-tuning, generalization, and mask boundary artifacts.
AI.method: Two components: (1) a prompt-guided multimodal alignment module that provides robust conditioning and mask motion sequences for multiple subjects; (2) a prior-based mask retargeting module that adapts the prior masks; these priors are then fed into a pretrained mask-driven video generation model to synthesize the edited video. The approach aims for strong generalization and compatibility with any mask-driven model.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on the MSVBench multi-subject benchmark show IMAGEdit consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods. The framework is compatible with various mask-driven video generation models, with code, models, and datasets publicly available.
AI.conclusion: IMAGEdit offers a training-free, generalizable solution for editing any number of subjects in videos while preserving non-target regions, significantly broadening the practical applicability of video editing and simplifying deployment.

title: Are Time Series Foundation Models Susceptible to Catastrophic Forgetting?
summary:
Time Series Foundation Models (TSFMs) have shown promising zero-shot
generalization across diverse forecasting tasks. However, their robustness to
continual adaptation remains underexplored. In this work, we investigate the
extent to which TSFMs suffer from catastrophic forgetting when fine-tuned
sequentially on multiple datasets. Using synthetic datasets designed with
varying degrees of periodic structure, we measure the trade-off between
adaptation to new data and retention of prior knowledge. Our experiments reveal
that, while fine-tuning improves performance on new tasks, it often causes
significant degradation on previously learned ones, illustrating a fundamental
stability-plasticity dilemma.

AI.tldr: TSFMs exhibit catastrophic forgetting under sequential fine-tuning; a stability–plasticity trade-off governs continual adaptation.
AI.motivation: To evaluate whether Time Series Foundation Models retain previously learned knowledge when fine-tuned on multiple datasets and quantify forgetting during continual learning.
AI.method: Create synthetic datasets with varying periodic structure; sequentially fine-tune TSFMs on these datasets; evaluate performance on old and new tasks; analyze forgetting dynamics and trade-offs.
AI.result: Fine-tuning improves performance on new tasks but causes significant degradation on previously learned tasks; demonstrates a stability-plasticity dilemma in TSFMs during continual adaptation.
AI.conclusion: Continual adaptation of TSFMs inherently balances plasticity and stability; future work should explore forgetting-mitigation strategies (e.g., regularization, replay, modular architectures) to preserve prior knowledge while adapting to new data.

title: Learn to Guide Your Diffusion Model
summary:
Classifier-free guidance (CFG) is a widely used technique for improving the
perceptual quality of samples from conditional diffusion models. It operates by
linearly combining conditional and unconditional score estimates using a
guidance weight $\omega$. While a large, static weight can markedly improve
visual results, this often comes at the cost of poorer distributional
alignment. In order to better approximate the target conditional distribution,
we instead learn guidance weights $\omega_{c,(s,t)}$, which are continuous
functions of the conditioning $c$, the time $t$ from which we denoise, and the
time $s$ towards which we denoise. We achieve this by minimizing the
distributional mismatch between noised samples from the true conditional
distribution and samples from the guided diffusion process. We extend our
framework to reward guided sampling, enabling the model to target distributions
tilted by a reward function $R(x_0,c)$, defined on clean data and a
conditioning $c$. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our methodology on
low-dimensional toy examples and high-dimensional image settings, where we
observe improvements in Fr\'echet inception distance (FID) for image
generation. In text-to-image applications, we observe that employing a reward
function given by the CLIP score leads to guidance weights that improve
image-prompt alignment.

AI.tldr: Learnable, continuous classifier-free guidance (CFG) weights ω_{c,(s,t)} conditioned on c and denoising timesteps, aiming to better approximate the target conditional distribution; extends CFG to reward-guided sampling for tilted distributions; shows improved FID and CLIP-alignment in image generation tasks.
AI.motivation: Static CFG weights often trade perceptual quality for distributional fidelity. By making guidance weights depend on conditioning and timesteps, the method seeks a closer match to the true conditional distribution while preserving quality.
AI.method: Introduce ω_{c,(s,t)} as a continuous function of conditioning c, the denoising time t, and the target time s. Train by minimizing distributional mismatch between noised samples from the true conditional distribution and samples from the guided diffusion. Extend the framework to reward-guided sampling using a reward function R(x0,c) to tilt the target distribution.
AI.result: Experiments on toy and high-dimensional image tasks show improved distributional fidelity and perception. In image generation, FID improves; in text-to-image, applying a CLIP-based reward yields better image-prompt alignment.
AI.conclusion: Learnable, continuous CFG weights can better approximate the target conditional distribution and enable reward-guided sampling, improving both sample quality and alignment with conditioning signals; applicable to diverse diffusion-model scenarios.

title: Stabilizing Policy Gradients for Sample-Efficient Reinforcement Learning in LLM Reasoning
summary:
Reinforcement Learning, particularly through policy gradient methods, has
played a central role in enabling reasoning capabilities of Large Language
Models. However, the optimization stability of policy gradients in this setting
remains understudied. As a result, existing implementations often resort to
conservative hyperparameter choices to ensure stability, which requires more
training samples and increases computational costs. Hence, developing models
for reliably tracking the underlying optimization dynamics and leveraging them
into training enables more sample-efficient regimes and further unleashes
scalable post-training. We address this gap by formalizing the stochastic
optimization problem of policy gradients with explicit consideration of
second-order geometry. We propose a tractable computational framework that
tracks and leverages curvature information during policy updates. We further
employ this framework to design interventions in the optimization process
through data selection. The resultant algorithm, Curvature-Aware Policy
Optimization (CAPO), identifies samples that contribute to unstable updates and
masks them out. Theoretically, we establish monotonic improvement guarantees
under realistic assumptions. On standard math reasoning benchmarks, we
empirically show that CAPO ensures stable updates under aggressive learning
regimes where baselines catastrophically fail. With minimal intervention
(rejecting fewer than 8% of tokens), CAPO achieves up to 30x improvement in
sample efficiency over standard GRPO for LLM reasoning.

AI.tldr: CAPO uses curvature-aware data selection to stabilize policy-gradient updates for LLM reasoning, masking unstable samples to improve sample efficiency—achieving up to 30x gains with minimal token rejection.
AI.motivation: Policy gradient optimization for large-language-model reasoning is often unstable, forcing conservative hyperparameters and expensive training; leveraging second-order geometry could stabilize updates and reduce data needs.
AI.method: Develop a stochastic policy-gradient framework that tracks curvature information during updates and design CAPO to identify and mask samples that cause instability, with theoretical monotonic-improvement guarantees.
AI.result: CAPO delivers stable updates under aggressive learning regimes where baselines fail; with less than 8% token rejection, it achieves up to 30x improvement in sample efficiency over standard GRPO on math reasoning benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating curvature-aware data selection into policy-gradient optimization improves stability and sample efficiency in LLM reasoning, enabling more efficient post-training and scalable training regimes.

title: LLM Routing with Dueling Feedback
summary:
We study LLM routing, the problem of selecting the best model for each query
while balancing user satisfaction, model expertise, and inference cost. We
formulate routing as contextual dueling bandits, learning from pairwise
preference feedback rather than absolute scores, thereby yielding
label-efficient and dynamic adaptation. Building on this formulation, we
introduce Category-Calibrated Fine-Tuning (CCFT), a representation-learning
method that derives model embeddings from offline data using contrastive
fine-tuning with categorical weighting. These embeddings enable the practical
instantiation of Feel-Good Thompson Sampling for Contextual Dueling Bandits
(FGTS.CDB), a theoretically grounded posterior-sampling algorithm. We propose
four variants of the categorical weighting that explicitly integrate model
quality and cost, and we empirically evaluate the proposed methods on the
RouterBench and MixInstruct datasets. Across both benchmarks, our methods
achieve lower cumulative regret and faster convergence, with better robustness
and performance-cost balance than strong baselines built with a general-purpose
OpenAI embedding model.

AI.tldr: Contextual dueling bandits for LLM routing using pairwise preferences, with Category-Calibrated Fine-Tuning embeddings enabling Feel-Good Thompson Sampling for CDB; achieves better regret, convergence, and cost-robustness on RouterBench and MixInstruct.
AI.motivation: To optimize per-query model selection under competing objectives (user satisfaction, model expertise, and inference cost) by leveraging label-efficient feedback and dynamic adaptation instead of relying on absolute scores.
AI.method: Formulate routing as contextual dueling bandits (learning from pairwise preferences). Develop Category-Calibrated Fine-Tuning (CCFT) to derive model embeddings via contrastive fine-tuning with categorical weighting. Use CCFT embeddings to instantiate Feel-Good Thompson Sampling for Contextual Dueling Bandits (FGTS.CDB). Propose four categorical weighting variants that incorporate model quality and cost, and evaluate on RouterBench and MixInstruct against strong baselines.
AI.result: The proposed methods achieve lower cumulative regret, faster convergence, and improved robustness and balance between performance and cost across both benchmarks, outperforming strong baselines built with a general-purpose OpenAI embedding model.
AI.conclusion: CCFT-based embeddings and FGTS.CDB provide a label-efficient, dynamically adaptable routing framework that effectively balances user satisfaction, model expertise, and cost in LLM routing.

title: Mechanistic Interpretability as Statistical Estimation: A Variance Analysis of EAP-IG
summary:
The development of trustworthy artificial intelligence requires moving beyond
black-box performance metrics toward an understanding of models' internal
computations. Mechanistic Interpretability (MI) aims to meet this need by
identifying the algorithmic mechanisms underlying model behaviors. Yet, the
scientific rigor of MI critically depends on the reliability of its findings.
In this work, we argue that interpretability methods, such as circuit
discovery, should be viewed as statistical estimators, subject to questions of
variance and robustness. To illustrate this statistical framing, we present a
systematic stability analysis of a state-of-the-art circuit discovery method:
EAP-IG. We evaluate its variance and robustness through a comprehensive suite
of controlled perturbations, including input resampling, prompt paraphrasing,
hyperparameter variation, and injected noise within the causal analysis itself.
Across a diverse set of models and tasks, our results demonstrate that EAP-IG
exhibits high structural variance and sensitivity to hyperparameters,
questioning the stability of its findings. Based on these results, we offer a
set of best-practice recommendations for the field, advocating for the routine
reporting of stability metrics to promote a more rigorous and statistically
grounded science of interpretability.

AI.tldr: Interpretable AI methods should be treated as statistical estimators; the stability of EAP-IG circuit discovery is questionable, as variance and hyperparameter sensitivity undermine robustness; recommends routine stability reporting.
AI.motivation: To increase rigor in mechanistic interpretability by treating interpretability methods as estimators with variance, moving beyond sole reliance on performance metrics.
AI.method: Systematic stability analysis of EAP-IG via controlled perturbations: input resampling, prompt paraphrasing, hyperparameter variation, and injected noise within the causal analysis; tested across diverse models and tasks.
AI.result: Demonstrated high structural variance and sensitivity to hyperparameters; findings are not robust across perturbations or configurations.
AI.conclusion: Advocates routine reporting of stability metrics and adoption of best-practice guidelines to build a statistically grounded, more reliable science of interpretability.

title: Population Synthesis using Incomplete Information
comment: Presented at 25th Euro Working Group on Transportation (EWGT) Meeting
summary:
This paper presents a population synthesis model that utilizes the
Wasserstein Generative-Adversarial Network (WGAN) for training on incomplete
microsamples. By using a mask matrix to represent missing values, the study
proposes a WGAN training algorithm that lets the model learn from a training
dataset that has some missing information. The proposed method aims to address
the challenge of missing information in microsamples on one or more attributes
due to privacy concerns or data collection constraints. The paper contrasts
WGAN models trained on incomplete microsamples with those trained on complete
microsamples, creating a synthetic population. We conducted a series of
evaluations of the proposed method using a Swedish national travel survey. We
validate the efficacy of the proposed method by generating synthetic
populations from all the models and comparing them to the actual population
dataset. The results from the experiments showed that the proposed methodology
successfully generates synthetic data that closely resembles a model trained
with complete data as well as the actual population. The paper contributes to
the field by providing a robust solution for population synthesis with
incomplete data, opening avenues for future research, and highlighting the
potential of deep generative models in advancing population synthesis
capabilities.

AI.tldr: A WGAN-based population synthesis method trained on incomplete microsamples using a masking approach; validated on a Swedish travel survey; synthetic populations closely match both a model trained on complete data and the actual population.
AI.motivation: Missing data in microsamples due to privacy or data collection constraints motivates developing a method that can learn population structure from incomplete data without discarding samples.
AI.method: A Wasserstein GAN trained with a mask matrix to represent missing values, enabling learning from incomplete microsamples. The model is compared to a WGAN trained on complete microsamples. Evaluation uses a Swedish national travel survey to generate synthetic populations and benchmark them against the actual population.
AI.result: The proposed method successfully generates synthetic data that closely resemble both the complete-data model and the actual population, indicating robustness to missing data.
AI.conclusion: The paper offers a robust solution for population synthesis with incomplete data and highlights the potential of deep generative models to advance population synthesis, with implications for privacy-preserving data analysis and future research directions.

title: The data-quality illusion: Rethinking Classifier-based quality filtering for LLM Pretraining
summary:
Large-scale models are pretrained on massive web-crawled datasets containing
documents of mixed quality, making data filtering essential. A popular method
is Classifier-based Quality Filtering (CQF), which trains a binary classifier
to distinguish between pretraining data and a small, high-quality set. It
assigns each pretraining document a quality score defined as the classifier's
score and retains only the top-scoring ones. We provide an in-depth analysis of
CQF. We show that while CQF improves downstream task performance, it does not
necessarily enhance language modeling on the high-quality dataset. We explain
this paradox by the fact that CQF implicitly filters the high-quality dataset
as well. We further compare the behavior of models trained with CQF to those
trained on synthetic data of increasing quality, obtained via random token
permutations, and find starkly different trends. Our results challenge the view
that CQF captures a meaningful notion of data quality.

AI.tldr: CQF can improve downstream task performance but does not reliably improve language modeling on the high-quality data; CQF implicitly filters the high-quality dataset, challenging the idea that it captures meaningful data quality.
AI.motivation: To understand whether classifier-based quality filtering (CQF) truly captures data quality and improves model performance on large-scale pretraining, given that data quality is nuanced and can affect both downstream tasks and language modeling.
AI.method: Provide an in-depth analysis of CQF, and compare models trained with CQF to those trained on synthetic data of increasing quality (generated by random token permutations). Evaluate on downstream tasks and language-modeling metrics to uncover patterns and potential paradoxes.
AI.result: CQF improves downstream task performance but does not consistently boost language modeling on the high-quality data; CQF implicitly filters the high-quality dataset as well, which may explain the paradox. Models trained with CQF behave markedly differently from models trained on synthetic data of increasing quality, indicating that CQF does not simply select higher-quality data.
AI.conclusion: CQF may not capture a meaningful notion of data quality as previously believed. The practice of using CQF to curate pretraining data should be re-evaluated, and alternative data-quality assessment methods or curation strategies may be necessary to avoid unintended filtering of high-quality content.

title: Target Population Synthesis using CT-GAN
comment: Submitted for journal and is under review
summary:
Agent-based models used in scenario planning for transportation and urban
planning usually require detailed population information from the base as well
as target scenarios. These populations are usually provided by synthesizing
fake agents through deterministic population synthesis methods. However, these
deterministic population synthesis methods face several challenges, such as
handling high-dimensional data, scalability, and zero-cell issues, particularly
when generating populations for target scenarios. This research looks into how
a deep generative model called Conditional Tabular Generative Adversarial
Network (CT-GAN) can be used to create target populations either directly from
a collection of marginal constraints or through a hybrid method that combines
CT-GAN with Fitness-based Synthesis Combinatorial Optimization (FBS-CO). The
research evaluates the proposed population synthesis models against travel
survey and zonal-level aggregated population data. Results indicate that the
stand-alone CT-GAN model performs the best when compared with FBS-CO and the
hybrid model. CT-GAN by itself can create realistic-looking groups that match
single-variable distributions, but it struggles to maintain relationships
between multiple variables. However, the hybrid model demonstrates improved
performance compared to FBS-CO by leveraging CT-GAN ability to generate a
descriptive base population, which is then refined using FBS-CO to align with
target-year marginals. This study demonstrates that CT-GAN represents an
effective methodology for target populations and highlights how deep generative
models can be successfully integrated with conventional synthesis techniques to
enhance their performance.

AI.tldr: CT-GAN can generate target populations for scenario planning; performs best alone among the tested methods but struggles with multivariate relationships; a hybrid CT-GAN + FBS-CO improves alignment to target marginals; demonstrates potential for integrating deep generative models with traditional synthesis.
AI.motivation: Agent-based transport/urban planning requires base and target population data; deterministic population synthesis struggles with high-dimensional data, scalability, and zero-cell issues, especially for target scenarios.
AI.method: Compare three approaches: stand-alone CT-GAN, FBS-CO, and a CT-GAN + FBS-CO hybrid. CT-GAN is used to generate a base population from marginal constraints or as input to the hybrid; the hybrid refines the CT-GAN output with FBS-CO to align with target-year marginals. Evaluation uses travel survey data and zonal-level aggregates.
AI.result: Stand-alone CT-GAN performs best among the three models when evaluated. It can reproduce single-variable distributions well but has difficulty preserving relationships among multiple variables. The hybrid CT-GAN + FBS-CO model yields better performance than FBS-CO alone by leveraging CT-GAN to create a descriptive base population and then refining to match marginals.
AI.conclusion: CT-GAN is an effective method for generating target populations for scenario planning, and integrating deep generative models with traditional synthesis techniques (CT-GAN + FBS-CO) can enhance performance.

title: A Visual Diagnostics Framework for District Heating Data: Enhancing Data Quality for AI-Driven Heat Consumption Prediction
comment:
Energy Informatics.Academy Conference 2025 (EI.A 2025), 3-6 December
  2025, Universiti Tenaga Nasional (UNITEN), Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
summary:
High-quality data is a prerequisite for training reliable Artificial
Intelligence (AI) models in the energy domain. In district heating networks,
sensor and metering data often suffer from noise, missing values, and temporal
inconsistencies, which can significantly degrade model performance. This paper
presents a systematic approach for evaluating and improving data quality using
visual diagnostics, implemented through an interactive web-based dashboard. The
dashboard employs Python-based visualization techniques, including time series
plots, heatmaps, box plots, histograms, correlation matrices, and
anomaly-sensitive KPIs such as skewness and anomaly detection based on the
modified z-scores. These tools al-low human experts to inspect and interpret
data anomalies, enabling a human-in-the-loop strategy for data quality
assessment. The methodology is demonstrated on a real-world dataset from a
Danish district heating provider, covering over four years of hourly data from
nearly 7000 meters. The findings show how visual analytics can uncover systemic
data issues and, in the future, guide data cleaning strategies that enhance the
accuracy, stability, and generalizability of Long Short-Term Memory and Gated
Recurrent Unit models for heat demand forecasting. The study contributes to a
scalable, generalizable framework for visual data inspection and underlines the
critical role of data quality in AI-driven energy management systems.

AI.tldr: A visual analytics dashboard for QA of district heating data identifies anomalies and guides cleaning to improve AI forecasts (LSTM/GRU) of heat demand.
AI.motivation: High-quality data is critical for reliable AI in energy. Sensor noise, gaps, and temporal inconsistencies degrade performance. A human-in-the-loop, visual inspection framework is proposed to systematically diagnose and improve data quality.
AI.method: An interactive web-based dashboard with Python visualizations (time series, heatmaps, box plots, histograms, correlations) and anomaly-sensitive KPIs (skewness, modified z-scores). Enables experts to inspect data and guide cleaning. Demonstrated on four years of hourly data from ~7,000 meters in a Danish district heating network.
AI.result: Visual analytics reveal systemic data issues and ambiguous data segments; the dashboard can guide targeted data cleaning strategies, potentially improving the accuracy, stability, and generalizability of LSTM/GRU heat-demand forecasts.
AI.conclusion: The study presents a scalable, generalizable framework for visual data inspection, underscoring the pivotal role of data quality in AI-driven energy management and its impact on model performance.

title: Reducción de ruido por medio de autoencoders: caso de estudio con la señal GW150914
comment:
in Spanish language, Presented at the RPIC 2023 (Information
  Processing and Control work Reunion)
summary:
This brief study focuses on the application of autoencoders to improve the
quality of low-amplitude signals, such as gravitational events. A pre-existing
autoencoder was trained using cosmic event data, optimizing its architecture
and parameters. The results show a significant increase in the signal-to-noise
ratio of the processed signals, demonstrating the potential of autoencoders in
the analysis of small signals with multiple sources of interference.

AI.tldr: Autoencoder denoising improves SNR of low-amplitude gravitational-event signals; trained on cosmic event data; shows potential for interference-heavy, weak signals.
AI.motivation: Improve detectability of weak cosmic signals by leveraging learned representations to suppress noise and interference.
AI.method: Adopt a pre-existing autoencoder trained on cosmic event data; optimize its architecture/parameters; apply to low-amplitude signals to denoise and improve SNR.
AI.result: Significant SNR increase in processed signals; evidence that autoencoders can aid analysis of small signals amid multiple interference sources.
AI.conclusion: Autoencoders are promising for improving weak-signal analysis; suggests broader applicability and need for further evaluation on diverse datasets.

title: GLAI: GreenLightningAI for Accelerated Training through Knowledge Decoupling
summary:
In this work we introduce GreenLightningAI (GLAI), a new architectural block
designed as an alternative to conventional MLPs. The central idea is to
separate two types of knowledge that are usually entangled during training: (i)
*structural knowledge*, encoded by the stable activation patterns induced by
ReLU activations; and (ii) *quantitative knowledge*, carried by the numerical
weights and biases. By fixing the structure once stabilized, GLAI reformulates
the MLP as a combination of paths, where only the quantitative component is
optimized. This reformulation retains the universal approximation capabilities
of MLPs, yet achieves a more efficient training process, reducing training time
by ~40% on average across the cases examined in this study. Crucially, GLAI is
not just another classifier, but a generic block that can replace MLPs wherever
they are used, from supervised heads with frozen backbones to projection layers
in self-supervised learning or few-shot classifiers. Across diverse
experimental setups, GLAI consistently matches or exceeds the accuracy of MLPs
with an equivalent number of parameters, while converging faster. Overall, GLAI
establishes a new design principle that opens a direction for future
integration into large-scale architectures such as Transformers, where MLP
blocks dominate the computational footprint.

AI.tldr: GLAI decouples structure from parameters in MLPs by fixing activation-derived structure and learning a path-based, quantitative-weight formulation, yielding faster training (~40% on average) while maintaining or improving accuracy and enabling broader use as a drop-in block for various architectures.
AI.motivation: Address training inefficiency of MLPs by separating stable structural knowledge (activation patterns) from numerical weights, enabling more efficient optimization without sacrificing universal approximation.
AI.method: Identify stable ReLU-induced activation structures, fix them, reformulate MLP as a sum of paths where only the quantitative weights are optimized; use GLAI as a drop-in block across architectures (supervised heads, projection layers, few-shot classifiers); claim preserved universality while accelerating convergence.
AI.result: Consistent matching or surpassing of MLP accuracy with equivalent parameter counts; average training time reduction around 40%; faster convergence across diverse experimental setups.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a new design principle—decoupled structure and parameters via path-based blocks—for efficient MLPs with potential integration into large-scale architectures like Transformers.

title: Rectifying Regression in Reinforcement Learning
summary:
This paper investigates the impact of the loss function in value-based
methods for reinforcement learning through an analysis of underlying prediction
objectives. We theoretically show that mean absolute error is a better
prediction objective than the traditional mean squared error for controlling
the learned policy's suboptimality gap. Furthermore, we present results that
different loss functions are better aligned with these different regression
objectives: binary and categorical cross-entropy losses with the mean absolute
error and squared loss with the mean squared error. We then provide empirical
evidence that algorithms minimizing these cross-entropy losses can outperform
those based on the squared loss in linear reinforcement learning.

AI.tldr: Mean absolute error (MAE) as a prediction objective improves control of the policy suboptimality gap in value-based RL, compared to mean squared error (MSE). Cross-entropy losses (binary/categorical for MAE, squared for MSE) align with their respective regression objectives, and empirical results in linear RL show cross-entropy-based methods can outperform squared-loss baselines.
AI.motivation: To understand how the choice of loss function in value-based reinforcement learning affects the underlying prediction objectives, and how this choice translates into suboptimality guarantees and practical performance.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis comparing MAE vs MSE as prediction objectives and their compatibility with cross-entropy losses; derivation of alignment between loss types and regression objectives; empirical evaluation in linear reinforcement learning comparing cross-entropy-based losses to squared loss.
AI.result: The study shows MAE better controls the suboptimality gap than MSE; cross-entropy losses align with the corresponding regression objectives (binary/categorical with MAE, squared with MSE); empirically, algorithms using cross-entropy losses can outperform those based on squared loss in linear RL.
AI.conclusion: Choosing the loss function in value-based RL matters: MAE paired with appropriate cross-entropy losses provides better theoretical guarantees on suboptimality and can lead to better empirical performance; this motivates reevaluating loss-function design in RL algorithms, particularly for linear settings.

title: BoMGene: Integrating Boruta-mRMR feature selection for enhanced Gene expression classification
summary:
Feature selection is a crucial step in analyzing gene expression data,
enhancing classification performance, and reducing computational costs for
high-dimensional datasets. This paper proposes BoMGene, a hybrid feature
selection method that effectively integrates two popular techniques: Boruta and
Minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance (mRMR). The method aims to optimize the
feature space and enhance classification accuracy. Experiments were conducted
on 25 publicly available gene expression datasets, employing widely used
classifiers such as Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest, XGBoost (XGB),
and Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM). The results show that using the
Boruta-mRMR combination cuts down the number of features chosen compared to
just using mRMR, which helps to speed up training time while keeping or even
improving classification accuracy compared to using individual feature
selection methods. The proposed approach demonstrates clear advantages in
accuracy, stability, and practical applicability for multi-class gene
expression data analysis

AI.tldr: BoMGene is a hybrid Boruta-mRMR feature selector for gene expression data that reduces features and maintains or improves classification accuracy across 25 datasets and multiple classifiers.
AI.motivation: Gene expression data are high-dimensional, making feature selection crucial to improve accuracy and reduce computation. While Boruta and mRMR each have strengths, a hybrid approach can leverage relevance, redundancy reduction, and stability.
AI.method: BoMGene integrates Boruta and mRMR in a two-stage pipeline: first apply Boruta to identify relevant features, then apply mRMR to the reduced set to optimize relevance against redundancy, yielding a compact subset used for classification.
AI.result: On 25 public gene expression datasets, BoMGene reduces feature counts more than using mRMR alone, accelerates training, and maintains or improves classification accuracy across SVM, Random Forest, XGBoost, and GBM, indicating higher accuracy, stability, and practical applicability for multi-class data.
AI.conclusion: The BoMGene framework successfully combines Boruta and mRMR to produce robust, efficient feature subsets that enhance classifier performance in high-dimensional gene expression analysis.

title: RiskPO: Risk-based Policy Optimization via Verifiable Reward for LLM Post-Training
summary:
Reinforcement learning with verifiable reward has recently emerged as a
central paradigm for post-training large language models (LLMs); however,
prevailing mean-based methods, such as Group Relative Policy Optimization
(GRPO), suffer from entropy collapse and limited reasoning gains. We argue that
these issues stem from overemphasizing high-probability output sequences while
neglecting rare but informative reasoning paths. To address these challenges,
we propose Risk-based Policy Optimization (RiskPO), which substitutes classical
mean-based objectives with principled risk measures. Specifically, we introduce
a Mixed Value-at-Risk objective that integrates weighted attention over
multiple regions of the reward distribution, thereby amplifying gradient
signals on challenging instances and preventing overconfident convergence. We
further design a bundling scheme that aggregates multiple questions into
bundles, thus enriching the feedback signal and yielding more stable and
informative training dynamics. Theoretically, we prove that the risk-averse
update alleviates entropy collapse and promotes exploration. Numerically,
RiskPO achieves consistent and significant improvements in mathematical
reasoning, multi-modal reasoning, and code generation benchmarks, surpassing
GRPO and its variants on both Pass@1 and Pass@k metrics. Our results
demonstrate that risk-based optimization provides a rigorous and effective
paradigm for enhancing LLM reasoning capabilities.

AI.tldr: RiskPO replaces mean-based objectives with a risk-aware mix of Value-at-Risk to amplify gradients on hard instances, improving LLM reasoning and code generation beyond GRPO.
AI.motivation: To fix entropy collapse and limited gains from overemphasizing high-prob output sequences in policy optimization for verifiable rewards in LLMs; rare but informative reasoning paths are neglected by GRPO.
AI.method: Introduce a Mixed Value-at-Risk objective with weighted attention over multiple regions of the reward distribution; use a bundling scheme to aggregate multiple questions into bundles; provide theoretical guarantees that risk-averse updates promote exploration; aim for more stable and informative training dynamics.
AI.result: Consistent and significant improvements in mathematical reasoning, multi-modal reasoning, and code generation benchmarks; surpasses GRPO and its variants on Pass@1 and Pass@k metrics.
AI.conclusion: Risk-based optimization offers a rigorous and effective paradigm for enhancing LLM reasoning capabilities by leveraging risk measures to enrich feedback and prevent overconfident convergence.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable yet Noisy Rewards under Imperfect Verifiers
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) trains policies against
automated verifiers to avoid costly human labeling. To reduce vulnerability to
verifier hacking, many RLVR systems collapse rewards to binary $\{0,1\}$ during
training. This choice carries a cost: it introduces \textit{false negatives}
(rejecting correct answers, FNs) and \textit{false positives} (accepting
incorrect ones, FPs). For instance, a rule-based checker may mark the correct
fraction $\frac{12}{36}$ as wrong when compared against the canonical
$\frac{1}{3}$ due to brittle parsing/equivalence rules (FN), while a large
language model (LLM) judges can be gamed by superficial cues or even a single
adversarial token, yielding inflated correctness for wrong solutions (FP). We
formalize verifier unreliability by modeling the verifier as a stochastic
reward channel with asymmetric noise rates. From this abstraction, we derive
two correction algorithms for verifier errors. The first is a \textit{backward}
correction that de-biases the observed binary reward to recover an
\textit{unbiased} estimator of the clean policy gradient. The second is a
\textit{forward} correction that reweights score-function terms so that the
expected update direction aligns with the \textit{clean gradient}; notably, it
requires only the FN rate. We implement both as lightweight hooks in a group
relative policy optimization (GRPO)-based RLVR pipeline and evaluate them on
math-reasoning models and benchmarks. Across models and datasets, both
corrections improve over uncorrected training; the forward variant converges
faster and remains stable under heavier noise. Finally, we show a practical
appeal mechanism in which a lightweight LLM verifier estimates the FN rate
online by rechecking rule-based negatives, obtaining outperformance compared
with other state-of-the-art contenders.

AI.tldr: Two corrections for verifier unreliability in RLVR (reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards) are proposed. A backward correction debiases binary rewards to yield an unbiased policy gradient estimate, and a forward correction reweights score-function terms to align updates with the clean gradient, needing only the false-negative (FN) rate. Implemented as optional hooks in a GRPO-based RLVR pipeline, both improve training over uncorrected baselines; the forward method converges faster and remains stable under heavier noise. An online FN-rate estimator using a lightweight LLM verifier further enhances performance.
AI.motivation: Verifier unreliability in RLVR due to asymmetric noise (false negatives and false positives) degrades learning when rewards are collapsed to binary. This leads to biased gradient estimates and unstable training, motivating principled correction methods that account for verifier errors.
AI.method: Model the verifier as a stochastic reward channel with asymmetric noise. Derive two correction algorithms: 1) backward correction that de-biases observed binary rewards to obtain an unbiased estimator of the clean policy gradient; 2) forward correction that reweights score-function terms so that the expected update matches the clean gradient, requiring only the false-negative rate. Implement as lightweight hooks in a GRPO-based RLVR pipeline and evaluate on math-reasoning models and benchmarks.
AI.result: Both correction methods improve over uncorrected training across models and datasets. The forward correction converges faster and remains stable under heavier noise. An online practical appeal mechanism estimates the FN rate via a lightweight LLM verifier rechecking rule-based negatives, outperforming several state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: Verifer unreliability can be mitigated with principled gradient correction techniques. The backward method provides unbiased policy gradient estimates, while the forward method offers faster, stable improvements with lower information requirements (FN rate only). The approach enables more robust RLVR training and practical online FN-rate estimation.

title: Large Reasoning Models Learn Better Alignment from Flawed Thinking
summary:
Large reasoning models (LRMs) "think" by generating structured
chain-of-thought (CoT) before producing a final answer, yet they still lack the
ability to reason critically about safety alignment and are easily biased when
a flawed premise is injected into their thought process. We propose RECAP
(Robust Safety Alignment via Counter-Aligned Prefilling), a principled
reinforcement learning (RL) method for post-training that explicitly teaches
models to override flawed reasoning trajectories and reroute to safe and
helpful responses. RECAP trains on a mixture of synthetically generated
counter-aligned CoT prefills and standard prompts, requires no additional
training cost or modifications beyond vanilla reinforcement learning from human
feedback (RLHF), and substantially improves safety and jailbreak robustness,
reduces overrefusal, and preserves core reasoning capability -- all while
maintaining inference token budget. Extensive analysis shows that RECAP-trained
models engage in self-reflection more frequently and remain robust under
adaptive attacks, preserving safety even after repeated attempts to override
their reasoning.

AI.tldr: RECAP is a post-training RL method that improves safety alignment for large reasoning models by learning to override flawed reasoning paths via counter-aligned CoT prefills, with no extra training cost beyond vanilla RLHF, boosting safety and jailbreak robustness while preserving reasoning and token budget.
AI.motivation: LRMs using chain-of-thought are vulnerable to safety issues, biased premises, and jailbreaking attempts that can derail safe responses. There is a need for a mechanism to override flawed reasoning trajectories and ensure safe, helpful outputs without sacrificing core reasoning abilities.
AI.method: Train with a mixture of synthetically generated counter-aligned CoT prefills and standard prompts using reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF). The approach teaches models to override flawed reasoning trajectories and redirect to safe responses, without additional training cost beyond vanilla RLHF.
AI.result: Substantial improvements in safety and jailbreak robustness; reduced overrefusal; preserved core reasoning ability; maintained inference token budget; models exhibit more self-reflection and remain robust under adaptive attacks.
AI.conclusion: RECAP provides a practical post-training RL-based solution for robust safety alignment of LRMs, enabling safer and more reliable reasoning without sacrificing reasoning capabilities, even under repeated adversarial prompts.

title: It Takes Two: Your GRPO Is Secretly DPO
summary:
Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) is a prominent reinforcement
learning algorithm for post-training Large Language Models (LLMs). It is
commonly believed that GRPO necessitates a large group size to ensure stable
training via precise statistical estimation, which incurs substantial
computational overhead. In this work, we challenge this assumption by reframing
GRPO as a form of contrastive learning, which reveals a fundamental connection
to Direct Preference Optimization (DPO). Motivated by DPO's empirical success,
we investigate the minimal two-rollout case (2-GRPO), a configuration
previously deemed infeasible. We provide a rigorous theoretical analysis to
validate 2-GRPO and demonstrate empirically that it achieves performance on par
with 16-GRPO, despite using only 1/8 of the rollouts and reducing training time
by over 70%.

AI.tldr: 2-GRPO matches 16-GRPO with only 1/8 rollouts, reducing training time by >70% by reframing GRPO as contrastive learning and linking it to DPO.
AI.motivation: Question the belief that large group sizes are required for stable GRPO, aiming to reduce computational overhead in post-training LLM alignment.
AI.method: Theoretically reframe GRPO as contrastive learning and draw rigorous connections to Direct Preference Optimization (DPO); analyze the minimal two-rollout setting (2-GRPO) and validate its feasibility; empirically compare 2-GRPO against 16-GRPO.
AI.result: 2-GRPO achieves comparable performance to 16-GRPO while using only 1/8 of the rollouts and reducing training time by over 70%.
AI.conclusion: Two-rollout GRPO is a viable, more efficient alternative for post-training LLM alignment, challenging the assumption that large batch-like groupings are necessary and offering substantial practical speedups.

title: Riemannian Consistency Model
summary:
Consistency models are a class of generative models that enable few-step
generation for diffusion and flow matching models. While consistency models
have achieved promising results on Euclidean domains like images, their
applications to Riemannian manifolds remain challenging due to the curved
geometry. In this work, we propose the Riemannian Consistency Model (RCM),
which, for the first time, enables few-step consistency modeling while
respecting the intrinsic manifold constraint imposed by the Riemannian
geometry. Leveraging the covariant derivative and exponential-map-based
parameterization, we derive the closed-form solutions for both discrete- and
continuous-time training objectives for RCM. We then demonstrate theoretical
equivalence between the two variants of RCM: Riemannian consistency
distillation (RCD) that relies on a teacher model to approximate the marginal
vector field, and Riemannian consistency training (RCT) that utilizes the
conditional vector field for training. We further propose a simplified training
objective that eliminates the need for the complicated differential
calculation. Finally, we provide a unique kinematics perspective for
interpreting the RCM objective, offering new theoretical angles. Through
extensive experiments, we manifest the superior generative quality of RCM in
few-step generation on various non-Euclidean manifolds, including flat-tori,
spheres, and the 3D rotation group SO(3).

AI.tldr: First-of-its-kind Riemannian Consistency Model enabling few-step generation on manifolds using covariant derivative and exponential-map parameterization; establishes equivalence between Riemannian consistency distillation (RCD) and Riemannian consistency training (RCT); introduces simplified objective and a kinematics interpretation; demonstrates strong results on flat-tori, spheres, and SO(3).
AI.motivation: Consistency models excel in Euclidean spaces but struggle on curved Riemannian manifolds due to intrinsic geometry. There is a need to enable few-step generation that respects manifold constraints.
AI.method: Leverage covariant derivative and exponential-map parameterization to derive closed-form training objectives for discrete- and continuous-time variants; prove equivalence between RCD and RCT; propose a simplified training objective to avoid complex differential calculations; offer a kinematics-based interpretation.
AI.result: RCM achieves superior few-step generative quality on non-Euclidean manifolds (flat-tori, spheres, SO(3)) compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: RCM extends consistency modeling to Riemannian manifolds, providing theoretical and practical tools (equivalences, simplified training) and broadening applicability of diffusion/flow models to curved spaces.

title: Random Feature Spiking Neural Networks
comment: 34 pages incl. references & appendix, 3 figures, 4 tables
summary:
Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) as Machine Learning (ML) models have recently
received a lot of attention as a potentially more energy-efficient alternative
to conventional Artificial Neural Networks. The non-differentiability and
sparsity of the spiking mechanism can make these models very difficult to train
with algorithms based on propagating gradients through the spiking
non-linearity. We address this problem by adapting the paradigm of Random
Feature Methods (RFMs) from Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to Spike Response
Model (SRM) SNNs. This approach allows training of SNNs without approximation
of the spike function gradient. Concretely, we propose a novel data-driven,
fast, high-performance, and interpretable algorithm for end-to-end training of
SNNs inspired by the SWIM algorithm for RFM-ANNs, which we coin S-SWIM. We
provide a thorough theoretical discussion and supplementary numerical
experiments showing that S-SWIM can reach high accuracies on time series
forecasting as a standalone strategy and serve as an effective initialisation
strategy before gradient-based training. Additional ablation studies show that
our proposed method performs better than random sampling of network weights.

AI.tldr: Introduces S-SWIM, a gradient-free, data-driven training method for Spike Response Model SNNs using Random Feature Methods; enables fast, interpretable end-to-end training and can initialize gradient-based training, achieving strong time-series forecasting performance.
AI.motivation: Training SNNs is hampered by non-differentiability and spike sparsity; Random Feature Methods (RFMs) from ANNs offer a gradient-free alternative; the work adapts RFMs to SRM-based SNNs to enable training without gradient approximation.
AI.method: Develop S-SWIM inspired by SWIM for RFMs in ANNs; employs data-driven random-feature representations within SRM-based SNNs to train end-to-end without requiring gradients through spike nonlinearity; usable as a standalone training method or as an initialization before gradient-based optimization; includes theoretical analysis and numerical experiments; ablation studies compare against random weight sampling.
AI.result: S-SWIM achieves high accuracy on time-series forecasting as a standalone method and also serves as an effective initialization for subsequent gradient-based training; ablation shows it outperforms random sampling of network weights.
AI.conclusion: S-SWIM provides a fast, interpretable, and effective gradient-free training pathway for SNNs by leveraging RFMs, broadening training options; it can speed up training and improve performance when used alone or as a initialization prior to backpropagation.

title: The Good, the Bad, and the Sampled: a No-Regret Approach to Safe Online Classification
summary:
We study the problem of sequentially testing individuals for a binary disease
outcome whose true risk is governed by an unknown logistic model. At each
round, a patient arrives with feature vector $x_t$, and the decision maker may
either pay to administer a (noiseless) diagnostic test--revealing the true
label--or skip testing and predict the patient's disease status based on their
feature vector and prior history. Our goal is to minimize the total number of
costly tests required while guaranteeing that the fraction of
misclassifications does not exceed a prespecified error tolerance $\alpha$,
with probability at least $1-\delta$. To address this, we develop a novel
algorithm that interleaves label-collection and distribution estimation to
estimate both $\theta^{*}$ and the context distribution $P$, and computes a
conservative, data-driven threshold $\tau_t$ on the logistic score
$|x_t^\top\theta|$ to decide when testing is necessary. We prove that, with
probability at least $1-\delta$, our procedure does not exceed the target
misclassification rate, and requires only $O(\sqrt{T})$ excess tests compared
to the oracle baseline that knows both $\theta^{*}$ and the patient feature
distribution $P$. This establishes the first no-regret guarantees for
error-constrained logistic testing, with direct applications to cost-sensitive
medical screening. Simulations corroborate our theoretical guarantees, showing
that in practice our procedure efficiently estimates $\theta^{*}$ while
retaining safety guarantees, and does not require too many excess tests.

AI.tldr: Introduces a sequential testing framework for binary disease outcomes under an unknown logistic model, trading off costly diagnostic tests against a fixed misclassification tolerance with high-probability guarantees.
AI.motivation: Reduce the number of expensive medical tests required in screening while ensuring misclassification risk stays below a user-specified threshold, despite unknown model and feature distribution.
AI.method: An algorithm that interleaves label collection and distribution estimation to learn both the logistic parameter θ* and the context distribution P. It computes a conservative, data-driven threshold τ_t on the logistic score |x_t^T θ| to decide when testing is necessary, balancing information gain with safety.
AI.result: With probability at least 1−δ, the method keeps the misclassification rate within the tolerance α and incurs only O(√T) excess tests relative to an oracle that knows θ* and P, establishing the first no-regret guarantees for error-constrained logistic testing.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides theoretically grounded guarantees for cost-efficient, safe logistic testing and demonstrates practical effectiveness via simulations in medical screening contexts.

title: Equivariant Geometric Scattering Networks via Vector Diffusion Wavelets
comment:
Accepted for presentation at the NeurIPS workshop on New Perspectives
  in Advancing Graph Machine Learning
summary:
We introduce a novel version of the geometric scattering transform for
geometric graphs containing scalar and vector node features. This new
scattering transform has desirable symmetries with respect to rigid-body
roto-translations (i.e., $SE(3)$-equivariance) and may be incorporated into a
geometric GNN framework. We empirically show that our equivariant
scattering-based GNN achieves comparable performance to other equivariant
message-passing-based GNNs at a fraction of the parameter count.

AI.tldr: A SE(3)-equivariant geometric scattering transform for graphs with scalar/vector features, integrable into geometric GNNs; achieves competitive performance with far fewer parameters.
AI.motivation: To build symmetry-preserving, parameter-efficient models for 3D geometric graphs by exploiting SE(3) (rotations/translations) equivariance in a scattering framework.
AI.method: Proposes a novel SE(3)-equivariant geometric scattering transform for graphs with scalar and vector node features, which can be incorporated into a geometric GNN framework.
AI.result: Empirically, the equivariant scattering-based GNN achieves comparable performance to other equivariant MPNNs while using a fraction of the parameter count.
AI.conclusion: SE(3)-equivariant scattering offers a compact, effective alternative to existing equivariant GNNs for geometric graph learning and can be integrated into broader GNN pipelines.

title: Meaningless Tokens, Meaningful Gains: How Activation Shifts Enhance LLM Reasoning
summary:
Motivated by the puzzling observation that inserting long sequences of
meaningless tokens before the query prompt can consistently enhance LLM
reasoning performance, this work analyzes the underlying mechanism driving this
phenomenon and based on these insights proposes a more principled method that
allows for similar performance gains. First, we find that the improvements
arise from a redistribution of activations in the LLM's MLP layers, where near
zero activations become less frequent while large magnitude activations
increase. This redistribution enhances the model's representational capacity by
suppressing weak signals and promoting stronger, more informative ones.
Building on this insight, we propose the Activation Redistribution Module
(ARM), a lightweight inference-time technique that modifies activations
directly without altering the input sequence. ARM adaptively identifies
near-zero activations after the non-linear function and shifts them outward,
implicitly reproducing the beneficial effects of meaningless tokens in a
controlled manner. Extensive experiments across diverse benchmarks and model
architectures clearly show that ARM consistently improves LLM performance on
reasoning tasks while requiring only a few lines of simple code to implement.
Our findings deliver both a clear mechanistic explanation for the unexpected
benefits of meaningless tokens and a simple yet effective technique that
harnesses activation redistribution to further improve LLM performance.

AI.tldr: Activation Redistribution Module (ARM) explains why inserting meaningless tokens before prompts can boost LLM reasoning: it redistributes activations in MLP layers, reducing near-zero activations and boosting large ones, increasing representational capacity. ARM mimics this effect at inference by adaptively shifting near-zero activations after non-linearities, achieving similar gains with minimal code.
AI.motivation: To understand the puzzling improvement in LLM reasoning when long streams of meaningless tokens precede the query, and to develop a principled, light-weight method to reproduce those benefits without token injection.
AI.method: 1) Analyze activation distributions in MLP layers to observe redistribution effects caused by meaningless tokens. 2) Propose Activation Redistribution Module (ARM) that at inference time identifies near-zero activations after the activation function and redistributes them outward, thereby enhancing informative activations without changing the input sequence. 3) Validate ARM across diverse benchmarks and model architectures with minimal code.
AI.result: ARM consistently improves reasoning performance across tasks, model sizes, and architectures, with only a few lines of code required. The mechanism provides a clear explanation for the benefits of meaningless tokens and demonstrates a simple, effective technique to harness activation redistribution.
AI.conclusion: The work offers both a mechanistic explanation for why meaningless-token prompts help LLMs and a practical, low-overhead method (ARM) to replicate and potentially amplify those gains by rebalancing activations during inference.

title: CurES: From Gradient Analysis to Efficient Curriculum Learning for Reasoning LLMs
summary:
Curriculum learning plays a crucial role in enhancing the training efficiency
of large language models (LLMs) on reasoning tasks. However, existing methods
often fail to adequately account for variations in prompt difficulty or rely on
simplistic filtering mechanisms to select prompt datasets within a narrow
criterion range, resulting in significant computational waste. In this work, we
approach the problem from the perspective of reinforcement learning gradient
optimization, offering a systematic and theoretical investigation into how to
improve the training efficiency of LLMs. We identify two key factors
influencing training efficiency: the selection of training prompts and the
allocation of rollout quantities across different prompts. Our theoretical
analysis reveals that the sampling distribution of prompts dictates the
convergence rate of gradient descent, while the allocation of the rollout
quantity influences the consistency and stability of overall gradient updates.
Based on these insights, we propose CurES, an efficient training method that
accelerates convergence and employs Bayesian posterior estimation to minimize
computational overhead. Experiments demonstrate that our CurES outperforms
Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) by \textbf{+3.30} points and
\textbf{+4.82} points with 1.5B and 7B models, respectively. Additionally,
CurES exhibits faster convergence compared to baselines, including GRPO.

AI.tldr: Proposes CurES, a curriculum-learning method for training large language models that optimizes prompt sampling and rollout allocation via reinforcement-learning gradient optimization, using Bayesian posterior estimation to reduce overhead. Demonstrates faster convergence and higher performance than GRPO on 1.5B and 7B models.
AI.motivation: Address inefficiencies in prompt dataset selection and rollout allocation in curriculum learning for LLMs. The paper posits that the prompt sampling distribution governs gradient descent convergence while rollout allocation affects gradient update stability, and seeks to develop a principled solution.
AI.method: Introduce CurES, a framework that jointly optimizes the distribution over prompts and the allocation of rollout quantities; employs Bayesian posterior estimation to minimize computational overhead; provides theoretical analysis of convergence and stability; compares against GRPO on 1.5B and 7B LLMs.
AI.result: CurES outperforms Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) by +3.30 points and +4.82 points on 1.5B and 7B models, respectively; shows faster convergence than baselines including GRPO.
AI.conclusion: CurES offers a principled, efficient training scheme for LLMs under curriculum learning by optimizing prompt selection and rollout allocation with Bayesian estimation, delivering faster convergence and improved performance over GRPO.

title: Gated X-TFC: Soft Domain Decomposition for Forward and Inverse Problems in Sharp-Gradient PDEs
summary:
Physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) and related methods struggle to
resolve sharp gradients in singularly perturbed boundary value problems without
resorting to some form of domain decomposition, which often introduce complex
interface penalties. While the Extreme Theory of Functional Connections (X-TFC)
avoids multi-objective optimization by employing exact boundary condition
enforcement, it remains computationally inefficient for boundary layers and
incompatible with decomposition. We propose Gated X-TFC, a novel framework for
both forward and inverse problems, that overcomes these limitations through a
soft, learned domain decomposition. Our method replaces hard interfaces with a
differentiable logistic gate that dynamically adapts radial basis function
(RBF) kernel widths across the domain, eliminating the need for interface
penalties. This approach yields not only superior accuracy but also dramatic
improvements in computational efficiency: on a benchmark one dimensional (1D)
convection-diffusion, Gated X-TFC achieves an order-of-magnitude lower error
than standard X-TFC while using 80 percent fewer collocation points and
reducing training time by 66 percent. In addition, we introduce an
operator-conditioned meta-learning layer that learns a probabilistic mapping
from PDE parameters to optimal gate configurations, enabling fast,
uncertainty-aware warm-starting for new problem instances. We further
demonstrate scalability to multiple subdomains and higher dimensions by solving
a twin boundary-layer equation and a 2D Poisson problem with a sharp Gaussian
source. Overall, Gated X-TFC delivers a simple alternative alternative to PINNs
that is both accurate and computationally efficient for challenging
boundar-layer regimes. Future work will focus on nonlinear problems.

AI.tldr: Gated X-TFC introduces a differentiable logistic gate to enable soft, learned domain decomposition in X-TFC, achieving high accuracy and efficiency for boundary-layer problems; includes operator-conditioned meta-learning for fast warm-start and scales to multi-subdomain and higher dimensions.
AI.motivation: PINNs struggle with sharp gradients in singularly perturbed boundary value problems and require domain decomposition with interface penalties; while X-TFC enforces exact boundary conditions without multi-objective optimization, it is computationally inefficient for boundary layers and not compatible with decomposition. A soft, learnable domain decomposition aims to combine accuracy, efficiency, and decomposability.
AI.method: Replace hard interfaces with a differentiable logistic gate that adaptively tunes radial basis function widths across the domain, removing interface penalties. Introduce an operator-conditioned meta-learning layer that maps PDE parameters to optimal gate configurations for fast, uncertainty-aware warm-starts. Apply to forward and inverse problems, demonstrating on a 1D convection-diffusion benchmark and extending to a twin boundary-layer equation and a 2D Poisson problem with a sharp Gaussian source.
AI.result: On a 1D convection-diffusion benchmark, Gated X-TFC achieves an order-of-magnitude lower error than standard X-TFC, uses 80 percent fewer collocation points, and reduces training time by 66 percent. The approach scales to multiple subdomains and higher dimensions, demonstrated with a twin boundary-layer equation and a 2D Poisson problem with a sharp Gaussian source.
AI.conclusion: Gated X-TFC provides a simple, accurate, and computationally efficient alternative to PINNs for challenging boundary-layer regimes. The method is scalable to multiple subdomains and higher dimensions, with future work focusing on nonlinear problems.

title: GEM: A Gym for Agentic LLMs
summary:
The training paradigm for large language models (LLMs) is moving from static
datasets to experience-based learning, where agents acquire skills via
interacting with complex environments. To facilitate this transition we
introduce GEM (General Experience Maker), an open-source environment simulator
designed for the age of LLMs. Analogous to OpenAI-Gym for traditional
reinforcement learning (RL), GEM provides a standardized framework for the
environment-agent interface, including asynchronous vectorized execution for
high throughput, and flexible wrappers for easy extensibility. GEM also
features a diverse suite of environments, robust integrated tools, and
single-file example scripts demonstrating using GEM with five popular RL
training frameworks. Along with this, we also provide a set of baselines across
24 environments using REINFORCE with Return Batch Normalization (ReBN), which
-- unlike GRPO -- is compatible with the full RL setting of dense per-turn
rewards and offers better credit assignment. We further conduct apple-to-apple
benchmarking of PPO, GRPO and REINFORCE in both single- and multi-turn settings
using GEM to shed light on the algorithmic designs. Lastly, GEM also functions
as a convenient evaluation toolkit besides a training environment. We hope this
framework can help accelerate future agentic LLM research.

AI.tldr: GEM is an open-source, OpenAI-Gym-like environment simulator for LLMs that enables experience-based learning via RL-style interactions, offering async vectorized execution, extensible wrappers, a diverse environment suite, and baselines across 24 tasks; it benchmarks PPO, GRPO, and REINFORCE with Return Batch Normalization to guide algorithm design and provides an evaluation toolkit.
AI.motivation: To transition LLM training from static datasets to interactive, environment-based learning. There is a need for a standardized, scalable, and extensible environment-agent interface (like Gym for traditional RL) to accelerate agentic LLM development and enable fair comparisons across methods.
AI.method: Introduce GEM with asynchronous vectorized execution, a flexible environment-agent interface, and wrappers for five RL frameworks. Provide a diverse set of environments, integrated tools, and one-file scripts. Establish baselines on 24 environments using REINFORCE with Return Batch Normalization (ReBN) and perform apple-to-apple benchmarking of PPO, GRPO, and REINFORCE in both single- and multi-turn settings using GEM.
AI.result: GEM provides a unified training and evaluation platform for agentic LLM research. Baselines using ReBN are compatible with dense per-turn rewards and show improved credit assignment over some competitors. Benchmarking across PPO, GRPO, and REINFORCE clarifies how algorithmic choices interact with multi-turn, dense-reward settings. The framework also functions as an evaluation toolkit in addition to training environments.
AI.conclusion: GEM is a scalable, extensible, open-source ecosystem designed to accelerate agentic LLM research by standardizing environment-agent interactions, enabling high-throughput experiments, and offering ready-to-use baselines and evaluation tools across a broad suite of tasks.

title: Eliciting Secret Knowledge from Language Models
summary:
We study secret elicitation: discovering knowledge that an AI possesses but
does not explicitly verbalize. As a testbed, we train three families of large
language models (LLMs) to possess specific knowledge that they apply downstream
but deny knowing when asked directly. For example, in one setting, we train an
LLM to generate replies that are consistent with knowing the user is female,
while denying this knowledge when asked directly. We then design various
black-box and white-box secret elicitation techniques and evaluate them based
on whether they can help an LLM auditor successfully guess the secret
knowledge. Many of our techniques improve on simple baselines. Our most
effective techniques (performing best in 2/3 settings) are based on prefill
attacks, a black-box technique where the LLM reveals secret knowledge when
generating a completion from a predefined prefix. In our remaining setting,
white-box techniques based on logit lens and sparse autoencoders (SAEs) are
most effective. We release our models and code, establishing a public benchmark
for evaluating secret elicitation methods.

AI.tldr: This work studies secret elicitation in large language models (LLMs), showing black-box prefill attacks can reveal hidden knowledge in many settings while white-box methods (logit lens, sparse autoencoders) excel in others; they release models/code and establish a public benchmark for evaluation.
AI.motivation: To understand and quantify vulnerabilities where an AI may possess secret knowledge and apply it without verbalizing it, enabling systematic auditing and assessment of LLM safety and transparency.
AI.method: Train three families of LLMs to encode and apply a secret (e.g., user attributes) while denying knowledge when probed; design and compare black-box (prefill attacks) and white-box (logit lens, sparse autoencoders) secret elicitation techniques; evaluate whether an LLM auditor can infer the secret across settings, against baselines.
AI.result: Prefill attacks outperform baselines in two of three settings; white-box methods (logit lens and SAEs) are most effective in the remaining setting; overall improvements over simple baselines; authors release models and code to establish a public secret-elicitation benchmark.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates vulnerabilities in LLMs to secret elicitation and provides a public benchmark for evaluating such methods, highlighting when black-box versus white-box approaches are most effective and informing auditing and safety practices.

title: Predicting Diabetic Retinopathy Using a Two-Level Ensemble Model
comment:
Accepted for presentation at the IISE Annual Conference & Expo 2025,
  6 pages, 2 tables, 1 figure
summary:
Preprint Note: This is the author preprint version of a paper accepted for
presentation at the IISE Annual Conference & Expo 2025. The final version will
appear in the official proceedings.
  Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a leading cause of blindness in working-age
adults, and current diagnostic methods rely on resource-intensive eye exams and
specialized equipment. Image-based AI tools have shown limitations in
early-stage detection, motivating the need for alternative approaches. We
propose a non-image-based, two-level ensemble model for DR prediction using
routine laboratory test results. In the first stage, base models (Linear SVC,
Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and XGBoost) are hyperparameter tuned and
internally stacked across different configurations to optimize metrics such as
accuracy, recall, and precision. In the second stage, predictions are
aggregated using Random Forest as a meta-learner. This hierarchical stacking
strategy improves generalization, balances performance across multiple metrics,
and remains computationally efficient compared to deep learning approaches. The
model achieved Accuracy 0.9433, F1 Score 0.9425, Recall 0.9207, Precision
