0.9653, ROC-AUC 0.9844, and AUPRC 0.9875, surpassing one-level stacking and FCN
baselines. These results highlight the model potential for accurate and
interpretable DR risk prediction in clinical settings.

AI.tldr: Two-level ensemble model using routine laboratory tests achieves strong diabetic retinopathy risk prediction without imaging, via hierarchical stacking of Linear SVC, RF, Gradient Boosting, and XGBoost (stage-1) with a Random Forest meta-learner (stage-2).
AI.motivation: Address limitations of image-based DR screening by leveraging readily available lab data, enabling accessible, cost-effective, early detection while maintaining high predictive performance.
AI.method: Stage 1: tune and internally stack base models (Linear SVC, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost) across configurations. Stage 2: aggregate predictions with a Random Forest meta-learner in a hierarchical stacking framework.
AI.result: Accuracy 0.9433; F1 0.9425; Recall 0.9207; Precision 0.9653; ROC-AUC 0.9844; AUPRC 0.9875, outperforming one-level stacking and FCN baselines.
AI.conclusion: Hierarchical stacking enhances generalization and balances multiple performance metrics while remaining computationally efficient compared to deep learning, supporting accurate and interpretable DR risk prediction in clinical settings.

title: Multi-Actor Multi-Critic Deep Deterministic Reinforcement Learning with a Novel Q-Ensemble Method
summary:
Reinforcement learning has gathered much attention in recent years due to its
rapid development and rich applications, especially on control systems and
robotics. When tackling real-world applications with reinforcement learning
method, the corresponded Markov decision process may have huge discrete or even
continuous state/action space. Deep reinforcement learning has been studied for
handling these issues through deep learning for years, and one promising branch
is the actor-critic architecture. Many past studies leveraged multiple critics
to enhance the accuracy of evaluation of a policy for addressing the
overestimation and underestimation issues. However, few studies have considered
the architecture with multiple actors together with multiple critics. This
study proposes a novel multi-actor multi-critic (MAMC) deep deterministic
reinforcement learning method. The proposed method has three main features,
including selection of actors based on non-dominated sorting for exploration
with respect to skill and creativity factors, evaluation for actors and critics
using a quantile-based ensemble strategy, and exploiting actors with best skill
factor. Theoretical analysis proves the learning stability and bounded
estimation bias for the MAMC. The present study examines the performance on a
well-known reinforcement learning benchmark MuJoCo. Experimental results show
that the proposed framework outperforms state-of-the-art deep deterministic
based reinforcement learning methods. Experimental analysis also indicates the
proposed components are effective. Empirical analysis further investigates the
validity of the proposed method, and shows its benefit on complicated problems.
The source code can be found at https://github.com/AndyWu101/MAMC.

AI.tldr: Introduces Multi-Actor Multi-Critic (MAMC) deep deterministic policy learning that uses multiple actors and critics with non-dominated sorting for exploration and a quantile-based ensemble for evaluation, achieving stable learning and improved performance on continuous control benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To handle large (discrete or continuous) state/action spaces and address value-estimation biases in reinforcement learning by leveraging multiple actors and critics, extending beyond traditional single-actor or single-critic architectures.
AI.method: Proposes MAMC with three key features: (1) actor selection via non-dominated sorting to balance skill and creativity for exploration, (2) a quantile-based ensemble strategy to evaluate both actors and critics, and (3) exploitation of actors with the best skill factor. The approach includes theoretical analysis showing learning stability and bounded estimation bias.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on MuJoCo benchmarks shows MAMC outperforms state-of-the-art deep deterministic RL methods. Component analyses confirm effectiveness of the proposed features and empirical results demonstrate benefits on complex problems. Source code is available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: MAMC provides stable, high-performance deep deterministic RL by combining diverse actors with ensemble critics, effectively addressing exploration and value-estimation challenges in continuous control tasks and enabling better performance on challenging problems.

title: Dynamical system reconstruction from partial observations using stochastic dynamics
summary:
Learning stochastic models of dynamical systems underlying observed data is
of interest in many scientific fields. Here we propose a novel method for this
task, based on the framework of variational autoencoders for dynamical systems.
The method estimates from the data both the system state trajectories and noise
time series. This approach allows to perform multi-step system evolution and
supports a teacher forcing strategy, alleviating limitations of
autoencoder-based approaches for stochastic systems. We demonstrate the
performance of the proposed approach on six test problems, covering simulated
and experimental data. We further show the effects of the teacher forcing
interval on the nature of the internal dynamics, and compare it to the
deterministic models with equivalent architecture.

AI.tldr: Introduces a variational autoencoder framework to learn stochastic dynamical systems from data by simultaneously inferring latent state trajectories and noise time series, enabling multi-step predictions with teacher forcing; validated on six problems including simulated and real data.
AI.motivation: To model dynamical systems with intrinsic noise and stochasticity, existing autoencoder-based approaches struggle to recover latent trajectories and noise; a method that learns both state paths and noise processes is needed for reliable long-horizon predictions.
AI.method: Proposes a VAE-based approach for dynamical systems that estimates both latent state trajectories and noise time series from observations; supports multi-step evolution; integrates teacher forcing to steer training; compares architecture to deterministic analogs.
AI.result: Demonstrated performance across six test problems (simulated and experimental data); shows effects of the teacher-forcing interval on internal dynamics; compares favorably to deterministic models with the same architecture.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a viable route to learning stochastic dynamics from data, with teacher forcing offering control over the learned internal dynamics and broad applicability demonstrated across diverse datasets.

title: Geometric Properties of Neural Multivariate Regression
summary:
Neural multivariate regression underpins a wide range of domains such as
control, robotics, and finance, yet the geometry of its learned representations
remains poorly characterized. While neural collapse has been shown to benefit
generalization in classification, we find that analogous collapse in regression
consistently degrades performance. To explain this contrast, we analyze models
through the lens of intrinsic dimension. Across control tasks and synthetic
datasets, we estimate the intrinsic dimension of last-layer features (ID_H) and
compare it with that of the regression targets (ID_Y). Collapsed models exhibit
ID_H < ID_Y, leading to over-compression and poor generalization, whereas
non-collapsed models typically maintain ID_H > ID_Y. For the non-collapsed
models, performance with respect to ID_H depends on the data quantity and noise
levels. From these observations, we identify two regimes (over-compressed and
under-compressed) that determine when expanding or reducing feature
dimensionality improves performance. Our results provide new geometric insights
into neural regression and suggest practical strategies for enhancing
generalization.

AI.tldr: Intrinsic-dimension perspective explains when neural regression models collapse or not, linking last-layer feature dimension to target dimension to predict generalization; two regimes (over- and under-compressed) determine whether expanding or reducing feature dimensionality helps; offers practical strategies to improve regression generalization.
AI.motivation: Understand the geometry of learned representations in neural regression and why neural collapse harms regression while aiding classification; leverage intrinsic dimension to guide model design and training.
AI.method: Empirically estimate the intrinsic dimension of last-layer features (ID_H) and the intrinsic dimension of targets (ID_Y) across control tasks and synthetic datasets; classify models as collapsed (ID_H < ID_Y) or non-collapsed (ID_H > ID_Y); analyze how performance relates to ID_H, ID_Y, data quantity, noise, and the regimes; identify practical guidelines.
AI.result: Collapsed models exhibit ID_H < ID_Y, causing over-compression and poor generalization; non-collapsed models have ID_H > ID_Y, with performance depending on data and noise; two regimes—over-compressed and under-compressed—determine when changing feature dimensionality helps; provides geometric insights and actionable strategies for better generalization in neural regression.
AI.conclusion: Offers a geometric lens to neural regression via intrinsic dimension, explaining when feature expansion or compression benefits generalization and proposing practical guidelines for model design and training to improve regression performance.

title: Augmenting LLMs for General Time Series Understanding and Prediction
summary:
Time series data is fundamental to decision-making in many crucial domains
including healthcare, finance, and environmental science. However, analyzing
this data often requires incorporating unstructured contextual information,
answering domain-specific questions, and generating natural language
explanations -- capabilities that traditional time series models lack due to
their inability to process text. While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at
contextual reasoning and knowledge integration, they struggle with numerical
time series due to inefficient text-based representations and limited exposure
to temporal data during pretraining. We address this gap by augmenting an LLM
with specialized time series perception through a patch-based encoder-decoder
architecture. We train this Time Series-augmented LLM (TsLLM) on a large corpus
of over 2 million interleaved time series and text examples spanning diverse
analysis tasks: forecasting with contextual information, time series
question-answering, pattern explanation, classification with natural language
outputs, and report generation. This training enables TsLLM to leverage both
its language understanding and newly acquired temporal reasoning capabilities.
While not designed to surpass specialized models on traditional benchmarks,
TsLLM demonstrates strong performance on tasks requiring the integration of
time series analysis with natural language -- capabilities that existing
approaches cannot provide. Our work establishes a new paradigm for time series
analysis that bridges numerical computation and natural language understanding,
democratizing access to sophisticated temporal reasoning through natural
language interaction.

AI.tldr: TsLLM augments an LLM with a patch-based time-series perception module to jointly handle numerical temporal data and natural language, trained on 2M interleaved time series/text examples; achieves integration-enabled NL tasks without aiming to beat traditional time-series models on standard benchmarks.
AI.motivation: LLMs excel at language but struggle with time-series / numerical data; traditional TS models lack NL reasoning and contextual text integration; need a unified framework enabling natural language interaction with temporal data.
AI.method: A patch-based encoder-decoder adds time-series perception to an LLM, trained on a large corpus of interleaved time-series and text; diverse tasks include forecasting with context, time-series QA, explanations, NL outputs, and report generation.
AI.result: TsLLM shows strong performance on tasks requiring integration of TS analysis with NL while not being designed to outperform specialized TS models on standard benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Introduces a new paradigm bridging numerical computation and NL understanding for time-series analysis, enabling accessible temporal reasoning through natural language.

title: Privacy Preserved Federated Learning with Attention-Based Aggregation for Biometric Recognition
summary:
Because biometric data is sensitive, centralized training poses a privacy
risk, even though biometric recognition is essential for contemporary
applications. Federated learning (FL), which permits decentralized training,
provides a privacy-preserving substitute. Conventional FL, however, has trouble
with interpretability and heterogeneous data (non-IID). In order to handle
non-IID biometric data, this framework adds an attention mechanism at the
central server that weights local model updates according to their
significance. Differential privacy and secure update protocols safeguard data
while preserving accuracy. The A3-FL framework is evaluated in this study using
FVC2004 fingerprint data, with each client's features extracted using a Siamese
Convolutional Neural Network (Siamese-CNN). By dynamically modifying client
contributions, the attention mechanism increases the accuracy of the global
model.The accuracy, convergence speed, and robustness of the A3-FL framework
are superior to those of standard FL (FedAvg) and static baselines, according
to experimental evaluations using fingerprint data (FVC2004). The accuracy of
the attention-based approach was 0.8413, while FedAvg, Local-only, and
Centralized approaches were 0.8164, 0.7664, and 0.7997, respectively. Accuracy
stayed high at 0.8330 even with differential privacy. A scalable and
privacy-sensitive biometric system for secure and effective recognition in
dispersed environments is presented in this work.

AI.tldr: An attention-based federated learning framework (A3-FL) for biometric recognition that handles non-IID data and privacy by weighting client updates, using Siamese-CNN features on fingerprint data, and achieving higher accuracy than standard FL and baselines, even under differential privacy.
AI.motivation: Biometric data are highly sensitive; centralized training risks privacy leakage. Federated learning offers privacy-preserving decentralized training, but challenges remain in interpretability and handling non-IID data typical in biometrics.
AI.method: Introduce a server-side attention mechanism to weight local model updates by estimated significance, combined with differential privacy and secure update protocols. Features are extracted via Siamese-CNN from fingerprint data (FVC2004). Evaluate against FedAvg, Local-only, and Centralized baselines; assess accuracy, convergence speed, and robustness.
AI.result: Attention-based A3-FL achieves 0.8413 accuracy, outperforming FedAvg (0.8164), Local-only (0.7664), and Centralized (0.7997); maintains ~0.8330 accuracy under differential privacy, indicating robustness to privacy constraints.
AI.conclusion: A scalable, privacy-conscious biometric recognition system for distributed environments; dynamic attention improves accuracy and resilience to non-IID data and privacy protections; demonstrated effectively on fingerprint recognition with Siamese-CNN features.

title: Eliciting Chain-of-Thought Reasoning for Time Series Analysis using Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Complex numerical time series analysis often demands multi-step reasoning
capabilities beyond current models' reach. Tasks like medical diagnosis and
weather forecasting require sequential reasoning processes -- including
counterfactual analysis, logical deduction, knowledge application, and
multi-modal contextual integration -- that existing time series models cannot
explicitly perform. While recent research has shown large language models
(LLMs) can achieve sophisticated Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning through
reinforcement learning (RL), these advances have primarily focused on
mathematical and coding domains, with LLMs still demonstrating poor performance
on time series tasks. We introduce Chain Of thought for Understanding Numerical
Time Series (COUNTS), the first framework that trains LLMs to perform CoT
reasoning across diverse time series tasks using RL with verifiable rewards.
Our approach employs a Residual Vector-Quantized VAE to create high-fidelity
discrete tokens that seamlessly integrate into a pre-trained LLM's vocabulary.
COUNTS undergoes a two-stage training process: first, supervised fine-tuning on
time series analysis tasks to master our novel representations, followed by
Group Relative Policy Optimization training on verifiable problems using
prompting strategies that encourage explicit reasoning steps before producing
final answers. Our experiments demonstrate that this RL-driven approach with
intermediate CoT reasoning significantly enhances LLM performance across
various time series analysis tasks, opening new possibilities for complex
temporal data reasoning.

AI.tldr: COUNTS trains LLMs to perform chain-of-thought reasoning on time-series tasks using reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards, leveraging a residual vector-quantized VAE to create discrete tokens integrated into the LLM vocabulary; a two-stage training process (supervised fine-tuning on time-series tasks followed by Group Relative Policy Optimization) yields improved performance across diverse time-series analyses.
AI.motivation: To enable explicit, multi-step reasoning for time-series tasks (e.g., medical diagnosis, weather forecasting), addressing the current gap where LLMs excel at CoT in math/coding but struggle with time-series data and explicit reasoning, by combining CoT with verifiable RL-based training.
AI.method: Use a Residual Vector-Quantized VAE to generate high-fidelity discrete tokens compatible with an LLM; train in two stages: (1) supervised fine-tuning on time-series analysis tasks to learn representations; (2) Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) with prompts that elicit explicit reasoning steps before final answers, using verifiable rewards as feedback.
AI.result: The RL-driven approach with intermediate chain-of-thought reasoning significantly improves LLM performance across multiple time-series analysis tasks compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: COUNTS demonstrates that enabling explicit CoT reasoning for time-series tasks via a structured RL framework and discrete token representations can substantially enhance temporal data reasoning and broaden the applicability of LLMs in complex sequential domains.

title: Breaking the Euclidean Barrier: Hyperboloid-Based Biological Sequence Analysis
summary:
Genomic sequence analysis plays a crucial role in various scientific and
medical domains. Traditional machine-learning approaches often struggle to
capture the complex relationships and hierarchical structures of sequence data
when working in high-dimensional Euclidean spaces. This limitation hinders
accurate sequence classification and similarity measurement. To address these
challenges, this research proposes a method to transform the feature
representation of biological sequences into the hyperboloid space. By applying
a transformation, the sequences are mapped onto the hyperboloid, preserving
their inherent structural information. Once the sequences are represented in
the hyperboloid space, a kernel matrix is computed based on the hyperboloid
features. The kernel matrix captures the pairwise similarities between
sequences, enabling more effective analysis of biological sequence
relationships. This approach leverages the inner product of the hyperboloid
feature vectors to measure the similarity between pairs of sequences. The
experimental evaluation of the proposed approach demonstrates its efficacy in
capturing important sequence correlations and improving classification
accuracy.

AI.tldr: Maps genomic sequences to hyperboloid space; builds a kernel matrix via hyperboloid inner products to improve classification.
AI.motivation: Euclidean representations struggle to capture hierarchical and non-Euclidean relationships inherent in genomic sequences. Hyperboloid geometry can preserve such structural information, enabling more meaningful similarity measures.
AI.method: Transform biological sequences into hyperboloid feature representations; compute a kernel matrix using inner products in hyperboloid space; use kernel-based analysis (e.g., SVM) for classification.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation shows that hyperboloid-based features capture important sequence correlations and improve classification accuracy compared to baseline methods.
AI.conclusion: Hyperboloid-based sequence representation with a kernel framework is effective for genomic sequence analysis and classification.

title: Rethinking Thinking Tokens: LLMs as Improvement Operators
summary:
Reasoning training incentivizes LLMs to produce long chains of thought (long
CoT), which among other things, allows them to explore solution strategies with
self-checking. This results in higher accuracy, but inflates context length,
token/compute cost, and answer latency. We ask: Can current models leverage
their metacognition to provide other combinations on this Pareto frontier,
e.g., better accuracy with lower context length and/or latency? Abstractly, we
view the model as an improvement operator on its own "thoughts" with a
continuum of possible strategies. We identify an interesting inference family
Parallel-Distill-Refine (PDR), which performs the following: (i) generate
diverse drafts in parallel; (ii) distill them into a bounded, textual
workspace; and (iii) refine conditioned on this workspace, producing an output
that seeds the next round. Importantly, context length (hence compute cost) is
controllable via degree of parallelism, and is no longer conflated with the
total number of generated tokens. We report PDR instantiations of current
models that give better accuracy than long CoT while incurring lower latency.
Setting degree of parallelism to 1 yields an interesting subcase, Sequential
Refinement (SR) (iteratively improve a single candidate answer) which provides
performance superior to long CoT. Success of such model orchestrations raises
the question whether further training could shift the Pareto frontier. To this
end, we train an 8B thinking model with Reinforcement Learning (RL) to make it
consistent with PDR as the inference method. On math tasks with verifiable
answers, iterative pipelines surpass single-pass baselines at matched
sequential budgets, with PDR delivering the largest gains (e.g., +11% on AIME
2024 and +9% on AIME 2025).

AI.tldr: PDR (Parallel-Distill-Refine) improves accuracy with lower latency by decoupling context length from total tokens: generate diverse drafts in parallel, distill to a bounded workspace, then refine conditioned on that workspace. Includes Sequential Refinement (SR) as a 1-d parallelism case; an 8B model trained with RL aligns with PDR. On math tasks (AIME 2024/2025), PDR yields the largest gains (+11%, +9%), surpassing long CoT.
AI.motivation: To overcome the accuracy-cost Pareto trade-off of long chain-of-thought reasoning. While long CoT boosts accuracy, it inflates context length, compute, and latency. The work investigates whether metacognitive strategies can yield better accuracy with lower context/latency.
AI.method: Propose Parallel-Distill-Refine (PDR): (i) generate diverse reasoning drafts in parallel; (ii) distill them into a bounded textual workspace; (iii) refine conditioned on this workspace to produce the final answer, seeding the next round. Control context length via parallelism degree, decoupling it from total tokens. Evaluate a 1-parallelism case (Sequential Refinement, SR) and train an 8B model with RL to align with PDR. Assess on math tasks with verifiable answers, comparing against single-pass and long-CoT baselines.
AI.result: PDR-based instantiations achieve better accuracy than long-CoT baselines while incurring lower latency. SR, as a special case, outperforms long CoT. On verifiable math benchmarks (AIME 2024/2025), iterative pipelines outperform single-pass baselines at matched budgets, with PDR delivering the largest gains (e.g., +11% on AIME 2024, +9% on AIME 2025).
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates a viable path to shifting the accuracy-cost Pareto frontier for LLM reasoning by decoupling context from computation via parallel reasoning and workspace distillation. Further training could push the frontier further; PDR invites exploration of other inference stratagems and their optimization.

title: A Practitioner's Guide to Multi-turn Agentic Reinforcement Learning
summary:
We study what actually works and what doesn't for training large language
models as agents via multi-turn reinforcement learning. Despite rapid progress,
existing frameworks and definitions are fragmented, and there is no systematic
formulation or analysis of which design choices matter across tasks. We address
this gap by first breaking down the design space into three inter-related
pillars -- environment, reward, and policy -- and empirically derive a recipe
for training LLM agents in situated textual domains. In particular, we test
TextWorld and ALFWorld, popular domains for testing situated embodied
reasoning, as well as SWE-Gym for more software engineering style tasks. (i)
For the environment, we analyze the impacts of task complexity in terms of
sizes of the state and action spaces as well as optimal solution length,
finding that even simple environments within a domain can provide signal on how
well an agent can generalize to more complex tasks. (ii) For the reward, we
ablate relative reward sparsity, observing that while dense turn-level rewards
accelerate training, performance and stability is highly dependent on the
choice of RL algorithm. (iii) And for the agent's policy, we explore the
interplay between reward sparsity and biased (PPO, GRPO) and unbiased (RLOO)
policy gradient methods in addition to showing how to find the optimal
Supervised Fine-tuning (SFT) to RL training ratio given a fixed budget. We
distill these findings into a training recipe that guides co-design across the
three pillars, facilitating research and practical efforts in multi-turn
agentic RL. Code: https://github.com/pearls-lab/meow-tea-taro

AI.tldr: Empirical study of training LLM agents with multi-turn RL, breaking design into three pillars—environment, reward, and policy—and giving a practical co-design recipe tested on TextWorld, ALFWorld, and SWE-Gym.
AI.motivation: There is no systematic formulation of which design choices matter across tasks in multi-turn agent RL with LLMs; existing frameworks are fragmented. The work aims to identify robust signals across environments and rewards and to guide practical design decisions.
AI.method: Three-pillar empirical study across domains TextWorld, ALFWorld, and SWE-Gym. Vary environment complexity (state/action space sizes, optimal task length); ablate reward sparsity (dense vs sparse); compare biased (PPO, GRPO) vs unbiased (RLOO) policy gradients; determine an optimal SFT-to-RL training ratio under budget constraints; distill findings into a training recipe.
AI.result: Findings include: simple environments still provide signals on generalization; dense rewards speed training but stability and performance depend on the RL algorithm; policy choice interacts with reward sparsity; a co-design recipe is distilled for environment, reward, and policy; code availability provided for replication.
AI.conclusion: Provides a practical, co-designed training recipe for multi-turn agentic RL, guiding researchers and practitioners in balancing environment design, reward shaping, and policy optimization across tasks; code available at the cited repository.

title: Prompt Curriculum Learning for Efficient LLM Post-Training
summary:
We introduce Prompt Curriculum Learning (PCL), a lightweight reinforcement
learning (RL) algorithm that selects intermediate-difficulty prompts using a
learned value model to post-train language models. Since post-training LLMs via
RL remains sensitive to batching and prompt selection strategies, we first
conduct a series of systematic experiments where we (1) determine the optimal
training batch size that balances generation efficiency and gradient quality
and (2) establish the importance of focusing on prompts of intermediate
difficulty for the policy. We build upon these results to design PCL, which
identifies prompts of intermediate difficulty for the current policy in an
on-policy manner by using a value model that is concurrently updated based on
the current policy. By focusing on informative prompts that yield high
effective ratios, PCL achieves either the highest performance or requires
significantly less time to reach comparable performance to its counterparts.
Compared to rollout-based filtering methods, PCL avoids costly rollouts and
achieves $12.1\times$ and $16.9\times$ faster speed on identifying
intermediate-difficulty prompts when training on MATH and DeepScaleR,
respectively. We further demonstrate that our value model accurately predicts
prompt difficulty and allows PCL to focus on progressively more challenging
prompts during RL. Our results present a new methodology that delivers improved
tradeoff between upper-bound performance and efficiency for reasoning-focused
RL.

AI.tldr: Prompt Curriculum Learning (PCL) is a lightweight RL method that selects intermediate-difficulty prompts via a concurrently updated value model to post-train LLMs, improving efficiency by avoiding costly rollouts while maintaining or enhancing performance on reasoning tasks.
AI.motivation: Post-training LLMs with RL are sensitive to batching and prompt choice; there is a need for efficient, effective prompt selection to steer RL toward informative, difficulty-appropriate prompts that yield better reasoning performance.
AI.method: An on-policy RL framework where a value model scores prompts (prompt difficulty) and is updated in tandem with the policy. The method identifies intermediate-difficulty prompts for the current policy, balances batch size for generation efficiency and gradient quality, and compares PCL to rollout-based filtering, achieving significant speedups on MATH and DeepScaleR.
AI.result: PCL achieves higher performance or faster convergence to comparable performance than baselines, and is 12.1x and 16.9x faster at identifying intermediate-difficulty prompts on MATH and DeepScaleR, respectively. The value model accurately predicts prompt difficulty and enables progressively harder prompts during training.
AI.conclusion: PCL offers a new, efficient methodology for reasoning-focused RL that improves the tradeoff between upper-bound performance and training efficiency by focusing on informative, intermediate-difficulty prompts without costly rollouts.

title: TabINR: An Implicit Neural Representation Framework for Tabular Data Imputation
summary:
Tabular data builds the basis for a wide range of applications, yet
real-world datasets are frequently incomplete due to collection errors, privacy
restrictions, or sensor failures. As missing values degrade the performance or
hinder the applicability of downstream models, and while simple imputing
strategies tend to introduce bias or distort the underlying data distribution,
we require imputers that provide high-quality imputations, are robust across
dataset sizes and yield fast inference. We therefore introduce TabINR, an
auto-decoder based Implicit Neural Representation (INR) framework that models
tables as neural functions. Building on recent advances in generalizable INRs,
we introduce learnable row and feature embeddings that effectively deal with
the discrete structure of tabular data and can be inferred from partial
observations, enabling instance adaptive imputations without modifying the
trained model. We evaluate our framework across a diverse range of twelve
real-world datasets and multiple missingness mechanisms, demonstrating
consistently strong imputation accuracy, mostly matching or outperforming
classical (KNN, MICE, MissForest) and deep learning based models (GAIN,
ReMasker), with the clearest gains on high-dimensional datasets.

AI.tldr: TabINR introduces an auto-decoder INR framework for tabular data imputation using learnable row and feature embeddings, enabling instance-adaptive imputations without retraining and achieving competitive accuracy.
AI.motivation: Missing values are pervasive in real-world tabular data and imputation quality directly impacts downstream models. Simple imputation methods can bias distributions; there is a need for high-quality, fast, robust imputers that work across dataset sizes and support instance-adaptive imputations.
AI.method: The approach models tables as neural functions using anImplicit Neural Representation (INR) with trainable row and feature embeddings. It is an auto-decoder setup that infers embeddings from partial observations, enabling imputations that adapt to each instance without modifying the trained model.
AI.result: Evaluation on twelve real-world datasets with various missingness mechanisms shows strong imputation accuracy, typically matching or surpassing classical methods (KNN, MICE, MissForest) and deep models (GAIN, ReMasker), with the clearest gains on high-dimensional datasets.
AI.conclusion: TabINR provides robust, scalable, and instance-adaptive imputations for tabular data by leveraging INRs and learnable embeddings, offering competitive performance across a range of datasets and missingness patterns.

title: Sample-Efficient Differentially Private Fine-Tuning via Gradient Matrix Denoising
summary:
We address the challenge of sample efficiency in differentially private
fine-tuning of large language models (LLMs) using DP-SGD. While DP-SGD provides
strong privacy guarantees, the added noise significantly increases the entropy
of gradient matrices, disrupting their low-rank structure and slowing
optimization. We propose a post-processing algorithm that leverages random
matrix theory to denoise gradients, restore low-rank structure, and improve
alignment with the original signal. Applied to DP-SGD fine-tuning of RoBERTa on
GLUE tasks, our method improves sample efficiency compared to state-of-the-art
approaches, substantially reducing training time when optimal performance is
not required. This work demonstrates that matrix recovery techniques can
enhance the utility of private language model training without compromising
privacy guarantees.

AI.tldr: A post-processing denoising step using random matrix theory recovers gradient structure in DP-SGD trained LLMs, boosting sample efficiency during fine-tuning with DP, demonstrated on RoBERTa/GLUE.
AI.motivation: DP-SGD injects noise that destroys gradient low-rank structure, hindering optimization; improving gradient quality could enhance data efficiency without sacrificing privacy.
AI.method: Post-processing gradients with a random-matrix-theory-based denoising algorithm to restore low-rank structure and better align with the true signal; applied during DP-SGD fine-tuning of RoBERTa on GLUE.
AI.result: Achieves improved sample efficiency compared to state-of-the-art private fine-tuning methods; substantially reduces training time when optimal performance is not required.
AI.conclusion: Matrix recovery techniques can improve the utility of private language-model training without compromising differential privacy, suggesting broader applicability to private ML.

title: Neural Hamilton--Jacobi Characteristic Flows for Optimal Transport
summary:
We present a novel framework for solving optimal transport (OT) problems
based on the Hamilton--Jacobi (HJ) equation, whose viscosity solution uniquely
characterizes the OT map. By leveraging the method of characteristics, we
derive closed-form, bidirectional transport maps, thereby eliminating the need
for numerical integration. The proposed method adopts a pure minimization
framework: a single neural network is trained with a loss function derived from
the method of characteristics of the HJ equation. This design guarantees
convergence to the optimal map while eliminating adversarial training stages,
thereby substantially reducing computational complexity. Furthermore, the
framework naturally extends to a wide class of cost functions and supports
class-conditional transport. Extensive experiments on diverse datasets
demonstrate the accuracy, scalability, and efficiency of the proposed method,
establishing it as a principled and versatile tool for OT applications with
provable optimality.

AI.tldr: A Hamilton-Jacobi-based OT framework that yields closed-form, bidirectional transport maps via the method of characteristics, trained by a single neural network in pure minimization, achieving provable optimality with broad cost-support and class-conditional transport, and improved efficiency by avoiding numerical integration and adversarial training.
AI.motivation: To obtain a unique OT map through viscosity solutions of the HJ equation and to overcome computational bottlenecks in existing OT methods that rely on numerical integration or adversarial training; enable broad applicability across costs and conditional settings with provable optimality.
AI.method: Formulate OT via viscosity solution of a Hamilton-Jacobi PDE; apply the method of characteristics to obtain closed-form forward and backward transport maps; train a single neural network via a loss derived from the characteristic relations (pure minimization); support diverse cost functions and class conditioning; avoid numerical integration and adversarial training.
AI.result: Demonstrates accuracy, scalability, and efficiency on diverse datasets; shows that the learned map converges to the optimal OT map with provable optimality; extends naturally to various costs and class-conditioned transport.
AI.conclusion: Introduces a principled, versatile OT framework with provable optimality, reduced computational complexity, and broad applicability; potential extensions include unbalanced/multi-marginal OT and richer cost structures.

title: Multi-Marginal Flow Matching with Adversarially Learnt Interpolants
summary:
Learning the dynamics of a process given sampled observations at several time
points is an important but difficult task in many scientific applications. When
no ground-truth trajectories are available, but one has only snapshots of data
taken at discrete time steps, the problem of modelling the dynamics, and thus
inferring the underlying trajectories, can be solved by multi-marginal
generalisations of flow matching algorithms. This paper proposes a novel flow
matching method that overcomes the limitations of existing multi-marginal
trajectory inference algorithms. Our proposed method, ALI-CFM, uses a
GAN-inspired adversarial loss to fit neurally parametrised interpolant curves
between source and target points such that the marginal distributions at
intermediate time points are close to the observed distributions. The resulting
interpolants are smooth trajectories that, as we show, are unique under mild
assumptions. These interpolants are subsequently marginalised by a flow
matching algorithm, yielding a trained vector field for the underlying
dynamics. We showcase the versatility and scalability of our method by
outperforming the existing baselines on spatial transcriptomics and cell
tracking datasets, while performing on par with them on single-cell trajectory
prediction.
  Code: https://github.com/mmacosha/adversarially-learned-interpolants.

AI.tldr: ALI-CFM: adversarially learned interpolants for multi-marginal flow matching to infer dynamical vector fields from snapshot data.
AI.motivation: Inferring continuous dynamics from discrete snapshots is challenging; existing multi-marginal approaches struggle to recover trajectories and produce consistent marginals. A method that learns smooth interpolants that align with intermediate distributions can improve trajectory inference.
AI.method: Propose ALI-CFM, which trains neurally parameterized interpolants between source and target points using a GAN-inspired adversarial loss to ensure the interpolants' intermediate marginals match observed distributions. These interpolants are then marginalized via a flow-matching algorithm to yield the underlying dynamical vector field. The interpolants are argued to be unique under mild assumptions.
AI.result: The approach outperforms existing baselines on spatial transcriptomics and cell tracking datasets and performs comparably to baselines on single-cell trajectory prediction, demonstrating scalability and versatility with released code.
AI.conclusion: ALI-CFM offers a flexible, scalable framework that combines adversarial interpolation with flow matching to perform robust multi-marginal trajectory inference, producing smooth, unique trajectories and accurate dynamics across challenging biological datasets.

title: Prosperity before Collapse: How Far Can Off-Policy RL Reach with Stale Data on LLMs?
summary:
Reinforcement learning has been central to recent advances in large language
model reasoning, but most algorithms rely on on-policy training that demands
fresh rollouts at every update, limiting efficiency and scalability.
Asynchronous RL systems alleviate this by decoupling rollout generation from
training, yet their effectiveness hinges on tolerating large staleness in
rollout data, a setting where existing methods either degrade in performance or
collapse. We revisit this challenge and uncover a prosperity-before-collapse
phenomenon: stale data can be as informative as on-policy data if exploited
properly. Building on this insight, we introduce M2PO (Second-Moment Trust
Policy Optimization), which constrains the second moment of importance weights
to suppress only extreme outliers while preserving informative updates.
Notably, M2PO sharply reduces the fraction of clipped tokens under high
staleness (from 1.22% to 0.06% over training), precisely masking high-variance
tokens while maintaining stable optimization. Extensive evaluation across six
models (from 1.7B to 32B) and eight benchmarks shows that M2PO delivers stable
off-policy training even with data stale by at least 256 model updates and
matches on-policy performance.

AI.tldr: M2PO introduces a second-moment constraint on importance weights to enable stable off-policy RL for large language models, tolerating high data staleness and matching on-policy performance.
AI.motivation: Asynchronous RL decouples rollout generation from training to improve efficiency, but stale data degrades performance. There is a need for robust off-policy methods that can leverage stale data without collapsing.
AI.method: M2PO (Second-Moment Trust Policy Optimization) constrains the second moment of importance weights to suppress extreme outliers while preserving informative updates, reducing token clipping under high staleness and enabling stable off-policy training.
AI.result: M2PO significantly reduces the fraction of clipped tokens under high staleness (1.22% to 0.06%), achieves stable off-policy training with data stale by at least 256 updates across six models (1.7B–32B) and eight benchmarks, and matches on-policy performance.
AI.conclusion: Controlling the second moment of importance weights is an effective strategy for robust off-policy RL in large language models, enabling scalable asynchronous training without sacrificing performance.

title: How Does the Pretraining Distribution Shape In-Context Learning? Task Selection, Generalization, and Robustness
summary:
The emergence of in-context learning (ICL) in large language models (LLMs)
remains poorly understood despite its consistent effectiveness, enabling models
to adapt to new tasks from only a handful of examples. To clarify and improve
these capabilities, we characterize how the statistical properties of the
pretraining distribution (e.g., tail behavior, coverage) shape ICL on numerical
tasks. We develop a theoretical framework that unifies task selection and
generalization, extending and sharpening earlier results, and show how
distributional properties govern sample efficiency, task retrieval, and
robustness. To this end, we generalize Bayesian posterior consistency and
concentration results to heavy-tailed priors and dependent sequences, better
reflecting the structure of LLM pretraining data. We then empirically study how
ICL performance varies with the pretraining distribution on challenging tasks
such as stochastic differential equations and stochastic processes with memory.
Together, these findings suggest that controlling key statistical properties of
the pretraining distribution is essential for building ICL-capable and reliable
LLMs.

AI.tldr: A theoretical and empirical study linking pretraining data properties to in-context learning efficiency and reliability in LLMs, showing that heavy-tailed, dependent distributions shape sample efficiency, task retrieval, and robustness.
AI.motivation: In-context learning remains poorly understood despite effectiveness. Understanding how pretraining data distributions affect ICL on numerical tasks can guide design of more reliable, efficient LLMs.
AI.method: Develop a theoretical framework that unifies task selection and generalization; extend Bayesian posterior consistency and concentration to heavy-tailed priors and dependent sequences; empirically vary the pretraining distribution on challenging tasks (e.g., stochastic differential equations, memoryful stochastic processes).
AI.result: Distributional properties of the pretraining data govern sample efficiency, task retrieval, and robustness of ICL. The framework reflects heavier tails and dependencies, improving reflection of LLM pretraining; controlling these properties is key to building reliable ICL-enabled models.
AI.conclusion: Careful control of statistical properties of the pretraining distribution is essential for developing LLMs with reliable and efficient in-context learning.

title: Simultaneous Multi-objective Alignment Across Verifiable and Non-verifiable Rewards
summary:
Aligning large language models to human preferences is inherently
multidimensional, yet most pipelines collapse heterogeneous signals into a
single optimizeable objective. We seek to answer what it would take to
simultaneously align a model across various domains spanning those with:
verifiable rewards (mathematical accuracy), non-verifiable subjective
preferences (human values), and complex interactive scenarios (multi-turn AI
tutoring dialogues). Such multi-objective reinforcement learning setups are
often plagued by the individual objectives being at odds with each other,
resulting in inefficient training and little user control during inference. We
propose a unified framework that: (i) standardizes {process reward model} (PRM)
training across both verifiable and non-verifiable settings to better supervise
models' chain-of-thought reasoning; (ii) performs {multi-objective alignment}
by training the LLM with our $\textbf{M}$ulti-$\textbf{A}$ction-$\textbf{H}$ead
$\textbf{DPO}$ (MAH-DPO) and a vectorized reward where the dimensions of the
vector correspond to the various objectives instead of a single scalar; and
(iii) demonstrates how such a system provides fine-grained inference-time user
control. Experiments across math reasoning, value alignment, and multi-turn
dialogue show that our framework improves performance across multiple
objectives simultaneously, while minimizing cross-objective trade-offs and
enabling flexible inference time user control. The code can be found at
https://github.com/pearls-lab/multiobj-align.

AI.tldr: A unified, multi-objective alignment framework for large language models that treats rewards as a vector across verifiable, subjective, and interactive objectives and trains using MAH-DPO with standardized PRM training, enabling fine-grained inference-time user control.
AI.motivation: To address that single-scalar objective alignment often fails in multidimensional settings, the paper aims to align models across mathematical accuracy, human values, and multi-turn dialogue while reducing trade-offs and increasing user control.
AI.method: Introduce standardized process reward model (PRM) training across verifiable and non-verifiable settings; train with Multi-Action-Head Direct Preference Optimization (MAH-DPO); use a vectorized, multi-dimensional reward instead of a single scalar; emphasize supervision of chain-of-thought reasoning and enable inference-time user control.
AI.result: Empirically improves performance across math reasoning, value alignment, and multi-turn dialogue; reduces cross-objective trade-offs; enables fine-grained user control during inference; code released at the provided repository.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that multi-objective alignment is feasible with a unified framework combining standardized PRM, vectorized rewards, and MAH-DPO, achieving better cross-domain alignment with controllable trade-offs.

title: Fiaingen: A financial time series generative method matching real-world data quality
summary:
Data is vital in enabling machine learning models to advance research and
practical applications in finance, where accurate and robust models are
essential for investment and trading decision-making. However, real-world data
is limited despite its quantity, quality, and variety. The data shortage of
various financial assets directly hinders the performance of machine learning
models designed to trade and invest in these assets. Generative methods can
mitigate this shortage. In this paper, we introduce a set of novel techniques
for time series data generation (we name them Fiaingen) and assess their
performance across three criteria: (a) overlap of real-world and synthetic data
on a reduced dimensionality space, (b) performance on downstream machine
learning tasks, and (c) runtime performance. Our experiments demonstrate that
the methods achieve state-of-the-art performance across the three criteria
listed above. Synthetic data generated with Fiaingen methods more closely
mirrors the original time series data while keeping data generation time close
to seconds - ensuring the scalability of the proposed approach. Furthermore,
models trained on it achieve performance close to those trained with real-world
data.

AI.tldr: A new family of time-series generators (Fiaingen) for finance achieves state-of-the-art overlap with real data, strong downstream task performance, and rapid generation times, addressing financial data scarcity.
AI.motivation: Data scarcity in finance hampers reliable ML models; synthetic data with realistic properties and fast generation is needed to augment limited real-world data.
AI.method: Introduce novel time-series generation techniques named Fiaingen and evaluate them on three criteria: (a) real-vs-synthetic overlap in reduced-dimensional space, (b) downstream ML task performance, and (c) runtime efficiency.
AI.result: Fiaingen methods achieve state-of-the-art performance across all three criteria: synthetic data closely mirrors real data in reduced space, improves or matches downstream task performance, and can be generated in sub-second to seconds with scalable throughput.
AI.conclusion: Fiaingen provides effective, scalable synthetic financial time-series data generation that mitigates data shortages and enables near-real performance in ML models trained on synthetic data.

title: On the Benefits of Weight Normalization for Overparameterized Matrix Sensing
summary:
While normalization techniques are widely used in deep learning, their
theoretical understanding remains relatively limited. In this work, we
establish the benefits of (generalized) weight normalization (WN) applied to
the overparameterized matrix sensing problem. We prove that WN with Riemannian
optimization achieves linear convergence, yielding an exponential speedup over
standard methods that do not use WN. Our analysis further demonstrates that
both iteration and sample complexity improve polynomially as the level of
overparameterization increases. To the best of our knowledge, this work
provides the first characterization of how WN leverages overparameterization
for faster convergence in matrix sensing.

AI.tldr: Generalized weight normalization with Riemannian optimization achieves linear convergence in overparameterized matrix sensing, giving exponential speedup over non-WN methods and polynomial gains in iteration and sample complexity as overparameterization grows.
AI.motivation: To understand the theoretical benefits of normalization techniques, specifically weight normalization, in overparameterized matrix sensing and to characterize how overparameterization interacts with WN to accelerate convergence.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis using generalized weight normalization combined with Riemannian optimization for the matrix sensing problem, proving linear convergence and deriving iteration and sample complexity bounds that depend on the level of overparameterization.
AI.result: Proves linear convergence with exponential speedup over standard (non-WN) methods; shows iteration and sample complexity improve polynomially with increased overparameterization; provides the first characterization of how WN leverages overparameterization for faster convergence in matrix sensing.
AI.conclusion: Weight normalization, when combined with Riemannian optimization, accelerates convergence in overparameterized matrix sensing and yields favorable complexity scaling, offering new theoretical insights into normalization's benefits for such problems.

title: COM-BOM: Bayesian Exemplar Search for Efficiently Exploring the Accuracy-Calibration Pareto Frontier
comment:
Accepted by EMNLP 2025 Main, Code:
  https://github.com/GaoxiangLuo/COM-BOM
summary:
Selecting an optimal set of exemplars is critical for good performance of
in-context learning. However, prior exemplar search methods narrowly optimize
for predictive accuracy, critically neglecting model calibration--a key
determinant of trustworthiness and safe deployment. In this paper, we formulate
exemplar selection as a multi-objective optimization problem, explicitly
targeting both the maximization of predictive accuracy and the minimization of
expected calibration error. We solve this problem with a sample-efficient
Combinatorial Bayesian Optimization algorithm (COM-BOM) to find the Pareto
front that optimally trades off the two objectives of accuracy and calibration.
We evaluate COM-BOM on multiple tasks from unsaturated MMLU-Pro benchmark and
find that COM-BOM beats or matches the baselines at jointly optimizing the two
objectives, while requiring a minimal number of LLM API calls.

AI.tldr: COM-BOM provides a Pareto-optimal set of exemplars that balance predictive accuracy and calibration in in-context learning, outperforming baselines on unsaturated MMLU-Pro tasks with fewer API calls.
AI.motivation: Exemplar selection for in-context learning traditionally optimizes accuracy but ignores calibration, a key factor for trustworthy and safe deployment.
AI.method: Formulates exemplar selection as a multi-objective optimization problem and solves it with a sample-efficient Combinatorial Bayesian Optimization (COM-BOM) to obtain the Pareto front that trades off accuracy and calibration (via expected calibration error).
AI.result: COM-BOM beats or matches baselines in jointly optimizing accuracy and calibration across multiple tasks from the unsaturated MMLU-Pro benchmark, while requiring a minimal number of LLM API calls.
AI.conclusion: Multi-objective exemplar selection with explicit calibration optimization is feasible and beneficial; COM-BOM offers a principled, data-efficient approach to improve trustworthiness in in-context learning without excessive API usage.

title: TOUCAN: Synthesizing 1.5M Tool-Agentic Data from Real-World MCP Environments
summary:
Large Language Model (LLM) agents are rapidly emerging as powerful systems
for automating tasks across domains. Yet progress in the open-source community
is constrained by the lack of high quality permissively licensed tool-agentic
training data. Existing datasets are often limited in diversity, realism, and
complexity, particularly regarding multi-tool and multi-turn interactions. To
address this gap, we introduce Toucan, the largest publicly available
tool-agentic dataset to date, containing 1.5 million trajectories synthesized
from nearly 500 real-world Model Context Protocols (MCPs). Unlike prior work,
Toucan leverages authentic MCP environments to generate diverse, realistic, and
challenging tasks with trajectories involving real tool execution. Our pipeline
first produces a broad spectrum of tool-use queries using five distinct models,
applies model-based quality filtering, and then generates agentic trajectories
with three teacher models using two agentic frameworks. Rigorous rule-based and
model-based validation ensures high-quality outputs. We also introduce three
extension mechanisms to further diversify tasks and simulate multi-turn
conversations. Models fine-tuned on Toucan outperform larger closed-source
counterparts on the BFCL V3 benchmark and push the Pareto frontier forward on
MCP-Universe Bench.

AI.tldr: Toucan is the largest publicly available tool-agentic dataset (1.5M trajectories from ~500 real MCPs) for training LLM agents, emphasizing multi-tool and multi-turn interactions. It uses a multi-stage pipeline (query generation, quality filtering, agentic trajectory generation with three teachers and two frameworks, plus validation) and offers extension mechanisms to diversify tasks. Models trained on Toucan outperform larger closed-source baselines and push leading performance on MCP benchmarks.
AI.motivation: There is a paucity of high-quality, permissively licensed tool-agentic training data. Existing datasets lack diversity, realism, and complexity, especially for multi-tool usage and multi-turn interactions, hindering open-source progress in building capable LLM agents.
AI.method: Construct Toucan by (1) sourcing ~500 real-world Model Context Protocols (MCPs); (2) generating a broad set of tool-use queries with five models; (3) applying model-based quality filtering; (4) creating agentic trajectories using three teacher models across two agentic frameworks; (5) applying rigorous rule-based and model-based validation; (6) adding three extension mechanisms to diversify tasks and simulate multi-turn conversations.
AI.result: Toucan yields 1.5 million trajectories and demonstrates that models fine-tuned on Toucan outperform larger closed-source counterparts on the BFCL V3 benchmark and achieve a stronger Pareto frontier on the MCP-Universe Bench.
AI.conclusion: Toucan substantially advances open-source tool-agentic data resources by providing a large, diverse, and realistic dataset with robust validation, enabling the development of more capable, multi-tool LLM agents and facilitating progress on established MCP benchmarks.

title: BroRL: Scaling Reinforcement Learning via Broadened Exploration
summary:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) has emerged as a key
ingredient for unlocking complex reasoning capabilities in large language
models. Recent work ProRL has shown promise in scaling RL by increasing the
number of training steps. However, performance plateaus after thousands of
steps, with clear diminishing returns from allocating more computation to
additional training. In this work, we investigate a complementary paradigm for
scaling RL, BroR-Lincreasing the number of rollouts per example to hundreds to
exhaustively Broaden exploration, which yields continuous performance gains
beyond the saturation point observed in ProRL when scaling the number of
training steps. Our approach is motivated by a mass balance equation analysis
allowing us to characterize the rate of change in probability mass for correct
and incorrect tokens during the reinforcement process. We show that under a
one-step RL assumption, sampled rollout tokens always contribute to
correct-mass expansion, while unsampled tokens outside rollouts may lead to
gains or losses depending on their distribution and the net reward balance.
Importantly, as the number of rollouts per example N increases, the effect of
unsampled terms diminishes, ensuring overall correct-mass expansion. To
validate our theoretical analysis, we conduct simulations under more relaxed
conditions and find that a sufficiently large rollout size N-corresponding to
ample exploration-guarantees an increase in the probability mass of all correct
tokens. Empirically, BroRL revives models saturated after 3K ProRL training
steps and demonstrates robust, continuous improvement, achieving
state-of-the-art results for the 1.5B model across diverse benchmarks.

AI.tldr: BroR—scaling RL by vastly increasing per-example rollouts yields continuous gains and overcomes ProRL's performance plateau by expanding exploration; theory (mass-balance) aligns with empirical improvements on 1.5B models.
AI.motivation: Improve scaling of RL for LLMs beyond training-step increases; explore whether exploration via more rollouts can sustain performance gains where ProRL saturates.
AI.method: Theoretical mass-balance analysis for token probability during one-step RL; show rollout tokens always contribute to correct-mass expansion; simulations under relaxed conditions; empirical training with high rollout counts; compare to ProRL on 1.5B models across benchmarks.
AI.result: Large rollout size N ensures dominated improvement from rollout tokens; increased probability mass for correct tokens; BroRL revives models saturated after 3K ProRL steps; achieves state-of-the-art on 1.5B model across benchmarks; continuous improvements with no observed saturation.
AI.conclusion: Expanding exploration through high-rate rollouts is a viable dimension to scale RL for LLMs, complementing step-based scaling, and can prevent saturation while delivering robust gains; requires substantial compute but yields strong empirical performance.

title: Temporal Score Rescaling for Temperature Sampling in Diffusion and Flow Models
summary:
We present a mechanism to steer the sampling diversity of denoising diffusion
and flow matching models, allowing users to sample from a sharper or broader
distribution than the training distribution. We build on the observation that
these models leverage (learned) score functions of noisy data distributions for
sampling and show that rescaling these allows one to effectively control a
`local' sampling temperature. Notably, this approach does not require any
finetuning or alterations to training strategy, and can be applied to any
off-the-shelf model and is compatible with both deterministic and stochastic
samplers. We first validate our framework on toy 2D data, and then demonstrate
its application for diffusion models trained across five disparate tasks --
image generation, pose estimation, depth prediction, robot manipulation, and
protein design. We find that across these tasks, our approach allows sampling
from sharper (or flatter) distributions, yielding performance gains e.g., depth
prediction models benefit from sampling more likely depth estimates, whereas
image generation models perform better when sampling a slightly flatter
distribution. Project page: https://temporalscorerescaling.github.io

AI.tldr: A simple, model-agnostic method to steer sampling diversity in diffusion and flow-based models by rescaling their learned score functions to adjust a local sampling temperature, enabling sharper or broader distributions without retraining.
AI.motivation: To control the fidelity-diversity trade-off in generative and predictive tasks by sampling from distributions that are sharper or flatter than the training data, without retraining or changing training procedures. This can improve task-specific performance across diverse domains.
AI.method: Rescale the learned score functions of noisy data distributions to adjust a local sampling temperature. This manipulation is applied to off-the-shelf diffusion and flow-matching models and works with both deterministic and stochastic samplers; no finetuning or training changes are required.
AI.result: Validated on toy 2D data and applied across five tasks (image generation, pose estimation, depth prediction, robot manipulation, protein design). The approach enables sampling from sharper or flatter distributions; depth prediction benefits from sharper sampling, image generation benefits from slightly flatter sampling, demonstrating task-dependent performance gains without retraining.
AI.conclusion: A simple, model-agnostic mechanism to control sampling diversity via local temperature rescaling of score functions, enabling improved task-specific performance across domains without modifying training or architecture.

title: Dirichlet-Prior Shaping: Guiding Expert Specialization in Upcycled MoEs
summary:
Upcycling pre-trained dense models into sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoEs)
efficiently increases model capacity but often suffers from poor expert
specialization due to naive weight replication. Our analysis reveals that
upcycled MoEs, even with conventional regularization, exhibit low-confidence,
weakly differentiated routing, hindering performance. We introduce
Dirichlet-Prior Shaping Loss (DPSL), a novel router regularization technique
that directly shapes routing probability distributions by matching expert
assignments to a target Dirichlet prior. DPSL offers fine-grained control over
expert balance and specialization, and enables encoding of inductive biases
such as encouraging experts to focus on specific modalities or tasks, without
requiring manual intervention; notably, DPSL is a general tool applicable to
any module that outputs categorical probability distributions, extending its
utility beyond MoE training. Experiments on upcycled MoE vision-language models
(with Qwen2, Phi3, Llama3.2 LLM backbones) show DPSL consistently outperforms
upcycling strategies and regularization techniques across standard
vision-language benchmarks, addressing the critical issue of poor
specialization and fostering more adaptive, higher-performing models.

AI.tldr: Dirichlet-Prior Shaping Loss (DPSL) regularizes MoE routers to match a Dirichlet prior, improving expert balance and specialization when upcycling dense models into sparse MoEs; generalizable to any module generating categorical distributions; empirical gains on upcycled vision-language MoEs.
AI.motivation: Upcycling dense models into sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoEs) often yields poor expert specialization due to naive weight replication, low-confidence routing, and weak differentiation even with standard regularization; a router regularizer that actively shapes routing distributions and encodes inductive biases is needed.
AI.method: Introduce Dirichlet-Prior Shaping Loss (DPSL), a regularization term that shapes router output probabilities to align with a target Dirichlet prior, providing fine-grained control over expert balance and specialization; can encode biases toward modalities or tasks; applicable to any module that outputs categorical probability distributions.
AI.result: DPSL consistently outperforms upcycling strategies and existing regularizers on vision-language benchmarks using upcycled MoEs with backbones like Qwen2, Phi3, and Llama3.2, by improving expert specialization and overall performance.
AI.conclusion: DPSL is a general, effective router regularizer for MoEs that can be applied beyond MoEs to any module producing categorical distributions, enabling controlled specialization and higher performance in upcycled models.
